description:
What a delight. A San Francisco land mark for many reasons. To honor the fallen in battle, a world class art museum, and architectural marvel, and incredible views.

Your general admission ticket also includes viewing at the Fine Arts Museum of San Francisco. One not only gets to enjoy art, but music and other venues are presented there. If you are a member you get the special privileges that come with it. Discounts, special showings, travelling exhibits, and more.

My Favorite area is the impressionists, but still, every room has something special that caught my eye. Especially the Rodin Exhibits. And don't forget to see the porcelain rooms and other special areas. 

If you wish dine at the café or get special gifts for the family in their gift shop. Everything is available right down to the self guided electric tours and the nice docents there.

It's not just a place for the rich to schmooze, or struggling artists. I can be for everyone. Even kids activities are there.
author: Thomas B.

description:
Even with parts of the palace closed for a private event later in the evening, this museum is terrific. Downstairs they have a small exhibit on scientific innovation and literature from the "Islamic world." It is there from August 25, 2018 - January 27, 2019. I was in love with it and spent quite a bit of time trying to read it and fail at it horribly as it's mostly in Persian and some Arabic and I haven't read either in at least a decade. What was funny to me was that the constant thanks to the ambassadors of art. I guess these are some major donor they wanted to thank so I'll mention them as well so no attention goes unnoticed. Lead Support was by The Francis Goldsmith Exhibition Fund and Major Support was from Barbro and Bernard Osher.

When you go upstairs its a literal feeling of all roads lead to Rome as no matter where you go you will eventually come back to the center after exploring every corner of a dedicated area. For me the best part about the upstairs were the Rodin sculptures. You can lose track of time just admiring them. Apart from that, there is an overabundance of Christian art work. At times it felt like I was looking at the Medici family rejects. 

There is a small room of impressionist work and it is absolutely beautiful. There is an area with coffins including actual mummies from Egypt. There is a machine that shows the X-ray of one of the mummy's on display. It was created in conjunction with or by the Stanford Medical School. 

There are so many things about the museums in California that I loved but one of the ones that I loved the most is that they let you photograph and don't make you feel like you're being intrusive when you are looking at art work. In Houston, people start shouting at you if you get too close to the work even if you are behind the line. 

Overall, this museum was a total joy. I wish I would have gotten to see the parts that were closed due to the private event.
author: Zain R.

description:
This is a beautiful museum inside and out, with a great, medium-size collection on display. The remote location in Land's End also means that it's not very crowded, at least during the week. There's nothing better than having a masterpiece all to yourself!

Admission is $15 for adults, $12 for seniors, and $6 for students. They offer free docent tours; check their website for the schedule. Apparently, your ticket to Legion of Honor also provides free same-day admission to the DeYoung museum in Golden Gate Park. But even for a hardcore art lover like me, that's a pretty aggressive itinerary!

The staff were kind of rude, and the bag policy is annoying. If you have a backpack, you have to check it--fair enough. But when I tried to check my large purse, to avoid lugging it around the museum for 2 hours, they wouldn't accept it. I wish they allowed you to check purses, or had lockers, like most museums.
author: Cathy Z.

description: It was the first Sunday of the month where there is free admission and we walked from the Cliff House. Only 15 minutes until closing but we were able to see the beautiful artwork at the Legion of Honor.
author: Mitzi W.

description:
Totally Magnificent Gem!  Every piece of Art is amazing.  I'm very impress with the architectural structure. 

It's very peaceful here and photographers will have a blast visiting this place.
author: Grace L.

description:
Came here first-time on a weekday afternoon. The weather here is incredibly pleasant! 

Highlights on museum surroundings: Crystal blue fountain in center of parking lot, neat lawn + historical statue, the Holocaust memorial, trails w/ great views of the golden gate bridge, & the sunlit golf court that offers the best photo spot during sunset. 

This visit is already worth it by exploring the environment! 

- Architecture + 2018 Installation: The signature 18th-century French Pavilion styled building is grand, elegant, & beautiful. Along w/ the glass, skylight, photo-worthy pyramid in the courtyard, stands the most recent installation: Exhibit by Julian Schnabel, (It includes pieces of large-scale fabric, painted in vibrant colors & abstract styles).

- Overall ambiance/ style inside museum is classy, formal, cultural, and elegant. 

- Julian's artworks are integrated on the museum interior walls. A delightful surprise to find the modern piece adding value to the gallery space: of traditional, historical, fine art exhibits. 

It's a mixture of western & eastern cultures, different genres, and definitely a wonderful clash of Modernity  V.S. tradition.
 
- Wish the Casanova exhibit doesn't extra $$ tho! (not included with museum ticket). Overall an adventurous & fun experience.
author: Jess W.

description:
The Legion of Honor, offers spectacular grounds and surroundings with museum exhibitions of world class art, along with a house collection that rivals some of the best. In a city known for fully embracing all of the arts, this quite unassuming facility is hard to beat for locale or content. Exhibitions are upstairs and the museum cafe downstairs. Parking is also free and plentiful.

Surrounded by the neighborhood public golf course, the museum is worth a visit for any art enthusiast and you can check for exhibition dates on their website. Beautifully maintained lawns and trails that provide a lush, relaxed and peaceful environment, that's literally only a couple miles from downtown. The golf courses standard upkeep makes the entire place seem pristine park like and it's hidden location is really quite close to everything. 

This peaceful place is within a very short walk of the SFVAMC Hospital and I often walk the grounds and course when here. There are quiet places to sit and enjoy spectacular views of both the bay and city. The golf course is inexpensive by most course standards and the course itself is a great place to get nine or 18 in when I have the extra time.

This is one of the hidden gems of the city, well worth the time for a visit. Great art, spectacular locale with world class views of the north bay. Though I've never had any issues, vehicle break ins seem to be a problem at times, and my reason for not giving 5 stars 

4 Stars- park accordingly and be aware of this potential risk.

00559
author: Ray F.

description:
Thank you Max Hollein (Director and CEO of the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco) for bringing the amazing Julian Schnabel exhibit to the Legion of Honor. Thanks also for the wonderful talk last night (4/19) with Julian in the beautiful Gunn Theater. Great conversation, just wish it lasted longer.

The new exhibit of Julian's work (Symbols of Actual Life) is stunning to see in person. The scale of his work is almost unimaginable, both the paintings and sculptures. It's truly a big deal to get these here, along with Julian himself. We're very thankful for this Director and the museum's continuing efforts to bring the best exhibits to the Bay Area. Amazing all around.
author: Theart P.

description:
Positively Splendid! If you enjoy and appreciate the beauty of Rococo art, the Casanova Exhibit is for you! Here, you will see some fine Rococo paintings. I never tire of the rich, beautiful hues of Nattier blue, as you'll see here, characteristically depicted in Thalia, Muse of Comedy.

You'll also see Bouche canvases, period costumes and even porcelain figurines from the famous Capodimonte Porcelain Factory from Napoli. Get a chance to view Venezia through the early and later works of Canaletto up close. The details of the latter are especially amazing.

Lastly, don't miss the "live, moving table feast", which enables you to partake in dining during these lavish, luxurious times.

TIP #1: There's so much more to Casanova than meets the eye. What an adventurous life he lived! My visit inspired me to read his biography, History of My Life, which I understand will be published online, in it's entirety, by the National Library of France.

TIP #2: The Casanova Exhibit runs through May 28. A must see!!!
author: Lori N.

description:
This is a lovely museum in a georgous setting overlooking the Pacific Ocean.  We thoroughly enjoyed the Degas, Impressionism and Paris Millinery Trade exhibit--very interesting and well done.  I am taking off one star for the Sara Lucas "Good Muse" sculptures placed around the museum.  These "purposefully confrontational" sculptures were apparently the museum's attempt at "bringing contemporary perspective to our understanding and appreciation of Rodin." I'm sorry, but I was neither inspired nor challenged by such twaddle as cigarettes protruding from sculpted derrières.  It missed the mark. 

Afterward, we enjoyed a long walk down El Camino del Mar to the beautiful Sea Cliff community.  It's an invigorating walk for both body and soul.
author: Kathryn B.

description:
This is normally my favourite museum in SF but I was really disappointed with it today.

No, I was beyond disappointed, I was more into the pissed off category.

Drove an hour into the city, and brought out of towners only to discover that half the museum is closed.  Total waste of time

No mention of this anywhere, not even while buying the ticket.  Not a word.  Nada!    But they've got no problem charging you full price.  Come on people!!   You've got no business charging full price when half the museum is missing. 

Needless to say, the visit was over in no time and wasn't worth the 2hrs driving.

Mummy and medicine exhibit was minuscule (2 mummies in total).  

Gift shop is overpriced.  35 dollars for a canvas tote bag anyone?  They also ask you if you'd like to round up your purchase and give them a donation.  Isn't that cute?
author: Nicole L.

description: I came here to check out the Rodin sculptures, and I was gladly surprised that they had some nice works of art inside. I also was very impressed with the wooden room that was transported from France, via NY city. There is definitively some substance to this museum. I also enjoyed free parking (Wow! It is a gift!). I also participated in the special exhibit, this time Casanova (he was real, wow!), and again, I found it gimmicky. One less star for gimmicks.
author: Julio H.

description:
What a beautiful museum, inside and out! The architecture of the museum is very nice (I love the domed ceilings, take a look up when you're inside.) There are some great works of art here, it's definitely worth checking out. There are benches throughout several rooms where you may sit and admire the paintings. On one end of the building, features quite a few Monet's. There's also some sculptures and porcelain as well. 

The Legion of Honor is located in Lincoln park which offers a nice view of the Golden Gate Bridge. Definitely walk around the area, it's great. 

Here's a tip: the first Tuesday of every month is free general admission (excludes special exhibits).
author: Jessica H.

description: Favorite museum in SF. Worth going to even if not going in. One of the most beautiful settings for a museum in the country and especially at sunset.
author: George R.

description:
Really enjoyed the Klimt and Rodin exhibit last month.
The Legion of Honor deserves 5*s all around for their setting, their permanent works and exhibitions. 
The café has a thorough variety of food and drink.
author: Camille L.

description:
This place is just majestic. A beautiful building with so much art and history surrounded by lush green grass and trees everywhere. Its not a huge museum but it does feel that way from the outside. Its a SF treasure that we all must see.
The Gustav Klimt exhibit got me to go and become a member. They have early and exclusive preview time for members. They have some gift shops and a  cafeteria to have lunch or breakfast-but it is a bit pricey and the menu varies.
There are stairs and elevators and plenty of parking. I highly recommend everyone to go become a member and enjoy the perks if you are local.
:)
author: Theresa G.

description:
Overall, I would say this is a cool museum to check out because they have a decent amount to explore. The general admission price isn't too bad - $15 for adults, but the price for the special exhibits are very expensive. I decided to only get a general admission ticket because it was cheaper. 

I thought all the paintings were great and that the all the artwork was very well placed. I would say this is an ok museum to bring the kids - there are other museums in the Bay Area that are much better for kids. I would say the coolest thing for me that I saw was the mummy exhibit! They actually display the body in the sarcophagus with all the bandages wrapped around it - I've never seen that before!! I thought it was cool that they had the mummy exhibit, but it is important to note that the general admission part of the museum was mostly Italian and French baroque era paintings.
author: Rithika V.

description:
Is this the most romantic place in San Francisco? It sure feels like it...

The location and the setting are one of the most beautiful in the city. They are complimented by the architectural richness of the museum building which is a smaller version of the Parisian Palais de la Légion d'Honneur. The museum is situated on a hill in lush green nature with views over the Golden Gate Bridge and the Pacific Ocean. It's as if the museum in its setting was built to compliment the fog itself. All the elements of this monument create a delicate veneer of mystery. It was originally built to commemorate Californian soldiers who died in World War I. 

The art collections are more than satisfying for an avid art lover: Rembrandt, Rafael, El Greco, Rubens, Degas, Renoir, Monet, Cézanne and others. Rodin's omnipresent Thinker and The Kiss are part of the collection. Laocoon is strategically placed against the foggy background in the garden so that it stays with you long after your visit. 

On a much less glamorous side: adult tickets are $15 and student tickets are $6.
author: Ani M.

description:
The Legion of Honor in Lincoln Park, is the largest public arts institution in San Francisco.  It's located in a very beautiful area with trees, flowers, gorgeous ocean view, and the water pond.  I love the museum architecture with many huge columns surrounding, the huge Rodin statue in the front,  and the light after dark is spectacular.  

Today was the last day for the Klimt & Rodin exhibit.  It's incredible to view the actual pieces of old Klimt arts close up and I paid attention to the details.  I have only previously seen Klimt works in books.  The Rodin exhibit was limited and randomly displaced in various areas throughout the museum. 

It's insane that I waited to visit the museum on the last day of this special event.  It's super crowded.  I was quite impressed with the people working hard at the museum to keep the place running smoothly and organized.  The ambiance is quite magical with rare and special art pieces. 

Parking was free but finding one is a nightmare.

I love art. I love this museum.  I'm a member of the museum!   Highly recommend it for all!
author: Ivory B.

description:
My friend compiled a list of all the museums and galleries in San Francisco and the Legion of Honor was on that list. 

After visiting the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art last week, I was inspired to come back to San Francisco and look at more art. However, I should have kept in mind that what I enjoyed most about the museum from last week was the contemporary art collection--something that would not be represented at the Legion of Honor. 

Luckily, General Admission was only $15 (not including the special exhibit) and also includes free admission the same day to the de Young Museum. 

I'm bored with the kind of art represented here and don't find it to be inspiring. However, I did see art by Vincent van Gogh and Claude Monet. I walked quickly through the museum and those artists were the only that made me stop and linger for a moment. 

There is something about historical art that makes me feel stagnant and again, not inspired. I wish I felt differently, but I guess not every experience will be the best and you start to learn what you gravitate towards and what you don't.

I don't see myself coming back here again. It may be something for you, but not for me.
author: Regina W.

description:
Absolutely beautiful museum. 

First off it's stationed next to one of the best viewing spots of the Golden Gate Bridge in the city! The second you park your car you'll find yourself snapping photos before you even get in.

I came here on a whim to see the Degas, Impressionism and The Paris Millinery Trade exhibit before heading to the airport as I was only in SF for the weekend.  It was fantastic. I visited with my father, we arrived bright and early around 9:30am on a Sunday and the place was already starting to fill up. He decided to purchase the annual membership which allows you to bring guests for free and gives you entrance into all exhibits including speciality exhibits. The annual membership is a great deal if you go more than 2x with a friend it's an annual cost of $119. 

The Degas exhibit had many pieces that had never been displayed before in the US. In addition to Degas there were also plenty of other fantastic artists showcased in this series as well as amazing period hats. 

After exploring all of the rooms we passed through the gift shop and of course couldn't help but snap some photos with the replica hats. 

If you have a chance to make it before the Degas exhibit closes I highly recommend!
author: Carlie S.

description:
This is a beautiful museum. There is an eclectic assortment of art and beautiful diversity. It is further from Golden Gate Park so you may need to find another way to get there (walking may be too long) but you can drive there. Note that the parking is awful lol.

I enjoyed the exhibits and they had a nice variety of artwork. You can gain entry here as well through Bank of America Museums on Us. It limits what exhibits you may see. They had Monet and Klimt as well.

Check it out if you are in the San Francisco area!
author: Natalie M.

description:
Absolutely beautiful building that will transport you to Europe. Must visit 10/10

Almost perched up a slight hill in location, this museum boasts of classical architecture and one of a kind exhibits giving it a very unique character. It is accessible by car and is a great destination for art lovers and design enthusiasts. 

We went to see the museum and were so impressed with the courtyard adorned by columns and a small louvre like skylight giving us an introduction to the museum. You can't miss the Rodin sculpture sitting tall to give you an idea of what great art lies ahead. You can buy a regular ticket ($15.00) which gives you admission into all spaces. Membership rates may very. 

We started from the lower level and made our way up. It's not a very large space but it has very rich work on display so it can be time consuming. Master artists like Rembrandt,Monet, Degas, among others are exhibited in the beautiful museum categorised by styles and eras. 

Note: Pick up a map at the lobby and map your visit so you don't miss the important stuff. Bathrooms are located at the lower level. 

I was fascinated by the natural light in the space and the curation of the works of art there. It took me the whole day almost to see the museum ( including the lunch and coffee breaks at their spectacular cafe). The cafe is set to highlight the very French ambience of the space. They have an indoor and outdoor space and the outdoor seating set amidst sculptures and green was my favourite 10/10. We got small bites and coffee here and everything was good considering it was a museum cafe. The prices are not too high bit were not too cheap either. The coffee was good too, I actually had a second cup. Maybe the ambience makes the food and drink taste even better ! 

Note : The house coffee has free refills here so grab a book and relax in the sunny courtyard. 

After walking through the whole space I felt like I had taken a trip in time and it was splendid. I highly recommend this museum as it checked off all aspects of being an ideal house of art and design. 

I will be back for sure!
author: Shivani B.

description: We came on the first Tuesday of the month- free. Honestly, I didn't care for many of the art pieces besides Claude Monet's "Water Lilies." I like checking out museums, but I'm not much of an art person. I know that sounds contradictory. What I did find impressive was the building itself with its thick wide columns and the statue of "The Thinker" by Auguste Rodin in the front of the museum.
author: Helen H.

description:
Today was my second time ever coming here. The very first time was while I was attending SF State as a Journalism major. Back then, I thought the art made people think of the paintings while viewing the art. Of course, I hadn't been diagnosed with ADHD at that time. 
Last summer, I drove a friend here for an job interview. She now works at the Legion of Honor Cafe. 
I should definitely come here more often to stimulate my mind, writing!
author: Julio B.

description:
I've always been a sucker for art museums and this place did not disappoint. I highly recommend coming on the first Tuesday of the month since it's free. 

The exterior architecture is divine and a perfect place to take pictures. Once you enter, there are many paintings and sculptures. I really enjoyed the monet paintings and was delighted to see that there was a Vincent Van Gogh painting. 

Right now there is a mummy exhibit and being able to see the ct scans of inside the sarcophagus. Amazing how well preserved these mummies are.
author: Ada H.

description:
There was a time in my life when I wanted to visit all the San Francisco museums possible. Several years later, I finally crossed off Legion of Honor. I want to say that I saved the best for last, but this was probably my least favorite out of all the museums in terms of content and environment.

I came here for the Klimt x Rodin exhibit, which was $40 per person. The artwork was enjoyable, but it was a little disappointing in terms of the AMOUNT of artwork and just the experience itself. Don't get me wrong. I'm sure tons of people love everything the Legion of Honor has to offer. It just wasn't for me this time.

The museum was super crowded the day I went, and it's a relatively small building anyways, so that makes sense when everyone is trying to see the same art pieces. There are other exhibits, but those were okay too. My friends and I ended up going on a walk around the building instead, and that was more fun.

I only came to Legion of Honor to see my favorite artist (Klimt) and I realized that to do him justice and feel content about seeing his work, I need to travel to other museums around the world. Exhibit aside, there was just a lower energy at this museum compared to others around the city, and it wouldn't be my first choice for sight-seeing if I had visitors in town.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
My favorite Bay Area Museum!  Just big enough to spend an hour looking at masterworks. Free parking, gorgeous views and Rembrandt! How can you not love this place. 

Last year I brought a group of music students and we toured the museum looking at hands and faces and listening to music written at the time the paintings were made. I'll go again this coming year. 

My only disappointment is that I wish there was more Rembrandt. How's that for snooty!
author: Scott H.

description:
Any museum that houses a Monet painting, much less an entire exhibit (however temporary it was) is a museum that I must visit.  I am madly in love with Monet's work, and so when I found out that I would be in San Francisco while Monet: The Early Years Exhibit was being displayed I dragged both my and my fiancé's butt up the hill to the Legion of Honor.  Of course, this museum was wonderful on its own accord, but I have been to several other art museums that I might prefer over this one (but I say that lightly because the other museums were also more expansive).  What I did particularly like about this museum was its collection of art from artists such as Rodin - I have not seen much of his work in any other museum I have visited.  The Legion of Honor also tickled my fancy because it houses mostly French art - and French art is something I can never get enough of.

As I mentioned, I loved this museum for the mere fact that it presented one of the most amazing exhibits I have ever seen - Monet: The Early Years.  In this exhibit, many of Monet's earliest works - some of the least publicly displayed pieces - were shown, some for only the second time in history.  That was crazy!  I saw some artwork that I never thought I would see because of how valuable they are - how did the Legion of Honor manage to obtain all of this artwork, especially those that had only been shown in public once before?  I don't know if I will have the answer to that question, but quite honestly it doesn't matter.  Clearly, the Legion of Honor has damn good curators that are able to put such wonderful exhibits together for their patrons.  

Though I wish the museum was slightly bigger, I must also say that because it was smaller, it was manageable.  You could easily spend an hour or two here and have seen almost everything there is to see!  This means you could go on to the other museums in the area or take a steep walk down to the beach not too far away from the Legion of Honor.  This museum sits atop a hill overlooking a luxurious-looking golf course, and it provides a great view of the city.  So, as you can tell, there is a lot of sight-seeing to do here.

And get this?  If you are visiting town and happen to buy the SF City Pass, you could gain access into the Legion  of Honor free of charge.  Mind you, that only buys you general admission and if you are to go see the special exhibits you will have to pay for those.  The special exhibits such as the Monet: The Early Years cost somewhere around $35; that could be viewed as a little steep, but if it's an exhibit you really want to see, I guarantee that it will be well worth the money.  The only thing that I didn't particularly like about this museum were the staff working here.  The staff who worked the front desk where tickets are bought were just plain rude - no doubt, it can be a monotonous job, but that's no reason for snotty-ness.

P.S. transportation to and from here can be a little tricky...you're best off taking a bus and then hiking it up the hill.  Just be prepared for a LOT of walking when you plan your trip here.
author: Lauren K.

description:
What's great about buying a ticket to any one of the fine arts museums of SF is that your ticket is good at all participating locations for that day. So technically you can "museum hop" - but there's so much to see, you'd probably really have to plan your day out. 

I've come to the legion of honor museum in the past, but only to admire the outside architecture and view. Which I must say, is great for photo ops. If you've never been here, seeing graduation or wedding photos being taken is not uncommon. This time, I enjoyed an afternoon of classic art/Monet with one of my favorite people. 

Student admission is only $6, so don't forget those IDs, kids! 

There are rooms and rooms and rooms of paintings and sculptures. So rich in history. We were able to go through it in 2 hours.
author: Melanie B.

description:
The Legion of Honor Museum is just great.  It is also referred to as the Legion of Honor Gallery and also as the Palace of the Legion of Honor. If you have the time while in San Francisco, please visit.  A horseshoe layout, the entry level consists of 16 galleries off of a center reception area.  The admission is $15 for adults, $10 for seniors over 65, students with ID $6 and free admission to children and others up to age 17.  No veteran discounts.  If there are special exhibits, a regular happening, there will be an additional admission charge.

We were there for the Rodin and Klimt exhibitions so the admission was $27 each for we seniors, which included the general admission.  So it goes for the other categories.  Of course, members are covered for a year.  Look at family memberships if you are in the area for a longer period.

Located in the Golden Gate Park, it sits atop a hill and is majestic in appearance.  Parking is tough.  We had to park at least a half mile down hill along the road.  Cars a-plenty are all over and you will have quite a walk if you are not there early. If you have someone who has trouble walking, especially up hill,  drop them off and you go park the car.  It was a weekend day for us and it was quite a mob scene.

Each gallery is a collection from certain periods and/or artist.  Sculptures and furniture are mixed in with the wall hangings.  Most pieces have descriptions that go beyond artist and dates.  I especially enjoy information giving background on the artists and the work itself.  The store has guides and you can purchase an audio headset that give you lots of information beyond what is on the small cards on the wall.

The downstairs floor has a few small exhibits, a gift shop and a great cafe which I will review in a separate posting.  Bathrooms are also on this lower floor, and there is an exit to the outside.

Give yourself at least a half day.  It is open daily from 9:30 - 5:15 and it will take you that amount of time if you are thorough, read a lot of the information and have lunch there.  But a great way to spend a day.  The staff do a great job:  A-OK.
author: Mitch K.

description:
Beautiful, majestic architecture and a good amount of art to look at.  This museum gets crowded pretty quickly.  There's also plenty to look around outside the museum.  Not a bad place to walk around.  

Probably one of the best places to see the Golden Gate Bridge from afar.  There's plenty of art to look around as well but I would prefer the de Young museum more when it comes to actually looking at art.
author: Jackie N.

description:
Fantastic visit.  We came to see the Gods in Color- but we stayed to see everything!  First. the special exhibit- Gods in Color was amazing.  I'll never look at plain white ancient marble statues the same way.  But then we went to the porcelain room- don't miss this!  It's on the same level as the cafe.  After that we went upstairs- and we were fascinated by the variety and the quality of the exhibits.  What a treat to see a Rembrandt!  The art spans most of Europe and also includes Egyptian works.  
Prices- I have the ROAM cards- because I am a member at a museum that gets me in free to other museums.  So we saved the 15 dollar basic entrance fee.  There was an extra fee of 10 dollars for the Gods in Color- and for a small exhibit some people might not feel it was worth ten dollars.  Also extra, the Klimt exhibit- another 10 dollars.  My friends did this- we did not- and they thought it was very small, and not really worth the ten extra.  There's plenty here without the extra exhibits.  Unless you have a real interest in what's "extra" just see the regular collection- and spend that money you saved in the cafe.

Make sure you try the cafe.  We found the food to be quite wonderful.  I had the pate salad and my husband had the truffled grilled cheese.  I really recommend a visit here.  Our bill was 51 dollars- which included a coffee and a soda water.  It was not cheap- but the food quality was good and the ambiance is nice and how great to eat great food at the museum!

There's a lovely walk down to Land's End and the Sutro Baths from the museum.  It's about a mile and downhill almost all the way.
author: Alex M.

description:
Came here with friends and their parent. I've been to the museum but never really take a tour of the museum and this is the first time I walked into this museum. Anyway, we visited the museum for Klimt & Rodin's exhibition and then saw there are Gods in color and decided to check it out as well. I never knew the ticket price is going to be that pricy. But I think we spent around $140 just for the 2 exhibitions.

For Klimt and Rodin's exhibition it was interesting but then I do wish they have more arts to be displaced. They had good 4-5 rooms for the exhibition. But then the room was more filled with people than the art itself. As for gods of color. It was kind of boring. It literally just shows if the marble curving used to have color or not. If so, where the coloring are coming from and what was the materials.

Overall, it was a good half day spent in the museum! Would come back if there are new things to check it out. But make sure you come early to get a parking spot! We got to the museum by like 9.30AM and there are only limited parking lol...
author: Jeff H.

description:
I wanted to visit this museum since I've moved to NorCal and I really enjoyed my time here. 

Museum: Good
- Admission on regular day is $15, I came during the first weekend for BoA Museum Day for free admission
- Ticket here is also good for any other fine arts museum in SF so you can hop around, just keep the sticker and ticket
- There are a few scheduled tours that I would love to come back and listen to 
- There are some nice/fascinating sculptures and paintings here for viewing, I was able to get through everything in 2 hours

Location: Great
- The museum is located in a beautiful area. I got here before my friend so I walked a few trails near by and had an amazing view of the ocean
- Parking can be tough during the weekends but if you keep looking, you'll find something for sure!

I would come check out the museum, it's a beautiful building located with an amazing view.
author: Pryscilla T.

description:
Klimt and Rodin exhibit. 
Truly amazing.
Well done to all that made it possible.
Tomorrow is last day
author: C R.

description:
If you have ever considered coming here, please do so soon.  Give yourself some extra time before or after.  You must enjoy the views...embrace the beauty of SF!  My breath was taken away when we arrived.  We took a short stroll and the views of the Golden Gate Bridge was magnificent.  She is truly a beauty!!! I now know why many people come here to take the engagement, wedding or any type of photo session!

My best friend and I came here to experience the Monet: Early Years exhibit.  It did not disappoint.  This gorgeous building is one to be in awe of.  I didn't realize how huge Legion of Honor was.  Needless to say, the exhibit lived up to what I thought it would be.  The paintings, learning about his background, admiring his work, made me feel so appreciative of all his hard work and being in that era.  I can see how much he loved painting and his muse, his wife, Camille.  On top of paying for the exhibit, you get entrance to the museum.  We spent time walking around enjoying the sculptures, art, paintings.  I love how they keep everything so pristine.  

We lucked out and came on a gorgeous day.  Walking away from the museum, I was grateful for the experience and already excited to come back.  I definitely will be back again!
author: Viclaire S.

description:
Landscapes, portraits and high ceilings. Amazing free views beyond the entrance. Work by Monet, Rosin, Van Gogh and more.

$15 admission but there are easily googlable discounts online (usually $12). Bank of America also has free museum weekends with valid debit/credit card.
author: Nick K.

description:
Came here because B of A sponsors a free entry for the 1st weekend of the month. The grounds were beautiful with great views of the Golden Gate Bridge. There were several great paintings and sculptures in the collection.

I wished I could spend more time here but I got here at 4.00pm and it closed at 5.15 pm. Bummer, but at least I got to see it this time and will have to do a return trip.
author: Keo N.

description:
San Francisco's Legion of Honor is another one of those super popular tourist attractions in the city that is worth going to. For only $15 (free on most weekends if you have a Bank of America card), you get general admission to a wide selection of artwork that will have your eyes focused in amazement. 

The collections vary from 18th century art on the second floor, to silver and plate ware on the lower floor. My girlfriend and I went on a Sunday afternoon and the museum was packed, but easy to navigate through. Paring may be a pain during high traffic hours but there's plenty of spots to park at around the park. We spent about an hour and a half there and felt like the money was well spent.

Even if you don't want to pay to get inside, there's plenty to do and see outside. For example, you can get a magnificent view of the Golden Gate Bridge, or grab a nice view of the museum at night from the outside. 

Tl;dr the price is very low but the experience is worth checking out!

Have fun and prosper,
author: Bryan W.

description: This is one of the best museums I've ever been to. Each member of the staff was incredibly helpful and kind. Some even offered to take photos for me (I was visiting alone). Incredible collection of art. The highlight for me was the Impressionist collection. The museum was incredibly clean and absolutely stunning. Wonderful views from the parking lot. Lots to see and wonderfully arranged. I am so glad I visited this museum during my short trip to San Francisco.
author: Marie J.

description: A gem in San Francisco! Every time I go for a special exhibit and then take in the rest of the museum I am reminded of why I love it so much. The magnificent entry, the friendly and hyper-knowledgeable staff, and the ever changing, world class exhibits. We are so fortunate to have this in our back yard. And, what a beautiful back yard. Take in the neighborhood while you're there.
author: Jean M.

description:
Beautiful art works, antiques and royal displays.

If you are lucky you will also find a misty presidio forest and musicians playing outside.

I dint have much expectations for this place but was well worth the trip.
author: Deebs M.

description:
Good for kids- good for groups - wonderful by yourself. I popped in to see the Monet exhibit - got tix online the night before. Tremendous exhibit! Well worth wading thru the masses.
When we do a "Museum Day" we start at the De Young and visit our favs as well as the new exhibit. The Frank Stella exhibit was tremendous. The annual Bouquet de Arts is breathtaking.    A short drive and a world away is the Palace of Legion of Honor - funded by The Spreckles      ( Sugar) Family. Thank you, Alma.
The location - with views of the City and proximity to Ocean Beach- is worth the trip. The Museum has a vast and wide variety of artifacts, furniture, art...veritable treasure trove.
Room after room - a spectacular museum.
Scoop: Ask a tour guide 'where the bodies are buried' and your socks will be knocked off...
Google it.
author: Kae D.

description:
Legion of Honor (visited on 3/18/2017)

Iconic, towering, elegant and magnificent in elevation, located in Lincoln Park overlooking the Golden Gate Bridge and surrounded by plush greenery stands the historic Legion of Honor, one of the largest Museums in San Francisco.  Designed by Architect George Applegarth's, the Legion of Honor is a Neoclassical architecture replica of Palais de la Légion d'Honneur in Paris.    

So, if you can't go to Paris, come here!  Versatile, the museum is great for viewing art of course!  But, weddings often take place here, a great view of the Golden Gate Bridge is in the background, and for photographers this is a great place to shoot pictures.  
I came to the Legion of Honor specifically to view the Monet exhibit: The Early Years (Feb 27 2017-May 29, 2017). 

Claude Monet is one of my favorite painters!  So for me, this is a once in a lifetime experience to view 60 amazing art pieces by French Impressionist painter Claude Monet from his pre-Impressionist years 1858 to 1826.  It is interesting to see the evolvement of his work to the famous Water lilies painting that is housed in the post impressionist gallery.  

Regarding this exhibit, you can definitely see glimpses of the emerging impressionistic style of quick, broad strokes of broken color, particularly in the atmosphere (i.e. water, sky, and clouds).  In this installment, through various paintings, one gets to peer into the inner world of Monet, from his struggle to break away the popular painting style of the time, to his comrade with fellow like-minded artists, his struggle financially, his big break, and finally his family life.  

Through, landscape scenes, portraitures, and still life, one can see the talent, experimentation with lighting and color and various focal points that contributed to Monet ultimately coming up with artistic style Impressionism 

About this museum:

PROS/TIPS

VISITING- To visit this museum come early or take public transportation!  There is a small parking lot in the front of the museum and a larger one lower, but because art enthusiasts coming to view this very special exhibit, I highly suggest coming early.  We arrived at 11am and were able to find parking in the lower lot.   

TICKETS- Tickets for adults are pricey $35/per person (good if you go to The De Young Museum the same day because it will be free and vice versa).  I used to be a member of The De Young Museum but did not renew my membership because of financial hardship but I am thinking of becoming a member again.  With the two tickets we bought, the sales agent said it would go directly to my membership fee and I would have access again to private member showings and discounts at both museums.

Legion of Honor and most museums in San Francisco are wheelchair friendly!  I love that SF is dedicated to supporting people with disabilities, or people like me who just happen to have an injury so walking through a museum is a lot less painless in a wheelchair.  The wheel chairs are available first come first serve, so come early!   

PERMANENT GALLERIES/EXISTING GALLERIES
**Auguste Rodin's" The Thinker" sculpture greets you, centered in the Court of Honor, when you walk into the plaza (amazing piece of art!)
**Permanent galleries- Several galleries include: Ancient art, Medieval art, 16th century- 20th century Neoclassical Art through Post Impressionism, Porcelain gallery, Sculpture (Rodin),
Florence Gold Theater (re-created)
**Current galleries
--------Monet: The Early Years (Feb 25, 2017 - May 29, 2017) (**5 stars)
--------The Future of the Past: Mummies and Medicine May 14, 2016 - Aug 26, 2018 
          This was pretty interesting exhibit it.  I just glanced around (**4 stars)
--------Letter and Image (Mar 4, 2017 - July 2, 2017)--- (**3 stars)....Very small exhibit, not that appealing to me, just various lettering from different cultures
--------Urs Fischer: The Public & the Private (Apr 22, 2017 - Jul 2, 2017)----***This exhibit was not on display yet when I came.
  
OTHER AMMENITIES

**Cafe is located in the lower level (**5 stars) - Good variety of food and drinks, breakfast items and lunch/dinner menu, chef was very nice and came to greet us and asked how we liked our food.   There were lots of seating inside and the outside patio.  Very surprised how fast the line went and how fast the waitress brought to us our food.
**Museum Store is located in the lower level (**5 stars) - Lots of items (books, posters, kitchenware clothing, prints, etc.)

CONS
Other con is that there is only one bathroom and that is on the ground level....I think a museum this large should have another bathroom on the second floor.  Also, regarding the elevator near the bathroom, the men's bathroom door swings open to the elevator entrance....Poor poor design....What a shame!
author: Tori Lynn L.

description:
Just fabulous!
I wish their expositions weren't as expensive and also separate from a general admission ticket, but I don't regret spending my dollars there!
Gorgeous place inside and out, fabulous cafe inside and out, and even a free organ concert on Saturdays!
Love the history, the atmosphere, the experience.
Perfect place for a date, outing, or just a way to spend an afternoon.
Will be back!
author: Daria L.

description:
Great museum. I came here one hour before closing. Although I only had a short time, I still enjoyed visiting this museum.  Only wish is I had more time!!!

Totally unexpected. We were walking around the lands end area and just decided to stop by here. Who knew? It was trip to Europe without actually traveling to Europe. They have extensive collections of arts from many of famous artists. I am sure you will recognize one or two or all of them! How did they collect so many and only charging $15 for admission? 

Oh don't forget to take a picture with the thinker while you are there. Also check out the memorial where the first Japanese ship arrived in the US.

I fully enjoyed my one hour here. Amazing collection. Must visit in SF!
author: Yuko H.

description:
The Degas hat exhibit is ok, but not the same caliber as many other special exhibits.  There have been so many excellent special exhibits, this pales in comparison unless you are a fan of historic hats.

Degas is usually associated with dancers, so this is a new take on his work.  He really seemed to empathize with the milliners who worked in sweatshop like conditions.  I never noticed how important the hats were in many of his works.  There are many works but other artists of his day including a beautiful Renoir loaned by Anne and Gordon Getty.  

There are also many antique hats that still look exquisite, obviously worn rarely by their wealthy owners.

So I would not make a special trip for this exhibit, but if you are going to the Legion, get the special ticket for this exhibit.
author: Joanna S.

description:
I've always been a fan of the Museum at the Legion of Honor, being a member for about a decade; but recently let my membership lapse.

That was a mistake.

The current Monet exhibit (ending on May 29th...so hurry), shows his early works, much of which is on loan from the Met and Musee D'orsay. Not only is the show fantastic but it has also influenced the food available at the museum cafe. (plenty of delicious french themed food at decent prices).

Urs Fischer: The past and the present shares playful installations throughout the museum.

Upcoming shows include Degas and "Mummies and Medicine"...

Oh, and here's a pro tip, if you're a student an annual membership is only $79. (good for admission for two for a year)
author: Aaron M.

description: Went to see Rodin/Klimt exhibition.  Was disappointed that there wasn't very many of Klimt's work displayed.  The museum itself is really nice, but it is a bit small.  It costed $25 to see Rodin/Klimt.  However, this fee doesn't include the exhibition on Greek gods that was downstairs.  You would have to pay a separate fee to see it.  The perimeter around the museum is gorgeous.
author: Mei W.

description: Absolutely stunning museum, always love seeing the permanent collection, as well as the rotating exhibitions. Monet: The Early Years was exceptionally gorgeous.
author: Chloe J.

description: Totally worth any price! The building is beautifully crafted and the art they have is always worth seeing. There's so much space in the building that there's no way you can get bored. On top of it, the view outside is fantastic. If you want to go to a museum that is a bit out of the city away from all the noise, go here.
author: Angelina R.

description:
Before you enter the museum, take a moment to embrace your surroundings. At the end of your museum visit, as you exit, take a look to your left at the view of the bay. This is natures art, no gallery needed. 

Sunday date day was my 1st visit to the Legion of Honor. Not to be confused with the Palais de la Légion d'Honneur in France. Although, it is a mirror image of the original, being granted permission by the French government to replicate in 1915. If you've ever been to any of the cultural buildings in France, Paris in particular, then you've seen the magnificence, impressive details and commanding presence these buildings offer. California's Legion of Honor will not disappoint!   

At present, the renowned Rodin sculpture 'The Thinker' (notice the French theme here) greets you as you walk through the archway. Inside are other various pieces from his collection, which were purchased by the museums founders way back in 1915 from the artist himself!

My sights were set on The Mummies & Medicine and the Monet exhibitions. 

~The Future of the Past: Mummies and Medicine~
I was a little disappointed in the size of this exhibit. Especially considering the length of time it has been on display - I would expect a sizable viewing. There were 3 sarcophagi: one mummy dating around 2500 BCE, the other dating closer to 3,000 BCE and several amulets. What about the abundance of sculpture, jewelry, and pottery this region of Africa is known to have created? What about the manuscripts, papyrus and relief paintings that are recognized globally? I was also disappointed that this miniature exhibit was tucked away in an end room alllllllll the way down the hall. Nobody puts baby in a corner! But that's exactly where she was. I think this exhibit could have been curated better. 

~Monet: The Early Years~
Now this is an exhibition! Most of us have seen the beautiful paintings of Monet's Water Lilies, or the gardens of his home in Giverny. But what about the artists work at the start of his career? Who was his benefactor? Who was his muse? This exhibit did a phenomenal job at "introducing" us to Monet, his friends and his wife. Which, once you read about his path, each of these elements play a key role in his artwork. Many of his pieces are phenomenal! The colors capture reflections that seem impossible with paint. Is this a photograph? No! It's really a painting. I was utterly blown away at his skill at capturing "the light." There's a bookshop as you exit the exhibit where you can purchase books, art etc. or not. I did buy some art to display in my home - the one with the gentleman sitting on the park bench. While some photography is allowed, there are a few paintings where it is not permitted. They're labeled. Rest assured, staff is watching and will check you hard. So don't try it! You'll be embarrassed. 

With so many rooms and halls and levels, the Legion of Honor reminds me of the Louvre, just on a smaller scale. You better come with plenty of time to spare, or at the very least have a check-list of specific art you intend to see for the day. We clearly were not prepared. Hungry and running out of time, we meandered through the French, English, Italian and Russian paintings. Sprinkled in between were full scaled rooms - literally somebody's 'chamber' on display; walls, floors, chandeliers and all! Breathtaking!

As we were roaming the halls about to make our exit, I began to hear what I imagined to be an organ. Wait! Am I late for mass?! Or is that the signal for it's time to go? Who knew there was a full scale organ in the museum! Indeed, starting at 4pm on the dot, each Saturday & Sunday you can experience a cathedral sound on the custom made Skinner Organ that is built right into the museum walls. What makes this organ unique from others is that the pipes are hidden. But, you still hear that majestic sound! 

There's a lot. I know! Take it all in. Experience it, enjoy and return.
author: Jaylena P.

description:
Price: 15$ general admission, 35$ if you want to go to the special exhibition, FREE after 4:30 PM. 

Duration: maybe 1 hour if you don't go to special exhibition

Great place to take pictures outside! People come here to take some wedding pictures.

If you aren't a big fan or European art this might not be the best place for you as its pretty small in general with only a few rooms too see. Id suggest you come here after 4:30 and not pay for admissions if you are coming with a group of people because its not worth it for everyone to pay to see this place
author: Cameron L.

description:
Came for the Monet Early Years exhibit and was blown away by the collection but not the crowds. Everyone and their mamas were at the Monet section. Fortunately, the other sections were relatively quiet. 

Small museum so less than half a day - maybe 2 hours to walk the whole thing. Get there before 11a on a weekend to get parking (people were crowding my car to fight for the space at 11a). 

Great views and overall nice museum. If you are going to visit at least 2 times with a partner - get the membership. It will pay for itself in 2 visits (4 entries).
author: Kelly G.

description:
Must visit museum in SF 
Place gets packed in The Weeknd's and you don't get parking
Take Lyft or Uber and you are better off.
author: Victor D.

description: Smaller than I hoped but a lot of outstanding masterpieces!  Really cool and you'll regret not going!
author: TheOnionedElk _.

description: Great museum to check out. There's so much to see. We only paid general admission so we're weren't allowed to check out the bottom floor.
author: Liz L.

description: ...always the superior museum in San Francisco...the story behind its origins and the location turn this extraordinary museum Into a fantasy of rich history...
author: Jay F.

description:
I love this museum so much, I come here every Valentines Day when couples are out having a good time with each other. Prior to 2015 I was a frequent visit member of this place and it was really worth it. Who knew I would find great art at such an undeserving time. My friends where also former members. I love how this museum is spread out all with art in different sections. You can see things on the stop floor and the bottom floor. If you can't find parking you can either be patient or take the 18 bus. I find that taking the 18 bus and then going into the museum is the best thing that I could ever do. Last is that it's a good place to visit after a weekend lunch and it's actually really quiet. 
Drawback: the museum has a small eatery on the lower level. If you want to get a bite do it before it's too late. It closes earlier than the whole museum combined.
author: Michael W.

description:
This is a beautiful, small museum.  We came here with my son's Kindergarten class. Although it went over the heads of the little ones a bit, this was a good exposure and start for the kids.  They were interested in the statute of The Thinker out  front thanks to the "Good Night Good Night San Francisco" book, the mummies, some statues, and the Monet was wonderful since it will be an art docent art project for them soon.

The facility is well kept and clean. Parking is free, and there is a free app that you can use to learn about certain pieces and find where you are in the building.

The museum is deep in San Francisco, so the trek out there for us (from East Bay) is a bit  tedious. But if you have the time, drive down the street to enjoy Immigrant Point Overlook, the Golden Gate Bridge, Fort Point, the Yoda Fountain, etc.
author: Tracy L.

description:
Love it here- 2 stories of art throughout the centuries filled with artifacts, paintings, sculptures, and even a mummy exhibit (when I went earlier this week). There's a cafe on the bottom floor and clean bathrooms as well. Before or after the museum, the view of the Golden Gate Bridge and surrounding hiking areas are great as well. 

*free first Tuesday of the month
*relatively easy parking
author: Corinna T.

description:
Close to lands end, located next to a golf course with some beautiful views of the ocean and the golden gate bridge. Highly recommend walking around outside the museum as well, plenty on beautiful art to see here along with the natural beauty. Bring a jacket though!

Now the main part, the actual museum. Absolutely fantastic place to spend a few hours. Very well organized, categorized by time period. Very interesting place to see art over the ages. Gorgeous statues, paintings, carvings, and other art (tea sets, armoires, desks, globes, porcelain, books). There is a rotating display, I got to see an Egyptian exhibit today with real mummies, ancient art and a modern CT scan of a mummies internals. They had a show with someone playing an antique organ (instrument), great music that you can hear throughout the museum.

Many famous artists here too - Van Gogh, Picasso, and more. Seeing the art through the ages is spectacular with the changes in styles depicting what was popular at the time. There is an extra section on the lower floor that costs extra to see, didn't do it this time, maybe next time! Bring your student ID for a discount.
author: Rohit S.

description:
Gorgeous museum worth the trip! Up on a beautiful hill tucked away perfect for taking a long stroll there and back!
Went for the Monet exhibit was insanely crowded but exhibit was done well
author: Morgan S.

description: The Legion of Honor is a wonderful museum! I visited Los Angeles' LACMA Museum this past weekend and the Legion towers over anything LACMA has to offer. I find the Legion of Honor (AND the DeYoung) to have wonderful presentation of their paintings/exhibits. Things are well-lit in beautiful settings and exhibit halls. Plus, the parquet floors add to the grandeur of the Legion of Honor! I love that place!! The artwork is very carefully displayed. Not too cluttered and with very good description(s) and simply placed. No hodgepodge in this museum, as if each and every piece is just 'so very special' and lovingly placed and cared for. Kudos to those who do the presentation(s) in both buildings (Legion and the DeYoung). Make a visit soon! It will be something you'll well-remember! Have fun!
author: Linda S.

description: Fantastic exhibit!  Plus the lecture series was superb.  I felt as though I had travelled there.
author: Frank S.

description: My favorite museum in the City! Classical, fine art museum. The building itself is a work of art. Combine it with a short hike around Land's End and Sutro Baths for a great afternoon in the city.
author: Semuteh F.

description: Beautiful building, amazing views. Monet exhibit got crowded. Rodin and the permanent collection, including mummies, were great. Enjoyed the 4 pm organ concert.
author: Carl B.

description: Saw the Klimt and Rodin exhibition and it was disappointing.    I love Klimt but they only had about 15 Klimt painting and of those many were not Klimts better paintings.   Maybe 8 or 9 were worth seeing.    The Legion of Honor already has many Rodin statues so I am not sure why they were included unless it was an attempt to cover up the lack of a credible Klimt showing.  I also love the Legion of Honor but this exhibit was poor.
author: Gordon S.

description: I love this museum. It's what museums are supposed look and be like. Great exhibits, wonderful location with million$ views. Nice cafeteria and gift shops too.
author: Peggy K.

description:
Legion of Honor is very beautiful (it's a great site for engagement shoot, haha) and I never get tired of looking at it!

It is part of the Bank of American Museum On Us list, so we've visited a few times for free already! It's also free on the first Tuesday of every month...not to mention you can normally purchase one ticket and be able to visit here and the de Young Museum, so it's an awesome deal no matter.
author: Cathy W.

description:
Of all the Legions around, the Legion of Honor is probably the best Legion in Northern California. Humor aside, this fine art museum lies at the northwestern tip of the City in Lincoln Park just south of the Golden Gate Bridge. Parking can be very difficult in the area, but transit is also limited, so getting here is a bit more difficult than finding the Legion of Doom.

The entry is just impressive. You walk through a large courtyard bounded by tall columns with a sweeping view of the City and Golden Gate. The layout of the interior is equally impressive with high ceilings and large display areas. Most of the artwork is classic with few modern or post modern exhibits. There is a nice Rodin sculpture area and a decent collection of Impressionists. The basement usually hosts traveling exhibitions with an additional admission fee.

The Legion of Honor is partnered with the de Young Museum, so memberships work at both facilities. It is a beautiful place with a beautiful collection in a beautiful - if remote - location. Assuming you can find a parking space, art lovers will love the trip.
author: Kristian D.

description:
The Legion of Honor is probably one of the most beautiful museums architecturally and in what is housed within. Unfortunately, unless you are somewhat well versed in the historical elements of a certain room, you can only see pieces for their aesthetic value. Nonetheless, it is still fun to walk from room to room appreciating the various details of the different time periods. 

Occasionally, a docent or a well-versed visitor will give a short lecture on certain works. We were lucky enough to listen in on a explanation of the French salons. The docent covered everything from the architecture all the way to the nuances of how the furniture was oriented!

The current special exhibit on Breguet timepieces is also worth the $5 in my opinion. The pieces are incredibly well-preserved and quite a spectacle to view.

My only complaint would probably be the standoff-ish nature of some of the employees. The lady working the front desk literally deigned to welcome us to the museum...it was very cold and odd. Then, at the gift shop, mom and I had to wait for the cashier to finish her idle conversation with the other store manager before we could proceed with our purchase - rude!
author: Elaine Y.

description:
Despite what the name suggests, Legion of Honor is not a military museum. Instead, this is the museum of European arts as a part of the San Francisco fine arts museum system. As impressive as the Greco-Roman temple architecture, Legion of Honor's art collection is definitely worth checking out!

The museum architecture is a masterpiece of its own: a fine example of a Greek column temple placed on top of the hill with spectacular view of San Francisco - certainly worthy of the collection that the museum holds within! In its medium-sized collection, you will find both familiar classics like Rodin sculptures and exciting surprises like a old basilica dome ceiling. Even without an audio guide, you will find at least a handful of art pieces to awe you.

By the way, did you know the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco is in a collaboration with Paris's famous Musee du Louvre? That means you may be able to catch the glimpse of France's world-famous art collection without having to fly!

Expect to spend about 1-2 hours in here, but your admission also includes the de Young Museum, which is the modern art counterpart, so plan for that as well! Even if you do not intend to enter, you should still go and see this impressive building with a remarkable view.

---
tl;dr version:
1) European arts "department" of the SF Fine Arts Museums
2) Awesome medium-sized collection that may/may not have Louvre pieces
3) Spectacular building to see on its own with a remarkable view
author: Jay Y.

description: Beyond disappointed. Flew to San Francisco, got a hotel room, and took a uber to the museum. Only to find out the the exhibition of Klimt and Rodin was sold out. This wasn't stated anywhere on their website I checked before leaving home. The staff didn't even apologize for the inconvenience.
author: Terrence S.

description:
The short: Stunning museum worth many repeated visits

I have known about this place for some time and my friends and I have roamed the grounds for pictures. I had no idea that it was a museum!  The exterior is wonderful for pictures, and I have seen several engagement/wedding shoots here too. There's Rodin's Thinker in the front of the museum, along with a glass pyramid, similar to the one at the Louvre.

Once inside, the ticketing process is very easy and there's a quick bag check. For first-timers, it helps to know that the whole museum is shaped like a U. You're in the deep part of the U at the entrance.

It was only a couple days ago that I stepped foot inside here for the first time. I came for the Breguet exhibit, which was very magical and astounding. 

Having arrived at the museum in the late afternoon, I didn't have a lot of time to pause and admire and contemplate the works of art in other galleries of the museum. I skimmed over the book collection and the porcelain and the silver wares. Instead, I spent most of my time on the Impressionist paintings and admiring the floors, the ceilings, and just the joyous moments of being inside a stunning museum. This museum is very open and for a January weekend (also the second to last day of the Breguet collection), it wasn't too crowded.

I'm going to try to make it a goal to come here at least once a season!

There's also a marvelous free (!) organ concert every Saturday and Sunday starting at 4 pm! The lovely music can be heard throughout the museum, though it is best heard in gallery 10 on the upper level.
author: Catherine W.

description: Come here after the museum closes, and stay and view twilight from here. The museum is lit up, and so majestic.
author: George T.

description:
Writing this review in hopes the Museum responds with preventative measures: 
YOUR PARKING LOT IS A HOT BED FOR THEFT, GET A SECURITY GUARD.
 On July 31st, 2016 I was the car parked closest to the enterance when some of your local crime decided to smash out my window. It's apparent that you are aware of the crime considering going you posted signs inside. It would seem to me an accredited museum could make a better effort to address this woth security guards or at least a volunteer. Listen to your reviews, respond  by protecting your paying customers.
author: Neko S.

description: Went for the Monet exhibit and the rest of the museum. Was constantly harassed by security not to get closer than 18 inches to anything. I wasn't, but said ok. Then they were talking on their radios but were at full volume - could hear them three rooms away. Ruined the experience. Also, when I was leaving the monet part, they were denying entry to people who had small children with them. They had paid $35 to go and they would not let them in the monet section with their kids. Very rude about it. Never going back.
author: Don B.

description: Beautiful wedding location! The staff around were very informative and helpful. There were parts of the museum closed during the wedding, so I will definitely need to return again the future.
author: Amanda R.

description:
Of the two art museums in SF, I prefer the Legion of Honor over de Young because it's more intimate, it's not over run by tourists and the location can't be beat!  We came during the Bank of America Free Museum Day which happens on the first Saturday of each month.

The last time I was at the Legion of Honor, we were taking engagement pictures. I've never been inside the museum until now.  I really like the open space and how tranquil it is inside, You can wander to your heart's content for a whole day. 

My favorite displays were the porcelain room and the paneled rooms.  The paneled rooms can give Filoli a run for its money.  Very pretty.

Tip:  For free museum days, kids can go in free with an adult with a BofA card.  However, every adult must have a BofA card in order to get in for free.  DH had a card but I left mine at home because I thought it's for the whole family.  Not so. However for the reasonable price of $10, you can get in.  That's a bargain considering it's $10 for the 4 of us.
author: Wendy H.

description: The people that work there are complete A-holes. We came here by mistake...we were actually trying to find The Palace of Fine Arts. Every employee we asked, describing the place we were trying to actually find, were just absolutely rude. Big F you to the staff here. We had two young children with us, you guys are perfect examples of how not to treat guests. On the plus side, got to see Monet's Water Lilies painting in person. They do have a great collection of paintings there.
author: Jonathan T.

description:
"High Style: The Brooklyn Museum Costume Collection" from March 14 - July 19 is the reason I paid a return visit to the Legion of Honor-just for this exhibit alone. And it was the first Tuesday of the month!  Free general admission yet paying a special exhibition fee ($11.00).

The principal reason I wanted to view the exhibition was the work of the Anglo-American couturier Charles James (1906-1978).  Charles James's work was the 2014 theme of the Metropolitan Museum's fund raising gala for its Costume Institute. From the Metropolitan Museum's website on James: "James's design process, specifically his use of sculptural, scientific, and mathematical approaches to construct revolutionary ball gowns and innovative tailoring that continue to influence designers today." There is a lot of material utilized behind the fabric and seams in the construction of a Charles James gown such as boning, tulle, and horsehair under all the draping, folding, and pleating. 

Many of his creations were worn by many of New York's elite socialites (i.e. Millicent Rogers, Babe Paley and Diana Vreeland) at galas and in their portraits of the 1940s and 1950s. Marlene Dietrich wore his designs. 

Christian Dior credits James as his inspiration for his revolutionary New Look. And amongst today's designers who cites Charles James as an influence in his work is Zac Posen. James and Posen's gowns are wearable works of art.

Even better--I was quite delighted to learn I could take no-flash photos of the collection. Good thing I had my charger key with me to power my iPhone as there were so many designs to snap photos of the exhibition.

Before going in, I inquired about the free docent tour as in "could I return to view the exhibition if I partake in aforementioned tour?" I was advised I could if I go sign up at check-in. I was just there checking in my backpack, so I went back and got my name on the list---lucky slot number three. I was delighted to learn the docent tour includes utilizing a free handset, no need to pay the eight dollars for the self-guided audio tour. And I was quite delighted I could use my own headphones instead of the ones provided with the device for the docent tour.

Charles James was the pièce de résistance of "High Style: The Brooklyn Museum Costume Collection." The exhibition also featured creations by Jacques Doucet, House of Drécoll, Steven Arpad, Callot Soeurs, Elsa Schiaparelli, Bonnie Cashin, Arnold Scaasi, Christian Dior, Yves St. Laurent, Madame Gres, Gilbert Adrian ("Gowns by Adrian"), Halston, and my personal favorite, Chanel. I was surprised and shocked there was only one Coco Chanel creation in the exhibition. Charles James's archetectual, artistic, and sculptural creations conclude the exhibition.

My film her-storian side was delightfully happy. The gown Ava Gardner wore in 1954's The Barefoot Contessa designed by the Fontana Sisters (Sorelle and Michol) is amongst the exhibition. It is a creation of pink duchesse silk satin, black velvet appliqués, and black silk velvet panelling. There is a 1960 pale blue silk taffeta dress Hubert de Givenchy worn by model-actress Lauren Bacall. 

I mentioned Adrian who was credited as "Gowns by Adrian" for over 250-350 MGM films, where he was the chief costume designer. "The Tigress" ensemble by Adrian is featured. Made of beige, black, and orange silk chiné and gold lamé, Adrian made this for his wife, the actress Janet Gaynor after and inspired by a holiday they took to Africa.

Charles James has two rooms devoted to his work of design sketches and his clothes. In the first room, in the center is the Clover Leaf ball gown, 1953. Made of pink silk faille, copper silk shuntang, and black silk lace with ivory silk faille backing. It is in a glass case and the visitor can walk to see all  360 degrees of the ball gown. It is surrounded by other James's works such as La Sirène (1939), Ensemble (1947), Ribbon (1947), Dinner Dress (1950), Bustle (1947) and muslins of some of the aforementioned designs.

The second room is devoted to James's other masterpieces, muslins and computer animation videos. These videos show the construction and underpinnings of James's B&W Clover Leaf (1953), Diamond (1957), Ball Gown (1951) and Tree (1955) along with the aforementioned gowns and muslins.

I plan to return before the exhibition's last day of July 19. I am bringing reinforcements--more cameras. It sure beats getting postcards. I did view the postcards available for purchase, unfortunately the selection was quite limited in what designs were featured. Translation: there were no standouts I wanted to purchase.
author: Chiara A.

description:
The Legion of Honor is a memorable museum to visit in San Francisco, as much for its setting facing the Marin Headlines and the Bay and its majestic building,  as for its collection and exhibitions. The museum was built for Alma Spreckels, by her sugar daddy (literally) and husband. Yes, THAT Spreckels. (If curious about city history, you can find her graceful and extremely statuesque likeness soaring in the skies in the middle of Union Square.)

The museum has a fairly small hodgepodge collection inside, but a pretty awe inspiring setting, classic columns and even a tiny crystal clear glass pyramid (inspired, no doubt, by the Louvre pyramid) set in the museum's front courtyard.

Typically more of a modern art fan, I still appreciate the neoclassical setting and the small but powerful collection of Rodin sculptures, English and Victorian works, a room full of Dutch masters (Rembrandt is always moody and evocative) and a bevy of impressionist paintings.  Its a small but poetic collection, a remarkable setting, and the exhibitions here are often creative and memorable.  Plan a visit here, if you can.  (A membership here gets you into the De Young in GG Park, so a great two-for-one for any museum fan.)
author: Rachel H.

description:
Have been a SFFAM member for years.  The Klimt and Rodin exhibit was a sore disappointment:  Very small, and in places very badly lit.  A friend and I got there just before 1pm on Saturday 1/13.  We had to wait until 3:45 to get in.  The male gatekeeper was very polite.  The female gatekeeper not so much so.  'Twas a very poor exhibit of a painter whose work I've loved, and longed to see, for decades.  And my guest and I both travelled two hours each way on public transit just to see it.

The gallery with the "resident" Monet waterlily painting was apparently closed.  So my friend and I didn't get to see that painting.  Kind of a big deal, as she was visiting from out of town, and I'd raved about it to her.

Friend and I stopped in at the café after seeing the exhibit, for coffees.  We had to wait to have the coffees brought to our table, which was fine.  While we were waiting, and finally sipping, an older Asian male café employee came to our table--TWICE within five minutes!--and told us the café was closing in 10 minutes.  Talk about a bum's rush.  Boo!

The exhibits at the SFFAMs have been declining in quality in recent years.  My last experience was so poor that I will have serious second thoughts about re-upping my membership in the future.  I certainly will not recommend membership to anyone else, tax-deductible or not.
author: Karen S.

description:
By far my favorite museum in San Francisco. They've got a fantastic collection of art, and the building itself is classically beautiful. You're welcomed inside by Rodin's "The Thinker" and a glass pyramid (a bit similar to the ones at the Louvre). 

Lots of Dutch work (think Rubens, Rembrandt), and there's an entire room dedicated to Rodin works. High ceilings with natural light flooding in gives the museum a beautiful ambiance. I could sit on the bench in the impressionist room (Manet, Monet, Seurat, Degas, van Gough, etc) for hours! 

We arrived just in time yesterday to hear the organ concert. Apparently they do it in the Rodin room every Saturday and Sunday at 4pm. We stopped to listen for a few minutes, but it was really magical to wander through the galleries and hearing the music as we went. 

Parking is easy (and free)! And the views from the parking lot are breathe taking. You can see lands end, and there's lots of tables and chairs around to take it all in.
author: Angela F.

description: We bought tickets on-line the same day for the Monet-The Early Years exhibit and spent the afternoon exploring this museum.  Parking was tough so we parked 3/4 of a mile away in a neighborhood and walked to the museum.  It was a holiday weekend so this didn't surprise us, we came prepared in good walking shoes.  We thoroughly enjoyed the display of the beautiful Monet paintings, a lovely collection.  We also toured the other rooms including the Rodin sculptures, even spotted a Van Gogh and many other very famous artists. A very pleasant day viewing incredible art.  Highly recommended.
author: Donna F.

description:
The artwork of Sarah Lucas scattered throughout the exhibits really help you appreciate the other artists. My first viewing was when I turned a corner and just as quickly as I saw her tasteless, lewd, shock triggering, cigarette sodomized sculpture dead center of the room I removed my gaze and was forced to behold the beauty gathered amongst the walls. Remembering the sign outside mentioning the provocative nature of her art I was determined to simply avoid all the rest of her pieces. But then the museum thought it was a good idea to drape a couple of Sarah Lucas' breast over The Three Shades. You'd think that they would have given her own exhibit room for the amount of pieces she had or better yet skip the Degos exhibit and showcase Sarah. The piggybacking off Rodin was a bit pathetic and the vague similarities attempted to be drawn of the two was further pathetic. I could draw no comparisons only the stark contrast of good and bad. 

Of course those admiring the work are the same propagators who are nothing more than a by product of San Francisco/Berkeley feminist liberalism. And view the unappreciative as Nazis and backward white supremacist. 

There is such a thing as bad art....

-1 Star for the administrations bad idea.
author: Alec G.

description: The LOH is one of my favorite museums in SF. They are a medium sized institution that features an outsized collection of fine and arts. They have an eclectic collection of medieval to impressionist works.  You can see works by Monet, Rodan, Van Gogh, and other well known artists. There are frequent contemporary exhibits featured in the galleries too. They seem to draw the line at the modernists as far a curation decisions go.
