There is currently a special exhibition of Degas downstairs.  Their collection of glass and porcelain ware is outstanding. It will take 2-4 hours to really enjoy the LOH and it is well worth the price of entry. They also have one of the finest Guard/Docent teams I have ever had the pleasure of interacting with. They just don't stand around staring. They are experts and engage guests in insightful discussions about the various artists and their work. They really make LOH special. There are also daily free organ recitals with a unique instrument that utilizes the domed atrium to amplify sound. On site feee parking. Great for the entire family.
author: Jerry M.

description:
Locals call it, 'The Palace of Legion of Honor' - generously gifted to the City  by the Speckles (Sugar) family. After you park (multiple parking areas around the museum) stroll around and take awhile to appreciate the numerous spectacular City views.
Yes, that's one of Rodin's 10 copies of "The Thinker." And it gets better.
Take your time...enjoy each floor, each gallery, restrooms on the lower level. Look for the  three golden angels as you walk into the  Cafe.
author: Miami S.

description:
The juxtaposition of Sarah Lucas' "art" with Rodin's breathtaking masterpieces was OFFENSIVE.  The worst part was that her junk was literally unavoidable, as it was co-mingled in with several other exhibits.  
The slashed dirty futon with flourescent bulbs looked like a lazy high-schooler's project.  My mother in law audibly gasped when she spotted Sarah's natty, spent-looking dirty nylon dolls laid at the base of a bronze sculpture.  I respect art, but this is recycled street trash at best, and if it is an "exhibit", it should be housed in its' own area and labeled as such.  Give us a chance to avoid this travesty entirely! 
This installation completely detracted from all the other legitimate, beautiful creations in this museum.  With all the art available in this collection, to be greeted by a plaster-of-paris mannequin with a cigarette up her butthole, well, it was fucking heartbreaking.
Get it together, you guys.  Nobody wants to explain that garbage to their kids. Or themselves.
author: Lea N.

description:
Location couldn't be more perfect. With the jaw dropping view of the ocean and the GG right up front a visit to this museum is a nice escape from the hustle and bustle of the city. Just approaching the main entrance is an experience in itself as you take in the gorgeous large enclosed courtyard. 

Viewing of the collections housed here never gets old but what usually keeps drawing myself back here are the fantastic exhibits. We are lucky to have this Fine Art museum right here in our fair city.
author: Esther A.

description: Legion of Honor is worth the walk up the hill to see the Italian Renaissance paintings. There are a few new exhibits sprinkled in which is both out if place and enjoyable.
author: David F.

description: We did not go inside the museum so I cannot rate anything in regards to that. These 4 stars are merely for the outside pillars and columns! Great for photo shoots as I see so many wedding photographers there while we were passing by.
author: Vivian N.

description:
This place reminds me with Griffith Observatory in Los Angeles. The view on the whole city of San Francisco, the Golden Gate Bridge and the Pacific ocean is unbelievable! 


Since I can be a certified tour guide in San Francisco, this is one of my important destinations to bring my visiting friends from outside SF. It's a must-to-see if you're visiting San Francisco. 

If you're a photographer, you could spend days taking pictures in this place.

Parking is easy. This place is fantastic to start a Saturday morning hike along the lands end trail.

#AwesomePlace #beauty
author: Ahmad A.

description: For travelers this seems to be off the main path...but it is worth the time. Make a day of it by spending time with the extremely well-curated exhibits (the early Monet exhibition in Spring, 2017 was excellent)...and then allow time to walk the park grounds and take in the views. The museum cafe offers a nice setting for a break, including a selection of wines from glass to bottle.
author: Ken V.

description:
I've lived in the Bay Area my entire life and had never heard of this place until about a week or two again. How in the world that I didn't know about this place is beyond what my puny brain can comprehend. Still, this place really does exist. 

This is a very European museum, mainly in the world of the French. Lots of French pieces of art and artifacts. The location is amazing. You have views of the Golden Gate Bridge and a golf course! Yes, a golf course! Still, it's a very beautiful location and I can understand why so many people decide that they want to get married here. 

I love visiting places that have classical pieces of art on display especially, European art. From mounts of armor, to busts, this place has so much to look at. There was a really weird dude in here though, who would literally plant his face into the the painting and make it awkward for everyone, but that's the world we live in. Everybody is different. 

The staff was bit on the hostile side though, and some of them looked like they hated life more than anything. One guy yelled at a lady for stepping out of the eating area with her glass of water, and another dude nearly had a stroke when someone get a little too close to a table. Some of these guys need to lighten up, but then again they were working on Valentine's Day. 

Still, this place has so much to offer than you will truly have plenty to look at. Would love to come here again at some point and show someone this place that hasn't experienced it.
author: Benny H.

description:
Legion of Honor is also one of the must see museums in San Francisco. The structure is nice and there are decent collections in the gallery. They have a Map and Visitor Guide in the entrance that you can grab freely so you can walk around on your own.

We didn't think we needed the tour since we prefer to actually tour on our own pace. But might sign in next time we visit. They also have a Porcelain Gallery at the lower level that you can check out. 

General admission is $10 and it includes a same day admission to de Young Museum. Definitely worth it although these two museums are not close to each other. So if you want to go to both museums, you can check this one first in the morning, then de Young in the afternoon.

Anyway, my boyfriend and I had to come here early to get good parking. It gets packed in the afternoon so beware.  

There is a shop that you can check out for some art books, gifts, and home decors. The Museum Cafe offers classic American and European cuisine but didn't get to try it though. 

Museum is closed most Mondays and select holidays.
author: Isabella D.

description:
What a wonderful facility - you need days to truly appreciate the incredible artwork. Unfortunately, we did not have time to take in the whole museum ( the Bonnard exhibit was highly recommended). As we walked up the driveway to the museum I was struck by the fact that there is a public golf course on both sides of the drive and a stunning view of the Golden gate Bridge once you reach the top of the hill.

The building itself is stunning (needs a little TLC) and the exhibits that we saw were just as stunning. Monet, Renoir, Degas, van Gough to name a few along with numerous other offerings. You can spend a long time in front of "The Russian Bride's Attire", a huge painting, and really look at the story being portrayed.

Definitely a stop on a "must see" visit to San Francisco.
author: Dave W.

description: Beautiful museum out of the congestion of Golden Gate Park. Went to see the Monet: early years exhibition which was informative and showcased a lesser known period in the artistic great's life. Funny fact: the porcelain exhibition is near the bathrooms... Coincidence?
author: JoAnn Y.

description: Amazing view. Amazing exhibitions. Degas right now. What an amazing place that we never knew of.
author: C C.

description:
Pretty view of golden gate bridge.  Great architecture.

Only saw the exterior.  Was closed when we visited.
author: Lan C.

description:
I'd give the Fine Arts Museums of SF 5 stars for their collections and the beautifully designed buildings in which they're housed, but unfortunately I can't because it's so difficult, despite being a member, to get online tickets to exhibits.  The "new, improved" website that was put up 4 or 5 months ago is one of the worst, if not the worst, I've experienced.  It's errors are creative, varied, and always frustrating.  For example, today it said that our "membership had been canceled from June 19, 2015 to June 25, 2015."  2015? It's September 2017.  So I had to call the museum to get my tickets.  
I can go to museums all over the world and get tickets easily from the US.  It's a shame that I can't do the same where I live.
author: CE F.

description: Definitely a tourist trap, but well worth a visit anyways.  The Legion is beautiful both inside and out.  Parking can be finicky and the chambers do get crowded sometimes, but there is nothing quite like enjoying a Picasso or taking in the "Thinker" and then stepping outside for a moderate hike to Lands End and catching a sunset and views of the Golden Gate.
author: David C.

description: You have to get here before it opens to find parking or to avoid crowds - at least on weekends. Great permanent collection, interesting exhibits, and definitely worth the membership if you're local!
author: Anees L.

description:
This is a review for the outer grounds of Legion of Honor which in my opinion, is the best part of the museum!
When you arrive the parking is pretty terrible! Not that there isn't enough parking but there are so much cars here!!!! It's not just the parking for legion of honor but parking for the nearby trails, legion of honor, overlook, and golf course. 
No after you find parking you will come up to the Legion of Honor and be confused when you first lay eyes on it. How can something so beautiful, so greek be just resting in San Francisco?!
It feels like a roman/greek building just for you to adventure and explore. 
First up the front of Legion of Honor does not have a gate around it which means you can come after 5PM and take some pictures here if you arrive too late. Majestic roman type pillars grace both sides of the building. Now if you come here before 5PM, you are greeted with the courtyard which has the pillar walkways on both sides. There are neat statues scattered around and there is also this one awesome half glass pyramid area where you are allowed to sit besides. Perfect for taking some cool pictures.
Then of course you have the museum which is kind of expensive and it is mostly painting exhibition interior, nothing like the exterior museum at all. So don't go in there expecting King Leonidas' house because you will say THIS IS NOT SPARTAAAAAAA

If you are facing the museum entrance, to your right is the land's end trail and an overlook to the Golden Gate bridge. To the left will be the golf course which you need to be weary of golf balls flying.
author: Jason H.

description:
Came here on a Tuesday to see the High Style exhibit. The exhibit was awesome! If you're into high fashion and can appreciate finer things, in my opinion, it's worth the $11 (even though it was a "Free Day.") I spent a good hour just ogling and ooing and ahhing at the craftsmanship and attention to detail of the pieces. 
Definitely come visit before this exhibit ends July 19!!

Outside of the High Style exhibit, there are Monets, Rodins, and works by Degas! An all-around exquisite  (albeit smaller) collection of old artifacts and works of art.

Minus 1 star for the Asian lady at the front ticketing desk. She was kinda cold and didn't seem very happy to be working there but at the very least she was fast getting out tickets.
author: Sylvia Y.

description: The Klimt show at the Legion of Honor is very disappointing.  Only a few finished pictures, poorly lit, and crowded.  And very expensive ($30/person) for a small, disappointing show.
author: S.K. R.

description: Amazing museum! I lived in SF for over 10 years, but somehow I had never been to it! Highly recommended. I also waited outside for friends to arrive so had a chance to stroll through the area outside. Beautiful location and views of the golden gate. There is not much parking, so I would recommend taking public transportation or a taxi/uber.
author: Alexandra B.

description: Tip: don't be a fool and leave anything of value in your car. This place is cased 24/7 by organized thieves. Saw two smash and grabs in 4 hours in broad daylight!
author: Clara A.

description: Great view outside and inside. The feeling is unique it sets you back to the Greek era. I love to come here with my lovely girlfriend. If you have a membership, it is a win.
author: Nuno V.

description:
It's quite awhile since I visited this museum.
Since I purchased a ticket to the De Young
Museum this also included free admission
to the Legion of Honor. 
   Amazing collection from Egyptian mummies,
to 13th century art, French , Italian, German
and Dutch, Spanish art. Degas, Van Gogh,
Manet, Renoir, Pizzaro, Seurat, Cezanne,Rembrandt, Monet to name a few.
No crowds. Free parking for 4 hours.
author: Gayle G.

description: This is pretty much SF's take on Le Louvre and the Metropolitan museum although much smaller. On the other hand, it's in a much more stunning location which quickly adds up to its value. Add to this the gutsy curatorial decision of mixing old masters with contemporary, this museum is a leader and a MUST see!
author: Amr A.

description:
I was never really fond of museums but this place definitely was beautiful. The external architecture was stunning. When I went here, there was a photoshoot for couples which I thought was interesting. Maybe I'll do one here.

The place was super quiet and everyone seemed to mind their own business. I spent about a total of almost two hours just looking at paintings and other forms of art.

My favorite piece was the Apocalypse painting. Majority of the painting was color black, but the color red brought attention to it that intrigued me.

Outside of the museum, you could see the Golden Gate Bridge and you could go there to take pictures. There were also cliffs nearby which was a pretty scenic view.

I'd definitely come back here again and bring a friend.
author: Aj C.

description:
We attended the Legion of Honor on a Friday in September. It was foggy driving in via the Golden Gate, and the cool breezes saved us from the dry Sacramento heat. On the agenda was a showing of Degas, Impressionism, and the Paris Millinery Trade. Featuring ~40 Impressionist paintings and pastels by Degas (many never before exhibited in the United States), Renoir, Manet, Mary Cassatt, Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec and more. There were also 40 well-preserved examples of period hats, some adorned with feathers, lace, and flowers on display throughout the exhibit.
Needless to say, we really enjoyed the full experience!
Since it was not a Saturday or Sunday, there were not as many visitors roaming about. We were able to find parking near the Museum quite easily. The price of the show was reasonable ($28), and the layout and presentation was impeccable!
Being fans of the Hitchcock film, Vertigo, we were also elated to finally see where part of it was filmed...right here at the Legion of Honor!
Afterwards, we were able to walk the full length of the Museum, and see all of the other exhibits and collections as well. Wow! One of our favorite rooms was Salon Doré, the 18th Century Period Room re-creation from the Hôtel de La Trémoille. It is a lot to take in, so be sure to give yourself plenty of time to enjoy it, and definitely take a stroll around the grounds for a bit too. Do not miss this opportunity!
author: Jason B.

description: I went a little while ago and forgot to yelp. Saturday late morning to early afternoon parking  was a little tough; but didn't have to pay for it! Love their collection of Auguste Rodin work; even if it isn't all original! I like the view of the Bay from the front of museum. Such a gorgeous museum!
author: Vaness C.

description: "hostage situation". $15 *extra* to see the klimt AND the *permanent* exhibition of rodin. so if i just pay the regular 15 (without the extra 15 for klimt), i miss the rodin which i would normally get to see for the regular 15. and little effort to seriously make any connection between klimt and rodin. it's really a ripoff. it should be $6 extra for the limited number of klimts.
author: J L.

description:
I was here for a wedding this past weekend because the bride chose this place to have pictures taken with her entourage. This past Saturday 6/28/14 turned out to be a gorgeous day in SF.  It was sunny and picturesque.  The building itself served as a great backdrop for all of the bridesmaids and groomsmen.  The columns were great to look at architecturally and the simplicity of the lines made for some great looking photographs where the bridal party was able to have numerous poses.  It's one of those places where photographers love to take pictures because of the great natural lighting.  In the distance, you have a clear view of the bay and the Golden Gate Bridge.  

I come to SF regularly and was surprised that I had never been here before.  Don't you love it when that happens?   Ah, the wonders of California and all the places we have right here in our own backyard.
author: Lorie N.

description:
Did you know that membership to the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco entitles you entry to both the Legion of Honor and the de Young Museum?  My Christmas present to my husband last year was a membership to FAMSF and we've been able to visit BOTH museums this year as members!  If you're not a member, you can use your tickets from the Legion of Honor to enter the de Young on the same day.  It's a bit of a challenge visiting two museums in one day, but it can be done and it can save you money.

The location of this museum couldn't be better.  Yes, it's far from downtown, but it's worth the trek.  It's in Lincoln Park and you can get a good view of the Golden Gate from here.  Get here early though if you want to be able to find parking!  That great view attracts many camera-toting tourists, so parking may be a challenge on peak times and weekends!

This museum is not very big.  It's smaller than the de Young and SF MOMA.  Three hours in this museum would be plenty of time to see most of the more interesting stuff.  The Rodin sculptures are always fun to see.  

We came here on Veteran's Day as I was off from work and wanted to see the Houghton Hall exhibit.  I admit that I was a Downton Abbey devotee for a while, and love the grandeur of English country homes, so it was a nice treat to see this exhibit.  It's not a very big exihibit, so you can go through it in about an hour.  An audio tour will cost you an additional $6, but it makes for a better experience.  The cafe also was also offering tea service in honor of the exhibit if you're into that.
author: Hazel C.

description: Our 4th visit in past two years and its always been a special treat.  Degas/Millinery exhibit was fine, a unique peek into an aspect of French history, but the guaranteed-to-be-in-your-face Sarah Lucas provocative display that everyone walking into the first floor had to experience (with all their young'uns in tow on the day we visited) belongs in a separate room off the main track.
author: Gregory A.

description: Beautiful museum! The setting is impressive. It's situated at the top left corner of the city, overlooking the city in one direction and the Pacific ocean in the other. It gives you the impression of unlimited space, which is unique in San Francisco, where space is always at a premium. They had a large collection of the European masters, beginning with Byzantine artwork, all the way up to Fauvism. The guards there were super nice and knowledgable about the collection. Definitely a must-visit for any art enthusiast, as well as people who enjoy history and architecture.
author: Kimberly T.

description:
I'm never impressed by the museums San Francisco has to offer.  The collections at the Legion of Honor are small and none are very impressive.  I came here recently for the special Matisse collection, needless to say, that was a waste of time.  If you're a fan of paintings, you might enjoy this museum a little more than me. There's a nice collection of Rodin sculptures, which I enjoyed more. 
Tickets are usually $10, but being a Bank of America member, the first weekends of the month are free, so that's a plus.
author: Karen L.

description:
An undiscovered Gem.

I've heard about this place. Seen pictures, been given recommendations. But I finally got around to getting up here, and it was worth the trip!

Admission is $10 if you aren't a member (I'm not), and whilst it's not as extensive as the Louvre, you can easily spend a good couple of hours here exploring the Rodin, Monet and other artists and sculptures.

It was amazing to me to see how old a lot of the paintings were! How well they have restored them, and that you can get so close you could literally touch them. Not that you would of course...

A great way to pass the time, absorb some culture and admire the amazing view! 

Glad I came, and definitely a place I will recommend to people coming to visit.
author: Jemma B.

description:
The Legion of Honor truly is San Francisco's most beautiful museum. Built to commemorate Californian soldiers who died in World War I, the Legion of Honor is a beautiful Beaux-arts building located in San Francisco's Lincoln Park. While the palatial monument is a work of art itself, the museum displays an impressive collection of 4,000 years of ancient and European art. The museum is one of my "must sees if you are in the city and have any interest in art. The museum is located in an unforgettable setting overlooking the Bay and the GGB. At the very least you can enjoy the area surrounding of the museum including Lands End. 

The museum's collections include Rodin's Thinker, which sits in the museum's Court of Honor, European decorative arts and paintings, Ancient art, and one of the largest collections of prints and drawings in the country.

There is a good cafe and a very cool bookshop in the museum as well. 

There is ample parking in the surrounding area. 

I look forward to returning to the museum soon.
author: David S.

description: This museum was a gift from the French government to the people of San Francisco.  It is set in the beautiful area of the Golden Gate Park and the San Francisco Bay and the Golden Gate Bridge.  The natural beauty is unrivaled on earth.  You truly understand the will of God for how could there be such combination of natural and man made beauty without Him?  There is a Stradivarius violin that used to be played only once a year by a famous musician and listened to by the museum members.  That violin is currently on loan to the San Francisco Symphony...
author: Jim J.

description: Wonderful shows at this museum, but average amount of cars broken into in the parking lot, both in front and on the side of the museum, is 2 -3 per day (just ask the museum staff)!  People are watching when you put your valuables in your trunk and will smash your windows and steal them.  Take everything inside to the free coat check and leave it there!  The last three times I've been there, I've seen car windows that have been smashed and all valuables taken.
author: Rebecca A.

description:
BE WARNED!!!
Our car got broken into while visiting this beautiful museum.  Went inside to report and was told "nothing we can do about it.  Happens all the time" really????  How about putting a frickin' sign up reeling people that??  Or maybe one in the lobby telling a people to bring valuables in with them. Very poor customer service.
author: John F.

description: The Klimt exhibit at the Legion of Honor is a bust.  Klimt  has an expansive amount of material that should have been included in this exhibit. I was disappointed. The exhibit was chopped into several rooms and appeared not to have any continuity. The quality of the material included in the exhibit did not provide a satisfactory representation of this fine  artist's skills.  Save your money.  Buy and enjoy the Complete Paintings of Gustav Klimt's.  Better yet, fly to Vienna, Austria and visit the Belvedere museum.
author: Mark P.

description:
This was mine and my boyfriend's first time in an art museum. It was a good first choice because the location is gorgeous. It outlooks the Golden Gate Bridge and the city (San Francisco). Beautiful scenery. 

General admission is $10 for an Adult. For me, I paid $6 for the Student fee because I brought my student ID with me!

The courtyard has amazing columns surrounding it. Many people were taking photos there and there were two groups - one bridal and one debut/cotillion - having a photoshoot outside. 

There are two levels. The first level has a bunch of artwork ranging from paintings, sculptures, objects, etc. There is a good variety! The colors of the walls on the rooms add a nice touch. The ceilings of some rooms are opaque so the natural light shined through beautifully. The lower floor contains a few more artwork, a cafe, and a gift shop. There is also an exclusive showroom, but in order to get in you need to upgrade your admission ticket. 

In conclusion, it was a nice experience. My boyfriend and I were very excited to see Claude Monet's pieces. The staff is friendly. However, beware of kids crying while you look at the artwork, hahaha.
author: Dominique E.

description:
What's a vacation without visiting the local museum? Legion of Honor was one of my top choices because of the architecture and impressive paintings, sculptures and artifacts.

This museum's entrance is protected by a courtyard which is a work of art itself. Once inside, the adult entrance ($10) gives you the ability to view the works from the 14th century to the early 20th at your own pace. They do offer free admission on the first Tuesday of the month. 

One room which made my heart skip twice was the dedicated display of Auguste Rodin's sculptures. You can also see "The Thinker" in the court of honor.

Each hall had their highlights and was easy to navigate through. Another favorite for me was Claude Monet's "Water Lilies".

On the lower level, you have a museum treat where you can watch the staff restore the pieces behind a glass window. It was amazing how they carefully handled these priceless collection.

Unfortunately, the weather wasn't cooperating and the fog rolled in which gave the outside views zero visibility. This would give me another reason to visit.

Go ahead and take an afternoon to enjoy this remarkable museum in the heart of San Francisco.
author: Santi T.

description:
Nice little museum tucked way out in the northwest corner of San Francisco - it shares park space with the Lincoln Park golf course and pretty much overlooks the South Bay.  Lots of free parking close by...great views of the city and nearby Golden Gate Bridge. There are also a few walking/hiking trails outside the museum which reach all the way down to the waterfront.

The museum was built by and gifted to the city of San Francisco by the Spreckels family in the early 1920s. Since that family had an interest in Rodin's work, a large part of the museum is a permanent and extensive display of Rodin's sculptures. Other exhibitions rotate through the museum. When we visited, two Matisse exhibits were there - Matisse from the SFMOMA, and Matisse and the Artist Book. 

This was a delightful museum trip. Since it is a bit out of the way and pretty much accessible only by car, it was not too crowded on the Friday afternoon we were there. But this museum is worth the trip. Nice café and museum shop in the basement complement your visit. Do this one.
author: Rick B.

description:
People are always looking for hidden gems, the kinds of places locals know about because they're a little out of the way. The Legion of Honor just past Sea Cliff is that kind of spot. It's a beautiful museum with art, sculpture and archaeological treasures. Much less crowded than other museums, perhaps because it's all by itself in a residential neighborhood, or because it has no exhibits for children.

We shared a snack after wandering through the galleries. They have a light-filled cafeteria and a small retail shop on the lower level. Unexpectedly, we got a bonus as we were leaving:  A camera perfect,  panoramic view of the Golden Gate Bridge and the bay from the front lawn. Fortunately, we were there on a blue sky/sunny day. 

From the entry courtyard ringed with elegant columns and statues to the galleries, it was well worth the cab fare but note, this is not a museum geared toward young children. 

TIP: Parking is free, but limited along a steep and shady hill on the golf course side.
author: Lynn S.

description:
I always wanted to go to SFMOMA, but since it's closed for renovation, I wanted to check out other museums that the city has to offer during my last trip to SF. Legion of Honor stood out to me due to its great collection and its beautiful location.

The museum is located inside Lincoln Park, a beautiful place, an oasis in the city. If you drive, they have a free parking lot. We took public transportation, got on bus #38 till Geary Ave. w. 34th Ave.  From here you can walk through Lincoln Park to the museum (around 10 min. walk if you have the time and the weather is nice). We took the bus #18 that takes you right to the Legion of Honor's entrance (less than 5 min. ride through the park).

The actual building is beautiful, like a European palace. The location couldn't be better, it's right near the ocean, it has beautiful views of the Golden Gate Bridge and of the city. Give yourself some time to explore the grounds and take pictures. Rodin's "The Thinker" welcomes you in. 

The museum has 2 floors of various collections, mostly European painters (from Renaissance - El Greco, to French & Italian Baroque - De La Tour, Watteau, Dutch painters- Rembrandt, Rubens, to 19th and 20th centuries great: Monet, Goya, Cezanne, Renoir, Picasso) and the biggest collection of Rodin's sculptures outside Paris (at the Musee Rodin which is one of my favorite museums in the world). Besides Rodin's sculptures (some of his famous) you can see a few of his muse, Camille Claudel.

The collection is very impressive, so allow at least 2-3 hours to browse the galleries. 

They also host a small part of the SF MOMA's collection, they have a Matisse exhibit (not bad!) to check out.

$10 admission (w. the same ticket you can also visit the De Young museum in the same day). Hours- 9:30am-5:15 pm, Tuesdays through Sundays. We got in for free w. Bank of America debit cards (some museums are free 1st weekend of the month if you're a BA customer). First Tuesday of the month is free. Or you can get $2 off admission w. proof that you used public transportation.

I enjoyed so much visiting Legion Of Honor, it's one of my highlights of my trip. It has a wonderful collection, it's such a nice, elegant museum with beautiful surroundings. What more do you want?
author: Jo S.

description:
You have until May 15 to get on over to the Legion and see the Bonnard exhibit...and if you like impressionist art (Renior, Van Gogh, etc), bright hues or pattern in art, then I highly recommend you go. I didn't know much about the artist, but now I'm a fan. 

I'm always good for a nosh at the café too. I wish the Legion weren't such a PITA to get to from the East Bay.
author: Linda M.

description:
While it is smaller and farther away than the de Young or the Moma, this museum is far from being negligable! Located in Lincoln Park on Land's End, just the front entrance with the pillars and The Thinker make the drive up here all worth it from the start! When you enter, you'll see that prices are very affordable, allowing me to pay only $6 for being a student. It can even be free if you went to the de Young before, and vice versa.

 Then begins the real fun. You'll get lost through all the different exhibits, becoming positively overwhelmed as you admire all the classically gorgeous works of art. I highly recommend this museum, and be sure to explore around the outside area too and see the Holocaust Memorial and Mile Rock Beach. There are only two floors, but the amount of instillations crammed in this calm and clean space will make you think there's more! :)
author: Kyrie S.

description:
My friend and I checked out this place since it was right next to Lands End.

Ok my friend and I did not pay to enter the museum! So this review is coming from a person that just enjoyed Legion of Honor without any cost...

Legion of Honor has awesome architecture. The columns along with the glass structure in the front reminds of the Louvre in Paris. You can just sit in the open grass area outside and listen to music played by one of the locals. I love that there's a huge waterfall in the front... which makes me want to jump in... Also the place is situated alongside a golf course and Lands Ends so the museum has this nature appeal as well... Loved it! Yay! :)
author: Stella M.

description:
This has turned into my favorite bay area museum.  They do a great job of bringing in great exhibitions, the most recent fav is the Zorn (Swedish master) works.  The standard collection is nothing to sneeze at either with a fabulous Rodin collection.  The grounds are also beautiful, so after your awesome museum tour you can walk around outside or take the trail from the parking area to the side down to the beach to stretch your legs.  

One down side is that I find the docent tours to be a big don't unless you just want the little wall plaques to read to you.
author: Heather D.

description: Fabulous museum in a beautiful setting.   The special exhibits are fantastic, The 2015 Brooklyn Museum Costume Collection was especially memorable.  The Cafe is a nice spot for lunch, free parking.
author: Mr Kitty K.

description:
A truly hidden gem in the outer Richmond district.  I grew up not too far away from there as a kid and I'm kicking myself for not appreciating it enough - but seriously, I was little...museums aren't supposed to excite little kids anyways.  

Now that I'm grown up, I always make it a point to stop by this locale, to make up for taking it for granted as a kid.  Months ago, I came by after it had closed for the day.  I was disappointed that I didn't get in earlier, but I still enjoyed walking around the exterior, snapping pictures through the gate, and enjoying the foggy view of the bridge and the ocean from the observation points.  The empty lot allowed for some great snapshots.  

I recently came back about two weeks ago and was really excited to see the Impressionists' exhibit.  The gorgeous day and hubbub of the museum-goers was truly refreshing to see.  The only awful part was finding parking.  If you drive all the way down the hill, you have to deal with an awful line of cars trying to turn around at the dead end if they were unfortunate enough to not get a spot.  

Overall, the museum is gorgeous and the artwork is thoughtfully curated.  If you're on foot and have time to spare, the Legion of Honor is coincidentally along the Land's End trail, too!  So if you're hiking and checking out the museum on a gorgeous day, you are most assuredly in for a San Francisco treat along the hidden gem of Land's End.
author: Viva C.

description: The biggest draw for me to coming here are the amazing views from the lookouts.  It's located near Lands End so either before or after you visit the museum, you'll enjoy beautiful views on a clear day.  The museum itself, it's a European art museum that has paintings, sculptures, photography and special exhibits.  The best thing about it for me is its collection of Dutch and Belgian paintings.  It's not that large so it isn't overwhelming.  Admission is $10 which isn't bad.
author: Anthony G.

description: Beautiful Art Museum.  The art here is amazing.  My friends and I were planning to go hiking, but got lost and ended up here by accident.  My bad navigation skills ended up being a blessing in disguise.  I forgot which exhibit it was, but my favorite was the one with all of the nature art.  My love for adventure drives to me hike and explore a lot.  Those art pieces truly capture the the beauty of nature.  There are a lot of classical European artworks and other ancient arts.  The outside of the museum has columns that looks like resembles old Rome.  Also, there is a guy playing a guitar on the outside.  Everything about this museum just takes you back through time.  Walking through here is like taking a stroll through history.  Parking is free and gives you a scenic view of the ocean.  Also, there is a nice little cafe and gift shop here as well.  If you are visiting San Francisco, then Legion of Honor should definitely be on your to-do list.  Trust me, you won't regret it.
author: Dang L.

description: They charge 35/person for the Monet exhibit (plus fees I'm sure) and then you have to wait until a time slot opens up hours later. I was just at the Met in New York less than a week ago, the cost was half (and you can pay less if you want) and there is no waiting, and there are exhibits that include Renior, Picasso, Rembrandt, Can Goh...  and the staff are a lot friendlier and able to provide a lot of context and background about the exhibits. One admissions staff member here mentioned to me this pricing scheme was a ploy to hustle couples to opt into purchasing a membership for a small amount more. Well what this really does is keep young people out, I gtfo'd real quick, and I don't think I'll waste my time coming back.
author: Justin M.

description:
The Legion of Honor is the older and more traditional of the two structures (located in different parts of the City) that constitute the Fine Art Museums of San Francisco. Although the de Young in Golden Gate Park also has a lovely setting, the location of the Legion of Honor is particularly striking, and one should definitely allow time to walk the surrounding parkland and enjoy the stunning water views if at all possible. The building itself is a reduction of the neoclassical original in Paris, interest in which was spurred by an international exhibition in San Francisco planned just before WWI.
The art collection within consists of a small number of objects of so-called ancient art from the near east and Mediterranean civilizations, and a much broader overview of painting in Europe from the Renaissance through the 1900s, with a smattering of decorative arts usefully included as well. The range and quality of works displayed provide a good survey of the development of the western tradition in art, particularly given the limited holdings of this material on the west coast of the U.S. compared with the northeastern U.S.
The museum also regularly hosts both domestic and international traveling special exhibitions. There is a pleasant cafe which includes outdoor seating and a museum store. The building is accessible and it is reachable via public bus from downtown San Francisco, particularly if you alert the driver to your destination when you board. If you've come out to the Legion in the morning, it is also quite possible to continue your journey to the de Young via public transit and enjoy a full day of the fine arts in SF in two beautiful venues!
author: Edward M.

description:
A really nice museum but doesn't have the cache' that the DeYoung Museum has.  As we're members of the DeYoung, we get admission to this museum too.  Niecey and I came here to view the High Style Brooklyn Museum exhibit of designer dresses.  Some are just exquisitely made.  Hard to believe they were able to make some of the dresses in the 1800's and 1920's without the assistance of computers.  
We trotted thru the museum after the special exhibit and I remember some of the paintings from my youth when school field trips would take us to the museum for a visit.  

We are so lucky to have such a lovely museum in our city.
author: Ry T.

description: I have to admit, I have lived in the City for three years now, and until last weekend, I had never heard of this place.  I came here for a wedding and was quite impressed when I pulled up to the museum that was shrouded in the fog.  Karl (the fog) definitely heightened the mood and added an element of mystery to the evening.  The museum is a pretty good size and the artwork keeps your attention (as some museum's collections don't).  The Legion of Honor pays it's respects to the Louvre in Paris right in it's courtyard.  I can't wait to come back to this museum during the day and explore even more of the venue.
author: Josh S.

description:
What can I say that hasn't already been said?  This is a great museum, and recommend all to come for a visit!  We were able to check out the Mummy exhibit, which is so fascinating.  Saw real mummies with bodies intact!  

Artwork is stunning. Lots of famous artist's works displayed.   Museum wasn't even that crowded on a Sunday.  Parking was a lot easier than I imagined.  

Only minor complaint:  I wear a small backpack purse, but was told by staff I had to hold it and not wear it as a traditional backpack.  It was very uncomfortable to hold the purse for hours like that.  Recommend not carrying a purse at all in this museum!
author: Marie B.

description:
WOW. Amazing views around the museum - of the SF Bay & Golden Gate Bridge. Had a fantastic time walking/hiking along the trails & golf course next door. Couldn't get enough of the views there; it was so nice. Fresh air, gorgeous sights, lots of tourists, haha :)

Inside the museum, it was lively. Apparently on Sunday afternoons, they have organ playing and people sit in the atrium to listen to the organ/piano performance. The music resonated throughout the hallways and exhibits. It was so soothing to view the paintings and artwork while listening to dramatic music echoing through the museum. 

Given my friend was a member, she could bring her guest in for free, so I was in luck. I also found parking right outside the museum along the sidewalk. I think coming in the late Sunday afternoon helped too. ;) No wonder many weddings and engagement photos are taken here; it's just stunning. Next time, I want to visit the sister museum (De Young) in the heart of SF! I'm sure they are both just as grand.
author: Yonnie C.

description:
This is one of my all time favorite art museums.  

I love that I can see everything I want in 2-3 hours, beautiful architecture, parking is free (in SF!!), great special exhibits, and I cannot imagine more beautiful grounds with the most breathtaking views of SF skyline and GGB.
author: Julia C.

description:
Legion of Honor is the perfect place to spend a rainy day. My parents and I spent 3 hours browsing its many, many halls of renaissance and classical European art. This is NOT a place you go to look at modern art, because you will not find any here. Although you can tell that just by looking at the architecture of the building. 

You know that scene in Pride & Prejudice where Elizabeth is in sheer awe of Mr. Darcy's estate? That's exactly how I felt being here. This place is just majestic, down to every detail. 

There's a cafe and a great museum shop downstairs. The largest painting I've ever seen, called "The Russian Bride's Attire" is not to be missed. They also have a couple Degas, Monet, Manet and van Gough's as well.

Come and see this place, at least once. Your visiting family will love it too. Legion of Honor makes for a very nice high-brow activity.
author: K M.

description:
Tons of history here at the Legion of Honor.  Sculptures, paintings, and porcelain items are only some of the items here.  Take your time reading each item there and expand your knowledge.  The fee here is $10/Adult which isn't bad at all.  If you are a student it is only $6.  

Tip:  If you have a backpack or a bag it must be held by your side.  They won't let you carry it on your back probably because they don't want people accidentally knocking over items.
author: Brandon L.

description:
Now, I've been here twice. 

You may very well be awestruck by the scenery outside and the juxtaposition of the ancient looking building (replica of Palais de la Légion d'Honneur) before you even get to the entrance. Yes, bring your camera (and leave off the flash when you do enter the building.)

This museum is surrounded by beauty--a full view of the Golden Gate Bridge, especially on an unusually sunny but foggy day, a view of downtown SF and the Sutro Tower, beach and plenty of green grass and trees.  (Also adjacent to the Lincoln Park golf course, so you may very well find a few golf balls, too.)

Plenty of European art, and the Rodin pieces are especially lovely and captivating. You'll notice The Thinker right away, outside the entrance. The galleries are laid out in an U-shape with marked numbers for the gallery, and rooms are interlinked.  It starts with dark Goth and ends with light Impressionism on the main floor.

Downstairs, they do have a porcelain gallery as well, and the special exhibit is located there, too (which is an additional fee.) The porcelain gallery is beautiful, and thankfully, most pieces are safely inside a glass case. The museum shop and cafe are also on this level, along with the all important restrooms. 

First Tuesdays of the month are free for all, along with the de Young museum, so if you've got the time, take advantage.  

Parking = free, and most spots are 4-hour spots.  Public transit accessible.
author: Fannie S.

description:
This location is one of the best in SF. Drive up here on a sunny day for gorgeous golden gate and city views. It ranks on the must-see list in SF for me.

The museum itself is equally pretty. The courtyard in front is stately and impressive, and houses rodin's the thinker.

Free parking around the fountain in the front, or around to the right side if you're facing the museum.
author: Quyen V.

description:
What a breathtaking peaceful location just a few minutes away from the hustle and bustle of downtown.

Unfortunately when we went the museum was actually closed so this review is based on the grounds.

So well kept and just simple peaceful. Going down a small trail off to the side of the main parking area you have a panoramic view of the Pacific Ocean and the Golden Gate Bridge. 

There is also a Holocaust Memorial located across the street from the main building as well that was unexpected and extremely eye opening. 

I'm really glad I got to experience this beauty on a day it wasn't crowded. However, I would love to take a visit when the museum is open.
author: Andy S.

description:
Can you say spectacular?  My kids love art so we decided to hit this place up over Spring break.  Let's just put it this way, we would revisit this place in a heartbeat just to hang out on the grounds outside. Talk about blowing up your Instagram feed! First of all, the property is situated in a prime location (as it should be!) with AH-MAY-ZING views of the Golden Gate bridge on the left and the city on the right. There are also a couple of large, beautiful sculptures gracing the front lawns. The architecture of the building itself is quite photogenic on it's own, add the stunning views, a wonderful collection of fine art, a gourmet cafe, reasonable admission prices ($40 total for 3 of us to get in and that included the additional fee into the Bonnard exhibit) and the whole experience is a win-win.  

We thought the collection inside was lovely.  Rodin, Monet, Fra Angelico to Picasso - all kinds of European art and furniture too. We went during the exhibition of the "Portrait of a Lady with a Unicorn", (ca. 1505-1506), which is on loan to the US for the first time.  The painting was supposedly inspired by the Mona Lisa.  Very cool.  

I didn't know this until our last visit, but the museum was built to commemorate Californian soldiers who died in World War I. The parking can get tight so arrive early if you can or plan to park further down the hill and walk a little ways up to the museum.  Try to find a sunny clear day to visit so you can get the full impact of the scenic views.  Make sure your camera has lots of room for pics too!  This place is totally worth it, even if you don't love art.
author: Margie C.

description:
I thought the museum would be much bigger but the layout inside was nice. Each exhibit and gallery's art pieces were displayed beautifully. Very informative for those at least trying to add some culture to their lives.

Where the museum is located is pretty cool too. There's a trail on the side with a view of the Golden Gate Bridge. Their Holocaust Memorial, as a reminder of dark period of time in history, is subtle yet speaks for itself.

Looking forward to the de Young Museum next!
author: Nicole D.

description:
I've been to museums in parts of Europe and I have to say this is one of my favorites. I love how there isn't an overwhelming amount of art (paintings, sculpture, deco art). It allows you to focus on a few that you really enjoy. 

At first, I never heard of this place. It's tucked away past Clement St. in the Sunset and the drive there is accompanied by a golf course on your right. You stop at this structure supported by columns and not far from your periphery is the ocean. I think the placement of this museum was perfect. Although it doesn't get much sunshine, on the days that there are, I think that the light rays play off the building impeccably. I went on a cloudy Tuesday (first of the month) and it was free admission for the general public & $10-11 for the special exhibit, which at this time was a collection of costumes from the Brooklyn Museum. FYI, de Young & the Legion are both free on the first Tuesdays of the month. 

I love paintings so I was happy when I came across Monet's "Water Lilies" and a few small pieces by Van Gogh. I was also introduced to the main attraction, "the Russian Bride" and if you haven't seen it, it's definitely a feast for the eyes. It commands your attention when you walk into the room. The artist captures the emotions of the bride and the many others in the room with her. The docent told us it was an arranged marriage and a young bride, she was betrothed to a much older man. 

As for the experience, I was very glad there weren't many people at the time we went because it was sometimes my friend and I alone with the painting. I have to say I was bit annoyed by these two ladies who couldn't help but take photos in front of almost every major piece, which forced us to step away from truly admiring the painting's grand presence. We eventually came back, so it turned out to be okay. My friend and I also decided to take a tour at noon and the docent emphasized the different decorative art one would see in a place of wealth and excess. I loved this artwork pieced together by different types of stone-- alabaster, marble, etc. It depicted a vase of flowers. Just the workmanship alone was incredible. It must have taken the artists a very long time to piece together a medium-sized picture such as this. I also loved the room reconstructed from wooden panels taken from a Parisian hotel (considered an apartment). I definitely need to come back to look at this room again. It took my breath away and I can't imagine how long this project took to complete. 

Overall, I had such a delightful experience even though it was a free day and I expected there to be lots of people, but if you come in early enough, you can skip the crowds. I would highly recommend anyone who has a taste for fine European art to visit this museum!!!
author: Brittany D.

description:
My boyfriend and I went to this museum yesterday and had a great time! I love historical art and found so much to see here. It was a fascinating evening.  I saw old Victorian paintings, and ceramics.  There was detailed inlaid wood furniture and rooms with old wood carved paneling in them.  I found lots of reasons to take pictures.  At the end of our time in the museum, we were treated to a live pipe organ concert where the man played classical and baroque music.  Overall this was a very fun time and I hope we get the chance to come back to this museum again.

Pros:
-an amazing selection of paintings and antiques  (some replicas)
-pipe organ concerts every weekend 
-free but limited parking nearby

Cons:
-the gift shop items are kind of pricey
author: Irene S.

description:
Beautiful museum with so many works of art. Entering the museum courtyard is amazing as you're greeted by a huge statue and open area. 

We opted for the $10 general admission and still had plenty to see and do. Wish we would've got a guided tour but I was really expecting the museum's app to work but its a dud and didn't work very well at all. 
 
I still enjoyed the beautiful scenery and works. The staff was very helpful. Great weekend activity.
author: Danny V.

description:
One of the most beautiful places in San Francisco and looks like a mini-Louvre complete with a mini-glass pyramid in the middle of the courtyard.  

Parking can be a little difficult to find.  My favorite spots are the courtyard which makes you feel like you're hanging out somewhere in Europe.  The views of the Golden Gate Bridge from the lawn is also great.  One of their main attractions are the Rodins in the courtyard and in the main gallery on the first floor. 

Great way to spend a couple hours.
author: Hieu H.

description: Visit here during the weekend for a world class art museum + high quality guided tours + a free -better than a symphony-organ performance at 4. Carol Porter was our tour guide and she was fantastic! Extremely knowledgeable and genuinely interested in talking about paintings, her guided tour was amazing! Don't miss the organ performance at 4 pm by David Hegarty. We could only cover half the museum this time, we'll be back soon.
author: Nathan S.

description:
A grand, stately museum and West Bay treasure that's worth taking a slight detour from the beaten path. 

Inside, there are many gems worth absorbing at a leisurely pace:
* a beautiful late-15th century ceiling that once graced a Spanish palace
* Dutch and Flemish masterpieces from folks such as Rembrandt, Steen, and Rubens
* more Impressionist and post-Impressionist masterpieces from Pissarro, Seurat, Cezanne, and Monet
* a gorgeous 18th-century European porcelain collection
* and, of course, a grand indoor hall devoted to Rodin sculpture.

But wait, there's more! And it's all outside, 100% free: the panoramic, breathtaking views of the Golden Gate, Marin, and Pacific, plus the museum's highlight, Rodin's "Thinker" sculpture in the front courtyard. 

A great place to hunker down and contemplate, especially on a rainy day. And the magnificent scenery outside beckons in any weather. True beauty, inside and out.
author: Vincent L.

description: What I could see was beautiful, total Nazis about getting you out on time, like relentless back off dude Nazis.  Also front desk said it was free after 4:30, without mentioning that they close at 5, so disappointed with the lack of customer service here.
author: Teresa B.

description:
This is a very nice museum with classic works.
There is a nice collection of works by Auguste Rodin amd of course they have THE THINKER.
author: Funtime P.

description:
Humans are naturally curious by nature.

We're all reluctant to admit that we've taken a little peek behind someone else's medicine cabinet, wondered what was behind a closed bedroom door, or have even been interested in what other people keep as their prized possession.

Come on now. This is how shows like Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous and MTV Cribs were spawned! Let's face it. We're all a bunch of nosy people!

For commoners like us, we imagine and live vicariously through such extravagance.

I came to Legion of Honor with the intention of doing just that. I wanted to see and experience how royalty lived during Louis XIV's reign as well as Marie Antoinette. 

When you come across this museum, the European inspired architecture takes you to a period far before the modern era of high rises and industrial cities. 

Louis XIV was in an era of particular craftsmanship. Exquisitely detailed garments, tapestries, lush fabrics, intricately designed household items, and self emulated sculptures to appease Louis le Grand, himself. Being the oldest and longest of any ruling monarch of any major country in European history, approximately 72 years, Louis XIV was a man of undoubtedly refined taste. 

The Louvre, in which his treasures are securely kept, were brought here to Legion of Honor. This was the first and only time that these treasures have ever been shown in the United States and some of which have never even left France. 

With the exhibit being Royal Treasures from the Louvre - Louis XIV to Marie Antoinette, I knew this was going to be pretty spectacular. 

I went from case to case admiring some of the most beautifully handcrafted items I had ever seen. From woven tapestries hanging from the ceiling to the floor, diamond encrusted pendants with delicately painted portraits of the King, enameled gold mounted pitchers and illustriously painted dining wear all at the table for the King and his royal court to enjoy. 

The items continued on to snuff boxes adorned with precious jewels and also realistically carved busts of Louis XIV and his wife, Marie Antoinette. 

Speaking of Marie Antoinette, this was the highlight of the exhibit for me. A girly girl's dream! The Sèvres porcelain and silver as well as the collections of ornamented vases made of agate and other hardstones were diviiiiiine dahling. Items belonging to his mistresses Madame de Pompadour and Madame du Barry were also showcased. 

This visit was such a treat and most memorable. A wonderful viewing of the royal life in past history.

I highly recommend for anyone with a strong curiosity for the arts of former centuries to visit Legion of Honor! 

Champagne wishes and caviar dreams. 

À la prochaine
author: Ann S.

description:
I am totally not a museum person, but this place i really pretty. From what I went through, this place is pretty big as well, but I didn't have the patience to go through every painting/sculpture. The outside of the museum is an art piece in self. When you go inside, there are several rooms with different exhibits. A lot of it is sculpture and paintings. Occasionally, they will have a special event that you can pay extra for. If you like more historical things, this could be the museum for you. 

Overall, I felt that this is a beautiful museum, though it's not really my taste of art.

Protip: I took public transportation and saved $2
author: Sophia Y.

description:
"Intimate Impressionism"

I love food. I love sports. I love traveling. Those three items I usually write reviews on Yelp. However, as stated on my profile, I also love art. (I can't be a meathead all the time.) My interest in art stated in college when I took an art history course just to meet women. There were some good looking women in my art history class. However when it came to decide a major the only one that interests me was art history. (Little did I realize that major at UC Berkeley is one of the most intense majors as the art history major is considered one of the top majors in the country along with NYU and Columbia).

Of all the art forms Impressionism is my favorite due to the visible brushstrokes, interplay of light, and informal subject matter.  About three years ago I went to the de Young Museum for the 2-part Musee d'Orsay Exhibition that exhibited the largest collections of Impressionism paintings in the world. When the opportunity of another Impressionism exhibition would be in San Francisco I couldn't pass it up.

I came here yesterday to see the Intimate Impressionism Exhibition. The collection in this exhibition is about one-fourth less than the overwhelming Musee d'Orsay collections that were displayed at the de Young. As a compliment to this exhibition I purchased an audio tour that provided me insights of specific paintings in the exhibition. From painting to painting your get a glimpse of history how Impressionism progressed. Since the collections on this exhibition weren't abundant as the Musee d'Orsay Exhibitions it took me about an hour and a half to analyze through all the paintings. This exhibition showed a small sample of works by Degas, Renoir, Manet, Monet, Pissarro, van Gogh, and other artists. You can see how each artist interprets its own interplay of light on the subject matter. Two paintings that stood out for me at this exhibition were Vincent van Gogh's "Flower Beds in Holland" and Antoine Vollon's "Mound of Butter". For the painting by van Gogh you can how the bright colors of the flower beds contrasted with murky background. On the painting by Vollon he uses the Impressionism technique of visible brushstrokes to capture the realism of butter; the painting looks like an actual butter. For those who inspiring to be painters instead of trying to be the next Picasso as a starting point observe this painting by Vollon to understand the basics of painting.

Even though I enjoyed this exhibition I couldn't give it a perfect 5-star rating as the 2-part Musee d'Orsay Exhibitions at the de Young were the best exhibition I ever seen due to the abundance of work displayed. However if you don't know anything about art and want a quick introduction of Impressionism I recommend checking the Intimate Impressionism Exhibition at the Legion of Honor.
author: Gerald R.

description: One of the best museums I have ever been to. Getting to know more about Impressionism and almost each of the pairings and statues is delicate and carefully preserved. Friendly staff and feel sorry for not catching up with one guide tour. Come early and you have more choices choosing tours. Parking are easy and you'll find the surroundings beautiful and breathtaking! Of course, go there on a sunny day! Nice for wedding photos, too.
author: Wei Z.

description:
Small but with great rooms and a few famous works.  View outside is scenic of the ocean.  

Lovely to have cappuccino under olive trees in the museum cafe.
author: Niniane W.

description:
Wonderful surprise 
Another wonderful surprise at the top of another wonderful hill if SF 
unexpected as you turn into the driveway & the Roman columns jump out at you ..flanked by two bronze horsemen . 
So unexpected to see such a large museum on inside!!! Loved the Monet , Renior .. All the displays .. Dutch & Russian paintings .
They have a cafe ( we had already ate ), next time we will eat there .
author: Debra S.

description: Great little museum within walking distance of Lands End (you really need to hike down to the beach for a great view of the Golden Gate Bridge and bay!).  The Degas with Hats exhibit going on right now is so much more than I'd hoped for!  I joined as a member which includes free admission to Legion of Honor and DeYoung museum in Golden Gate Park.  Between the two of them there's something for everyone!  This one has a good collection of Rodin sculptures and a cute little cafe.  For the price of admission you can also head over to the DeYoung, if only for late Fridays and amazing views from the tower!
author: Jenn T.

description: It's an art museum, so of course it's going to be beautiful! :) that being said, all of the staff was SO friendly except for the admissions woman (the first one you encounter upon coming in.) She had an incredibly short attitude with me and my friend, and it dampened the whole experience. My friend was still talking about how intimidating this woman was by the end of the day, and I'd never been yelled at for reserving a ticket online before. But the outgoingness and genuine conversation from the rest of the staff, such as the greeter and the store workers, made up for the woman's behavior. A security guard even offered to take a picture for my friend if she was trying to take a selfie (she wasn't, but it was so nice of him to be considerate)! The display rooms are pretty large, and each explanatory sign and frame was in excellent upkeep and matched the interior color scheme. The paintings are arranged by time, and it was a pleasant surprise to even encounter two real mummies here! The commentary on each painting demonstrated real introspection and interesting historical details/context. Plus, it offers an expansive parking lot that leads to a beautiful plaza, lawn, fountain, statue, and view of the Golden Gate Bridge out front! I can't wait to visit here again!
author: Aly G.

description: What a beautiful place both inside and out. It was so close to the Golden Gate bridge that we barely paid anything for transpo. This place has a magnificent view of the Lincoln Park, the golf course and the surrounding water. Every single corner had a picturesque view and a story. We couldn't stop taking photos. There was ample parking. Restrooms were clean. They have a cafe for a quick fix. Entrance is affordable and they have discounts for locals and students. The staff was so nice and helpful. So many displays to check out, I had a great time. Very informative and enjoyable experience. Will definitely visit this place again in my next chance to go to SFO.
author: Liz G.

description:
Beautiful place to visit!!! Boyfriend and I checked this place out before we started our hike to Lands End trail. 

We didn't go all the way inside but we checked the area with the pillars and statues. We didn't want to run out of time! We will definitely be back soon to check the inside as well as the cafe. There is a charge to go in of course! You can also be a member :)
author: Abigael M.

description: Not accessible to young families. Finally got a moment to get to the Monet Exhibit that I was looking forward to for months. Arrived to learn that no strollers are allowed in key exhibits. IMPOSSIBLE to listen to the headset with a young child in your arms - ripping off my ears, unplugging it, hitting the buttons. Canceling my membership until daughter is at least 10 since I have a membership to Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco specifically for these exhibits. Worst experience!
author: Amy B.

description:
This place is magical. The combination of the location, the architecture, and the views of the city alone is breathtaking and that's before you've even set foot inside.

I have a deep and abiding love for Impressionism and also for Auguste Rodin's sculptures so this is my happy place. I could spend many hours here and not get my fill. Easily one of my favorite places in the city.
author: Mariel G.

description:
Taking a full benefit of the membership of the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, I visit Legion of Honor after my visit to de Young this week. This museum houses all artworks from Europe, paintings, sculptures, terracotta and porcelains,  ancient furniture and decorations, plus a pipe organ performance on weekends. I spent almost 7 hours on my first time visit. 

The museum's cafeteria serves dumplings made of local tofu and vegetables. Have sit and sip of coffee before joining a free docent tour. 

Parking spots are plentiful.
author: Phil Y.

description: You can't say a bad word against classical antiquity. It's beauty is timeless and enduring. At first sight, I could appreciate the sublime views across the bay. Inside, the painting is what kept me going. There are some great works of Historical significance inside. Rubens, Rembrandt, Bouguereau, just to name a few.
author: Michael W.

description: Such a great place to visit in SF! After all the visits I've done to this city I finally visited this place! Will def be back
author: Eva O.

description: Beautiful place and beautiful art works they have. I enjoy all art work they have, and they have special collections every season.
author: Dhwani T.

description:
European Art with a Great View of the Golden Gate Bridge

The Legion of Honor offers great European paintings and sculpture in a pleasant setting.  The museum features works from David, Manet, Degas, Renoir, Monet, Van Gogh, Cézanne and others.  Adding to the paintings, numerous sculptures by Rodin round out the permanent collection.  Special exhibits are also on view.

After spending time inside with the art, enjoy the natural beauty of the museum grounds.

Do not miss the Holocaust Memorial outside near the entrance.  The image sticks with me:  a lone survivor presses against a cruel barbed wire fence, separating him from the Pacific Ocean.  On one side of the fence, the Golden Gate Bridge.  On the other side, dead bodies strewn on the ground.

The Legion of Honor Café and Museum Store are located on the lower floor.

The Legion of Honor is open Tuesday through Sunday, 9:30 AM to 5:15 PM, and closed on Mondays.  Entrance to the permanent collection is $10.00 per person.  The ticket includes same day general admission access to the nearby de Young Museum.
author: David S.

description:
(Long overdue review):  We visited the museum on September 14, after not having been there for more than 27 years.  The physical setting in Lincoln Park is lovely - including the views - and we enjoyed wandering around the adjacent grounds (there are some beautiful sculptures near the museum's entrance).  Our favorite part of the museum was the European Decorative Art & Sculpture collection.

Note that admission to this museum also includes admission to the de Young Museum.  Also; if you go there on a weekend (we went there on a Saturday), you might want to arrive early.  Even though we arrived right around the time the museum opened, the (huge) parking area was nearly full.
author: Susan L.

description:
The Intimate Impressionism special exhibition hails from Washington DC. The deep blue walls really brought out the paintings with sharp contrast. The paintings are definitely by famous impressionists from Renoir, Manet, Monet to Cezanne... but most of the paintings are smaller in sizes, and don't expect to see any blockbuster paintings here. Plenty to admire, but generally, the paintings are less expressive (don't see a whole lot of paint, some paintings are smooth, and some felt like painting sketches). There were definitely a handful of noteworthy pieces, though small in size. 

The tours are self guided with each open room usually dwells on one specific painter, you can start by reading his biography or a background plaque and then starts to view the paintings in order, along the wall. It isn't always obvious where to start. Generally clean, easy tour, and a small collection.

Tickets too expensive? La Boulange cafe orders a coupon to get 20% - it's an impressionist post card
author: Dilys S.

description:
Im quite biased in the fact that European art doesn't excite as much as modern or non European art. This place has great stuff to offer, but I wasn't thrilled.This place can be blown through pretty easily, or easily skipped, compared to what else is offered in town.

If you are like me and don't get too excited over neo classical sculptures or rococo art, then you can skip here.
author: Gill S.

description:
Rodin for days. 

But that's not why this museum is amazing. Everything starting from the grounds and ocean views are Instagram #PicOfTheDay :P

You can spend hours and hours in this world class museum and not get bored. They have a good rotation of exhibitions and their permanent collection of mostly European art (everything from medieval iconography to Dutch masters to more and more and more) is a real walk through art history.

Bonus points are the employees (docents, guards, even the gift shop clerks) seem to all love their jobs and are approachable.

I feel really lucky to have access to this amazing space.

First Tuesday of the month is freeeeee!
author: Czarina B.

description: It has a nice collection. This is definitely not a modern art museum. It's more classical, antiquity, portraiture, and such. Saw Rodin, Monet, Van Gogh, Manet, Renoir, etc. Go here on the first Tuesday of the month for free. Check out their exhibitions that you pay extra for. Nice building and nice views of SF. Nice to visit once in a while or if you are a tourist.
author: Denise C.

description: Came by here with my wife. I wasn't that interested in most of what they had in the building. The building itself and the grounds were really cool. I was also sick so I wasn't that into being in an art museum. I was expecting more here, there were some nice impressionist paintings.
author: Jonah K.

description: A lot of photo ops. Nearby is a golf course, a hiking trail, view of the Golden Gate Bridge, a waterfall, and if you're there at the right day and the right time you might even see me there flexing my muscles.
author: Gemini M.

description:
The location of this place is great! It's so peaceful and quiet compared to the rest of the city. There's also an entrance to the amazing Lands End Trail right next to the museum, which I totally recommend checking out after you visit the Legion of Honor!

There's a very small parking lot right out in front of the museum. The day I went, I got there pretty early (close to the time the museum opened), so I was able to snag a spot. I believe it's free parking for 4 hours. I think the architecture on the outside is so beautiful. The giant fountain, the lions, the tall pillars look so regal and are very reminiscent of old Greek architecture. It's no surprise to see why people are having little photoshoots outside!

The architecture on the inside is also quite nice. It kind of reminds me a lot of the National Gallery in London, but on a MUCH smaller scale. I recall one room here with a really ornate ceiling that was beautiful! I enjoyed the collections of art in this museum. It's all very fine art, which I don't really know much about, but I enjoyed looking at them. Again, the museum is quite small and you can probably get through it in an hour.

With a ticket from the Legion of Honor, you can also get into the deYoung that same day! I actually prefer the Legion of Honor, though, despite how much smaller it is. I felt like I had a much more simple, quiet experience here that is better for enjoying art compared to the deYoung. But I totally recommend visiting both if you have the time as they each have very different, but good things to offer!
author: Karen T.

description:
This review is for Legion of Honor as a wedding reception venue. We held our black tie reception here last year and it was truly a magical event space. We rented out the full museum to accommodate ~550 guests, which worked well for that crowd size. A couple of key things to keep in mind when planning an event here:

- The doors to the museum close at 5pm. If your event starts at 6pm or 7pm, this leaves very limited time for vendor setup. I would recommend not starting your event until 7:30pm and giving vendors a setup goal of 7pm. We made the mistake of planning these times too close together and several early arrival guests ended up waiting outside in the cold :(

- The museum requires little additional floral decor, given the existing beauty of the architecture, which is a plus. Your biggest decor expense will likely be lighting, particularly if you want to light the outside columns leading into the museum. 

- Clarify with your caterer when food will be served. I forgot to ask, assuming it would be when the doors opened at 7pm, and the food was not served until 8:30pm given the limited set up time window. We had people drinking for about 1.5 hours without food, which is not a good combination. Tell your guests to eat something in advance or make sure to have some appetizers that are easier to serve earlier in the evening.

- There is quite a bit of price variation in the vendors on the museum's preferred vendor list. I recommend requesting multiple quotes to find the ones that are right for your budget before deciding. 

- Expect to pay several hundred dollars in event insurance specific to a museum.

- Consider hiring the museum organist for party music. We did this for a portion of the evening and it was a really special addition to the night. He is very flexible and has a wide range of repertoire styles.

- Consider hiring a valet service for a large event. We had 100 guest arrive in their own cars, and in black tie attire it's a bit far to walk from the parking lot to the entrance, especially in winter! We worked with CA Parking and they did a great job.
author: Aleta C.

description:
I came here because it was the last weekend of the year for free entrance into the museum with my BOFA card. If you dont have a card, you can pay $10 for general admission for a somewhat small exhibit. I thought since it was free, I might as well experience this even though I am not an artsy smartsy person. The only painters I recognized were Picasso and Monet. That was the highlight of my trip because I remember in Titanic, Jack mentioned the Lily painting and how the vibrant colors blended together. It was the last painting I viewed and it definitely lived up to the hype. The painting is absolutely beautiful and I tried to understand the deepness of the painting by reading the description. Haha I just liked reliving the Titanic scene in my head. Only one floor is accessible for general admission and it took an hour or so for a quick browse. It is free so I couldnt really complain but I liked deYoung better because there was more of a variety of art like sculptures and paintings and historical references. I noticed a religious theme in the different showroom.

There is actually a small free parking lot right in front of the museum but if that runs out, there is a smaller free parking lot at the entrance from the street which is about .4 miles away. I parked on the street on Saturday around 11am because I thought closer parking cost money but as I walked closer, I noticed the different parking lots. Try to get as close to the museum as possible.


**TIPS**
1) I am not sure how long free admission will last but this weekend may be your last chance with your BOFA card. When I went to deYoung, my friend was able to download the BOFA app and got free admission, so maybe they will let you here. If not, bring a check as proof.
2) Parking lots along the way are free but limited.
3) Enjoy!
author: Amy H.

description:
This is a fairly small museum with a nice collections that showcases a variety of European styles from the Middle Ages to Rodin and the impressionists. 

Except for the Rodin collections, the others are not very extensive. They showcase a nice collection of characteristic pieces--paintings, furniture, and china. The design of the building is beautiful and worth a visit for its own sake. The museum has breathtaking views. 

Parking is free, if you can find a space. Student tickets were just $6.
author: M B.

description:
Sis and I enjoyed the *Impressionist on the Water* show very much.  

We went on a soggy Saturday when they opened...(so no world class views ;-( 
It was so worth the early wake up!! Not crowded, and easy to see these canvases. One really does need to move out a bit with Impressionism.

We had a wonderful time!

Hit both gift shops, and the fixed collections, it was fun to see what resonated with us.....we really have very similar tastes.

Lunch in the cafe was great, and we *floated* home in the early afternoon.

My favorite Bay Area art venue did not fail!!
author: Katherine F.

description:
