Finally able to visit the Legion of Honor. It's not the largest museum, less than a half day affair, with numerous rooms of art, with multiple rooms bunched into same themes. LOTS of religiously themes works of art, which, I don't know about you, but I'm just tired of. It's essentially like my views on Egyptian exhibits whenever I'm at a museum... skip. Not saying the art is profound or well made, but when you're looking at the millionth rendition of Mary and Jesus, you start wondering if you're at an amateur hour during The Renaissance where everyone's jumping on the latest craze.

The artwork here is extremely classic, even with a porcelain collection on the lower floor. Very Eurocentric, which some 'Asian' works bought by Europeans... or when looking at the porcelain works on the first floor, they explain some background how Europeans wanted to copy these works to increase their collections more easily. Cuz... money.

The special exhibit during our visit was titled 'High Style: The Brooklyn Museum Costume Collection'. Not really for me, maybe because I'm not in the scene. A lot of interesting fashion, some really eccentric, but some very elegant.

In a way, I feel like I'm committing heresy with my 3 star review. The place is nice and elegant, but I didn't find things extraordinary or something to drool over. I feel it's very difficult to find exhibits going on that you are interested in.

Truth be told, I really enjoyed walking around outside, taking some of the trails down to the coast... but then again, that doesn't pertain to the Legion of Honor itself.

To each his own.
author: Kevin J.

description: I visited the Legion of Honor for the first time and I think it's def worth a visit if you're in the Golden Gate Park area.  We drove up to the Los Lobos hiking trail and hiked for about 15-20 min to the Legion of Honor Museum.  The trail is right by the water with great views of the Golden Gate Bridge. The Museum was currently under construction but Rodin's Thinker statue was prominently out in front.  Inside, the museum houses a good number of French art with over 80 statues of Rodin's works.  I found out that the Legion of Honor houses the most number of Rodin's works - second to the Rodin museum in France. Also, a good tip to know is that a general admission fee ($10 for adult and $6 for students with ID) also includes admission to the de Young museum which is right in the heart of Golden Gate Park.
author: Lizzy P.

description:
If you are coming from Richmond take Bart, get off Embarcadero or Montgomery then take the muni line M get off on Stonestown shopping mall center hope on the 18 it will take you right in front of the Legion of Honor.

I came around 10:30 and it wasn't busy. My first time at an Art museum and I must say it was very interesting. The building is self is so awesome reminded me of Rome with the big columns. They are remodeling so there is construction going on and noises. 

The paintings are beautiful and it's neat how you can be close up and see the brush strokes and paint. It's nice and spacious you can just stand or sit and look at the artwork for server all mins and hours if you wanted to. 

I came here for my art history class and I'm really glad to have gone. If anyone is touring or live in San Fransisco totally check this place out
author: Jennifer T.

description:
The museum itself is beautiful. The exhibits weren't my favorite kind of art, but I still found myself exploring everything. 

The only sad part (for me) was that there was a wedding going on, so the beautiful courtyard was closed. 

This is a great addition to a trip to the Sutro Baths.
author: Ryan H.

description:
I figured I would give this place a review since I erroneously assumed that it would have very few reviews. I was wrong but, oh well, here goes anyway. 

First of all, MINI-LOUVRE as you walk into the courtyard?! Hell yeah. If the marble columns, "Honneur et Patrie" sign, and bronze statues of dead white men didn't bring me straight to Paris, the miniature glass pyramid certainly did. 

But we didn't see the actual museum. We were there to see a chamber music performance by the SF Symphony in the Florence Gould Theater. As soon as I walked into the 200-person theater: INSTANTLY BACK TO FRANCE AGAIN. I couldn't stop staring at the colorful lush frescoes on the ceiling when I was supposed to be staring at the world-famous violinist playing his multi-thousand-dollar instrument from the 17th century. 

The Legion of Honor gave us a great experience, and, much to their delight, we will likely be repeat customers--we want to go back and see the museum itself now. The Legion is a delightfully beautiful way to take an escape from the States and enter Europe for an afternoon.

So why only 4 stars? THE PARKING COULD NOT HAVE BEEN WORSE. I understand that this is not their fault, but it caused us great frustration and wasted half an hour. We looped around the front roundabout and the side aisle 3-4 times each before throwing our hands up in sheer frustration and driving down past Fulton to park near Balboa. It was only about a 10-minute walk to the Legion from our parking spot, but we wished that there was adequate parking at the Legion to accommodate both museum patrons and chamber music performance-goers. 

Other than that, our day was absolutely lovely, thanks to the Legion and its collaboration with SF Symphony, with due gratitude to Mozart and Franck as well. :)
author: Rebecca M.

description:
Wow! Our trip to the Legion of Honor wasn't even planned. We had planned to go hiking at Lands End and were doing so when hunger struck and we found a trail that led to a golf course, which had a paved road that led up to the entrance area of the Legion of Honor. I had initially noticed a memorial piece at the Holocuast Memorial which stood out because it was of a man holding onto a barbed wire fence. Then looking around we found that we had stumbled across a museum. 

Since we had ditched Lands End (which was amazing by the way) to get food, it worked out perfect that we paid admission to the museum and they had a cafe located downstairs that we ate at prior to browsing the rest of the museum. I'm so glad that they did have a cafe because we spent 4-5 hours browsing the museum and even then, we could have spent more time there. 

The museum itself is huge with sculptures outside and on the inside it is a maze of amazing pieces of art from different periods on multiple levels. Most of the work is on the ground level, but they have a theatre located downstairs as well as the cafe and a place to check in bags since they don't want you carrying any backpacks while walking through the museum. I'm glad that we ended up here and would recommend that you check it out if your in the SF area. When you pay admission, they say it is good for their sister museum, but I can't imagine doing two museums in one day and being able to take it all in and truly appreciate all that it has to offer.
author: Nathan G.

description: I love this museum.  What  can I add that hasn't already been said?  Well, I highly recommend you read the book "Big Alma" and learn all about Alma Spreckels and how she built and donated the LoH to the city of San Francisco.
author: Chloe M.

description: NOT "FREE" 1st Tuesday of the month.  While admission to the museum is free, the Monet exhibit (which is probably why you are going) is still $35.  IMHO, they should not advertise this...it's misleading and a bait and switch.
author: Janet R.

description:
Did the highlights tour with docent Michelle.  She's probably one of the BEST docents I've met.  Her tour was so well given, and I was able capture and absorb all the material she gave in her half hour tour.
If you come visit, I highly recommend seeking out a docent tour done by her.

Another tour worth doing in the Rodin sculpture tour.  They have a good collection, and it's a find and silly thing to take pictures with them and try to imitate their poses.  Much harder than it looks! =P

The most famous thinker statue is outside but it was SOOO disappointing that they blocked it all off for a special event.  They should notate that on the website.  Some people come visit specifically for that....

Parking here is ironically easy and the spots are so spaciously marked. It's beautiful to walk around afterwards. 

There's a discount if you take MUNI or if you buy online.  Also, buying a ticket here comes with free admission to De Young which is a HUGE value.

Everyone who works here is pleasant and genuinely nice.  Some of the patrons however aren't.  There were a group of ladies who were so mad that I was taking photos. I was not using flash, and my auto focus light which comes on for a split second was ruining their experience there.  They were proud members and I applaud them for this.  Since photography IS allowed, I recommend the museum to provide sunglasses to these patron members who can't bear the brief orange auto focus light. Thank you.
author: David W.

description:
This is a great museum.  The building itself is a marvel.  Most works are from Western artists from the medieval period to the 18th Century.  Great examples of Rodin, Monet, and artifacts from the Ancient Egyptians to the 1800's.  

Parking was a little hard to find but its free.  I would suggest taxing or busing to the location next time to avoid the line of cars.  Its located next to the Holocaust Memorial and located near the coast with Lands End.  When we were outside the front gates at the beginning, there were no less than 5 couples doing their quinceanera, wedding, engagement shots there.  When we left, the number never went down.

The price is little on the high side even on discount.  $19 for the student ticket including the Intimate Impressionism special exhibit.  Luckily, most of us are BofA customers and we went on the Free Museum weekend.  The museum main hall was packed!  I've never seen a museum with so many people in such a small space.  We just got unlucky and a children dance performance ended and a organ recital was just beginning.  Very loud with the children and people coming in and out at the same time.
author: Jeff C.

description:
I'm not an art connoisseur by any means but I do enjoy walking through fine art museums.  

Heads up - Bank of America debit and credit card holders can enjoy free general admission the first weekend of each month to many fine art museums nationwide including the Legion of Honor.  Per cardholder.  

It doesn't include any special exhibits. 

Parking is available.  More times than not we have to park alongside the adjacent golf course and walk up the hill.  

My fave are the Monets in one of the permanent art galleries.
author: Shirley N.

description:
Some of the best views in the city are from the front steps of the Legion of Honor. Go early and parking won't be a problem. The interior is strangely laid out but enjoyable to walk through. I found their pottery to be especially beautiful. They have a good collection of Rodin sculptures. 

Be sure to check out the Holucaust Memorial to the left of the fountain. Take time to enjoy the view.

TIP: If you purchase a ticket for a special exhibit online, your general admission is already included.
author: Tara H.

description:
I had a school project that required me to visit the Palace of the Legion of Honor Museum and at first I wasn't really excited but when I finally arrived, the stunning Palace overlooking the horizon told me otherwise. 

--------------------------------------------- 

[Location]

This is said to be one of the most beautiful museum in the country with respect to the location and wow... you'll have to see it to believe it! If you're a photo buff, bring your camera because within walking distances is a little road leading to amazing views of the Golden Gate Bridge, Marin Headlands in the distance, and also the Holocaust Memorial site which is just as emotionally moving as its name. If you're hungry during your tour inside the museum, you can also find the museum's Cafe which offers decent food for brunch and lunch. Did I mention two awesome gift shops?! One book store and one with art jewelry and replica art prints.

[Decor/ Art]

The permanent collection for this museum includes artwork from the Ancient, Medieval, Renaissance, Baroque, and even early Modern time periods. For a guy who wasn't really into art, I loved it! 

Some of my favorite works at this museum is-

The Russian Bride's Attire: Located in gallery #17. You can't miss this painting, it's huge! It's a Russian history painting about the Tsar's choosing of a wife among the group of nobles. You can notice how the light from outside of the window illuminates the room, especially the bride who's at the center. You can also see the sadness in her face as she look below to her (sister?). This painting is absolutely beautiful, truly a works of art.

In the same room as The Russian Bride's Attire you'll find the painting, The Broken Pitcher. It's of a young pretty peasant girl sitting beside a drinking well and below her next to her feet is a broken pitcher. The broken pitcher is supposed to be a sexual symbol, maybe lost innocence or a broken heart. I'm kind of unsure lol but it does kind of makes you think for a second. That's the point of art right?!

[Price]

Admissions: $10, with a Student ID: $6

[Tip]

First Tuesday of the Month is FREE. Also, Bank of America has a promotion for every first weekend of the month. I went on Saturday (5/4) and it was free but please double check that online to see if the promotion is still going on.

Also, no flash photography, it can damage the painting!

------------------------------------------------

Overall, this museum was stunning, even for me! I highly recommend giving yourself one free day to visit this museum. You won't be disappointed!
author: Daniel N.

description:
What a beautiful museum! Of all the years that I've lived in the Bay Area, this was finally the first time that I made it into the Legion of Honor. The architecture of the building, the surroundings, the exhibits, all contribute to what it has to offer.

I happened to go on the first Saturday of the month. At least for this year (or maybe it was just this month), it was a free admission day, if you are a Bank of America debit/credit card holder. *yay for freebies* Despite being a free day, it was not crowded at all. I could walk through each gallery at a leisurely pace and without having to rub elbows with the other visitors.

I would have to say that I'm not entirely a huge fan of fine art; however, there are certain classical eras that I do enjoy.  The Legion of Honor has a great variety of work, so there's bound to be something for everyone to enjoy.

If you plan to stop and have a bite to eat or drink, the cafe is well situated, so on a beautiful day, it will be nice to sit out in their patio to soak in the weather, remain at peace, before walking back into the building.

Great place to go on a leisurely afternoon! And if you have time, I would even recommending starting the day/afternoon at Lands End, then walking to the Legion of Honor and back. It's a short, beautiful walk!
author: Audrey C.

description:
This is my favorite museum in the city (especially now that MOMA is closed until 2016). The art collections are beautiful, historic, and quite famous. I have an art history minor and geek out every time I come here.

It's free the first Tuesday of every month!

Also, pack a picnic and eat in the grass with great views of the museum and GG Bridge.
author: Ashley E.

description:
This is not a review of the Legion of Honor. It's not even a review of the cafe.

It's a review of the Legion of Honor Cafe's BLT sandwich as experienced on a single day.

After hiking the nearby trails (accessed from the southish end of the parking lot on the water side), I wandered in with my son. Thought I'd bribe him with a snack so I could dash through the Brooklyn Museum Costume Collection (member here: I'll see any exhibit, any time). After viewing the menu and the outrageous prices, we decided to split the BLT. Added on avocado. The bill? $18.75. Not even kidding. This is a *museum cafe* people! Unbelievable.

Then the sandwich arrived--unassuming, underwhelming, sizable but not huge, standard 'mixed greens' salad on the plate. We each took a bite and stopped talking. Three or four or five slices of crisp, melt-in-your-mouth bacon. Fatty salty perfection. Tomatoes roasted until they were rich and flavorful, the juice releasing and soaking the greens when I bit down. Lightly dressed leaves--is that a hint of lemon?--and creamy, succulent avocado. Lightly toasted bread holding it all together. Every bite sublime. Absolutely obscene. One of the best sandwiches I ever ate. Ever.

We ate silently, slowly. My son nodded with each bite. 

The exhibition was pretty good, too.
author: M. C.

description:
Located in Lincoln Park, one of the most scenic areas in San Francisco. The Legion of Honor is a musuem filled with art from all over the world.  I got to see two Rembrandts, one upstairs and one down.  You can take photos upstairs but not down so I was able to get some good shots.  There are sculptures and porcelain, clay pots, etc.  We spent about 1.5 hours until it closed.  I would have loved to spend more time but that's what happens when you get there late like we did.

Try and go before the Mosaic leaves (I think in August) and goes back to Israel where it was recently discovered and unearthed during a road widening project.  It's awesome to have it before you and there is a short video showing how they removed it from the ground and preserved it.  

Don't forget to check out the overlook of the golf course and stop by the Holocaust Memorial.  The Memorial is located outside next to the lookout.  It's amazing that there were so many death camps.  You hear of Auchwitz but there were many, many more and they're inscripted on the memorial.  It's a sad but gentle reminder of what horror the Jews endured during a tragic time in history.  

We always drive down the park to see the spectacular view of the GG Bridge while we're at Lincoln Park.  I love to sit on a bench (there are quite a few) and enjoy it all, especially on a sunny day.
author: Ruthie V.

description:
I was truly impressed with this museum.  It's just simply breathtaking inside and out.

First of all, regarding parking:  There is limited parking in the museum parking lot, and if that's full (most likely it might be) you can park at a lot down the road from the museum OR on the street to the right of the museum.

Walking up to the museum, I was just in awe looking up at the building, it's like something out of a history book.  Everything from the courtyard, to the grounds, to the magnificent columns lining the perimeter of the courtyard just takes your breath away.  

You're "greeted" at the entrance to the museum courtyard by a sculpture called "The Thinker" who is in a hunched position looking like he's....what else, thinking of course.  There is a pyramid structure near the entrance to the museum (that honestly looks Lourve-esque), which looks like it may have a light feature to be used in the evening.  

$:  Admission to the museum for adults is $10 general and $15 for general + admission to the special exhibits.  

TIP:  Make sure to pick up a map/guide to the museum when you pay admission, as each section is numbered and the guide will tell you what art/pieces are from each specific time period.

The upper level contains the majority of the exhibits:  Paintings, sculptures, chairs, glasses, couches, etc.  The galleries are wide and spacious with high ceilings and definitely give the patrons an almost regal emotion or feel as they view all of these exquisite and inspiring pieces of art.  I have to say that the gallery that gave me that feeling of "awe" was the gallery 1 which contains paintings by Monet, Cezanne, and Picasso.  I have to say I couldn't believe my eyes that I was in the presence of artwork by these famous and historical artists.  The lower level contains the museum cafe and giftshop, more exhibits, and most importantly, the special exhibits, which as of this writing is Pulp Fashion.

Bottom Line:  A must see for the art-lover if visiting SF.  Wonderful. Amazing. Inspiring.
author: Michael C.

description:
What kinda name is that?!

Actually this 3/4 scale adaptation of the original landmark in Paris, France, was commissioned by a couple who wanted to dedicate a fine arts museum to the California men who lost their lives on the battlefields of France during WWI.  

Unaware of this museum, I was pleasantly surprised by the collections encountered upon visiting!  You're hit with Rodin's "Thinker" right upon courtyard entry, Monet a short while later, a statue by Picasso (yes, statue), and many other notable great artists.  It's a small-ish museum which won't take you too long to peruse it all.  

WOA:
* Yes, you can take no-flash photos
* No, like all museums, you cannot touch 
* Teeny gift shop on lower level
* Additional fee to visit special exhibitions

Great way to spend a beautiful afternoon near Lincoln Park~
author: Sandee T.

description: Great museum.  Artwork displayed beautifully.  Came here at 11am on a weekday and was able to get through the museum in 1.5 hrs.  Plenty of parking and not crowded.  Ticket was good for De Young on the same day... great value.
author: Linda L.

description:
You are reading this because you are wondering if it's worth your time to visit this place right?  Well, it is.  One becomes a different person after each visit.  The permanent collection be old friends to visit often - the portraits stare back with emotion knowingly.  The traveling exhibits tell a story through the work of different artists.  There is a visual and a historical connection with the past that makes one walk away a different person.

602 reviews.  Do your really need another one to get you over there?  Well, if it takes 603 reviews to convince you then please read my review and make it over there to see this amazing museum.   It is the best museum in San Francisco:

Location 
- out away from the city on a hill with nice views of the bay. 
- It is far enough away that you can find a parking place
- Close to some nice restaurants that you can enjoy after the museum: Geary and Clement street - take your pick.

The exhibits
- Sofie and I always enjoy the exhibits.  I didn't want to see a couple of the traveling exhibits because the art seemed boring (Georgia O'Keeffe) but after attending the exhibit and learning about O'Keeffe's art I bought a print because the people at Legion of Honor did such an outstanding job of displaying the works and explaining what was behind them... the painting of a few leaves meant a lot to me because I understood what she was saying through the drawing!
- Audio tour - we always get the audio tours - very informative.  (Sometimes I bring my own headphones and just plug into their device... creeps me out wondering who last wore those headphones and wondering if they ever wash their ears.)
- I like the quirky little exhibit downstairs showing different printed matter. Current exhibit is Artists & Editions: A Publication in Memory of Steven Leiber (1957-2012).  My favorite was a yellow sign "Back in 1 Minute".  Have you considered that a little yellow sticky could end up in an art museum?  Nice.

Tips:
- Bring a snack if you think you will be hungry... or a suitcase of money because the cafeteria is costly.
- If you rent the audio tour for an exhibit - do not turn it in... haul it upstairs and listen the notes for the permanent exhibits... then return it when you are done.
- Come early to get a nice parking spot and avoid the crowds.
- Nice bathrooms are downstairs
- Get a membership!  You will be able to see the de Young and Legion of Honor for free all the time and bring  friend.  If you see even one major exhibit the membership price will pay for the exhibit - and they send a great magazine if you are a member.  Sofie reads the magazine and I look at the pictures.  Then, when we go to to the museum she tells me stuff and I say, "Wow!  That's pretty interesting!  Where'd you learn about that?!"  Sofie says, "I read it in your magazine."  I say in a still and quiet voice, "Oh."
author: Steve S.

description:
Super amazing... Here a few hours ago, super weather and all around happiness due to wonderful views and that wonderful European vibe.

Today and tomorrow, all BofA cardholders, free admission to general exhibit. $10 for the special Impressionists on the water exhibit!

Go----but know the parking situation aint so easy (or pretty). Cant ever come here without seeing married couples taking wedding pics.
author: Jana C.

description: Came on the BOA free museum day. I was surprised by those exhibits. Good to parking, and good for both kids and adults. You could learn a lot there if you want to.
author: Charles S.

description:
Great place to visit!!! Have enjoyed it for 70 years.
The café is very nice and so are the employees. Nice desserts too!
author: Clifford D.

description:
Gorgeous grounds overlooking the bay surround this treasure that makes you feel like you're outside of SF.  Inside there are well organized galleries filled with antiquities art and artifacts from the beginning of time. 

Get up close and personal with faberge jewelry, Rodin sculptures and Monet. The French receiving room is incredible and docents on hand to provide additional info are much appreciated.  

While the cafe does not have the greatest menu, sitting in the outdoor patio makes for a nice escape.  The gift shop is worth a spin through and your purchases go towards a good cause. 

I will definitely be back!
author: Carlyn C.

description:
Very European type art museum. Clean lines and roomy interior to view art. Been there several times for special exhibits, other art work remain fairly static. July 2014 several new objects from SF MOMA were on loan due to SFMOMA remodeling.
Only two floors of art works and bottom floor for auditorium for special events. Annual membership maybe not worthwhile unless you come here often or go to the SF museums with reciprocal entry. Note: Special exhibits are extra fee paid at entry way although general entry not charged on reciprocal membership entry. Parking is generally available on lesser special exhibits including handicap spots. Muni bus (#29?) available but wait can be long especially for those tourists who bought the City Pass multi-day pass that included free muni ride pass.
author: Clifford W.

description:
I have been to this art museum few times and it never gets old . This museum has some great European art works from
some amazing artists . 
Not to mention the Legion of Honor is in an amazing location with some spectacular views . You can get some great views of the Golden Gate Bridge . All around this is a beautiful museum and a must see .
author: Alexandra A.

description: Museum is nice, but the staff are rude, at least some of the ones who are standing and watching people in the exhibition hall. They reminded me of holding my backpack like I'm a criminal.
author: Han Y.

description:
This is one of the most stunning museums in San Francisco. The views of the bay are incredible and the architecture is beautiful. I loved the collection here and they frequently have some amazing guest displays. 

This is the sister museum to the De Young so if you get a membership, then you get both museums! The De Young has a larger collection, but I like the location and beauty of the Legion of Honor. Both are wonderful art museums.
author: Kari G.

description: My first date with my boyfriend was here. We went to look at art and some of it was really nice. The area around and inside is amazing. It makes you feel classy to come here. Parking was not hard to find, and free as well!! Lands end is around the area and perfect for a quiet little walk around sunset time. There is a golf course next door.
author: Amy Y.

description:
Parking: There is a lot in front of the museum but if you can't find any just circle around the park.

With student ID it was less than 10 bucks and included admission to De Young. Though the name is very epic, probably the words LEGION and HONOR. This is a relatively large painting and sculpture museum. 

I am not very refine to enjoy paintings and interpreting them as anything other than the face value. Nonetheless, it was fun listening to the tours and seeing the paintings in a different light. Though there was a lot of over analysis of the paintings, it was still educational. 

Random rant....
Beware of intense parents and intense art lovers with children on the tours though because my brother got chewed out when his camera which has a orange light that pops up when it is about to take a picture called out for damaging the pictures. The tour guide didn't even care. But whatever, if light like that can cause damage, then a screen should be placed over the pictures because it was nowhere near the intensity of a flash, probably more damage from the reflection off the reflections of your jewelry than from the camera light indicator so chill.
author: Willis W.

description: Pretty place but would amount only to a small wing of the Louvre.
author: Inigo M.

description:
Hike down the cliff to the ocean. Grab a lungful of fresh air (it's been scrubbed clean by thousands of miles of blue Pacific). Take photos of goofy poses among the colonnaded halls. Do your Thinker pose next to the oversized poser. Once inside, walk among over a hundred Rodin sculptures. Hang out like a crazed French monarch in a French salon. Channel Ferris Beuller ogling Cezanne, Seurat, Monet, Degas, Manet, van Dyck, Picasso and a horde of other masters; the collections rotate so you might even see a Rembrandt or van Gogh on occasion.

And if you're lucky enough to catch an organ recital on Sunday afternoons, well, do it.

Someday I'll play that golf course out front.
author: John H.

description: I got to participate in a super fun scavenger hunt at the Legion of Honor and it was a wonderful place to read everything and look for details. The museum and grounds are absolutely beautiful and always has super interesting exhibits.
author: Megan S.

description:
First of all, the building. The architecture is stunning, reminiscent of ancient Rome. Just outside, you can see views of the Golden Gate Bridge.

As for the art, the museum is meticulously organized by era and region, giving a sense of purpose to every room. The Legion of Honor houses countless sculptures by  Rodin and a few pieces by Monet, Van Gogh, and Bouguereau. The museum is very well-lit and the staff is kind and helpful. Please stop by if you're staying in San Francisco! It's a little out of the way, but definitely worth it.
author: Zak C.

description: Great place to go for with kids, friends, or dates. There are so many things to see and at a good price. The De Young museum was amazing.
author: Jessica J.

description: I cannot believe how big this place is. It took us 4 hrs just to finish walking through all the exhibits. I really love all the exhibits that they have. The building is also very beautiful and nicely located inside the park. A must see!
author: Katie T.

description:
Got there at 4:30 so it was FREE. 
Just an amazing experience. The art was breath taking.
author: Zain E.

description:
The location of this building alone is breathtaking.  The artwork inside this museum is awe inspiring with works of Rembrandt, Monet, Matisse, and Picasso. Although this space isn't as large as other museums I've traveled to I could walk around these grounds for hours getting lost in each piece. The building itself can be a bit overwhelming with the Doric columns outside awaiting your arrival but fear not and step inside.  you wont regret it.  

try and get there early as the parking lots fills up fast.  Take a stroll along the cliffs and watch the waves crash against the rocks below.
author: Kevin J.

description:
My corporate holiday party was hosted at the Legion of Honor so I was fortunate enough to get to experience the museum in a slightly different setting than it is typically appreciated.  The first time I came to San Francisco, I wandered around the perimeters of the museum and was astonished by how beautiful the views were.  

This time, I actually got to see inside which was very exciting, and it was more exciting because I got to see their current exhibit, Treasures from the Louvre.  Some of the pieces from that exhibit are truly spectacular.  My favorites were a collection of goblets, and one was made out of a chunk of amethyst stone.  Stunning.

I thought that the museum made a wonderful event space as well, on a completely separate note, since I was able to experience that side of things.  If you are looking for a larger and fancier venue to have your corporate party in, this might be a good fit for you.

All in all, I thought this was a great museum and it definitely is one of the better ones that I have been to in the US.
author: Alyx F.

description:
Really pretty location with a decent collection of art work.  I was pleased to find they had the even had in possession a few of Claude Monet's paintings.  :)  At the time of my visit, they had the "Royal Treasures from the Louvre," exhibit on display.  I was also able to walk through their other exhibit,  "Gifts from the Gods: Art and the Olympic Idea."  Both exhibits were quite fascinating to see.  

The only thing I did not care for was what felt like the lack of air circulation inside parts of the the museum.  It was an unusually warm spring day at the time of my visit and there is  no air conditioning within the museum, which I can understand because San Francisco usually has cooler climate.  It just felt very stuffy and uncomfortable.  I think the next time I visit, I will try to come when it is cooler and leave my sweater at home.
author: Amy C.

description:
I don't really have any good reason to give most museums under 5 stars.  Legion of Honor is beauuutiful, spacious, offers discounts for students, for taking the muni, etc... but my favourite thing about Legion of Honor is its one of its rooms upstairs that lets you watch the art restoration technicians restore art!!  I watched one of the technicians put gold plating on a wooden slab and carve out some part of a wall of a foyer (: 

The Legion of Honor Café is also adorable.  All the employees dress like they're in another decade, and (the manager?) or one of the guys in charge is the sweetest thing.  On weekdays, the Legion of Honor Cafe will be filled with seniors, but it adds to the charm of the place ;)
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Gorgeous architecture. The views surrounding are amazing. Great for wedding and engagement photography. 

I'm a photographer and take my clients here for their post wedding and engagement shoots. Out of towner are awe inspired by it.
author: Natasha G.

description: My first time visiting The Legion of Honor, I was amazed by the beauty of the landscaping, architecture, and of all the wonderful art work inside! I highly recommend to anyone in the San Francisco or visiting to Che knout this museum.
author: Nick T.

description:
The sight of the Legion of Honor as you drive up 34th Avenue is as classic as San Francisco gets. As most everyone knows, it's an imposing Beaux-Arts building with a grand courtyard set on a subtle bluff that takes in panoramic views of the bay toward the Golden Gate. So taken was Alfred Hitchcock with the building that he filmed a key scene here when Jimmy Stewart is stalking Kim Novak as she sits staring at the painting of Carlotta Valdes. 

Now I know the painting was done just for the movie, but don't you think they should have a replica on display for photo ops? I think it's a moneymaker just waiting to happen. Anyhow, there is enough here otherwise to satisfy more refined tastes than mine. My friend Maggie was kind enough to allow Jamie W. and me to take advantage of her membership in order to see the current Impressionist Paris exhibition, which provides a lovely and sometimes haunting evocation of the city through historic prints, paintings, and photos. 

There's also the Rodin gallery and a copy of "The Thinker" in the courtyard, as well as familiar works from Monet and Renoir and George Segal's dramatic sculpture, "The Holocaust" out near the parking lot (see photos). There is the inevitable cafe with a much nicer menu than can be found at the MoMA. There is also the expansive gift shop for consumerist non-connoisseurs looking for a place to tap their iPhones. Just don't do it in front of me in the galleries as the grand impressionist masters would turn over in their graves and get all French-nasty on you.
author: Ed U.

description: The building itself is absolutely stunning, and located near Land's End. You could combine the two into one day: go to the museum and do a hike (in any order!). They have some great pieces inside and I appreciated the variety of media (painting, sculpture, murals, etchings, furniture) as well as the diversity of dates from which the pieces were created. I particularly enjoyed the work by Rodin; this is one of the 10 places in the world where you can see "The Thinker" as Rodin made 10 different casts of it that are now at various museums throughout the world (Paris, DC, Melbornne, Geneva). I give it 4 out of 5 because nothing here is particularly mind blowing and I wouldn't characterize anything as a "must see." Lands End hike plus the museum would be a great combo tho!
author: Neil T.

description: Came for Bank of America Forest free weekend. Totally worth it! Came Saturday around noon and parking was a bit tough, maybe took 5-10 min or so to find a space, but good thing it was free. There was a money exhibit so lots of people lined up for that. Too bad it costs $20 extra per person. We spend 2:30 min here. Wear comfortable shoes and layers, done areas were hot and others were not. The bathroom situation here sucks, only one set for the whole place so lines can get long. There was a good variety of paintings, furniture pieces and ceramics/statues from different eras and civilizations. Also nice view of Golden gate bridge from outside.
author: KoKo K.

description: I just went to see the Monet special exhibit with my son today. I was impressed with the selection of paintings, including ones that have only been on public display once or twice before. The people at the Legion of Honor are also cheerful and kind. We enjoyed our visit as we have every time we go!
author: Chien H.

description:
I'm not an "art" fan, but this place made me one.  I couldn't believe how inspiring this place can be to such a lug head like me.  I was actually staring at a painting by Mattia Pretti (who? I don't know) but it was of John the Baptist looking at me  and pointing behind him --and it was as if he was talking to me.... then I read the information plaque nest to it and it said that maybe that was what the artist was trying to tell the viewer,  "Behold the Lamb of God". Whoa.

There were also some strange paintings in this place, but I'd be lying if I said if I like those.  

The big reason to like this place just to like it:  The outside.  Beautiful building, grass areas, views of Golden Gate Bridge, and the city. Whoa.
author: Al O.

description: This was one of the last museums in SF that I visited, over a period of years, and I wish it had been the first! This place is the perfect size for a day visit - not too big. The building is absolutely breathtaking and the cafe inside serves great food. (FYI the oat tart is delish!!) The Legion of Honor has a great baroque collection, and a piece that took my breath away - Girl With Broken Jug. They had quite a few impressive decorative art pieces from France and Spain as well. And their medieval and Renaissance collections were great! We caught the organ concert as well, which happens everyday at 4 I believe, and I would go back just for that. All in all, a great place to spend the day with some really great art. GO! You won't regret it.
author: Adrienne S.

description:
Beautiful museum in a beautiful setting 

BUT BE VERY CAREFUL LEAVING YOUR CAR.  My family and I stepped away from our car for 20-30 minutes on a late Friday morning (sunny and people around) and came back to the back passenger side window smashed in and our belongings stolen.  Then we were juggled between the parks department and the city police as they debated which of the departments had jurisdiction (neither wanted to deal with it).  Apparently car break-ins have been very common here lately (and given the attitude and behavior of the museum's parking lot security staff, I'm inclined to believe they are actively involved in facilitating the break-ins).  The museum should do a better job of securing the parking area nearby (actually installing cameras if car break-ins are so common would be a good starting place).
author: Larry B.

description:
Literally found this place while driving around SF one day with my son. It was a weekday and the parking lot was nearly empty. We didn't even know what we had stumbled upon. When we went inside (yes there is a fee) we were amazed at the gorgeous pieces of art and the diversity of mediums and periods this place had to offer. We have been back several times with the rest of the family and friends who are visiting from out of town. One of my favorite features of this building is a plaque on the wall outside that reads:
THAT MEN MAY NOT FORGET,
 THE LIVING LEGION, IN CONVENTION,
 SPEAKING IN COMRADESHIP WITH THE DEAD,
 AGAIN VOICE THEIR LOVE
 FOR THOSE WHO GAVE THEIR LIVES
 THAT WE MIGHT BE FREE

Heavily weighted words that should be read and understood by all future generations. This place is not to be missed.
author: Leslie G.

description:
As someone who's lived on the East Coast most of her life, one of the things I miss the most out here in the Bay Area is the European-ness of the US Northeast (Boston, NYC, etc.). Different part of the country = different history, so one could hardly expect California to offer all that. 

Legion of Honor is easily the most "European" place you will find in San Francisco. It is absolutely stunning, a jaw-dropping marvel of Parisian architecture from George Applegarth who modeled it after the Palais de la Légion d'Honneur in Paris. The French influence can be seen everywhere, from the glass pyramid in the courtyard (reminiscent of the Louvre) to the perfect circle of a fountain (reminiscent of Versailles). That the museum sits atop gorgeous Lincoln Park/Lands End (a surreal wonderland of nature that doesn't seem like it could possibly exist within urban San Francisco) only adds to its mystical beauty.

The European essence permeates the entire museum. Legion of Honor is truly a cosmopolitan art museum, offering almost every form of European art, from paintings to sculptures to furniture to whole re-created rooms. In keeping with my other Yelp reviews of cultural institutions, here are the pieces I most recommend seeing:

1) The current special exhibit, "Royal Treasures from the Louvre": If you've never been inside the Louvre (or have and can't remember anything more than a feeling of tortured claustrophobia and the occasional glimpse of a painting peeking out from amidst the throng of tourists), this exhibit is for you. I especially loved the Mosaic Tabletop, the display of ewers (esp. #104) and the Personal Collection of Marie Antoinette.

2) Porcelain Gallery: It has the feel of an antique shop rather than a museum wing with its plush rugs and sitting chairs, but there are some lovely objects to see here, especially the twin Tulipiere vases

3) Rodin's "Victor Hugo": The most captivating (in my opinion) of the museum's rather large collection of Rodin's work 
 
4) Louis XV/Paneled Room: The kingwood is breathtaking, as are the artifacts

5) Glass Goblets: Bright and glittering, especially the Roemer

6) Religious panels from the Middle Ages such as Bicci di Lorenzo's "St. John the Baptist and St. Miniato": These take me back to grade 12, when I did a project on art of the Middle Ages

7) Jean-Leon Gerome, "The Bath": The perfect representation of Europe's (rather misguided and romanticized) fascination with the Middle East during the 19th century

8) John Martin, "The Assuaging of the Waters: A mesmerizing use of color to re-create the Great Flood. Try to find Noah's Ark without reading the description plaque. I think part of why I like this painting so much is because the interplay of light and water reminds me of my favorite painting in the whole world, Claude Lorrain's "Seaport with the Embarkation of the Queen of Sheba"

9) The Impressionism/Post-Impression Room: A well-rounded collection of works from heavyweights like Monet, Cézanne, Pissarro and my personal favorite, Degas

Happy viewing!
author: Josephine L.

description: Beautiful art, atmosphere, breathtaking views; one of the many reasons why you tend to leave your heart in San Francisco.
author: Jacqueline J.

description: It's pretty amazing to stand face to face with Monet's paintings. The art here is so impressive with the constant changing exhibits. The lawn outside is a perfect spot to have lunch with an amazing view of the the bay!
author: Christy M.

description: I attended a holiday party here and this is a truly amazing place. The museum has a grand entry way and carries through out the architecture of the building. The collections were interesting and I will definitely go back and visit.
author: Ana O.

description:
great art and rodin's 'thinker' statute outside alone is worth visiting

have golfed many a time almost hittin tourists w/cart or yelling fore as I found myself on the otherside today....glad I finally stepped foot inside after only 7 years

although I have the art inst, met, getty, louvre on my viewing resume as dumb luck...i'm definitely culture deficient as I favor the grasshopper cafe and sex museum to the rijks.  

i do appreciate it though, just not one to stand in awe w/arms crossed and nodding w/index finger on my chin talkin fictitiously or facetiously.  that and its usually intimidating to me.  similar to your first date way back when w/fake id ordering wine as garcon at applebees hands you the cork...it's boones pal, thanks but no thanks

so be and so crates in the words of bill and ted's
author: Clark G.

description: It's free on the first weekend of the month if you have a Bank of America account. Or another option is go there on the first Tuesday of the month. You can go in for free general admission. But if they are hosting something special on the underground. Chances are you would need to pay to attend. Kids who are under 12 are free for general admission.
author: Michael Q.

description:
Went here last year for an art project for school. I'm not much into art but i thought everything here was amusing. Really nice displays. Doesn't cost too much to go in. If you have a college or school ID, you also get a discount! There's parking out front and along the coast. Nice view of the bridge and there's benches to sit. 

There is also a golf course area nearby. Don't go around along the back of the museum. There's nothing there and i got yelled at by some cranky old white guy saying that i was a distraction for walking into his sight of his shot! Well then!
author: John L.

description:
If you've ever wondered what Heaven looks and feels like, this is it. Well - for me anyway. High above the San Francisco Bay perked on a mountain overlooking the enchanting rollings hills of the San Francisco terrain - rests the Legion of Honor.

Housing the most celebrated collection of Rodin, this Impressionists-inspired museum is a breathtaking haven for people who want to take in an wonderfully curated gallery of 19th century art or just revel in the sheer beauty of the structure. Marble-lad floors invite you in to a circular foyer flanked with even more enticing galleries. Marble statues in one direction, royal furniture pieces in other. The architecture of the building itself recalls the very era of the art that resides in the museum: Neoclassical French. It's graceful and whimsical, yet classic and clean.
author: Frances H.

description:
I would like to go on record as saying the Legion of Honor is getting old and tired.

Please somebody do something to make this place a showcase of fine art in the Bay Area!
author: Mr. O.

description: Came here on a Saturday with two friends. Only $6 with college ID, or $10 without, and free parking. The museum is a good size for what you pay- not too big that you get overwhelmed and not too small. We spent about an hour and a half here which was perfect. They have some really good pieces like Raphael's unicorn and Monet's water lilies among many other wonderful pieces.
author: Samantha H.

description:
Legion of Honor is such a beautiful museum inside and out. I almost felt like I was in some European country. It certainly isn't quite the Louvre but the collection is still impressive. They have mostly European paintings, statues and some ancient art. 

Take your date here on a sunny day and stroll through the gallery. Watch the sunset at the park outside afterward and finish the day with a nice romantic dinner in the city. It doesn't get better than this, does it? 

Parking could get difficult on the weekend so plan to come here early.
author: Mona W.

description:
Besides having the best name in the world, Legion of Honor is a well curated, architecturally significant museum. If you are a strict fan of contemporary art, your aesthetics will be tested by countless rooms of 18th century art, decor and furniture, but if you invest the time in closely ogling these Old World paintings you will be astounded by the content, color and technique.

The building itself is a throwback to more regal times, sitting atop Lincoln Park gifting views to those who choose to visit. Take the time to soak in the views before presuing the art inside. The layout of Legion of Honor is a seemingly never ending maze of rooms on the top floor. Each room flows into another one and it seems as if you may miss a few rooms without ever knowing it.

Museum staff was friendly and the museum itself is curated beautifully as the displays, including the background wall colors, match the time of the works being exhibited. The permanent collection is spaced very well and specifically the sculptures are smartly stood away from the wall so you can see the process behind much of Rodin's work.

While we were there, we also had the chance to see the Anders Zorn exhibition which was exceptional. A Swedish Master, Zorn captures water more perfectly than humanly imaginable. As you look close, all you see are small brush marks and as you step back to view from afar you see brilliant water, as far into the painting as you can look. I didn't mind for one second paying the extra $6 to see this show as it was very comprehensive, covering numerous room and the artist's entire career.

A visit to Legion of Honor is a must for art lovers. The only negative is that it is extremely heavy in terms of 18th and 17th century art, but that is its mission. It just becomes a little overwhelming going from room to room of the permanent collection seeing very similar styles and objects. It is certainly a very nice lesson in the periods displayed. At $10 ($16 total for admission and special exhibition), it is a bargain. You can easily spend 3 hours here without missing a beat. If you are hungry, visit the cafe, it is excellent.
author: Jonathan G.

description:
Okay, I have never actually been inside the museum.  We always park outside.  We take family and friends here as one of the highlights when touring San Francisco.

The views of the bay and the Golden Gate Bridge are fantastic from here.  Make sure to bring your camera!  

Word of warning:  Do not go on the golf course cause your likely to anger some people!  

The Legion of Honor area is simply beautiful!
author: PatrickJ T.

description:
Truly a beautiful museum and in my opinion, the most European feeling of all in our fair city.  Since my elderly, over-grown teenager of a father seems to do nothing but lay in bed all day lately as his health deteriorates, we have been trying to come up with ideas that will force him to walk and get some exercise.  Tuesday morning, I realized that the first Tuesday of the month is free at the Legion of Honor (and De Young) so we poked him out of bed and came here.

Ever since the major renovation they had over a decade ago, the Legion of Honor has always been one of my favorites, especially with all the Rodin that Mrs. Spreckels donated many years ago.  She made many worthwhile contributions to the city in her time and this museum is one of them.  As we walked through all the various halls, I explained to my dad about her and reminded him of the statue of her that I had pointed out while dining at Burger Bar in Union Square.

Rodin has always been my favorite and seeing his timeless staues is always a moving and emotional experience for me.  In one hall, I was surprised by a statue of a squatting female that I had never noticed before which seemed especially risque.  I don't remember the name, but believe it was named after a woman with a name starting in E.  Elsa?  I don't remember, but thought it to be especially racy for the era.

Didn't think to take a picture of it at the time, but did take a couple while there.  Next time, I'll get one of her for sure.

In an era of greed and ridiculous price gouging for just about everything imaginable, it is comforting to see that the prices for our city's museums remain at a reasonable rate so that everyone, especially today's youth can explore and enjoy.  I recently went to Coit Tower the other day, only to discover that the stairway was closed (as always for years) and that the $3.00 fee for the rickety elevator ride to the top was now $7.00!  For three people, that would have been $21.00.  You have got to be kidding me.  Hmmm, I see another review coming up. 

Unlike the Academy of Sciences, the Legion of Honor and De Young museum still have reasonable admission pricing and also a free day, once a month.  These are not profit centers nor were they ever intended to be.  Hoping that whoever is in charge will work hard to keep it this way so that future generations of San Franciscans and visitors can enjoy and get their culture for years to come.  That's what museums are all about.
author: Roy N.

description:
As part of the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco (FAMSF) along with the de Young museum, the Legion of Honor houses some of the world's most beautiful works of art, with extensive collections in both Ancient and European art.

One of the main attractions is the impressive collection of sculptures by French artist, Auguste Rodin (my personal favorite and the majority of my time is spent here).  He was known for his radical and individualistic approach to sculpting, especially when it came to the human body and its realism.

As you approach the entrance, one of Rodin's signature pieces, "The Thinker", towers over you.  Standing in this courtyard, one really gets a feel of the majesty that this palace provides to its visitors.  Almost every time I come here, I see professional photographers at work for wedding pictures or for even just regular couples trying to capture the moment.

As if the Rodin collection wasn't enough, you can also check out some great pieces from the Impressionist era, such artists like Pissarro, Seurat, Cezanne, and another one of my personal favorites, Claude Monet.

I really love how the curators set up one of Monet's masterpieces, "Water Lilies".  As you turn the corner and head towards its section, you can immediately view the painting from a distance as the corridors are perfectly aligned so that you can see all the way to the back wall.  And voila, there you will find all of its glory and beauty!

In the central room on the top floor, you'll find an organ player where they usually set up seats for people to sit and watch.  During one memorable performance, they had played a piece from the Broadway musical, Phantom of the Opera, that just blew me away.

You'll find the museum cafe and gift shop on the lower level.  The cafe actually serves pretty decent food and drinks and also includes a pretty big outdoor courtyard with plenty of seating with a small view of the Pacific.  This is a great place to sit down and enjoy a book and I've also seen people study here as well.

There have been many special exhibits at this museum, including Cartier & America, Japonesque, and the recent one for Italian artist, Gian Lorenzo Bernini, best known for his sculptures and architectural works throughout Rome.  The highlight of this particular exhibit was Bernini's sculpture of the classic Greek myth "Medusa".  This piece of art was truly impressive to see.
author: Tony L.

description:
My review pertains to the ship of fools who work at the Legion of Honor - the museum itself was quite nice, except for the parking situation which was just deplorable.   But I am sorry to say that I will NEVER set foot in that place again due to the total tools they employ.
    
This weekend, I went to see the "Impressionists on the Water" exhibit with my daughter.  From the moment we set foot there, the first people who greeted us at what I later learned was a ticket desk, barked at everyone to move along, right past them.  While some people went through, the folks in front of me seemed to be as bewildered as I since we still needed to buy our tickets. Now, perhaps the people who went in before us had pre-purchased tickets, I don't know.  But when we asked where to get tickets, we were ordered to come back into the line to buy them. The same ass who waved everyone through was very rude to the people ahead of us, and treated them like they were the idiots.  Wow.  Fortunately, a woman waved us over, and was somewhat more pleasant.

After the rather pointless "light saber" wanding of our bags (I had a pocket knife, as did my daughter - I wonder what they were looking for?), we were passed through to the gallery.  As we attempted to enter the exhibit, Tweedle Dumb and Tweedle Dumber, who were apparently posted by the velvet ropes to check tickets, had wandered off to playfully push and shove each other like the pimply teens they were.  As we attempted to pass however, they came scampering back to order us, rather indignantly, to show them our tickets - again, as if we were trying to pull something over on them, rather than a product of their own ineptness.  Whatever - cuz you so badass, working at the museum.  Oh well, better than McDonald's, I guess.

As we went through the gallery we were repeatedly reprimanded by the "guards" for getting too close to the exhibits, even though there were no signs posted anywhere about maintaining 18" of distance from the paintings on the wall.  Of course, the rules only seemed to apply to us, since we unknowingly must have done something to offend them - they didn't appear to have a problem with anyone else, even though they got much closer than we did.
    
The final gems were in the gift shop.  When I had the gall to attempt to ask one of the counter princesses if there were any postcards of a particular painting that I liked, before I had even formed my question, Miss Thing rudely cut me off and said that everything they had was out on the floor, "I mean, it's the last weekend of the exhibit, you know!!!"  Please forgive me - I am such a dolt to assume you might have had something that I may have overlooked in the piles of overpriced crap that they had left over, spread liberally around the shop.  I promptly put down the items I had intended to purchase and left without giving them another dime.  God forbid I should force my stupid money on you.  Please, get back to your important gossiping instead of doing the jobs you are paid to do. 
  
People have a bad day occasionally, but really?  The whole stinking crew?  I have never seen a more uppity bunch of snotty little oinks in one place in my whole life.  You know, just because you have the fortune to be employed at a place where great works of art are displayed, doesn't mean you're better than the people who pay a sum equivalent to twice your daily wage for the privilege to look at them.  I have been to many museums, all over the world - without exception, the people who worked in them were eager to answer questions and share their knowledge with their GUESTS.  Sadly, I did not feel like a guest at this place.
author: LINA W.

description:
Went to Legion of Honor on Sun 1/15/12 and got there kinda late, we lucked out on parking because someone was leaving.  They have a small FREE lot, down the hill are signs saying "No Parking Any Time" and people still were parking there - crazy.

Things we saw:

Pissarro's People - Lower level.  It was ok.  

Artistic SF - some neat artwork on SF scenes.  Lower level.

Favorite things: Exhibit of artist books in memory of David Logan - old books, no photos allowed.  Meh for me.  Lower Level.

Bernini's Medusa - Just the one bust.  Neat & a bunch of us took pics & didn't get yelled at, just No Flash.  Main level.

Organ player was playing Sundays - that's always cool.

Bathrooms: lower level.

Closes at 5:15pm.  Stayed 1hr15m.
author: Ann L.

description:
I came here with the GF for her holiday party.  The museum was closed off for just our party so that was pretty awesome.  I am not that much of an artsy person, so I do not think that I fully appreciated all the wonderful works of art with thousands of years of history.  Yet, I had fun walking around the exhibits, being able to take pictures, when it explicitly said no photography, just because no one was watching!  Watch out we got a badass over here!  

The Legion of Honor is fairly big, with two floors (that I could see).  Downstairs is a patio area where some of the food was being served.  It was quite the fancy party.  At night, the lights illuminated the exterior of the museum so well.  It was quite the marvel to see.  Inside is slightly dim, except when entering the many exhibits.  

This place is nice, but without her company throwing the party here, I do not think I would have ventured here on my own.
author: Victor L.

description:
As a San Franciscan, I am embarrassed to say that I have never visited the Legion Of Honor, until today.

Modeled after the Louvre in Paris: this is a museum that I find myself revisiting. Beautifully designed in simple luxury, clean, inviting, boasting fine works of art from Europe, and friendly staff. 

I went for the "Royal Treasures from the Louvre" exhibit, and I was amazed! I found that a lot of the objects from this exhibit, I would most likely have or replicate in my own home, my friend said "that is so flamboyant of you, but I like your luxurious taste". All the gold, the gems, and the shimmering diamonds - oh what a dream. I'm blown away that these treasures (some) where gifts commissioned by the King of France to foreign diplomats. Can I travel back in time and pose a foreign diplomat? Perhaps just in dream. 

It's great that the de Young and Legion Of Honor are sister museums, because after our "The Girl With A Pearl Earring", I only spent $10 to enter the royal treasures exhibit. 

The museum is currently building a room that features original panels from Versailles, and I can't wait to visit that!
author: Alex C.

description: This year Microsoft had their holiday party at this place. I took some time to see a few of the exhibits the museum had on display. Really liked it. Would recommend.
author: Martin G.

description:
What a spectacular museum! I came to visit with my family on one of their free admission days, and to my surprise, it wasn't as busy or hectic as I was dreading it to be. Yes, it was crowded, but not overwhelmingly so.

The layout is interesting. When I first noticed it I wanted to dock a star, but after viewing what all the rooms had to offer, it's really a small inconvenience more than anything. We started with the lower level before jumping in to the main rooms that are on the main level. The layout that I consider interesting is in the main level.

If you walk straight in, you are caught in what seems to be the special exhibition room. It's the one that most people are in. When you turn left, the artwork gets older. When you turn right, the artwork gets more modern. I don't quite like that. 

I ended up walking as quickly as possible to the room that contained the oldest artwork and slowly made my way through the ages. I'm not one to be obsessed with chronological order (after all, I loved Memento), but there is something about viewing art in that order - I love seeing the progression.

It is rather strange for me that photography is mostly allowed. No complaints, except that people can get really obnoxious about it. So please be respectful.

The architecture of the building itself is also quite spectacular. It felt like I was in a museum in Europe. Well, as far as I can tell from my extensive experience...um...watching movies set in Europe. Ahem. 

Truly glad that I finally got to visit this museum after years and years of visiting SF and the bay area at least once a year. Yet another reason why it's my favorite city in the US of A.
author: Rayni K.

description:
Who would have thought that such a wonderful art museum would be found in the middle of a green and scenic golf course and hiking trail? 

Arriving here is a little other-worldly as you walk up the stairs, past a stone lion and then in to a grand open space with Rodin's "The Thinker" staring down at you. Go further, hand over $10, and then take an hour or so to explore various rooms filled with art from the 19th century. You'll see familiar names on the walls (Matisse, Monet, Renoir...) and will be rewarded with one of the largest collections of Rodin sculptures outside of France.
author: Tresna L.

description:
Pros: Beautiful art housed in classical architecture, homey, scenic views
Cons: Limited selection based on your preference, small

Legion of Honor has been one of my favorite places in SF to visit ever since I took art history there in high school. Of course, the LoH isn't as big as the other museums in the city (i.e. DeYoung and Asian Art) but it definitely makes it up in its architecture, art and atmosphere!

As you traverse the museum's entry court to enter the museum itself, you're greeted by a replica of Rodin's "the Thinker" while being surrounded by a colonnade. They say first impressions are the most important and this display of classical art and architecture definitely leaves a lasting impression. 

The LoH has a lot to offer in terms of architecture, art and atmosphere. If you check their schedule, they even have live classical music performances every now and again!   Organ concerts every Saturdays and Sundays at 4pm! Free museums visits first Tuesday of the month! What could be better?
author: Wing C.

description:
I love love love this museum.  I've been here at least 20 times, and make a point to see all of the visiting exhibits (which are always amazing -- over the years, I've seen artifacts from King Tut, Man Ray and Lee Miller, the Magna Carta [yes, *that* Magna Carta], Impressionism in Paris [from the Musee d'Orsay] -- and this list goes on).  

Why I love it:  

1)  It's far enough out of the way that it's never crowded.  It's you, and the art, and that's my favorite kind of museum experience!  I last came on a Saturday afternoon in July, and there were maybe only 20 other people there in the main galleries (a few more in the special exhibit downstairs).  

2)  Organ concerts.  Awesome.  
 
3)  The best collection of Rodin sculptures (cast during his lifetime) outside of Paris. 

4)  Parking.  I am not kidding, free parking.  In San Francisco.  

5)  You buy a ticket to the Legion of Honor, you get a free admission to the De Young in Golden Gate park on the same day!  Totally bang for your buck!

And yeah, if you need an event venue, this is the classiest space in SF.  The courtyard alone is amazing.  Imagine a reception in the Rodin hall?  Amazing.
author: Olivia L.

description:
Took an art class last semester and had to pay a visit to this place. Man, I never knew one could really appreciate art at such a higher lever...and to think, I am just getting started!

Great museum with a wonderful collection... their rooms will take you from Renaissance, Baroque, Rococo, Hellenistic and more. I am just so incredibly sad that I missed  Bernini's St. Teresa of Avila in Divine Ecstacy. 

Went with my BF and my son who was 4 at that time and they both loved it! My son was so engaged and kept asking about all the pieces so this is also a great place to bring kids to introduce them to art. (Although he did have an episode, because I told him the "commercial" story of Cupid, and he said he did not want to get shot by the arrow since he was not ready to fall in love yet).... really, kid? 

Anyways, we made a fake call to Cupid, told him not to shoot my son, and things were all good again. 

I can't wait to go back again and again!
author: Janis M.

description:
In the true spirit of Saturday, Jake and I played "geriatric married couple" and took a stroll around LoH -- it's worth going up there for the view alone -- you're facing the Marin Headlands and GG Bridge on one side and then sweeping views of the city on the other -- a treat.

The art is pretty solid -- I explained it as very representative of certain periods of time (British 19th C, Dutch 17th C), but perhaps not major works by name brand artists -- though they do have some of the most lovely Rodin sculptures I've seen Stateside.  The current Pissarro exhibit is worth a look -- lots of sketches, as well as finished oils -- nice to see the process -- and the write ups accompanying the works are well done, if not a bit repetitive (apparently he was a Sephardic Jew anarchist?)

The actual museum is beautiful -- similar to the Frick in NY but with more marble -- it feels like you're walking around your billionaire uncle's amazing house, who happened to have a thing for sarcophagi and marble busts of Louis XIV. Did I kind of want to suggest we spent the night there? Yes, kind of....in a real way.

Oh, and for the golfers in the crowd, the Presidio golf course abuts the grounds, so you can scoot over there in your golf cart, see some art, sip a nice little soy latte at the cafe, and then get back to tee-off.  

Overall, a hidden gem.
author: Rachel N.

description:
Here's a tip: I recommend seeing the exhibit "Impressionists on the Water" before it ends October 13.  It's a special exhibit that costs $10 extra, but it's worth it.  Join the Docent tour at 11:30.  Great info on 1850s recreational boating on the Seine around Paris, all tied in very nicely with various artists and art movements.  It's worth going just to see Renoir's "Oarsmen at Chatou"

The only other thing that's worth a trip is the Rembrandt portrait of "Joris de Caulerii": http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/legion-of-honor-san-francisco?select=9Su432VQbsbCtHqzCA-v-w#-k4W5k8DZILHuPUXozoFqg
It's in the gallery to the right as you enter.
author: Scott F.

description:
Gorgeous building with amazing architecture. Twice, I came here by myself just to walk around and absorb in the beautiful ambiance.

Note: they do not allow backpacks in here. Wait, no, let me take that back. They do allow backpacks but you have to carry it with your hand. Since my backpack was heavy, I opted to check my bag in at coat check. The guy working in the coat check room was extraordinarily friendly! For such a mundane job, he sure did not make it seem like it. You rock, dude.
author: Annie S.

description:
I like to imagine that I secretly live here and that I just happen to have all this art in my hallways. I mean, it's completely normal to have amazing works, sculptures, and a gift shop in your home, right? 

Admission is free the first Tuesday of the month.
author: Loli L.

description: This is a first class museum. I went  to the Louvre in Paris in 1981 and though smaller, I would rate this museum in the same category. You really need a few days to really study and appreciate the pieces here.
author: Teresa S.

description:
I have enjoyed every exhibit ever attended but The Gaultier was completely  over the top. Absolutely fantastic. It was so brilliant and entertaining. I couldn't take my eyes off the mannequins (the clothes are stunning works of art)  and the drama of the setting was nothing short of genius. 

It was fun to see how many people really dressed for this occasion. It brought out the whimsey and creativity. 

Friday night music, dancing and cocktails...

I think we need to start wearing hats!
author: Diane W.

description:
Came here for a class assignment. Really great collection and location for this place. Parking was so easy; right up front! After checking out all the exhibits; i took a walk around the place! amazing view! Golf course right next door and so was the Golden Gate Bridge. 

Had a blast. BRING YOUR STUDENT ID for discount pricing! The lady at the front desk was nice enough to give me a discount, cause i forgot my ID but i showed her my assignment! THANKS!
author: Ryan L.

description: Saw the Breguet exhibition here and have been here several times before. Always a great place to visit with some excellent art. I especially enjoy still art and they have some great examples here.
author: Will D.

description:
The California Palace of the Legion of Honor is a neat fine art museum, both in terms of their collections and the building itself. And because of its location near the water, it's wonderfully scenic and romantic. No wonder I often see happy couples having their weddings and/or pictures taken.  Parking can be challenging, but is not impossible and there are times that I feel that I have this museum to myself. And somewhere in the middle of my visit, I like their cafe and museum shop. If you want, you can then drive over the the De Young on the same admission. But personally, I'd stay here within this great open and well lit space as long as I could.

And here's today's Historical footnote:

The Legion of Honor was the gift of Alma de Bretteville Spreckels, wife of the sugar magnate and Thoroughbred racehorse owner/breeder Adolph B. Spreckels The building is a three-quarters scale imitation of the Palais de la Légion d'Honneur. It was completed in 1924.

The museum building occupies an elevated site in Lincoln Park with views over the Golden Gate Bridge. Most of the surrounding Lincoln Park Golf Course is on the site of a potter's field called the "Golden Gate Cemetery" that the City had bought in 1867. 

The plaza and fountain in front of the Palace of the Legion of Honor is the western terminus of the Lincoln Highway, the first road across America. The terminus marker and an interpretive plaque are located in the southwest corner of the plaza and fountain, just to the left of the Palace.
author: Eric B.

description:
The Legion is the sister of the De Young, which is located in Golden Gate Park, and personally, I like the De Young better, mostly because it's larger and there's a wide range of exhibits, compared to the Legion.

There are definitely less people at the Legion and I love the paintings, but I've seen most of them (after several trips) and I only come when there's a special exhibit, which are definitely worth coming to. Once or twice is enough, unless you're here for the special exhibits.

Directly to the right of the museum, there is a small trail that leads to a spectacular view of the Golden Gate bridge. Parking is tight. The entrance to Land's End (amazing!) is just down the street if you go east.
author: Kevin L.

description:
I work near here and yet I'm still drawn to it.  The architecture is beautiful and the exhibits within are quite intriguing.

I came here for the Magna Carta and the Pulp Fashion exhibit.

Parking is a bit hard to find and there was a line even on a gloomy Saturday with only a few hours left till closing.  My suggestion is to order your tickets in advance to avoid the long line.  It didn't take too long to get in, but I'm just impatient.

The Magna Carta was amazing.  It still had the original wax seal.  The lettering was beautiful (even though I couldn't make out most of it).

Pulp Fashion-I never knew you can make something look so real and so beautiful out of pulp.  I had a blast comparing the pulp replica to the original artwork through out the museum.  The attention to detail was amazing the and dyes were vibrant.

I have a whole new appreciation for dyes because of this exhibit.

In addition to that there were other exhibits that had Japanese art, pottery, paintings from the baroque era, cabinets with intricate detail and beautiful craftsman ship, etc.  There was even live music upstairs where they featured artwork from Rodin.

All in all it's not the biggest museum, but it is definitely filled with great exhibits.

The view outside is spectacular as well.
author: Michelle S.

description:
I love coming here for their exhibits, permanent collection and just the grounds it sits on.  Coming here while the Legion is engulfed in a cloud of fog really sets the mood and makes for a cozy viewing experience.

I've come here a couple times now and love it even more everytime.  They have great traveling exhibits and works of art that come here and I always enjoy the calm and serene atmosphere.

I had no problem parking here and the staff is ready to help you out with navigating around the building.  It's so wonderful to come here and enjoy this beautiful building and the works of art it has to offer.

A must see if you ever come to SF and have time for a museum.
author: Jackie H.

description:
Back in the day it was easy to come here and find parking. Not so anymore. Came here on a Thursday and was lucky to find someone leaving.

The place is beautiful and the art inside is speechless, since there are rarely any stupid kids running around.
author: M C.

description: This museum is a bit on the smaller side which means it's much more selective in it's offering. We went in specifically for the High Style exhibit which had a great selection in regard to fashion. The recreated rooms were well put together as well however the selection of art presented throughout the museum was lacking. With that being said, if you think of it as more of an art gallery, then it's right on the mark for what it presents.
author: Shauna S.

description:
The museum is small, but beautifully designed. I was told it's supposed to be a little Louvre. I really enjoyed the sculptures and the special exhibit (The Victorian Avant-Garde). I was disappointed that there wasn't an outdoor garden since it seems like the perfect addition.

+ for not being crowded on a Saturday
author: Margaret R.

description:
omg this place is spectacular esp during night time! I even saw an import model taking professional pictures here!! 

There are great exhibits here, but even before you go in, the legion of honor building will blow you away. I can't believe something so magnificent and beautiful is a bit hidden away in sf. I feel like I've transported to Europe when I come here. Definitely take your significant other, parents, and friends here because it is just astonishing.
author: Grace C.

description:
Gorgeous place. I love museums that eeek out "I'm such a legend." The art here is pretty much like the Getty Museum, so I wasn't too impressed, but I still enjoyed looking at them.
