Still want to go back one day and look at everything. I was hoping to see more silly things like at the NY Metropolitan Museum, which would be more fun. 

We came on free museum day, but at 4:30pm, it was already free anyway, so didn't need to use my free pass. 

I see people doing bridal and model shoots in the courtyard.

At 5:15pm (closing time at 5pm), they will herd you out real fast unceremoniously. I heard voices saying "that was rude." I think they should use the loudspeaker system and remind people at 4:45 that the place will be closing in 15 minutes.
author: Linda W.

description:
This place is incredible.  First, I'll start off with the location.  Nestled in northwestern San Francisco, it's perched high above so you get a spectacular view of the Pacific Ocean/the Bay, and it is pretty isolated, so the Legion of Honor looks all the more majestic.

Second, of course, is the overwhelming collection of art they have inside.  I love the layout because it is super organized, and easy to remember if you've been to all of the rooms (simply labeled 1- 15).  There are special exhibits downstairs, but we didn't check those out.  Each of these rooms contained amazing works, and I was amazed to see some original Monet, Picasso, and Van Gogh.  What more can you ask for!

A great rainy/sunny day activity, and the cafe downstairs (I'm going to write a separate review) is fantastic.  Wonderful museum, wonderful location.
author: Mel G.

description: This is one of my favorite places to visit in the city. The view is second to none, and the building itself is easily as beautiful as some of the most renowned museums in Paris, Vienna, Florence, and Moscow (four places I've spent a lot of time). You are greeted as you enter by one of Rodin's "The Thinker" statues, as well as a smaller version of the glass pyramid outside the Louvre. The permanent collection is impressive and includes works by Monet, Degas, Renoir, Rembrandt, Manet, Vermeer, El Greco, and many sculptures by Rodin. There are always interesting things going on, including regular exhibitions. When we were there last weekend, we saw the High Fashion exhibit, which was amazing and included dresses from the 1920s through 1980s by designers such as Dior, Chanel, Halston, LaCroix, Givenchy, YSL, and Charles James. So much fun! The museum also has a lovely gift shop and a cafe with genuinely good food and coffee/tea. It's a great place to spend an afternoon!
author: Cynthia B.

description:
Great place, and as a DeYoung Charter Member I get in free - plus I have a small stack of guest passes if anyone wants to join me.  Great exhibits without the crowds of the DeYoung.  And the views from up there are spectacular.

4 of us went there last week to see Cabaret with Liza Minelli.  Have I confused you?  I went to a museum and saw a movie?  Yes, there is a nice little theatre in the Legion and have a program called Cinema Supper Club.

In honor of the special exhibit, "The State Museums of Berlin", they are having a Berliner Film Fest - showing movies based in Berlin - through November 20.  And for the $10 entrée fee (members) you get the movie and admission into the exhibit.  You can also make dinner reservations in the Café - which I did.

The Exhibit has some great pieces from the 3rd millennium BC to the 18th century AD.  Items from early Asian, the Silk Road, Egypt, and Europe.  My favorite was a Lion Relief from a processional way in ancient Babylon.  Really cool.

The next movies are:
- Grand Hotel - Nov 6
- Run Lola Run - Nov 13
- Wings of Desire - Nov 20
author: Jeff H.

description: Located in Lincoln Park, this museum is definitely not on the main drag, but it offers a vast collection of impressive art as well as an amazing view of the Golden Gate.  I love their special exhibits, but my favorite section has to be the room at the end with the Impressionists.  Parking is free but fairly limited, so get there early, especially on weekends.  From the entry courtyard, featuring Rodin's Thinker, to the positively haunting Holocaust Memorial, there is a variety of art to engage everyone.
author: Lydia C.

description:
Strolling, noshing and gawking play essential roles in the viewing experiences of 21st century visitors to the Impressionists on Water exhibit in this beautiful neo-classical museum. The pastime of viewing such great artists such as Monet, Caillebotte, Signac and others captivate us with their nautical subjects in light-infused compositions. Those of us who own boats and spend much of our time on the water can appreciate the leisurely life style of these boat owning artists.

Of course, boating themes appear frequently in the history of French art, spanning documentary marine paintings of the 18th century, romantic and naturalist works of the mid-19th century, the Barbizon School, the House Painters School, the School of Scandal and even the School of Hard Knocks which has come down to our time in various colors of black and blue. 

We, the post-post-Impressionist viewing public, approach this subject matter with dynamic new digital techniques and emphases such as iPod and Droid Robot non-flash phone cameras and Paint apps including the textured and feathery audio tour machines available at the entrance to this amicable collection.

The fleeting effects of light and shadow lead us inexorably to the transformed gift shop where books on competitive boating and au courant motifs drawn from the artists and America Cup racers' daily lives enchant us and cause us to purchase many artistically thick and heavy collections of prints to be placed on our coffee tables and those of our descendants. 

Note that noshing in the Cafe, where even the lowly hot dog has the name of a French artiste, is a highly recommended and salubrious nautical experience especially if one sits in the plein air courtyard and feeds bun crumbs to the blackbirds (against the rules.) Watch your 2-year old closely lest he SQUEEZE THROUGH the bars of the locked gate forcing you to run at top speed all the way through the museum, out the door and around the building while trying to suppress images of him rolling down the hill and onto the street only to find out that he has now squeezed back through the fence and into the courtyard and is happily chewing on your hot dog and feeding the rest of the bun to the birds.
author: William L.

description:
Legion of Honor is located on a beautiful hill overlooking the sweeping views of SF.

Don't be surprised if you see family portraits or engagement shoots occurring here when you arrive as the architecture of the museum itself is magnificent and grand.

There's also grassy lawn right outside of the museum (on an Indian summer day it would be perfect for a picnic).

Parking can be a challenge but along the side of the museum there are quite a few spaces and there are people leaving all the time.

If you are a BoA card holder, don't miss out on getting in for free on the first weekend of the month.

The artwork inside as others have commented on is Renaisance/medieval (I'm a modern art fan myself) When we went they had Medusa's Head on exhibit and there are rotating special exhibits depending on when you go.
author: Betty C.

description:
As you approach you'll be awed by some of the best views in the city. Not a bad spot for watching the Blue Angels if it's Fleet Week or for fireworks, etc.

Inside the gallery was a little of ho-hum (though better imho than what was on display at the De Young last time I was there). The flow was a little weird, one room you'd have modern stuff and the next would be ancient artifacts. Pet peeve: lack of information, though this is a weakness of most art museums I've ever been to. I think any layman, commoner, or hoi polloi like myself should be able to understand the collection and each individual work without having to have an art history background if we're willing to read. Would it kill you to have more details on the placards? Or less fluff and more meat in the collection summaries? Anyways I digress. 

The Rodin sculptures were nice, though Stanford's collection is cooler (especially at night, see my other review). They have one or two things on display for pretty much any well known artist: da Vinci, El Greco, Dali, you name it.

For all my kvetching it's a pretty nice place to spend an hour or so, especially if you're like me and had never been!
author: Jeremy S.

description:
Day 2 of MWLAWMBF:
The view from the museum is awesome. It has a great view of the Golden Gate bridge - perfect for pictures. The museum itself is very beautiful as well. 

I though I had been here before this visit...and I was right! I came here when I was...like 14? for some leadership conference. It was pretty interesting to me that I could remember some of the pieces from them as well. Of course when I was 14, I didn't appreciate the art as much as I did this time around. 

Much of the artwork is from the 14th century until the 18th century. There aren't too many ancient pieces or modern pieces. It's super fun to go from piece of art of another piece trying to "analyze" it. We saw about 20 different Madonna and Child paintings as well. 

I feel like I wished there was more information about the paintings sometimes. I would look at the painting and there would only be the artist and name of the artwork and nothing else. Sometimes I wish that I would understand more about the pieces while looking at them. 

I think my favorite pieces that we both saw was a piece called "Love and its Counterfeits". I swear we both were staring at it for quite a long time to figure out what the piece was suggesting. 

Love the museum, but sometimes I feel like going to the museum once is enough since the art pieces there will basically be the same.
author: Nina Y.

description:
Out of all the museums in SF, this is the one that amazes me the MOST. If you only have time or chance to visit one museum in SF, this is THE ONE to go to. Very beautiful location, very open outside ground, lots of beautiful pictures to be taken here. This place makes me happy and excited in more ways than one. I have no idea what it is. They have painting, sculptures, and very unique exhibitions here, which I can come back to and still be amazed. 

For me, it's mainly about the sculptures! There is something about them that accurately captures the essence of people of ancient times. I stare long enough and I swear I can picture living back in those time era, like a dejavu or something. I don't believe in reincarnation or anything like that, but I do truly appreciate the beauty of art and the impact it has in world history. 

I haven't had a chance to come back here again since my first time, but I will love to do so again soon. Don't get lost here!
author: Andrew I.

description:
What a beautiful museum. It's architecture and placement are sublime, and of course, the works inside are pretty good too.

Some of my favorite features are the Rodin sculptures and all the French victorian rooms (which I believe are permanent fixtures.) Also, as a Classics major, I appreciate the modest collection of greek/roman pieces in the downstairs section.

I don't go up as often as I'd like because it's a bit out of the way unless you live around that part of the city. But there are a lot of great exhibitions here and it's really worth the trek. Also, because it's so far out, I feel like it gets a slightly less tourist vibe than some of the other museums in the city (which is definitely a plus.)
author: Jon T.

description:
Coolest building in the city?  Yes.
Nice selection and presentation of Rodin?  Yes.
Compete with MET (http://www.yelp.com/biz/jVncyqXwlx_D9f2xZn05tg), Chicago (http://www.yelp.com/biz/AkcZ1fUyB3RocKLYGFu20Q), or MFA in Boston (http://www.yelp.com/biz/8xuUthCjEwYO-40S7FPMqQ)?  No.  Size and collection is far smaller.

However, Monet Exhibit was world class.  I'm not an art guru, so I don't understand religious art (pre 18th Century work) nor understand why Rodin sculptures are so special.  Therefore, although they only have 1.5 rooms of late 19th Century European art which I like, keeping a close eye on special exhibits may be the way to go. 

First Tues of every month is FREE!  On free days, they have discounted prices to special exhibits.  For example, Monet exhibit normally $15 was only $5 on FREE day.
author: トモ T.

description:
One of my favorite places to be in San Francisco when I am in one of my pensive ish moods. I am definitely the furthest thing from an art connoisseur but there is just something about this place, perhaps the nostalgic Louvre-esque feel or the gorgeous location, that draws me back again and again.

I have some favorite pieces here that I start to miss like old friends and need to visit. Rodin's sculptures, for example, Monet's Water Lilies, and Bouguereau's "The Broken Pitcher" are some of my favorites. The period rooms and artifacts are amazing and always give me the chills! It's also extremely cool to watch the conservators work on restorations (I think they are doing Salon Dore period room now). I also chanced upon an organ concert on a Sunday afternoon. 

I really enjoyed the Gifts from the Gods: Art and the Olympic Ideal exhibition they had over the summer and the Impressionists on the Water (still going till Oct. 13!) was fun to see, too. Make sure to bring your student ID and show your muni transfer or clipper card for a discounted ticket! (#18 Bus) I only wish the museum cafe didn't suck so much, but what can you expect from a museum cafe...? There's plenty of great eateries just down the hill from the museum, though, which I guess is another plus! Five Stars for this awesome place.
author: Ariana O.

description:
The views and landscape surrounding the Legion are almost as beautiful as the pieces of art inside... I love this museum. Every time I go, I notice how friendly the employees are and how happy all of the visitors seem. It's more than worth the $10. It never seems too crowded which makes it more appealing to me. 

There are beautiful collections here - lots of Rodin sculptures and a traveling Matisse exhibit from MOMA (while it's under renovation). My favorites: Columbus as a Boy, The Broken Pitcher, Portrait of a Lady. The porcelain gallery downstairs shouldn't be missed - gorgeous lavender walls and rows of old European vases, dishes and tea sets. 

Swing by their cafe for some really tasty food (with lots of healthy options).  Eat it outside on a nice day.

I am so lucky to have this museum in my neck of the woods! 

Tip: Organ music on Saturdays and Sundays at 4pm
author: Christina K.

description:
Great little gem of a museum in SF! 

The actual museum is gorgeous! There's also a great view of the golden gate bridge from the museum.

$10 for general admission.

Free parking, definite plus.
author: Kim-van T.

description:
Beautiful museum in a stunning location.

The Legion of Honor is one of my favorite places in San Francisco.   I've been a member for many years, enjoying some incredible special exhibits over that time.  A few of my favorites -- Marie Antoinette, Japanese Woodblock Prints and Lalique.  The permanent collection includes, Monet, Picaso, Salvadore Dali, Faberge, French period rooms and much more.  This is a lovey museum with a lot to offer, including its location overlooking the Pacific Ocean and Bay.
author: Donna P.

description:
The museum in itself is so beautiful and large! I went specifically to see the Flemish exhibit which was an absolute feast for the eyes! The audio-guide was a great tool and really to the point. The virtual presentation at the entrance of the exhibition really helps focus the visitor. The permanent exhibition is huge and a tad confusing at first (so many periods, so many rooms lined up) but you quickly get the hang of it. 
I like the diversity in the museum, in terms of styles and periods (not native, or Asian art unfortunately although there is currently a small ukiyoe exhibit). I wish they could add a bit more about the history of the Museum in itself: how come there are so many Rodins? Why the French flag?

I recommend going early, and I should note that the tall Asian gentleman at the admissions desk on Saturday mornings is a sweet as they come..

The golf park in which it is in is massive and beautiful as well, a great walk! Visiting the park and going to the museum actually makes for a great outing! Should you be hungry, the brand new Fresh & Easy at 32nd and Clement offers some delicious fresh food. I haven't been to the Museum cafe yet tough..
author: Emeline V.

description:
Walking into the Legion of Honor is like stepping into a European plaza. I loved the pillars and the thinker statue. Plus the grounds and view, I'm thinking I need to come back and have a little photo session. 

I came to see the Pulp Fashion exhibition. WOW! Simply amazing. I couldn't get over the amount of detail and how intricate some of the pieces were,  especially the lace collars.
author: Christy Z.

description: I came here when I was a wee little high schooler, with my French class. I don't remember anything except the outside and the view. Now that I've moved back, I've loved climbing up here from the beach, a beautiful and leisurely little hike. There's a huuuuge Rodin collection, lots of classics. I especially enjoyed the little exhibit on A Swarm, A Flock, A Host: A Compendium of Creatures, though, near the cafe. It's not a big museum, but I spent more time here than at the de Young.
author: Vivian H.

description:
The Legion of Honor is a real treasure for the city of San Francisco. Not only does it feature the SF Summer Jazz Series, it also has the best permanent exhibits and visiting exhibits I have ever seen. I recently saw the Man Ray / Lee Miller exhibit and learned a lot about that tumultuous love affair / friendship that lasted for almost 30 years.

This is a "must see" place for out of town visitors. Love this place!!
author: Courtney S.

description: Was hiking near by and asked if I could use the restroom. Said no only ticket holder. Thanks for nothing
author: Zuhaib S.

description:
A beautiful museum in a beautiful location, with an excellent collection. It really is a must visit when in San Francisco. 
The collection is varied, with a particularly good selection of impressionist works, and of course a large number of Rodin's works.
A lovely day out, especially when the weather is fine.
author: Bob S.

description: If you want to see SOME nice paintings and not being the whole day in a museum, this one is for you. I don't recommend you the concerts because the walls are not real and the acoustic is horrible.
author: Francisco T.

description:
Went here today with a group of friends after going to the de young museum, this place is scenic with great views of the city, the golden gate bridge, the Marin headlands and of course the legion of honor building. The museum is full of paintings mainly European with a few sculptures mixed in. I liked this place but I liked the De Young Museum better. But you HAVE to check this place out at least once.

Mp's take: check it out.
author: Maninderpal M.

description:
An amazing museum. 

$10 is kinda steep, but the architecture is outstanding (see my pictures).

I'm not an art connoisseur but the building alone is worth a visit. The parking situation could be better, but not that bad. 

 It's strange to see classics in person. This is a very traditional museum so don't go expecting to see modern art (see: SF Moma for that).

Don't forget to walk around the museum and check out their views of the bay.
author: Carlos A.

description: if you ever have a chance for an event here, makes for a perfect venue.  ie. TEDMED. uplighting and pin spotting worked beautifully.  food catered from the cafe was actually pretty good.
author: Rob C.

description: Went to see the Impressionists on the Water exhibit (which was wonderful).  Gorgeous facility.  I had no idea it had the Rodin collection it has.  Worth going just for that.
author: Roger Y.

description:
This was a wonderful way to spend a few hours...wondering the exhibit halls and taking in all the beautiful art work and sculptures.  Not being a member, the general admission was reasonable.  They do give discounts to seniors and students, and if you have a Bank of America credit card, you can get in free on Sunday.  The special (on loan) exhibits are an extra charge.  Parking is free in the area around the museum, but it does fill up quickly.  I suggest you get there close to opening (9:30 am) or you have to take your chances on someone pulling out as you arrive.

What a treat to see some of the famous pieces here.  You don't have to travel to Europe to take in these beauties.  We did not choose to enter the current special exhibit (High Style), but there was plenty to take in with the general admission ticket.  A good representation of art and sculpture.  The museum building itself is beautiful to look at, too.  Don't miss the small Holocaust memorial at the side of the parking lot, beside the big fountain.
author: Kathy G.

description:
My brother made fun of me endlessly for wanting to go here. We have a pretty strict "no culture" code in my family. 

I decided to go when he was at work, but of course the museum was closed (Monday... why can't my job be closed on Mondays?), which is just as well because I'm a cheap ass and going to museums sucks enough as it is, let alone when you are, uh, alone.

I mainly just wanted to see the Thinker, and perhaps take an inappropriate photograph with said cast/statue.

I was both thrilled and disappointed. I was thrilled because a) There was like nobody there. Mainly because it was closed, b) I could see the statue and it was really powerful in person. It made me think. I was sad because the statue was in an outside courtyard on your way into the museum, and the courtyard was gated and locked, mainly because they were closed. I mean I get it. I understand why they have to keep it locked up when they are closed. Mainly because of people like me. But still. It was like he was in jail. Seriously. I think he is thinking about how to tunnel the eff out of there.

Walking the rest of the grounds was fun. Some really awesome statues. A fountain. Lots of cool trees. Close to the Holocaust Memorial. And when I say close, I mean the memorial is, like, in the parking lot of this mueseum.

I hate golf, but I've never wanted to do anything as bad in my life as I wanted to play golf when I saw that golf course. It seriously looked like a freaking fairy tale golf course. 

I despise everything French, and wonder why we feel the need to copy everything the Frenchies do. Other than that, this would be at the top of my list for places to go in SF.
author: T. M.

description:
This is one of the best museums in San Francisco.  It's a lovely place where you can walk right outside onto the golf green and walk a few more steps and see the breathtaking views of the Marin headlands.  

As you approach the front of the museum (on a day where Bank of America sponsors admission --first Saturdays of each month, I believe), you're greeted by the perfect place after place to take photos.

Be sure to bring your camera, and plan to spend at least 30minutes walking around the space.  The exhibits are often very interesting --from mummies to Cartier jewelry.

The curators and museum staff are helpful and friendly, while the printout guides are also logical and informative.
author: Jennifer Y.

description: 5 stars. Really. This museum is well organized, extremely informative, and has a great staff. For about $14, you can spend an hour or all day here soaking up all the art. Beautiful bay view, outstanding photography opportunities, and great parking. Nothing here not to like. Wear comfy shoes: you're going to walk a lot.
author: Lou B.

description: This is an absolutely gorgeous art museum with several pieces by Rodin, Monet, and others.  The admission fee is very reasonable for the SF Bay area at $10 ($20 if you want to see the special exhibit, which I recommend!). You will need a couple of hours to make your way through it all.  When finished, be sure to explore the immaculate and lovely grounds.  By the way, if you are visiting the Bay area, the road leading to the Legion of Honor hosts some awesome views of the GG Bridge and the Bay, so prepare to stop for pictures!
author: Rose L.

description:
This museums by far is the best place to visit in San Francisco
Those of you that are Alfred Hitchcock fans, might have seen this in his film "Vertigo"
Amazing grounds and places to walk even before you step inside the building.
Take a good half hour or even an hour and walk the grounds to see how many spots you can take in the views of the Golden Gate Bridge.

The Legion of Honor has constant changing exhibits to keep you coming back.
It's an amazing place to see all different works of art.
Take your time and grab and audio tour device and really get into what your looking at.
Those of you that have IPads/iPods can download audio tours from their main website. For a fee of course. But it's worth it if your a constant visitor.

There are benches to sit on and really observe all the works of art.
Very peaceful place.
Rain or shine. It's a terrfic way to spend an afternoon.

Those of you that don't want to leave for lunch or are having trouble finding a place to eat that's close by, The Legion of Honor has a nice cafe to eat inside of.
That way your not interrupting your museum experience.
author: John S.

description: This place is my personal favorite place in San Francisco! It has the best scenery and walk combination. I would highly recommend coming here and walk along the entire trail, from end to end.
author: Sam K.

description:
I think everything about this museum is so cool: the building, the bay views, the surrounding park, the artwork and the special exhibits.

I was recently here for the "Cartier and America" exhibit, which was amazing.  It's a thorough look at Cartier's influence on American style and culture in the 20th century.  One can see the detail that went into each intricate piece of jewelry.  From brooches, to tiaras, to earrings, to necklaces and watches, it was a very impressive showing of art.  Some of the most memorable pieces included yellow diamond and emerald-encrusted crocodiles and a diamond-encrusted snake.  One of the most creative pieces were the mystery clocks, which seemed to show the clock hands suspended in midair.  I was here for 3 hours and didn't even have time to see the rest of the museum since the exhibit has so many pieces to see.

Besides special exhibits like "Cartier and America", they also have a really good permanent collection, which mainly focuses on European art and ranges in styles from traditional, to impressionist to cubism.  The building itself is really cool and the surrounding grounds includes impressive views of the bay and the Golden Gate Bridge.

The cost is bit much ($20 for an adult), but you can save some money with your MUNI pass or transfer ticket or try to go on a free day of the month.  It's definitely worth it.
author: Ken G.

description:
What can I say that hasn't already been said? 

Wonderful collection, amazing exhibitions, pleasant cafe with good food and not-so-good coffee, friendly staff, attractive gift shop, and gorgeous architecture.

Drove up from OC to see the Japanese Print exhibit and I was moved to tears. The Japanesque exhibit was also intriguing, though I much prefer the more traditional items.

The Legion of Honor is the perfect size with an amazingly selective collection. It's not so extensive that you become over whelmed and exhausted. After leaving the de Young to view the Post Impressionist exhibit on loan from the Musee d'Orsay, I would easily say that the de Young is like the Huntington whereas the Legion is like the Norton Simon, arts and artifacts respectively.

Beautiful. That's all I can say.
author: Yuki M.

description:
Location, location, location: you can't get better than perched atop a hill with a spectacular view of the Golden Gate Bridge and the city.

But substance matters, too, and the Legion of Honor delivers.  Whereas the de Young has an amazing American art collection, the Legion of Honor focuses on European art (my preference).  From Rodin's tortured sculptures to Dali's surreal portraiture, the permanent collection has a lot to offer.

The special collections, though, are even better: I've seen the sparklegasmic Cartier display (and would like to live there), Marie Antoinette (where a guy walked up to me and handed me a piece of paper with his phone number, then scampered off without saying anything), the paper gowns exhibit, Pisarro's People, the Mourners and Bernini's Medusa (possibly my favorite), ancient Roman mosaics, the MAGNA CARTA (still bitter they were not selling Magna Carta merchandise)... basically, the stuff of history/art/legal nerds' dreams lives here, and I've been lucky enough to see most of it.

The best time to go is early on a weekday morning (not the free day), when it's quiet and energetic children don't interfere with your serene contemplation re: how that Cartier tiara really should be yours.
author: Jennie K.

description:
Went for the special exhibit on the fashion designs of Isabelle de Borchgrave which was so awesome! Plus, we got in for free. First Tuesdays are free...nice!
I love the building and the interior and exterior. 
The artwork that is always there is the old baroque style stuff. Big ornate frames etc.  Not my fave but ok.
Enjoyed the Teapot and China collection. Very cool.
And yes, I enjoy the area so much. It is a nice place to hang out.
author: Cindi W.

description: Although it is a fraction of the size of the Louvre,this place offers all you need for a great afternoon!  The building is beautiful (inside and out), ample parking, spectacular view of the Golden Gate.  Nice display rooms plus a decent collection of artwork including Rodin, Raphael (touring), Renoir, Manet, Monett, Degas ...
author: Ray L.

description:
I probably shouldn't talk this place up.  One of the best things about it is how few people are there.  I'm always amazed that a place this amazing isn't packed to the gills.  

I'm not going to add anything that isn't in other reviews.  The permanent collection is amazing.  They have some great special exhibits.  The building itself is a work of art. The view is one of the best in the city.

The astonishing thing is that they have plenty of free parking.  That's practically unheard of in San Francisco.

If you have the opportunity to spend a few hours here, you really should do it.  Just don't do it on a day when I'm there.  I love the practically empty feel.
author: Phillip A.

description:
This is a local favorites for wedding pictures or just professional photography.  It has a breathtaking view of the Bay and right next to a golf course.  This is one of the few places you can catch fresh air in the city.

The last time I came here was on Sunday 8/29 when they were exhibiting the Impressionist Paris collection as well as featuring a free organ recital by John Walko.  The museum was built to allow daylight into many of its exhibition rooms.  I learned last Sunday as well that there there was a majestic organ built into the infrastructure of the museum.  The organ itself is over 70 years old with 4,500 pipes controled by a single console with much too many buttons for my comprehension.  Though not a church goer, I have learned to appreciate the powerful sound of the organ.  It takes quite a lot to be an organist, having to play with both hands and feet.  It was incredible.

This is a great place to get some fresh air and a bit of culture.
author: Annie N.

description:
Okay, so this happens to be an awesome museum, but I was here as a Hitchcock aficionado.  This was one of the sites they shot for Vertigo and that alone made my day.

See Vertigo.  Then come here.

Oh yes, and enjoy the art :-)
author: Stephen H.

description: It took me 8 years of living in San Francisco before we finally made it out here, prompted by the scenes from Vertigo. I had never really been sure what this museum was all about, and it turned out to be a pleasant surprise. We looked at all sorts of different furniture and sculptures, along with plenty of paintings - something for everyone. One of the highlights is just the location - it was foggy when we arrived but bright and clear by the time we left. I just wish there were clearer paths around the location for strolling.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Likes: Love the courtyard, especially on a sunny day.  Perfect place for photos and apparently a popular spot for wedding photos.  Friendly security guard who explained this cool painting of women where one of the women is actually a man in disguise if you can pinpoint him.  Free first Tuesdays.  Outside you can see the Golden Gate Bridge.

Dislikes: Not a whole lot to see compared to other museums but the outside makes up for it.
author: Karen M.

description:
I seriously considered not going here on my last day in SF, thinking it might waste my time and money that I could be spending in Haight-Ashbury.  

In the end... I am glad I went.  It is a beautiful museum filled with gorgeous art pieces separated by rooms (which makes it easier to go through), a mummy, and at this point, Cartier jewelry.  

I thoroughly enjoyed it and would recommend to anybody.
author: Jessica P.

description:
I came here on a weekend with my friend who is a Bank of America cardholder. (Tip: if you're a Bank of America cardholder, you get free admission first weekend of each month!) Even though it was a free day, the museum did not feel crowded at all, which is a nice contrast from all the other museums that suddenly explode with people on designated free days (but I mean, that's reasonable -- who doesn't like to save a couple bucks here and then?!). When we went, the Impressionism exhibit was up, and there was a very impressive Matisse gallery as well! I was very excited. :) Overall, the museum had a nice variety of paintings/sculptures and great exhibition information regarding the artists, but none of the big name pieces. There was also very few Asian art (but perhaps that's why there is the Asian Art Museum a couple blocks away...). The docents and staff members were also extremely nice and gracious. 

The view from the Legion of Honor looks onto the Golden Gate Bridge and the Bay -- absolutely fantastic if you are here on a sunny day! Also,there is plentiful free 4hr parking, some spots just may be farther away. I loved my visit here, and will definitely be back again when there is a new exhibit!
author: Hurnan V.

description: Great museum. Have some amazing sculptures. I would have loved more paintings that were not boring portraits. As a gallery it was well put together.
author: Mike A.

description: It is a good, eclectic museum, that has everything from Egyptians to the impressionists, not a huge collection, but good as an introductory experience. It feels a little bit like it looks, very grand and on the posh side.  I went there on a Friday with my children and was reminded of going to an opera or at least a very good theater show. The place was full of older, well dressed connoisseurs. I felt out of place in my sneakers there, so a tip: dress nicely if not fitting in bothers you.
author: Karina D.

description:
Not to disrespect my hometown of Seattle but the museums in San Francisco are some of the best I've seen on the West Coast. The Legion of Honor is no exception. 

The first thing you see is "The Thinker" by Rodin in the courtyard. For some reason, I thought it was a very nice looking copy so asked a museum employee where the "real" statue was. Fine arts faux pas right there. Also didn't realize there are several casts of this statue all over the world, everyone wins! 

Since there was barely an hour to closing, my friends and I got to slip in for free. They were displaying Bernini's tortured cast of Medusa as one of their special exhibitions, originally on display at the Capitoline Museum in Rome (where I was lucky enough to see it for the first time studying abroad). Two other special exhibits were "The Mourners" and "Pisarro's People" (the latter for an extra fee). 

By far, my favorite rooms housed an impressive Rodin sculpture collection and gorgeous paintings by instantly recognizable French Impressionists, both extremely beautiful and distinctive of their era. Their permanent collection alone is impressive for a small museum. 

It's a relatively small place and I was able to see everything I wanted in the hour we had left. In addition to the wonderfully grand name, it's less stuffy than most arts museums and they have a mini glass pyramid homage to the Louvre out front. Plus they allow non-flash photography in most of the exhibits. Love their style and would pay a second, third and fourth visit in a heartbeat.
author: Faith Y.

description:
Oh, come on.  

You don't need a review for this place--what are you doing here, reading this?  The Legion of Honor is a San Fransisco landmark, a local gem.  It is seriously one of the most beautiful spots in the Bay area and it's a perfect little getaway from the city.  Come with a loved one to canoodle or come alone to reflect.  Either way, you'll leave feeling better for having stopped by.
author: Alina M.

description:
It blows my mind how surprised people are by the art in the permanent collection. I know the Legion of Honor is small, but it packs an impressive collection. 

PERMANENT COLLECTION: Here's a sampler of what you can expect to see (and recognize if you've taken an art appreciation class) when you visit:

- Waterlilies by Claude Monet (1914)
- St. John the Baptist - El Greco (1600)
- St. Francis Venerating the Crucifix by El Greco (1595)
- Trotting Horse by Edgar Degas (1881)
- The Grand Canal by Claude Monet (1908)
- The Eiffel Tower by Georges Seurat (1889)
- A whole Rodin collection (not as good as the Cantor in Palo Alto), including The Thinker and The Kiss

Other big names include Rembrandt, Gainsborough, Jacques-Louis David, Renoir, Cézanne, just to name a handful. 

CAFE: I love this cafe so much. They theme their menus around the special exhibits. Most recently, they offered Dutch fare to go with the current Dutch and Flemish Masterworks from the Rose-marie and Eijk Van Otterloo Collection exhibition. Despite the fact that the specifics on the menu change, the quality never waivers, and you can expect perfect pastries and sandwiches each visit. I had the Quiche Lorraine, and I'll be bold and say it was probably in the top 5 quiches I've had in my lifetime.
author: Jennifer B.

description: YOU CAN SEE THE GOLDEN GATE BRIDGE! It's situated in a beautiful part of San Francisco, where the scenery itself is an art work. Inside, there are many classical works of art, French impressionism, Christian stuff, etc. I really liked them all. Very inexpensive to get in: $8 for adults, and $6 if you are a student. Please take your kids, neighbors, family, and dates there!
author: Iljin C.

description:
The Legion is my favorite museum - the Rodin sculpture collection is unrivaled - if they moved the mesoamerican collection to here, it would have everything I love.  The building is fantastic - and there are views and trails to enjoy all around the museum.  

Members get to enjoy member's evenings with live organ concerts - it's just a really civilized, thoughtful way to spend your time.
author: Jenn C.

description:
I hardly knew of this place until I got a membership for the museums of San Francisco.  I now try to get here for every major exhibit.  Now on display are The Mourners, PIssarro's People, and Medusa.  And you will not turn to stone looking at the head.  

The special exhibits can be very good, and worth a look.  The permanent collection is nothing to sneeze at, but go for the special exhibits.  No matter when you go there will always be something to see.

You don't need timed tickets to visit, and can just show up.  Parking can be hard at times and you may need to hike a bit.  Make a picnic and enjoy the great views, when it's not fogged in.
author: Michael M.

description:
This museum has a number of nice pieces. It's not nearly as large as some others around the country, such as the Met or the Art Institute. However, that's not necessarily a bad thing since large museums can get overwhelming. It was nice to cover most of the museum in an hour or two, and then go grab lunch.

However, this review is mainly for the staff and their incompetence. We stopped by last weekend on a Bank of America free weekend (+1 star). We had rushed to get to the museum in time for the 12pm European highlights tour. After getting our tickets, we went over to the membership/information counter to ask them where to meet for the tour. In response, we got a shitload of attitude and condescension from booth guy. It was weird. I think he was irked that we weren't members, but it was like he had forgotten that Information was part of his booth responsibilities. He kept emphasizing that we needed tickets over and over again (which we already had). No shit we need tickets. Finally, they seemed slightly unsure of themselves, but told us to wait in the main lobby for the tour.

After checking out a few of the sculptures, we returned to the lobby a few minutes before the hour. A handful of people seemed to also be waiting for the tour. And wait we did. About 5 minutes after the hour, a docent still hadn't shown up. We checked in with the staff. Initially, they told us just to keep waiting. Then we checked in again. Apparently the docent had signed in and was around, but was running late.

A few minutes later, the staff told us that it was really a 12:15 tour and that the docent really wasn't late, but rather, was "on time." What the fuck? Tell that to your fucking website and sign above the membership counter, both of which still say 12:00. Tell that to your dumbasses that failed to mention that to us earlier, when we had asked about the 12 o'clock tour. Tell that to the 5-10 of us who wasted the last 20 minutes of our lives waiting for a docent who never showed.

We gave it another 10 minutes, and then decided to check out the museum on our own. However, by then, I was just so miffed by their incompetence that it was difficult to enjoy the art.

+1 star for the Bank of America free weekend
+4 stars for the art
-4 stars for the staff

Message to the museum management: Please get your shit together and teach your staff/volunteers to be a little more professional.
author: Nathan C.

description:
I remember the first time I visited this museum.  My daughter, Joy took me here to see the Monet art exhibit.  Since then, I have taken quite a number of out-of-town visiting friends to view all the different art exhibits displayed at this museum.

I hope one day I will be able to rent this entire space for my film screening party.
author: Shirley M. J.

description:
Amazing view. Amazing exhibits. Absolutely beautiful in every single way. I look forward to coming back.

Also enjoyed the Holocaust sculpture scene they have outside in the front to the right towards the ocean. It's surrounded by a gorgeous view and beautiful foliage. I enjoyed it in an appreciative respectful way for my ancestors that have fallen, a very strong emotion evoked appreciation for the museum for this permanent display: Never Say There Is No Hope is the moto for this from a Jewish song. Definetly sparked alot in me
author: Brittainie B.

description:
Small but spectacular! 

Never been to a wedding here, but this place would be a great venue for one! 

The art doesn't stop when you exit the museum. What a gorgeous view of San Francisco! Looking up at Rodin's sculptures with the blue sky and Museum in the background is just magical. I don't know why Tim Tebow gets all the credit for his little pose, it was totally ripped off from "The Thinker." I guess Tebowing is easier to say than Thinker-ing. 

The admission price may seem steep for such a small museum, but the parking is free and there is some solid art to check out! Even if you are not an art enthusiast, they have at least one piece from all the big names. 

I'm not going to deduct any stars for the security who was tailing my friend and I after departing an Art History tour. I turned down the wrong walkway & it became obvious that she was in fact, following my ass. We just laughed about it & she left us alone as we checked out the Japanesque exhibit. 

Next time I'm going to check out the cafe.
author: Tiffany B.

description:
This place is a gem. I bought a membership to the de Young last year when the Picasso exhibit came. It's definitely a bargain, as it includes free access to both museums for me and a guest. 

Yesterday my aunt told me about this incredible organ that is there. She had always wanted to hear it, so I said let's go! I'm so glad we did. 

Everything -- from the grounds and the views of the City to the exhibits, including the collection of wood engraved illustrated children's books; one of Monet's Water Lilies; the antique furniture; ancient ceramics; and porcelain collection, to getting to see and hear the largest organ in the entire world live (4700 pipes and all) in its greatness -- made this place a remarkable find. 

I would definitely go again. Visit on a Saturday. That's when they play it, at 4:00pm. 

The Verdict: one of my new favorite places to visit in the City.
author: Cara S.

description:
I am giving the museum 4 stars and the cafe 2 stars so it evens out to three, I guess.

The museum admission price of $11 is perfectly reasonable given the small size of the museum. This is no DeYoung, but it is has some nice exhibits. I particularly enjoyed the Olympics exhibit. The grounds themselves are beautiful, situated in Land's End, a wonderful wooded area on the SF coast just south of the Presidio. I even saw a wedding taking place on the grounds, and almost felt envious ;P. 

We didn't end up going to the Louis XIV special exhibit because it was WAY more expensive. I love that the museum offers free general admission tix to Bank of America card holders but I hope that they expand that same offering to other banks in the future. 

Lunch in the cafe was OUTRAGEOUSLY expensive. Obviously, I knew it was going to be a bit pricey but sheesh. The food itself was OK. Eat before you come here.

Got lucky with a parking spot right in front. Given all the honking and angry motorists it seems like parking here is a hassle.

We stayed for the symphonic organ concert at 4:00. It was a beautiful concert (especially loved the Phantom of the Opera suite) but because of how the organ pipes are arranged in the walls, it sounded like most of the music was coming from the right hand side of the room. So, even though I was sitting directly behind the organist, the music sounded like it was coming from a speaker system where the left hand speaker had stopped functioning. Oh well.
author: Theresa K.

description: Its beautiful.  Free parking.  Beautiful art.  Amazing view.  Very nice docents.  This is a treasure, a majestic experience, ruined only by soccer moms pushing strollers of screaming children.  When your kid is old enough to not scream, feel free to bring him or her.  Until then, don't f'up my experience of enjoying the serene environment.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
Any place that lets me get close enough to see the brushstrokes of Monet's water lily or Picasso, Dali, Van Gogh, etc.

This is a manageable (not overwhelming to the senses) art museum that lets you REALLY experience the art - you can get close enough to it to see what the artist did.  

Love it here.
author: Cameron M.

description: Its a pretty place to walk around look at some old things. I wasn't particularly impressed with the collection though. If you can carry a conversation regarding art and history then its not a bad place to take a date after a meal in the outer Richmond. I'd likely be bored pretty quickly if I went alone and I would only go back if there was a particularly special exhibit.
author: Huy V.

description: We love this museum it's in a beautifull location. The architecture is fantastic. We went to see the Houghton House exhibit. We did the Docent tour it was free and very informative. Worth it for sure. If you are a veteran ask  about a discount. Plan on about 4 to 5 hrs to see whole museum. Cafe was expensive but food was good. We shared a dish. Special tea for exhibit was WAY OVER PRICED FOR WHAT YOU WOULD GET. 50 dollers is too much. Only real thing i thought was silly. We didn't get it. But we ordered a chicken dish that my wife really enjoyed. Upstairs paintings were FANTASTIC. Monet paintings Roden sculptures and others. Wear comfortable shoes and pace yourself to really enjoy everything.
author: Simon H.

description:
Kids today have it so easy. They wanna see porn, all they have to do is fire up their Macbooks and launch Safari and you are seconds away from ending up in a confessional this Saturday. But back in my day, to catch a glimpse of girls sans clothes I had to travel half way around the world.

The year was 1986, I was 12 and had never seen naked boobs in full motion. I was too young for R rated movies and there was no internet. So really my only access to viewing porn was whenever I was at my friends house and checking out his big brothers stash of Playboy. 

That summer my parents entered a triathlon in Roth, Germany. We would be tagging along with one of my dad's coworkers and his 14 year old son. I had never heard of Roth before, but I did know it was a small town and not to expect too much excitement. 

Race Day.

The day came, and my parents knowing that spending 10 plus hours watching a triathlon wouldn't be the most exciting thing ever left me my dad's friends son together back at the hotel.

 "Now don't you boys get in any trouble ok?"

My friend and I hanging out playing a hand held video game (Yes kids, we had video games back then) when he looks up and says to me. "you know, there is a theater in town that shows X-rated movies"

Ok, I'm listening.

He goes on to tell me that this being Europe, that the locals are much more open when it comes to nudity and that anyone at any age can walk into a movie theater and see naked ladies.

So where might this X rated movie theater be?

"It's just a few blocks away, they are showing a matinee at 1:00 we could go and be back before our parents return and they would never know"

I must admit, I was feeling very nervous and thought something might go wrong. The German Police could be planning a sting and arrest us as we try and purchase tickets. But I weighed my options and boobies won out.

Just as my friend had promised, the theater didn't bat an eye and sold us tickets. It was assigned seating and took a few minutes to find our digs. At this point I started hyperventilating. I mean in just a few minutes I am going to see real live boobs! 

But, something was just not right. I take a look around the theater and see quite a few families sitting around us. Moms with their young children seated just a few feet from us. I started to think that German parents were the coolest parents on the planet. I mean taking your kids to a porn flick? How rad is that?

The lights dim and the movie starts. Long story short, it was an animated flick about a girl and her missing balloon. And no, the girl was not naked.

Fast forward a few years later, and today it's historical documents and Impressionist art that gets me hot. And Tomorrow the Legion of Honor will be porn central as they will have in it's temporary collection an original copy of the Magna Carta.
author: V B.

description:
bigger than I thought, with nice Monet and Van Gogh paintings, french furnitures and Rome gallery
there was a Organ concert on the weekend afternoon
also the building itself is a piece of art
author: Peter W.

description:
I can't say how it is if you have more time. We came here after doing part of the Land's End trail and were happily surprised to find out that if you get there after 4:30 pm, it is free (unless you want to do a special exhibit). Now, it closed at 5:15 which didn't leave us much time to walk around, but just enough to explore and see a lot of art! We really liked the Olympic exhibit which had super old coins and artifacts as well as more modern pieces.

If you are in the area, you should definitely check it out. The building itself (the outside) is also really cool for pictures.
author: Aly M.

description:
We went here for Mother's Day.. and when we got here found out to our pleasant surprise.. you get in free on Mother's Day! That includes *everyone,* not just Mothers! This place was obviously *meant* to be a museum.. Each room has a nice high vaulted roof and skylights that let in good light for viewing the art. As with the deYoung, I like it that you can get your face right up next to most of the oils and get a nice inkling of how the long-departed painter must have felt as he was doing the original.. Loved the Rodins ... and for Mother's Day they even had a good-time jazz band entertaining among the Rodins.. 

We managed to score some complimentary tickets to the downstairs exhibit of Tiffany and Faberge objects.. T'was interesting.. didn't take my breath away.. even though I was viewing objects of exquisite craftmanship and mind-boggling expensive materials... I was just thinkin' as I looked at all the ornate eggs and punchbowls and combs, and perfume bottles.. "WHY?" .. what sort of life would a person have to lead to find the pleasure derived from the acquisition and possession of these extravagant objects fulfilling and emotionally worth what they paid for them?

I could not imagine living such a life.. Better.. my own life.. as ordinary as it is.. I imagine it is in many ways much richer than theirs.. Although I can also imagine some Rothschild heir.. reading this.. and snickering.. "that old workerbee middle-class fool doesn't know what he's missing.."
author: Weide Z.

description: Great and beautiful place to take pictures. I would bring people from out of town to come here.
author: Henry S.

description: Beautiful place, breathtaking views, easy parking, wonderful customer service in both gift shops and amazing art. I was in heaven today for 2 whole hours. I almost fainted when I seen the El Grecos. And even thought I'm not a huge Monet fan I must say it was one of my favorite parts of the museum. The cafe was clean, nice and served good strong mochas. I cannot wait to go back!
author: Dee L.

description: Saw some Dutch realist paintings from when the Netherlands controlled the world, whenever that happened. The Jan van Eyck paintings were of course marvelous, and the Legion of Honor is exquisite. They have a Heifetz violin which my mom almost had a heart attack seeing, since she played violin, so that is a conversation starter for her anytime she hears of the Legion of Honor. This place is by the de Young, so might as well get some culture and stop by there too.
author: Kevin C.

description:
First Time Visitor and well worth it.  Spent an afternoon wandering the majestic galleries.     The location is great (in the distance can see golden gate bridge, skyline of downtown SF).    Parking is easy (Note:  Do not leave valuables in car).   

The displays [Sculptures-THINKER,  Paintings by a great people (Monet),  restored old ceilings from a Spanish palace, restored Louis XV era room, Restoration Project, Fabrege Jewelery, European Porcelain, etc)  are varied and every one splendid.    

In this museum, one will find definitely find an exhibit that will mesmerize you.  

Took my gf there and she was impressed at finding such a great jewel in S.F.
author: harryg g.

description:
In all my years as a wee-laddie and now for the first time  in over three decades living here in MY hometown, I cannot recall ever having been within the beautiful walls of this museum. I have been outside at the front and of course captured the seriousness of "The Thinker", but that's about it. In Europe (or at least Spain), I had to show my resident ID and I'd get in for free....  too bad the USA can't do the same and thus encourage more visitors to actually visit!

That aside, I was enthralled by the spaciousness, the beauty and the history of it all. As a photographer, I saw many things that I love capturing: reflections, details and architecture. Granted, one cannot use a flash nor tripod within its confines, but I use none to get my images, and had a great time!

I went with friends and my sister  - she mainly to delight in the Fabergé eggs which I have seen pictures in magazines of, but to see them before your very eyes is something to behold. 

I wandered around snapping here, in awe of the arte there, and just walking through so many halls that opened or led to yet another huge massive room that I was lost beyond hope! I loved the paintings and admired the details of the old paintings...  I thought I was back inside a spanish museo and enjoyed it thoroughly; we were wise enough to arrive just as the museum opened so there crowds didn't build yet on that Easter Sunday!

A great day enjoying humanity, arte and gorgeous architecture of the Legion of Honor!! Always go VERY early to avoid the crowds. Taking a camera? NO tripods/flash and set ur cell to vibrate. NO photography at ALL at the special exhibits. I was so pleased to see that the museum security knew the rules regarding handheld FLASHless photography and didn't stop me as they sometimes do in most european museums simply because they're ignorant/lazy.
author: Tony L.

description: Go see the Anders Zorn exhibit (Nov 9, 2013 to Feb 2, 2014) before it's gone, some amazing work, particularly the illusion of the water waves reflections.  Looking up close, it's obvious that it's a watercolor, but move back and it captures the essence of the water reflections, looks so real.  Small discount showing proof of payment coming there on Muni.
author: George L.

description:
Went for the special exhibit on the fashion designs of Isabelle de Borchgrave (http://www.isabelledeborchgrave.com/) which was spectacular by the way. 

Otherwise, the Fine Arts Museum at the Legion of Honor is a sad reminder that that San Francisco is not a world class cultural city. SF has allot of things going for it, but the fine arts is not one of them. (Sorry, I'm just not that into Tilson-Thomas and Mahler.) They try real hard, but none of their collections from any period are significant enough to provide much of a perspective. A few Athenian vases over here, a few eclectic Realist and Impressionist works over there, and a few 
sculptures in between. 

I'm grateful I had enough representative samples from different periods to educate my 10 year old son on the basics of art history. But even he seemed to note the sparsity. "What, no water lilies or a Van Gough?" He even noted the irony of their having a mini-pyramid out front: "are they trying to be like the Louvre or something?"
author: David P.

description: Best fine arts museum in San Francisco. Better than de Young, and I was lucky to come during their "Impressionists on the Water" exhibit which was pretty fun to see. There's Egyptian artifacts dating back over 2,500 years. There's art dating back to the 16th Century as well. My only complaint is that the museum isn't bigger. I'd love to see more!
author: I G.

description:
The Legion of Dishonor;

Make sure to see the beautiful signage(industrial strength) in front of the Holocaust Memorial you can't help not to miss it. 

"Never forget"...  to Lock Your Car!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Compliments, kudos and hats off to the management and of course the city of San Francisco.  I will certainly never forget.
author: thomas s.

description:
Very nice museum.  Beautiful architecture and landscape.  There was live music playing in the background as you peruse the paintings.  I didn't really get to enjoy it as much since I was wearing heels and waiting for a wedding to take place here.

The surrounding area is very nice too. You have a view of the golden gate bridge.  The wedding ceremony took place on the grass overlooking the golden gate bridge and the reception took place in the cafe.  Beautiful ceremony and wedding reception.

They really transformed the cafe into a nice lounge for the wedding reception.
author: Kaylin O.

description: Love this place.  We have been coming her for many years.  Take the bus and save $2.
author: April M.

description:
I'm definitely a history nerd and love going to museums. the Legion of Honor is one of the most gorgeous museums I've been to. I can definitely see what many people have photoshoots in the area. 

One of the best exhibits that I've seen at the Legion of Honor was the Cartier and America. Although it got a little claustrophobic at times, I was in shock and awe of the amazing displays and beautiful pieces. Another of my favorites was Very Postmortem: Mummies and Medicine. 

I definitely appreciate the flow of the museum. Parking may be a little difficult, at times, though.
author: Steph W.

description:
I went to see the Faberge Egg Exhibit and was completely amazed at everything in this particular exhibit.  It was a bit crowded and seemed as though everyone that was in the museum was all viewing this exhibit at once.  After leaving the Faberge Egg Exhibit, we went through the rest of the museum and it was quite impressive.  Everything was greatly spaced, had it's own themes, and fully engaged my boyfriend and I.

Something that I thought was a great treat was the organist that played that afternoon.  He played absolutely beautiful soothing music that just filled the main room.  I would've paid for the entrance just to sit there and listen to him play.

Also the entrance of the museum in itself is extraordinary.  I sat in that courtyard for hours just admiring its amazing architecture.  I felt like I was in a whole 'nother country.  You will always see plenty of weddings photos, filming, & etc going on in the immediate area.

In my opinion, this isn't a great museum to bring kids to ... I believe that the mid-20's crowd would enjoy and appreciate this museum a lot more.
author: Pia V.

description:
This review is for the Legion of Honor as a wedding venue.

We choose the Balustrade Lawn for the Ceremony and the Rodin Galleries for the Reception.  Our wedding here was amazing!!!  We couldn't have asked for a more beautiful venue, especially the view during our ceremony with the Golden Gate Bridge in the background.  

We chose the Rodin Galleries because if you are going to have a reception at a museum, why not be surrounded by amazing artwork?  The café holds more people, but it was a little too plain for our taste.

Here are the reasons that I didn't give it 5-stars.  (These are also tips if you are thinking about the Legion as a venue.)

1. Budget.  I know weddings are expensive and everyone always go over budget, but here are some things that you should consider when booking there.  Everything had to be rented.  There is pretty much no lighting except for what is lighting the sculptures (prepare to spend at least $2000 on lighting, we spent about $3000.)  You are required to use only approved caterers, which vary in price.  The Legion does not supply anything with regards to chairs or tables (unless you have the reception in the café.)  For a 100 person wedding, we spent about $6000 on rentals for the ceremony and reception (of course prices will very depending on your vendor).  $400 was spent on the fire permit (required for the caterer.)  About $300 for insurance because of the artwork.  And we were charged rush set-up fees from a couple vendors because of the short timeline that they give you to set up.  If you want more time than the allotted 4 hours, it is $1500 an hour.

2. Timeline.  Your vendors have an extremely short amount of time to set up because the museum is open until 5:15pm (except Mondays when they are closed).  So depending when your reception is (which must start by 7pm, according to their policy), your vendors have to "haul a##" to set up, and you are probably too busy getting married to oversee any of it.

3. Policies and Procedures.  The Legion gives you 17 pages of policies and procedures that you must follow.  The important ones include a number of rules regarding the flowers or other "organic materials." You can kiss all candles goodbye (the fire permit mentioned above is for catering.  No live flame allowed in the galleries.  Hope you like battery powered tea candles.)  All vendors must be approved by the Legion and must do a walkthrough, which is hard to coordinate when you have a lot of vendors.  No rice, flower petals, or even bubbles can be used during the ceremony, even for the ceremony on the lawn.  Lastly, no animals allowed.


Again, the wedding was beautiful!!!  And we don't even slightly regret having our wedding at the Legion of Honor.  You should just be aware of the extra costs and rules if you are considering a wedding there.
author: Matthew M.

description:
My fiancé and I came here to check it out as a possible venue for our wedding.  I thought this would be the definate space we would be hitched in; however, after visiting I don't think it is.  I must say it is beautiful just not what we want.  I still suggest checking it out.  Here are some things we didn't like:

Feels too pretencious. Yes I know it is he Legion.  But... If you want to get married about a bunch of rich white men looking down at you, this is the place for you. just didn't feel right.

Your wedding would be separated into three seperate rooms which I personally don't like.

To tent off the court yard and do it outside it would be 25,000

Just as late of a start time as other mesum venues and just as much.
author: Lauren T.

description:
The Legion of Honor is a favorite place to visit. Scenic views provide a relaxed, picturesque location. Waters edge is within view and the Roman architecture is cool and calm. I could feel my blood pressure drop as I walked into the Museum. The Legion transports me to a different time and space. No personal photo gallery should be without a few shots under the arches or next to the columns. 
Roaming the many rooms of great works is a fun afternoon for the art lover. The permanent collection features works from the 15 - 18th century. Massive painting cover the walls offering images of baroque portraiture or scenes of daily life. 

I highly recommend this museum if you're looking for works from this time period. I gather inspiration from the basement collection of Greek works. A nice selection of jewelry, black painted vases and found glass vases are in the side cabinets. A gallery filled with impressionist works are also on view featuring minor works from Van Gogh and one of Monet's later "Water Lily" painting are part of the permanent collection. 

Not just the masters here. Cutting edge traveling exhibits from the post modern era are also on view. 

I have to give a big thank you to the donors of these works who allow the general public to take in the colors. I appreciate you giving up such beautiful pieces of artworks. 

Bay Area residence are lucky to have an extensive permanent collection at our fingertips and all for the admission fee of a very affordable $10.
author: Veda F.

description:
Such an elegant gem of a museum.  It's the right size (not large enough to overwhelm but large enough to keep you occupied for a 2 to 3 hours), parking is FREE (how amazing is that), and the grounds are gorgeous (flowers, lawns, statues).  I love how the museum sits atop a hill with amazing views of the Bay and city.  The Greco-Roman architecture and marble columns lend an air of solemn grace. 

The ground floor is home to their European paintings and Rodin sculptures.  The paintings cover the Baroque period, Renaissance, Impressionism, and so forth.  I didn't think they had any 21st century paintings but they had one - by Picasso.  

I love the pipe organ and the concerts they have there and they also have movie nights.  I didn't think I liked glass art but the Chihuly sculptures look like crazy Christmas ornaments and somehow feel right in the museum setting.  There's something organic about them.

I went to see the temporary exhibit, the Dead Sea Scrolls.  Disappointing.  They only have the smallest scraps - in one case.  You can see much more of the scrolls here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image:Deadseascrolls.jpg

The lower level can get stuffy when crowded.  You'll find the special exhibition there, the café, and a small gift shop.  The ceramics room is fairly interesting.  It's interesting how the English were so influenced by Chinese art in their ceramics. I also like the Greek pottery. 

The portraits fascinate me in their ability to convey the subject's personality.  I always wonder about the lives led.  There are two morbid looking portraits that I wish I could own.  They're next to each other.  In one, the woman holds the head of a man she had beheaded.  In the other, the woman is stabbing herself.  See my pictures.

Admission is free on the first Tuesday of every month.  Adult tickets are $10 - quite reasonable.
author: Lolia S.

description:
The most worthwhile piece of art at the Legion of Honor is the Holocaust Memorial created by George Segal. 

Most people go to the Legion and have no idea it's there. It certainly isn't mentioned on the website, or on the brochure they hand you when you enter the museum proper. It's not inside the building, but you'll find it nearby if you look.

It is chilling. It is sobering. It will make you wonder how 6 million people could possibly have been killed, for being different, essentially yesterday. And it will make you glad that you are alive.
author: Gwynnie P.

description: Beautiful location and views of golden gate and sf. Some  Monets on display. Get a $2 discount if you take public transport
author: Nauman F.

description:
Just lovely.
Great view of the GG bridge.
Beautiful to take pictures outside for a photo shoot.
The museum is cool too, if you like museums.
It's free the first Saturday of the month for BofA card holders.
author: Grace P.

description:
wow. this museum is wonderful. probably one of my favorite in the united states.

it is very modest, but the art is curated wonderfully.. the top level (the floor you enter) is in chronological order starting from gothic, all the way up to the beautifully realistic but romantic Rodin sculptures. each room has different lighting and wallpaper, to fit the mood of the era of painting you're in. there are a lot of big names, but a few very popular pieces, which is why i mention the modesty of the place.

i had one of the most delicious salads in the museum restaurant, which was filled with fresh leaves, fruits, veggies, nuts, raisins, and balsamic vinaigrette. i asked for no meat, since there was really no vegetarian option there but it was perfect and delicious after the few days of gluttonous gorges. 

WARNING TO TOURISTS WHO DONT HAVE CARS: legion of honor, if coming from central SF, is a really really really REALLY long bus ride. well, we had to take a few busses and 1 subway train ride. it took over an hour and a half to get there... but it's worth it if you are a lover of the arts.
author: Ava M.

description:
Being a semi-jaded appreciator of more modern art, I was blown away by the Legion of Honor's collection! Majestic Rodin sculptures! Madonnas and Renaissance paintings! Monet's Water Lilies that almost made me cry because of their vibrant beauty. I could live in the blue of that pond!

They also have a pretty amazing paper exhibit going on downstairs, but please, no photos.
author: Tiffinie T.

description:
There's nothing like going for a run and finding yourself face to face with an original iron cast of The Thinker at the top of the hill. 

The Legion of Honor was dedicated by the Speckles family to honor the fallen of WWI. Sure it's on the usual sights to stop by for tourists but every local should make the trek to the end of the richmond and up the golf club to realize just how crazy it is to have this here in our fair city. It's a monument, it's like very few things in the city, it's classical in every way. 

The way they make use of the space, the arrangement of exhibits is fascinating. You'll be shocked at how much they do with the square footage they have. It really is like stepping out of the city and into some pocket of a European site. We have a few of these in San Francisco - it's kind of funny how many styles of architecture the city has when you take a moment to think about it. It's not just Victorians and Edwardian, it's monuments like this and the Palace of Fine Arts off by the Marina - not to mention the more modern stuff that tips its hat off to contemporary styles. 

Even if you don't end up going to see an exhibit IN the legion, take some time to go check it out - it's seriously worth it on a good day, hell, any day.
author: Samantha D.

description:
I use museums to distract myself. 
"From what?" the reader casually asks.
Museums are really good for anxiety related to over active imaginations.  It's also really good for that mid-week slump in one's life when the coffee just isn't as strong, the jokes are not as funny, and that bottle of wine gets smaller since it somehow only contained 3 glasses, not 4.  
The De Young is a nice museum.  If you like crowds while viewing fine art.  I'm talking about people up in your personal space.  People who could describe the scent of your deodorant, detergent and perfume by the end of the exhibit.  Sometimes, I purposely dress a little shabby to make sure no one treads on me.  Shabby-smelly.

The Legion of Honor is a real museum.  For the price of one membership, you get an experiment in social indignation and an imitation Louvre.  My parents and I visited this location after we realized that January 18, 2010 was the last day of the Van Gough exhibit and there was going to be a herd of culturally lacking people trying to check something off their culture bucket list.  Or crazy school kids.  

As we pulled up the drive to the Legion of Honor in our little silver Prius, the magnificent sprawling courtyard with a fountain completely distracted my parents from the equally sprawling Beaux-Arts building.  Off to the right, beyond the small circular parking lot, the view of San Francisco is the same view that inspired, motivated, and encouraged countless generations.  This is what San Francisco was built on.  A little something for everyone, viewed from the top of this rocky hill, someplace where anyone can find a place to fit in.  

My parents have never been to the great museums of Europe.  They are both Artists with degrees in Fine Arts.  They've been to museums in China.  But that's almost like viewing artifacts at the excavation site.  My mother was awed and impressed by the courtyard of the Legion of Honor.  My father liked the detail in the marble.  He liked the marble itself.  

Inside, the Legion of Honor feels like a real museum.  It feels like you're walking through these very precisely laid out rooms that are coordinated for the purpose of showcasing some fantastic works of art.  Square rooms, tastefully minimal, pastel walls, inlaid wood on the floor, filtered skylights, chandeliers.  It's not all angles and forced perspectives.  It feels like a proper, fancy, beaux-arts museum.  

I love it.  I don't know how I'm going to get here since it's a 10 minute drive from the Golden Gate Park, but I'm going to visit this place one a week until I see it all.
author: Christina C.

description:
We found the 18 and caught that up to the Legion of Honor.  I have to say I love how Muni has bus lines to just about all its attractions made things so much easier for GBF#1 and I.

Anyways we arrive up at the Legion of Honor and take in the beautiful surroundings and grounds, and the view it was all breath taking.  Before heading in we walked around for a bit and discovered the Holocaust memorial, while nice was kind of small, while enjoying the views of the Golden Gate Bridge and the Bay.  As we head inside I notice the glass sculpture by Dale Chihuly, it's funny I never notices his stuff in Seattle but always spot it everywhere else, digression I know...

We notice that there was an Anne Leibovitz exhibit going on, so we paid the extra $5.00 and grab our ticket/sticker to allow us entry.  We decided to do the Anne Leibovitz exhibit first and I will say I was impressed, I've always enjoyed her photography and this exhibit was Annie overload but in a good way.

After spending some time in there we decided to check out the rest of the museum.  It had a nice variety, like others I enjoyed the Robin sculptures, The Dead Sea Scrolls exhibit, Monet, Rembrandt, and the Chihuly glass sculptures inside were pretty nice too.

It was smaller than I expected but I was OK with that because we now had plenty of time to head over to Golden Gate Park and check out the De Young Museum, with the CityPass we had you could visit both museums on the same day so we did.
author: Me H.

description:
The Legion of Honor is great.  They have standing exhibits such as their fabulous fine china and works from a mix of European artists as well as rotating exhibits such as the current Pissarro show and 'Medusa' by Bernini.  
The building itself is a half scale replica of the French Legion of Honor in Paris.  The building was a gift from the French after WWII.  A must see if you are in this part of town...and if you buy a ticket here you can also get into the basic exhibits at the DeYoung.  Score!
author: Elizabeth J.

description:
After all these years of living in San Francisco, not once have I gotten the chance to visit Legion of Honor!I came here with a couple of friends, parking was a pain in the butt. We ended up parking outside of the area and had to walk a couple of minutes to get there. 

Walking to the entrance was beautiful already, when we got inside I was amazed at the architecture every room was designed beautifully. There is a lot to see and you'll probably be doing a lot of reading. The top floor had a lot of paintings and sculptures, it took us awhile to finish the top floor because there was a lot of reading and staring into paintings.

The bottom floor had the Cartier exhibit, which we didn't check out. (but I will next time I visit). But, we did check out some cool stuff like fruit shaped bowls or vegetable shaped porcelain containers, really cute stuff. Overall I had a lot of fun just looking around and reading about things, even though I couldn't touch it!
author: Heather C.

description:
This place was worth the drive.  I enjoyed the architecture of the building and the view of the Golden Gate Bridge.  Also, I would double check the website before you head out to see which special exhibit is being hosted by the museum.  ;)

p.s. If you have a BOFA card, make sure to bring it.  They give special pricing on BOFA holders.
author: Julie M.

description:
Spent the day at Legion of Honor yesterday for the Dead Sea Scroll exhibit & was overjoyed to find out they also had a Women Impressionists exhibit as well

Layout of the grounds is spectacular - the views all around are breathtaking & the pieces of art throughout the grounds (in this case, one Chihuly glass sculpture in particular) were phenomenal
