Inside the museum is likewise outstanding w/ nice open spaces, great lighting, lots of different art periods, furniture, porcelain, literature / publications as well as previews of the DeYoung Museum's current exhibit - additional Chihuly glass to temp you to venture over to DeYoung

Rodin sculptures, another room of Impressionists (Monet, Renoir, etc...) & I'm in absolute heaven

AND towards the end of the day, the Organist started playing the famous Legion Organ & he was wonderful - really added an ambiance to the whole day!

Price was cheap at $15 - to spend all day, meandering the museum grounds & drinking in all the majesty of the various exhibits.  Also highly recommend taking the Docet tour of Women Impressionists - it's free w/ your admission price & who doesn't want to know even more about art?!

PLUS - your $15 admission is good for a same day visit to BOTH the Legion & DeYoung.  Next time we're going to plan more accordingly so we can do both!

Can't wait to go back!!
author: Adrienne G.

description:
No words. There simply are no words that can adequately describe the beauty this museum has to offer. 
 Sculptures, paintings, furniture, jewelry; all can be found in the Legion of Honor. Art that will make your head swirl and history that will make you appreciate humanity. 
 If visiting on a Sunday, do stay for the live organ recital, held in the first chamber of the museum. The sound eminates throughout the building and is something one must witness in their lifetime.
 Fun fact: Did you know the museum is technically considered one of the three cemetaries in San Francisco? During seismic retrofitting, hundreds of skeletons were found under the grounds of the museum. Turns out the land was once a 'Potter's Cemetary' where peasants and ethnic people were laid to rest. The City held a large service for the remains and while most were transferred to Colma for burial, many skeletons still remain under the museum grounds, making the museum a mausoleum as well.
author: Melissa T.

description:
Although this place is so much smaller than most museums I've seen in Paris and London, I still think that this place definitely holds its own because it really knows how to show the things that it has. 

The collection is definitely smaller but it's not exhausting thinking that you could go through this museum in a couple of hours. 

The flow of the building is kind of weird since it's shaped like a horseshoe and you enter through the middle but at least it'll give you a second chance to revisit the pieces that you didn't notice the first time walking through.

The museum tends to be free on certain Tuesdays so try to go on a Tuesday so that you don't have to pay. There also have great exhibits here occasionally.
author: Rylan C.

description:
One of my fave old school classical embodiments of what museums us to be before the advent of fantastically modern architects and the developers who contract with them.

I fell in love with this place ever since I saw it on the Hitchcock film Vertigo with James Stewart, and immediately became a member.

A large expanse of white marble and stately Grecian reflection, this establishment hosts exhibits and arranged in consecutive order of style and years.  I've enjoyed the Picasso exhibit here, much more than the MOMA hosting.......and the Rodin sculptures are immaculate in their conveyance of beauty done in the stark hardness of bronze.  I also caught Monet's exhibit as it rolled through...

I'm a geek, but an art geek forever.  The Legion has held my concentration and interest piqued for 2-3 hours on end.
author: Miika M.

description:
Free museum Tuesdays on every first Tuesday of the month FTW! Why didn't I know about this until recently? I met up with a few friends and walked up to Rodin's The Thinker Statue. How cool is that? I happened to come during the City of Light exhibit. A exhibit featuring works of art from Paris during the mid 1800's-early 1900's featuring Seurat's Eiffel Tower and various paintings, photographs, etchings and paintings. 

Even if you don't intend on going inside, it is just a beautiful place to take a stroll and seeing the spectacular views of the city, Golden Gate Bridge and the bay. 

You have to come here! It will not disappoint!
author: Darryl P.

description:
Perhaps it's unfair that I compare every major city art museum with the Art Institute of Chicago, the Metropolitan Museum of New York, and the Kunsthistoriches in Vienna.  The Legion of Honor was a fine place to spend two hours on a Wednesday morning, but it seemed a bit sparsely stocked.

The grounds and exterior are quite handsome, not to mention the view of the bay.  The hike up here is great exercise. 

The collections left a lot to be desired, though.  The 80-piece Rodin gallery was amazing.  Other than that, there were a few notables: Rubens, Degas, Manet, Renoir, Monet.  I was there late last August, when they had a very good exhibit of paper works from the Middle Ages to the present.  

Since I got in for free with my friend's annual pass, I can't complain much.  But it just isn't a world-class art museum.  It felt too empty and echo-ey.  It's too bad that I missed the de Young Museum; together they might have been noteworthy.
author: David R.

description: I come to this area a lot. Outside, there is already plenty to see. There are breathtaking views of the Golden Gate, presidio, and half of the city. There is also a very sad remembrance of the Holocaust outside near the parking lot. Inside the museum is VERY nice. Its well-maintained, clean, and the staff is always there to help. I used to come here just to sketch drawings, and stare at the portraits in awe. They have many exhibits to see, and since I consider myself an artist this is basically a second home to me. I do have to warn others that the security people do not like people to wear backpacks, and I have seen them run after and call out those who do wear them. You have to hold them or, better yet, not bring them. I'm unsure why, perhaps it has to do with knocking something over?At any rate, come to this museum its hidden up in the hills you will love it.
author: Apple F.

description:
The Legion of Honor is one of San Franciso's hidden gems. Who would have known that such a beautiful site could exist within the hustle and bustle of the Richmond district? This is one of the city's most beautiful museums, but even without the artwork, I'd still come just to enjoy the sites outside. This is also where a lot of couples come to take their wedding pictures.

The Legion of Honor is one of the sites that makes me proud of San Francisco. JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
Who'd think SF has its own mini Louvre with pyramid and all. Came by for the Medusa exhibition and got a little culture. Love all th mini galleries especially the Impressionists and Rodin. So inspired I got a little "Water Lillies" print for my WC. Now I am craving another trip to Paris for warm baguettes and foie gras. 

Also loved the tons of wedding parties getting their ubiquitous Legion shots for their photo albums...it may not be the City of Lights but it might as well be the City of Love.
author: vic f.

description:
It was nice. Beautiful architecture of the building. Great for pictures!

Came here because of our SF city pass so we didn't have a lot of time to explore but we did enjoy our time here. =)
author: Leanne D.

description:
Probably the prettiest place in SF.

Their current special French exhibit is tremendously thought-provoking. Made me realize how deficient my knowledge of French history is. If you enjoy French impressionism or studying France, you must see this exhibit while it lasts! It is more etchings than paintings, while the special counterpart showing at the deYoung is more paintings. Both are awesome, and they're buy-one-get-one, so there's no reason not to see both. Yes, the Legion is more out in the boonies, but sooo worth it.

I can't say enough about the beautiful architecture, views, and peaceful feeling here to do it justice, so please go see it for yourself. Parking was a breeze, and the whole atmosphere was very relaxed. 

The setting is especially perfect for photos, so if you plan to take pics, allow plenty of time to fully take advantage of all the scenery. We only snapped a few as we didn't have much time, but next time we go, we'll get a lot more. In one shot, we got: trees, sky, blue bay, stonework, hills, lawn, hedges, and ourselves. That's what I call bang for our photo buck!

The layout inside was a bit odd, but with all the inner and outer beauty, it didn't matter. Even the ladies' restroom is wonderfully high-class. 

We packed a lunch, so I can't comment on their food offerings. We went on a regular weekday, not a free day or weekend, and it was very uncrowded. They even have beautiful art in their eating area!
author: Sue Ellen E.

description:
This museum is on the smaller side but still packs in plenty.
Probably the most famous piece is Monet's Waterlilies but you also have some piece from the same ear by Renoir, Degas and Manet. I'm not art connoisseur so I can't go into detail. This is a review from someone who happened to be at the place at some time.

When you arrive, you have to battle for parking, there's not really a sizable lot to speak of so good luck on that front. I'm not sure if this had anything to do with the fact that it was a BoA weekend where you can get in for free or if it's always like that.

When you approach you are visually greeted by the architecture of the place. It's fairly imposing as you walk up to the entrance. As you walk past the main gate you see what looks like a mini replica of what looks like the Pyramid at the Louvre made more well known by Tom Hank's movie "The Da Vinci code"

Once inside it is pretty easy to navigate and see everything without the need for a map. On display at the time of our visit were amongst other things were the Mourners.These are small statues from Burgundy in France made hundreds of year ago. The detail and quality are impressive given how long ago these were made. Definitely a highlight. No pictures allowed but nevertheless amazing.

The rest of the museum contains contemporary pieces, from oil painting by the aforementioned artists and some sculptures by Rodin all the way to some more modern pieces.

All in all - a very worthwhile visit. I'll be back.
author: Nick L.

description:
The Palace of Fine arts is located in Lincoln Park in the northwest part of San Francisco. The building alone is a work of art as it's a three-quarters scale imitation of the Hotel de Salm in Paris. An interesting piece of little known history is that the Lincoln Park Golf Course that surrounds the museum was once the site of the Golden Gate Cemetery. The bodies were moved down to Colma, CA in 1908 when the cemetery was closed; however, in the 1990s when the city was doing seismic retrofitting of the surrounding park, coffins and skeletal remains were still unearthed. Very cool history for a very cool spot in the city. Also, the beautiful historic building is a popular backdrop for couples taking their engagement pictures as well as day-of pictures with their wedding party.

The name is used for both the museum building and the collection it houses. The Legion's collection spans more than 6,000 years of ancient and European art. Some of the collection highlights and my favorites are: St. John the Baptist by El Greco (1600), The Trotting Horse by Edgar Degas (1881), and Waterlilies by Claude Monet (1914). The museum has a variety of classic and innovative traveling exhibitions. I've seen a traveling exhibit of beautiful Cartier jewelry and works from the Louvre and Museum de Orsay.

Currently the Legion is showcasing Pulp Fiction: The Art of Belgian artist Isabelle de Borchgrave. de Borchgrave creates fashion literally out of manipulating paper. The exhibition features masterpieces of intricate paper clothing inspired by early European paintings or from famous museum pieces from around the world. The exhibit is somewhat of a history of fashion from such famous individuals as the Medici family, Elizabeth I, Marie-Antoinette and Christian Dior, and Coco Chanel, to name a few. The pieces are literally amazing and its mind boggling how she was able to create these extraordinary pieces of clothing (and shoes) out of paper. The Legion is the first American museum to dedicate an entire exhibition to these works of textile art. 

The exhibit costs $15 for adults, $12 seniors, $11 for kids 6-17 and college students with ID. The museum is open from 9:30am to 5:15pm and has a delicious cafe with outdoor seating.
author: Alice S.

description:
The first Tuesday of every month is free day at both the Legion of Honor and the De Young (which makes sense, since they are sister museums). I ended up going there with my friend Casey to revel in french art as he procrastinated on studying for his finals.

It's out of the way, but completely worthwhile with gorgeous architecture and amazing views of the Golden Gate Bridge. I must state that I'm not the sort of art person that sits for a long time and ponders the meaning of a piece. I'm more likely to sit and stare at the ceiling amazed by the architecture of a building and the artistic layout of a particular room. I found the layout to be a bit strange (when you get to one end of the museum you have no choice but to go through everything you've already seen to get back to the middle and visit the other side). 

The Rodin sculpture selection was absolutely stunning and I loved that they had paintings organized chronologically from almost every artistic movement in Europe. I wish they'd had a greater selection of Impressionist work, but it was still an amazing collection. We didn't have time to go to the Cartier in America special exhibit, but the permanent collection was so fantastic that we can always take in the special exhibits another time.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Oh, my, this place is beautiful.  The front of the building is gorgeous, and you have a beautiful view of the golden gate bridge (slightly) and water.

The place is actually pretty big inside, and it's really tiring to look through all the art if you're the type who does that.  

Notable pieces include The Thinker, The Kiss (Rodin), and Water Lilies (Monet).  Lots of great pieces.

I've seen pictures of a giant, ornate ceiling and almost missed it had I not looked up.

There is also a Holocaust memorial on the grounds that's pretty poignant.

Look for free days!
author: Lily N.

description:
I took a course on the creative works of Paris and after traveling the globe my professor said this is "the most beautifully situated museum in the world" and to my knowledge I completely agree! The view from the fountain totally puts into perspective the Pacific coast and the roaming hills in San Francisco. It's absolutely breathtaking on a sunny day!

Impressive collections, too, from the viewpoint on a art newbie. Lots of famous French pieces from Rodin, Monet, Gerome, etc. and cool artifacts like sedans (those little carts the serfs would carry kings and important people in), powder boxes, silverware and utensils, and they even transplanted an entire room to the museum so you can feel what it would be like inside an ornately decorated 17th century Parisian palace complete fancy crown moldings.
author: Chelsea P.

description:
I came here last for an Annie Leibowitz exhibit which was a disspointment.  It was promoting her new book and the photos were a mix of personal and professional shots that didn't have that usual "WOW' factor that Annie's work usually makes me feel.  This exhibit is now over and done with, but it took me a while to write this review.

However, while we were there, my mother and I did stroll around the rest of the museum.  It had some interesting exhibits--most notable some  Chihuly's. 

It is a lovely space, but it's desirability is greatly influenced by the weather.  The museum's location can be in the good weather, or the worst San Francisco can offer.  It just depends on the day.
author: Katharine A.

description:
Wonderful exhibits, not to mention the Achenbach Foundation Library on site at The Legion. Staff is very knowledgable, and, go out of their way to help students who are doing research for school projects.
Great views on the museum grounds. Just breathtaking:)
author: Anne M.

description:
Coming to this museum can make me forget that I live in California or even the United States--it has lovely old architecture and a collection that transports you to Europe. It's not the Louvre, but it does have it's own small glass pyramid, so it'll do. 

The main collection is nice for a quiet afternoon of art appreciation, but it's the special exhibits that I really enjoy.  (Relatively) recent favorites include: Art Deco, Monet, and a fabulous retrospective on the 1906 earthquake. Also, they have a wonderful organ that is played at 4 on weekend afternoons. Whether you sit and listen or simply enjoy the music as you stroll through the upper galleries, the effect is tremendous.

Once you are done inside, be sure to look around outside. You will have seen The Thinker on your way in, but across the parking lot there is a very moving Holocaust Memorial. There's a man standing in front of many dead bodies who is looking out through barbed wire that gets me every time. The look in his eyes is so haunted. Once you are able to tear yourself away from his stare and look around at the glorious sight of the ocean and the city around you, you will get a strong reminder of how lucky you are.
author: Katie I.

description:
What a bargain.  $16 entry; no parking fee; beautiful views of GG bridge and a FABULOUS exhibit...worth much more that $16.  Only wish it
didn't end.  Period clothes all made of paper & hand painted...shoes,
jewelery, hats....everything paper....unbelievably talented artist!
author: Carol W.

description:
Why is it when "I" go to an "Art Museum" I suddenly start thinking like Thomas Crown..  OK, OK, so I'm a little more "Pink Panther"...   More Peter Sellers than McQueen/Brosnan for sure!!  At any rate, met my old Pal at the Seal Rock Inn (nice place) before his surgery at the great VA Hospital near "Lands End" to yuck him up before goin' under the knife...
Got there early, so I decided to take in the Legion of Honor.  Beautiful area and surrounded by a great looking Golf Course that had some spectacular views of the Ocean & Golden Gate.  Took notice of a warning sign at the front gate noting car break-ins.  Moved my loaded down Subaru to a front, highly visible spot.  Off I went for a speed-walk tour of the museum.  
Very nice, but how much can a guy interested in NBA playoffs look at 15th Century bibilot??  I really did like the Rodin's work and the restoration going on of woodwork and panels..  Once a "woodbutcher"......   Finally I reached the "Masters" wing...  Goya, Monet, Cezanne, Renoir, Dali, Degas, and Picasso.  Grand woodcarvings and ceilings.  The ancient art and coins got that "Mission Impossible" click going again.... I needed a cop 'o Tea after the "Porcelain" exhibit...
Out in the parking lot I encountered a young European Lady who had just had her American visit RUINED by the A**HOLE who broke into her car and stole it ALL......
A cop came along, but her vacay had evaporated...  I hope lightening cauterizes and welds together that jerk's various sphincters in the not too distant future...
I'm sure they came out of the Museum feeling great only to be dragged into the gutter of San Francisco and America...
I felt a degree of shame...  BOY, did thief boy ever miss a HIT with me...
Spent the night with my Bud, saw he and his Gal to surgery, saw him in recovery and beat it North!!  Passed over the Bay Bridge and Oakland/ Richmond without having to draw a weapon in road rage and was out into the Sacramento Valley 'fore anyone even knew it...
LOVE THAT!!!!
author: Frank K.

description:
The THINKEEERRRRR! Now if they could just make him into an action figure. Imagine The Thinker's special move: placing a finger on his forehead!

Damn, powerful! I love this guy! Hence, I love the Legion of Honor! ;-)
author: Jordan N.

description:
As a native San Franciscan I am ashamed to say this was my first visit here. This is a beautifully built museum that reminded me of the museums I visited in France, just on a smaller scale. 

I came while they showed the Dutch and Flemish Masterworks. The exhibit was wonderful, but I enjoyed the porcelain display the most. The museum has a lot to offer inside and out. The beauty of the exhibits and the views of the SF Bay Area will leave you speechless.
author: Adelina W.

description:
Yet another place I'm surprised I haven't reviewed yet.

So a little history.  The Legion of Honor was given as a gift to San Francisco by Alma Spreckels, wife of the heir to the Spreckels Sugar Company (Adolph Spreckels).  It is a scale copy of the Palais de la Lgion d'Honneur in Paris, France.  The Spreckels family is deeply rooted in San Francisco (for instance, Spreckels Lake in GG Park, the Spreckels Mansion on Washington St.)  

Okay so now that the history lesson is out of the way.  I absolutely adore the Legion of Honor.  Not only for it's beautiful setting and location in Lincoln Park, with its views of the Golden Gate Bridge to the North and San Francisco Skyline to the East.  But also for the grandeur  of its architecture and design.  I have seen some of the best exhibits here, everything from "Eternal Egypt" and "Art Deco" to the more recent "Marie Antoinette."   

I highly recommend becoming a member of the Fine Arts Museums of SF (includes the de Young as well).  You get:

1. No waiting in line access to the museum
2. No having to pay to get in
3. Free special exhibit access with no line
4. Cool membership cards
author: Serge S.

description: Beautiful museum. My boyfriend's company rented out the entire museum to have one of their holiday parties here a couple years ago and it was amazing. We got to see all of the exhibits, and they transformed the area outside where they have The Thinker Statue into a tented dance floor/food & drink area. It was pretty cool ordering drinks right in front of The Thinker.
author: K S.

description: They have one of Monet's Water Lilies! If that is not enough to lure you to the Legion of Honor (in which case...what is wrong with you?) then you will surely be won over by the beautiful view of the Golden Gate or the chance to do your best "Vertigo" reenactment.
author: Meghan B.

description:
This place is situated in beautiful surroundings on vista with 360 degree views of SF, Lincoln Park, and the Pacific Ocean...

... but it's an embarrassment as an art museum, especially if you've been to any art museum on the East Coast.

Save the money and hang out in the outdoor areas for free.  The most impressive work of art we saw that day was the building itself.
author: Mike B.

description:
With the likes of Le Penseur (aka the Thinker) thoughtfully welcoming patrons at this scenic museum, it's hard to resist the Legion of Honor and all her charms. 

It helps that it's practically in my backyard, but I'm a member for a reason. The Rodin sculptures, the eclectic mix of artistic periods covered, and the classical layout, all help to make this a perfect museum visit. You can see it all in one go and you feel more exhilarated than exhausted by the time you leave.

People complain that it's not The Louvre, or the Uffizi, or the Prado. Of course it's not like any of these museums, but it never claims to be. Appreciate it for what it is - a uniquely beautiful museum with plenty of elegance and class to spare.
author: Art O.

description:
UGH! What more could I ask for? 
I became a member last year when I saw my first Titian. I die.

They always have amazing exhibits. Cartier Through America- seriously?!Love it.

I was lucky enough (and so grateful) to go into the Achenbach Graphic Arts Council and see some original prints of early photography. I was in heaven. The people who work here are so incredibly knowledgeable. And so nice and accomidating. Usually when you go to places like this you get some stuffy old woman who keeps saying "Dont touch that!" - but here I was filled with so much knowledge and facts. I loved every minute.

The cafe they have is outstanding. Best lobster bisque I've had in my life. And their store is filled with amazing books and little trinkets you can take home. 

I never drive here, always take the bus. Which is relatively on time. It's a great experience here. Definitely add it to your museum must-sees.
author: Amanda S.

description: I love this museum and I love its location.  Walk around and go behind to the cliffs...amazing views...oh and the art is great to!
author: Mark B.

description:
This is a great museum.  Unfortunately, there is a vandalism problem in the parking lot.  My car got broken into yesterday and some property was stolen.  The management at the museum don't seem to care and avoid discussing the subject. The police tried calling the museum , and they were put on hold.  We gave up.  
You would think the museum could afford some type of surveillance or law enforcement presence.
author: Hector V.

description:
My Favorite Past Exhibitions 
- Cartier and America 
- Artistic Luxury: Fabergé, Tiffany, & Lalique
- Pulp Fashion: The Art of Isabelle de Borchgrave 

I Love Chihuly & Wearable Art. 
I enjoy each visit. 
Everything is so beautiful.
I recommend coming here.
author: Mariel F.

description:
I went to the BLING, aka Cartier exhibit at the LOH.  It's easily one of the most sparkly exhibits I've seen.

Diamond studded tiara's, precious stones that had me  fantasizing about pulling a Tom Cruise/Mission Impossible heist. 

The Cartier exhibit has been extended through May 9th 2010. The charge is $20 to enjoy the exhibit, along with the permanent collection, plus the Very Post Mortem...aka mummy exhibit showing through August 15th.  

If you haven 't been to the Legion of Honor, the grounds alone are enough reason to go, breathtaking views of the bay will have you lingering outside.
author: Benita S.

description: I'm not a very artistic person when it comes to painting and sculptures but its was an amazing place that had so much to enjoy but have to say that the Victorian Era is the part that interested me the most. I wouldn't recommend children only cause well they wouldn't enjoy it as adults or teens. The only part they will enjoy is the outside which is huge and a big play ground in my eyes. Other then that I would say go check it out and with a charged phone, You'll want to take pics.
author: Rosa A. F.

description:
The Legion of Honor is one of my favorite museums in San Francisco. 

As you head away from crowded Downtown and want to get a more peaceful sense of the city near the beach and Golden Gate Park, make sure to go to the Legion of Honor. Located on the hilltop of a golf course park, the museum's entrance is a grand, multi-columned courtyard and  "The Thinker", sits right in the middle of the courtyard to greet you. 

The only time i visit the Legion of Honor was due to their "Art Deco" exhibit but other rooms house a variety of artwork from ancient mediterranean to 17th, 18th and 19th European to more modern graphic design work. 

I love the fact you can get a great view of the city on one side and of the Golden Gate Bridge and the Pacific Ocean on the other.
author: Carol Y.

description:
Every time I come here, I marvel at the beauty of the Legion of Honor. I always see brides taking their pictures here and it's so easy to see why. Such a beautiful location and if you go to the nearby street, you can see the Golden Gate Bridge. 

Rodin's The Thinker sits in the courtyard, beckoning you to come inside the Legion's doors to explore and think about art. 

The BF and I came here for the Impressionist Paris exhibit, a companion exhibit to the DeYoung's Birth of Impressionism. If you had tickets to the BIrth of Impressionism, you could go into the Legion's exhibit (and museum) for free. Score!

We spent an hour or two wandering through the exhibit before he had enough of  Impressionist art and wanted to leave. 

Next time we're here, we are going through their permanent collection.
author: Julia W.

description: Love the architecture of this museum. Took wedding photos here. Beautiful location. Art is okay.
author: Beginning P.

description: One of my favorite museums in Bay Area. It looks like a mini size of Louvre because its front door. A great deal of collections and including several Claude Monet's paintings.
author: Ting L.

description: This was the first time at this art museum. Wow, I love the architecture here! Absolutely stunning! I got to see lots of art from the Baroque period and the Impressionist era in Paris. I saw Seurat's Eiffel Tower. It was so gorgeous that I had to purchase a poster for my bedroom. I haven't been to Paris, but one day I will go and I know I will be in awe. I also loved Monet's Water lilies. Absolutely beautiful! I can't wait for the next exhibits starting in October-January which are Ando Hiroshige and some Van Gogh. I love those art pieces from these two artists too. I am eagerly waiting for the next exhibition!
author: Jennifer G.H. W.

description:
It's sooo pretty here, outside and inside! It's not very big so you can walk through everything pretty quickly. The french jewelry exhibit was amazing, i wish i could've touched all of the old diamonds from cartier! It's small, but quiet and beautiful. Tons of free parking and a nice view of the city. there were people outside just hanging out on the grass, napping etc

P.S. you can get in free if you have a ticket stub from the deyoung or the other way around :).
author: Stella C.

description:
Again, tons of great work under this roof, but it's an overwhelming amount to get through. I felt that some of the rooms were a little repetitive. Also, they don't really have any memorable pieces of art that you'd find in your art history books, but it's all very good art. I found the furniture pieces to be amazing. Divide and conquer through multiple days.

Best piece is by a one William Adolphe Bouguereau. I stared at it for 10 minutes.

The Finnish exhibit was really impressive.
author: Jason L.

description:
This museum surpassed my expectations two-fold. As many reviewers before have mentioned; they have a substantial Rodin collection here. Having been to the Rodin Museum in Paris (it being one of my all time favorite museums, ever) I was impressed with the pieces the Legion of Honor had.

Also, a huge bone and porcelain china collection downstairs. Sometimes these pieces can be overlooked too quickly, but there really is some amazing work to be seen in the collection. Any dish collector would be very lucky to acquire. Another note, is the LOH building. It is massive and quite beautiful. I really enjoyed my visit here and will definitely be back to admire my favorites. 

Keep in mind, that admission here gets you into the de Young Museum for the day as well.  2 for 1... who doesn't love that!
author: Nichole P.

description: The building is incredible and is the reason (plus the views) that I come to this museum. There are some great special exhibits that come through on occasion like Georgia O'Keef or Monet's Water lillies. Yet often I find the place a bit stuffy and the art a bit boring. Yet the grounds are stunning, the building is amazing, the cafeteria is great and for that reason it is worth going or bringing a date.
author: Natasha M.

description: If you or someone is one of the persons who are into art and enjoy spending time at art galleries, the Legion of Honor and Asian Art Museums are one of the best places to go to. In these museums, not only are you looking at works of art from other artists but you'll also get the inspiration to be an artist or reveal your artistic side as a talent or hobby. I haven't walked through the entire Legion of  Honor yet. I should definitely go to Legion of Honor to view all the artwork masterpieces!
author: Bennett W.

description:
This is the second part of my amazing birthday present.  I had only been here once before I got my membership.  It was with my mom and little sister (16) and we went to see the Marie Antoinette show.  I got to see the bed from her bedroom.  Her clothes and furniture, it was all very cool.  

Then the first time I went this year was to see the Pulp Fashion show.  I thought it was going to be a show of Elizabethan era dresses, which would be cool in itself.  But when I get there it is one of the most amazing things I've ever seen.  PAPER DRESSES! FROM MY FAVORITE PAINTINGS!  My first thought is who has been doing these amazing works and why haven't I been following them around in a VW Bus for the past decade. Such delicate that all you can think is "how maddening it must have been to try and get that tissue paper to drape exactly like that".  My best friend and I found our wedding dress there, but we found it would be in poor taste to try and try it on.

I also saw the Japanese print show.  WOW.  i now am obsessed with Hiroshige and Hokusai.  What amazing colors and beautiful landscapes. And their dedication to the beauty of Mt. Fuji fired up my own feelings of dedication I have for the bay area and its beauty.

Then there are their small shows ( no pun intended) that you walk into not knowing anything and fall in love.  Their miniature show made me a little girl again.  I forgot how much I loved pretty little things.  So, so, so tiny.  How could he make that knight killing that dragon so colorful and detailed, and about a half an inch in diameter. Freaking amazing.

Then there are the grounds around the museum.  After each visit, before I leave I like to walk over on the lawn towards the bay and sit on the wall.  Just sit and look out at the bay and the marin headlands and end all that surreal beauty you just saw inside with some very real beauty all around you.
author: Meara G.

description: Gorgeous museum, less expensive than academy of sciences which I appreciated since I am a college student. Me and my friends went to go see the treasures from the louvre which were amazing. I had no idea how decadent everything was. It was also possible to view the restoration process behind the treasures that are displayed there. First time going and I will definitely be back!
author: Isabella O.

description:
FOR THE CARTIER EXHIBIT AS WELL.

Gorgeous, the museum and the Cartier exhibit. Dropped by for the very first time this last Tuesday and was DEEPLY impressed with the Cartier Exhibit as well as the beauty of this museum. The layout was nice, and their collection was impressive. My favorite was the mummy in the Very Postmortem Exhibit! This was what I was hoping to catch a glimpse of in the King Tut exhibit, of course not King Tut himself, but a mummy at least!!! The Legion of Honor should have let De Young borrow their mummy!

I was also excited to the see the Impressionist exhibition. This was my first time in the presence of a real MONET, and it was splendid!!! The art was so lovely. It's hard to believe that a few strokes of color here and there can be turned into something so beautiful and fluid. Monet=Splendid.

Back to Cartier. Wow, if you have not gone to this spectacular display of sheer brilliance, literally, then go now!! Stop reading and just go!! I'm not even a jewelry person, I always laughed at the notion that ALL women were moved by diamonds, since I, certainly was not. After seeing the exhibit though, well... I can definitely see why "diamonds are a girl's best friend!"

The sheer decadence and beauty each piece provoked teared me up with joy and envy!! Damn you diamonds!!! Why are thou so SHINY!!! Glittering pieces of gorgeousness!! I have to give it to Cartier, they are truly the masters of their craft!! You could just see the blood, sweat and tears that went into each piece. Sooooo beautiful!! 

I came in with a relative notion of beauty, and I came out with a deep understanding of pulchritude....and a wish list a mile long!! As soon as I, or my husband wins the lotto, I know how I'll be spending the money!! Thanks Cartier for reintroducing me to American Decadence and Materialism!! This exhibit rocks!!
author: Cami N.

description: Always wonderful ... last June my daughter and I saw the Gaultier exhibit.  Was not excited about going at first, but WOW ... what a crazy good way to showcase such an eclectic artist!
author: Julianne W.

description:
Outstanding exhibit until October 1: "Impressionists on the Water". Specially curated by the Lof H, the range of paintings and other artwork from the permanent collection, as well as from private collections and other art venues, is impressive. 

I have read much criticism of this exhibit as a "bust". Not sure what the viewer/writer had expected, but seeing this specialized array of paintings and drawings was a nice experience. Our FAMSF membership got us in free of charge (but we did pre-order timed admission tickets, also free) on a Sunday afternoon. You could go to lots of Monet and other Impressionist venues around the world and still not know that many painters of that era were sailors and boat designers! And boat builders! There are some boat models mixed with the paintings, and even some post-Impressionist works included. 

Thanks to the LofH for putting this together to celebrate the S.F. site of America's Cup in 2013.
author: joyce h.

description:
I love the Legion of Honor.  It has got to be my favorite museum in San Francisco.  Great place to take the kids!  

The architecture of the museum is breath taking.  It was modeled after a French palace "Palais de la Légion d'Honneur ".  Perfect place to take photos.  

They have a lot of European paintings and decorative art.  My favorite has got to be the Rembrandt and Monet paintings.  

Rodin's famous "Thinker" bronze sculpture can be found here.   

They offer a double membership, where it allows you and a guest to visit the Legion of Honor and De Young museum for free.
author: Jo P.

description: The location and backdrop of this museum make it a very special place. On one side you have the San Francisco cityscape and then on the other side you have the Pacific ocean with giant trees lining the whole area. The art displays and special exhibits are inclusive of the biggest time periods in art. A wonderful day trip and one I highly recommend for tourists and locals alike.
author: Shicara S.

description:
This museum has a little bit of everything for anyone out there.  You could see anything from sculptures, renaissane paintings, Japanese art, ect.  There is even a cafe downstairs with pretty good food.  Downstairs is a store and a section with Japanese art.  I love the art there and it is definitely a place for art lovers.  Even if you're not an art lover or not knowledgeable about this stuff you could still appreciate this museum.

What makes this museum special is the art inside and outside of the museum.  Just walking towards the museum is just beautiful.  So much, that you will see many couples take wedding pictures here.  I swear every time I go there someone is taking pictures in their wedding dress.  But hey, the museum is that beautiful.

Not to mention the the view of the bay and Golden Gate bridge just outside the museum.  In fact if you don't find parking in front of the museum you could just park down the street with that beautiful view.

Overall this is a really nice museum.  I think its free on the first Tuesday of each month.  Definitely worth a look.
author: Glenn P.

description:
Fantastic!
Amazing greek-inspired architecture
Killer view - the ocean, the Presidio, and this beautiful, serene golf course from atop a hill
Mind-blowing French Impressionism collection (to walk into room after room seeing works of art you've only read about as a kid?!)
Unbelievably preserved furnishings from 1600-mid 1850's Europe, some straight out of notable monarchs' bedrooms
The most extensive collection of Rodin sculptures - will move you to tears.
Oh, and I received a book from the presstour of the Cartier jewelry collection. WOW. I can't even wrap my head around that one, the $$$ worth of all those gemstones.

I also attended an organ performance once, which was wonderful.
author: Y K.

description:
Gorgeous museum in an unforgettable setting. Great views of the GG bridge & the city. The walk from the Legion of Honor along Lands End is spectacular. But, the museum collections just didn't do much for me. 

We went here last Saturday mostly to see the Mummies & Medicine exhibit. I was disappointed when I found that the exhibit was confined to one small room tucked away in the back of the museum. It was a nice little exhibit where an actual mummy was on display but it was a bit of a letdown. The Cartier exhibit isn't open yet so the Mummies were the only special exhibition on display. 

Now I'm not much of a fan of pre-20th century European paintings & the Legion has a whole lot of these. I cruised fairly quickly through these rooms. The 18th century porcelain collection on the ground floor was pretty impressive. 

I would definitely come back for another special exhibit because it is worth it to come, enjoy the view, & maybe hike along Land's End & end up at the Cliff House.
author: Erin S.

description: A classic elemental venue for arts and other museum and public events.  The special events here are especially well - done and admission tickets are reasonably priced.  I would recommend this place to anyone touring the area, and parking, on the other hand, might be an issue - there is heavy foot traffic some days, especially on the weekends.  Nice place for a date, too, though some people do not like the character of some of the pieces, nor the tone of the place and just end up running through and away from it.  This is not due to anyone's poor taste, though sometimes the subject matter of some of the pieces here can be touchy for one patron or another.  Really good!
author: Thomas H S.

description:
Best museum in San Francisco. Really huge and chock full of stuff that you would otherwise need to spend a week in Paris to see. Very beautiful grounds as well.

Highly recommended.
author: Andrew L.

description:
Very beautiful place.. both inside and out... scenery outside is fantastic... artwork (paintings and sculptures) are very open and visitors can get right up and personal.... actually I would be worried about people sneezing on these masterpieces!

No flash photos, but there is so much natural light that photos come out just fine.. cafe was very nice also.. great food and nice to sit outdoors.  My 6yr old daughter wasn't too interested in the paintings, but she loved the sculptures.

Parking was plentiful as they have a lot across the street, plus also there is street parking all along the side... next to a nice golf course as well.

First weekend of the month was free to BofA customers.. can't beat that deal !
author: Brian C.

description: My boyfriend and I were leaving Baker Beach and we wanted to do something around the area that was free. Luckily, it was the first Tuesday of the month and Legion of Honor was one of the free museums that day and it was just a 5 minute drive from Baker Beach. I was so amazed how beautiful the outside was. I'm not an art person but I thought it was a great experience. All the paintings and sculptures were beautiful. My favorite exhibit was the Mummies and Medicine because I love the Egyptian culture. Believe it or not, this is the second mummy I've seen. The first time i saw one was at the Haggin Museum in Stockton in 1998. Other than that, it's a good location to see the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Janice V.

description: Beautiful building and area.  Don't run over the multiple wedding brides taking their photos
author: Joshua L.

description: One of the best places to see art works past and present.  Place is full of history.  Location is outstanding.  Great for everyone who appreciate artwork.  As a kid I've always thought this place is where  Comic Superheros are housed - I was so wrong.  This place offers history through art.  Outside of this place you can walk  to a little area by the fountain and look for the  Holocaust Memorial created by artist George Segal - a definite must see.
author: Nixon L.

description:
My favorite museum in all of San Francisco.  With my one of my favorite sculptures ignominiously placed in the hallway decorating the entrance to the theater.  

The permanent collection is quite nice, I feel there is something for everyone to appreciate and you don't have to have an art history degree to "get" most of the art.  

When I take my family and friends on easy hikes along the Land's End trail, we'll stop inside, see the art, drop by the cafe and keep going.
author: Poppy C.

description:
My tastes are a little more modern, but I still appreciated this great addition to the SF arts scene. One of the best parts if before you even get inside - the absolutely stunning views. The Golden Gate Bridge is to your left, downtown straight ahead, Twin Peaks to your right. Just a subtle reminder we live in the most beautiful city. Ever.

Inside are room after large room of primarily European art. It's easy to get lost, and while nothing blew me away, it was an impressive collection of works. My favorite section was the current Cartier exhibit, easily the most expansive (and expensive) collection of jewels I've ever seen. The diversity in design was incredible.

Go for the views, stay for the art, appreciate our city.
author: Jason B.

description:
For many reasons, this is my favorite museum in San Francisco. 

Reason #1: A great variety of art with amazing exhibits. I did the art deco jewelry exhibit awhile back as well as the Helnwein Gottfried even further back. I have a fascination with the Renaissance and classic art and this definitely sates my appetite for that.

Reason #2: One of my favorite paintings of all time resides here. Jean Leon Gerome's The Bath. The use of color is just...amazing. 

Reason #3: The outside is jsut as spectacular as the inside. Amazing views. Beautiful architecture. And just a really pleasant place. I always envy the people who have their weddings there. I don't think I want to know how much they pay for that though.
author: Lindsey G.

description: free first tuesday of the month! By far the best museum in sf! Parking is tough on a free day but you get the best view and a little bit of europe when you visit this place. You can see the golden gate bridge clearly. The architecture is great!  Not to mention the pieces are spectacular.
author: Diane S.

description:
It is not a big area. I love the water fountain outside. I once left a friend sleeping there on purpose.

Go there early.
author: Ronald N.

description:
Love many of the oil paintings here, especially the ones of people.  I like to look at them and try to figure out what the artist was thinking about when they were drawing them, and how they saw the person.  In addition, I wonder what the person was trying to portray to the artist.  

There's also some really cool and black and orange terracotta pottery downstairs.  I learned it is made using some kind of reverse method.  Ask someone because I forgot what I learned in school.
author: Debbie N.

description:
This is a gorgeous museum, both inside and out. On a clear day, the view of San Francisco and the Bay is breathtaking. 

We went for the last day of the Japanese Print art exhibit, and even though it was insanely crowded, we still really enjoyed it. 

However, it was my first time at the museum (even though I'm a member...I know...for shame) and I wanted to see the Water Lilies. We wandered from room to room and finally came to the gallery where it should have been. I looked around the entire room, 3 times, just to be sure I wasn't missing it and...it wasn't there! 

There was no signage to indicate that one of their main attractions wasn't on display, or when it would be back. It was a huge letdown. It would have been nice for the museum to give it's patrons a heads up about that, instead of making me hunt around the place for a painting that wasn't there.
author: Rachel A.

description: This is one of my all-time favorite museums. I love coming to see the special exhibits. Beautiful location, too.
author: Katie R.

description: I was there for the Louvre exhibit recently & had a wonderful time at the museum. A lot of fine art tucked inside of an imposingly beautiful building. Parking was a bit of a bitch but it's manageable if you're patient.
author: Lew A.

description:
Haven't been inside since I was in elementary? Recently went back and definitely a nice place to snap a couple of shots. 

Only problem no bathroom and I had to go like a racehorse in the final race. Thankfulyl its quiet and deserted enough to pee in quiet. Or build a shack out in the middle of nowhere and become the Unabomber. Whatever floats your boat.
author: Andy C.

description: I've been here a few times over the years, and have always enjoyed each visit. Today I took some family visiting the San Francisco area from out of the country, to see the "Annie Leibovitz Photography Exhibit". Since we went in the middle of the day on a Wednesday, it wasn't too crowded making it quite enjoyable. The Legion of Honor is such a lovely place, scenic views of the Golden Gate bridge to the right and the golf course and ocean to the left. Peaceful and serene the grounds are so enjoyable to walk about. We didn't walk the whole museum today but did see a few of the Rodin, and these amazing glass sculptures by chihuly. The last time I was there two years ago to see The Monet exhibit and that too was breathtaking. Always a wonderful day trip. (see glass photos added 5-08)
author: Susan D.

description: Another fabulous museum in San Francisco. It is in a beautiful look out point location and is home to some truly incredible pieces. We should feel so privileged to have such an esteem variety of museums to choose from so close to us. This is definitely a gem of an art house and I highly recommend visiting if you have to do so. They have so many pieces that even their permanent collection gets rotated often even to keep things interesting.
author: Mandy L.

description:
This will be a fairly incomplete review, as I've had a fairly incomplete experience with the Legion of Honor.  I have as yet only been once, for the "Japanesque" exhibit, and I was unable to truly take in the splendors present in the majority of the museum.  And in the true spirit of art, the Legion of Honor appears to be a complex, multifaceted, beautiful whole, the parts of which I intend to enjoy more thoroughly at a later date.

And how could I not?  The grounds are beautiful and lovingly kept - it was such a joy to take a turn off the main road and be met with rolling fields and trees.  When I made it up the hill to the museum itself, I was in absolute awe of the view.  I love the courtyard area out front, I love the Thinker, and I love all the tourists taking pictures of themselves thinking with him.

The Japanesque exhibit itself was in the lower level, and was really quite nice.  There was a lot of material to see, but it was organized very intuitively, and the placards by the pictures were informative - and interesting, too!  If you're the type of person who doesn't often read them (and I'm not saying I am!), I imagine they would be quite enough to hold your attention.  The only thing that made the experience any less than stellar was the enormous guided tour going on, but I know that can't be helped - and for what it's worth, the guide sounded very knowledgeable!

While my experience wasn't life-changing, the Legion of Honor served its purpose well.  I wanted to know more about the Japanese influence on French artistry.  I got that and more in a lovely setting that's really quite close to where I live - and for only $8 with a MUNI pass.  Yes, I admit there is much more about the Legion of Honor I do not now.  But I plan on finding those things out very soon indeed.
author: Becca S.

description: I thought that this was the best of the major art museums in San Francisco. Smaller and uncrowded, with a broad overview of European art and a large sculpture collection.  And I can't forget to mention the beautiful location!  The only problem is that for a visitor without a car, it's far away from everything else you want to see and it takes a while to get all the way out here on the bus.
author: Mike W.

description:
i remember taking the 18 down the great highway to this gorgeous museum.  the ride is absolutely beautiful with a grand view of the pacific.

be sure to check out the holocaust memorial some feet away from the museum.
author: Amy L.

description:
SHINYSHINYSHINYSHINYSHINY

...woo, sorry, still in Cartier exhibit overload.

The jewelry is stunning, and the artistry--particularly in the mystery clocks--is so evident that you needn't ask why diamonds are art.

The only unfortunate part?  Even on a Tuesday afternoon, the exhibit was still seriously overcrowded.  And old ladies have SHARP elbows.
author: Caitlin M.

description: Excellent place to spend a sunny, or cold day, in SF.  The views outside the museums are breathtaking and great for photos (engagement, family, etc).  The Thinker is there also, and who wants to miss seeing that? I saw Leonardo da Vinci's "Lady with Ermin" there it was such a great experience since he is one of my all time favorite artists.
author: Erica K.

description: I just checked out the Pissarros People exhibit. It runs until January 22nd. I highly recommend it. I splurged for the headset. I found it very rewarding. I learned a lot about the artist and had a much greater appreciation for his work. The best part of his work is the dimension and point of view his work takes. I would turn around and see one of his paintings from across the room and fall in love with it even more then from a couple feet away. There is also the chance to see one of his paintings that has not been restored. It was recently discovered. The texture of the painting is that of when it first was painted. It was great to see the difference between one that has not gone through any restoration process and those that had.
author: Ashley S.

description:
One of the most beautiful museums I've been to.

What I like best about it is that there are so many beautiful views from this site, and not only of the museum itself. 

The 18 bus wil take you straight up the hill there, but I recommend you walk through the grass area. It's quite therapeutic and there's a bench and a view of the city at the top. There's a million daisies in the grass so you can make daisy chains to wear. 
To the side of the museum, there's a woodsy area where you can get a view of the good old Golden Gate Bridge. 

Also, I believe if you take the Muni and save your proof of purchase pass, you get $2 off your admission price. (Or this may be at the deYoung. I'm not sure which one)
author: J L.

description:
Great setting like out of a European tourist guide but in San Francisco. Lots of classical collonades and stonework surrounded by well manicured grounds (what a golf course in the city?). 

There are a lot of cool paths around the outside of the museum to stroll and check out the views and memorials.

Really liked the Rodin sculpture garden.
author: Brad C.

description:
I never been to the Legion of Honor, although I've been a SF Bay Area resident for 10 years. I was totally excited because I was using my free day admissions with my BofA card. Moreover, my daughter who is 12 and under got in free too. 

Driving up to Legion, I was so amazed at the beauty of the museum. When we walking towards the entrance, the courtyard was filled with not only the 'The Thinker' statue, but of a wedding couple and party taking advantage of the cultured appearance. 

There were so many rooms to choose from and so many exhibits to see. You can get lost after awhile to the multiple openings to each room and of course the spectacular paintings. Our save for last moment was the Monet 'Water Lillies' which reminds how lucky our world is to have artists who capture our hearts and appreciation. I can't wait to go back for other exhibits!
author: Jamie L.

description: The Legion is an absolutely beautiful location and building. You can find a nice view of the Golden Gate Bridge from the edge of the surrounding golf course. It's more secluded than other museums so it's less crowded, and offers same day free admission to the de Young.
author: Andrew W.

description:
Me @ the Exploratorium: Where is the art museum at the Palace of Fine Arts?

Young Help Lady: Ummmm this is the only museum in the PFA... 

Me: Oh, I meant the Legion of Honor!

Young Hep Lady: OH, you're totally in the wrong neighborhood! You should take the 28 to the Outer Richmond...

DUH 

So from there I took the 28 to the foot of the Golden Gate Bridge (yeah, totally unintentional), got off since the driver wasn't the most informative (I WAS on the right #@$&#(&$ bus!), got back on the 28 and then to the 38 Geary where I walked the rest of the way. 

As I was walking towards the monumental building, I saw the finishing setup of a wedding about to take place in front of the courtyard on that beautiful Saturday night. 

The art that interested me the most were the impressionism and post-impressionism paintings of Monet (one of few Water Lilies collection. There is another set at the MFA in Boston), Renoir, and more. The collection is nothing too impressive though. 

Definitely worth the visit, especially when I got in free with a BofA card during the 1st week of the month. 1-1.5 hrs is the max I would spend here. Not somewhere you can be lost in, however, like the SF MOMA.
author: Kenny L.

description:
[pics added]

we came here specifically to see max klinger's work, and to check out the baldessari special show. especially cool was the interactive part of baldessari's exhibit. i was surprised that these artists were featured at the legion of honor because i've always assumed the LOH showcased a more classical/baroque kind of art. needless to say, i was delightfully surprised.

bouguereau's The Broken Pitcher made me cry. just a little bit. hormones do betray, indeed. also of note: the beautifully dramatic 15th century spanish ceiling.

i agree with other yelpers in that the location and actual museum is gorgeous. truly, the $10 admission is well worth it, as it also counts for free admission to the de young. there are additional discounts for students and those who show their muni bus transfers as well.

there is no photography allowed of any kind in the special exhibitions, though no-flash photography is allowed throughout the rest of the building. we left when the organ man began to play. something about the blaring church music amidst egyptian artifacts downstairs creeped me out in a way i can't begin to even explain.
author: Vanessa D.

description:
I have very mixed feelings about the Legion of Honor. The view on the way up to the entrance, around a golf course, is beautiful. I highly recommend lacing up your hiking boots, looping your camera around your neck, and checking out the amazing overlook.

Once there, you'll notice the building's really quite lovely, large neo-classical plaza entrance. So has everyone else...and their photographer! You might have to duck past several album cover and head shot sessions before you get to the actual exhibits.

The museum's collection includes more Rodin than I've seen anywhere outside of Philadelphia. (Yes, really. It is on the Benjamin Franklin Parkway at 22nd Street and it is a must-see, but I digress.) They say the European painting displayed there represents works from the 1300s to 1900s. That's a long time, encompassing a wide range of amazing objects, but I found the quantity and variety underwhelming.

The sense I get is that this is a museum you visit for its featured Special Exhibitions -- like the Japanese prints that were on during my stay -- and not for its more fixed, rotating galleries.
author: Hillary C.

description: I have lived in the bay area all my life, and this is the first time I have ever been here. Bank of America has a promotion where you can get into the museum free on the first weekend of the month, so we took advantage of this offer. Me and my husband did the audio tour, which costs extra, but well worth it. If you do the audio tour, allow for at least 4 hours to go through the museum. The parking is free, but I recommend to get there early to get a spot. They do have a café inside, but it is a bit expensive. Good thing we brought our lunch and ate it outside afterwards. With the same ticket, you can also get into the De Young Museum for that day. However, we decided to take a hike on the local trail around the legion of honor, which was also wonderful. Next time I will need to wear better shoes for the hike.
author: Dee P.

description: The Legion of Honor is a stunning museum inside and out.  Their collection of paintings is wonderful, but I the Rodin sculpture gallery gives the Legion it's uniqueness.
author: Marissa R.

description:
Very nice museum in a great location! Been walking/ hiking around Land's End several times but didn't see the inside of the museum until yesterday. 

They are having the Cartier exhibit and I really enjoyed it. Lots to see, and who doesn't love to see gigantic diamonds?? Tiaras, necklaces, rings of famous ladies are all out on display. Also has the history and drawings of some of the jewelry from the 1900s there! Great collection!!

I have to say don't bother with the audio headset ($7), it's pretty much the same info of what you can read on the sign of each display.
author: Florence W.

description:
4. Four Impressionist masters
3. Three galleries of Rodin sculptures 
2.  Two El Greco paintings (including a stunning John the Baptist)
1.  A mummy! 
0. Free admission for children under 12. First Tuesdays (9:30-5:15) are also free and not crowded during the school day.

According the their website they have some Matisse, but there was not one on display. You can search the collections of several Museums here: http://legionofhonor.famsf.org/search-collections
author: Ria J.

description:
I came for the Cartier exhibit (which was amazing) but the rest of the location fell a little flat. The setup of the museum is prime for getting lost almost immediately. I would come here for special exhibits but it's a little too far out of the way for regular trips.

Perk: You can probably get free street parking fairly close to the museum, that's a rarity in San Francisco.
author: Morin O.

description:
The permanent collection is quite nice, there are several galleries which I particularly like, such as those which contain the Renaissance paintings. It's enjoyable being able to return often and see my favorites.  That said, the permanent collection could do with a more frequent "refresh."

These days, the main attraction is certainly the temporary exhibits.  They're usually done well, but not quite as well as at the de Young.  Get a membership and enjoy free or reduced-price admission.

The entrance and reception desk area is poorly organized, and for as long as I can remember, staffed by mostly grumpy volunteers.  Shame, really, since that's everyone's first impression of the venue.  Non-members are supposed to enter the main door, and stop at the desk on the left.  Members are supposed to enter through the right side door, and stop at the desk on the right.  This direction is not sufficiently siged, and the security guard will gladly show you the door out so you can enter through the proper one instead.

One of the most fantastic things about the Legion are the pipe organ recitals on Saturday and Sunday.  One artist is David Hegarty, whom you'll recognize, perhaps only from the back, as the performer on the Wurlitzer at the Castro Theater.

Only recently tried the Cafe on my last visit.  It was standard walk-up fare, but reasonable, considering.  The dining area was ample, and a bit noisy.  Sitting outside was delightful.  There are lovely shade trees, and a bit of a view down the cliffs and over to the Headlands.

Despite some shortcomings, the Museum is most definitely worth exploring!
author: Ken B.

description:
The location and building are beautiful and there are always great exhibits. 

The only thing about this place (and this is obviously nothing they can do about) is how crowded their special exhibits are. I recently went to the Cartier exhibit and I literally had to battle old ladies for a spot to view ANYTHING. I think they ought to sell a limited amount of tickets b.c. for $20 you not only get the exhibit but a boxing match with everyone else that is trying to view the exhibit. 

Another thing - the staff has been getting bitchier and stricter with years...not sure what has happened in the hiring department but I saw the "guards" lash out at everyone - from drinking water (water!!!)) to yelling at kids to get with their parents (when they WERE with their parents) to entering in the wrong way - major tude from all the employees but I guess it makes sense if you're protecting the Cartier exhibit :)

The museum has a lot going on and plenty to see. If you come here on a sunny day you can even enjoy the outside.
author: Sasha B.

description: We went to the Legion of Honor on our honeymoon trip to San Francisco. It's the most beautiful place and unexpected. One minute you are in the heart of San Francisco surrounded by city streets and hustle and bustle. A minute later you are surrounded by rolling green hills and gorgeous architecture. It was a really nice break from the city. It's not a huge place but it is really beautiful - even if you just look at the outside and don't go in.
author: Melissa M.

description:
Wedding review:

My husband and I got married at the Legion in May of 2008 and the experience was exceptional in every way. The result was a memorable, romantic ceremony and reception, which our friends and family, more than a year later, are still talking about.

I read a really negative review of the Legion's event staff, which is what promoted me to write now - over a year after our wedding. I was really surprised at the negative review I read as my wedding was around the same time and I had none of those issues. I am very sorry that bride had difficulties, however my experience was great. 

We got married in the Court of Honor and the entire bridal party had access to the theatre and dressing rooms (and bathroom!) prior to the ceremony and throughout the evening - good thing too because my sister left my husband's ring in her bag down there and one of the groomsmen had to run and get it during the ceremony! When we arrived we were greeted with a plate of yummy cheese and several bottles of champagne. It was a lovely, relaxing way to prepare for the ceremony.

The ceremony itself was a dream and I know that Vince the facilities manager for the Legion and Jill from Bon Appetit had a lot to do with it.  Additionally, the coordination was really quite impressive (while we were taking pictures after the ceremony, we watched them break down the chairs, etc - they did it in under 20 minutes - amazing!). Both Vince and Jill were VERY helpful and responsive. 

Lastly. It's hard to imagine what the cafe will look like all dressed up, but it's really quite nice. The wooden floors, chrome bar and black and white photos on the walls result in a modern and elegant look that when paired with the right linens and flowers is really quite stunning.
author: Michelle D.

description: I love this museum. The location is unbeatable and the views of the pacific are great. The art exhibits are classy and include a large selection of Rodin's works which are an excellent look into early 20th century style. There is a fair amount of paintings representing many impressionist greats ( not their major work, but a good sampling). The presentation is very classy and impressive. It absolutely blows away the Neo modern De young museum with it's horrible dress and other  "art" exhibits which reek of commercialism and pretension. When done inside the Legion of Honor, make sure you look at the holocaust memorial which is stunning and painful. The ocean unwraps below you giving you hope and wonder.
author: Sheva B.

description:
ARTISTIC LUXURY:  FABERGE, TIFFANY, LALIQUE 

What a fabulous exhibit! 

Walk into rooms filled with jewelry, silver and gold, and amazing miniatures. See the art that started Art Nouveau. See a dressing table of hand-hammered silver! 

The art on display came from the 1900 World's Fair in Paris, and demonstrates the superior workmanship of the best the world had to offer for the rich and famous. Not only Faberge, Lalique, and the two Tiffanys, but also their best competition, are represented here. 

Standing in this exhibit, I thought, "between the price of the raw materials, the artistry and craftsmanship, the rarity and age of the work, and its place in art history, I am sure this exhibit is worth millions, if not billions of dollars." Between the rubies, sapphires, diamonds, silver, gold, platinum, and innumerable other materials worked like cake icing in nearly microscopic detail, I could not help but feel rich and prosperous myself. Even the names of the collectors who lent their treasures for this exhibit were inspiring. 

Lunch in the museum cafe also was a treat, as the sunlight in that room and the view of the lawn were as inspiring as ever. 

$20 per person admitted us into the special exhibit, and showing our Muni transfer awarded us each a $2 discount. General admission is free the first Tuesday of the month, so it will only cost you $10 to see this exhibit on those days. 

This special exhibit runs through May 31, 2009.
author: David D.

description:
The exhibit is Artistic Luxury: Faberge, Tiffany and Lalique which for an antique/jewelry fanatic like me is like going to heaven a few years early. 

Some of the amazing highlights for me were the 7 Easter eggs made by Peter Carl Faberge; the US premiere of Tiffany's Magnolia Window that belonged to Baron Stieglitz, a close associate of Czar Nicholas II of Russia, including an translucent peacock lamp and the autumn leaf globe lamps from the Cleveland Museum of Art.

You can also see Tiffany jewelry and the breathtaking art nouveau jewelry, glasswear and sculpture from Rene Lalique's Paris World Fair exhibits of 1900.

My favorites are of course the Tiffany's, brilliant otherworldly molded stained glass assembled in 3 dimensions. His typical lamp shades were made from hundreds of pieces of stained glass cut from poured sheets and then carefully layered to create varied tones, values and trick effects. The surface of the glass was then rippled, mottled, dicrolic to effect a change in color when the light was active.

Utterly unique, Tiffany's could be multi-themed... floral, geometric, fruited, plantlike. The only limitation was inside the creative and fertile mind of it's maker, the geniused Louis Comfort Tiffany who also attached his kaleidoscoped translucent glassworks to shades and bases of copper that unified and linked the shards together. In fact, the bases themselves were also works of art that often enhanced the entire package beloved by millions and sought by museums and collectors throughout the world.

In the presence of such genius, it is often difficult to put into words something so precious as you gaze upon matched and mismatched sections of design as bases and shrouds can be removed and transferred easily in order to achieve a completely different affect. 2 dimensioned photographing cannot capture what in person is alive and living, breathing, and altering itself as time applies her patina in sections and arenas. Circling each hand-built, mind dreamed creation allows the viewer to capture more fully a complete original entity. Each a mini half-globe, pulsing, throbbing, flashing as different angles of inner light flow through from the center through to the outside atmosphere.

The exhibit is available and alive until the end of May. Go, take an aficionado with you and together you can experience what is not just greatness but divine inspiration formed into touchable, usable, functional wonderment.

In the meantime, I bought a book for my Mom's birthday, as soon as she opens her present, I'll take pictures and post them here but to experience them for yourself, you must go and submerge your entire being into what is more than greatness, it is unbelievable. I'm still awestruck by what I've just witnessed.
author: Terry H.

description:
I've been here a gaggillion times, and I have always enjoyed their collections, but I could definitely not pass up the Cartier exhibit.  Luckily a museum friendly college bud came to visit, so we caught the exhibit while catching up!

The pieces were AMAZING!

but the highlight of the walk through was a lovely gentleman named, Sam.  I'm not sure if he was security or Legion staff, but he stopped us (two beautiful 20 somethings), and directed us on how to correctly walk the exhibit and then made sure that we circled back past him, so he could let us "try on a bracelet."  of course gullible me was like "Hell yea!" but Zandy was less trusting.  

Long story short Sam played a smoke and mirrors trick to make it look like the amazing jewelry was hanging on our wrists and necks by positioning us just right at the reflection on the glass.  smart!  although getting reacquainted with an old friend was the highlight of my week, Sam was a quick second.

go, and if you are a Gap.Inc employee don't forget your ID!  BTWs the museum is closed on Mondays!
author: Gina N.

description:
Went to the Legion of Honor for the first time yesterday. It was free Tuesday so I love that! :) The Legion is an incredible building and is in a beautiful location. The collection is reasonably sized (read: not too big).

So the truth of the matter is that I'm really not a huge fan of the genre of European art that dominates the museum. I haven't seen that many paintings of Jesus in all my life. But still, there's some pretty cool stuff. 

Oh, I was also surprised at the size of the Mummies and medicine exhibit. Was hoping it would be a bit more substantial. Overall though, a great experience capped off with a walk on the beach nearby.
author: Leslie C.

description:
Classic.
Timely.
Elegant.
Like an elegant pant suit designed by YSL, this museum brings you back.

With any museum, I highly encourage the audio tour...if not, you are just walking around aimlessly without any background or direction. Sure you can stare at it, but it's nice to get the most for your buck.

I tend to like Modern Art, but sometimes the modern naked funk freaks me out. Classics history is always a nice change. Love that rooms are all painted in beautiful colors. Love the marble. Love the ceilings. Love the view.  It's just so grand.  

Definitely buy the pass that gets you into this and deYoung Museum, as it makes it that more economical.  
Best way to put it...when I go to the Legion, I feel like someone out of Great Gatsby book, or someone in Roman times with the name of  Apollonia-wait wasn't that the Prince Dancer...?

Either way, you get my point. 
.
author: Flor D.

description: Legion of Honor is my favorite museum in the area. The elegance of this museum is the closest thing San Francisco has to the museums of France. The special exhibits are always well done, with a lot of quality pieces to see without it being overwhelmingly large to the point where you're exhausted by the end of it. I'm proud to be a member of this museum to support the fine arts. The parking can get tricky on especially busy days and weekends. But just keep looking and you'll eventually get lucky with a free spot.
author: Kristy C.

description:
I have memberships of several museum not only in San Francisco, but also in other cities. I like this small museum since they have good exhibitions 1-2 times per year. Unfortunately, the cafe is too small. The good museums usually have very nice cafe inside where you can enjoy even only the food. 
Also, the museum shops have limited selection and the catalogs are not translated at all. I asked the lady in the shop and her answer was "No international version. We are FRENCH museum!". I speak French, but I didn't even see French version at all. Lesson should be learned - many art collectors are not English speakers.
author: Y T.

description:
The California Palace of the Legion of Honor is still my favorite museum in San Francisco.  Their special exhibits including Art Deco, Monet in Normandy and Women Impressionists have had a lasting impression on me.

The current exhibit: "Artistic Luxury: Fabergé, Tiffany, Lalique" is fantastic.  In these bleak economic times, a few hours at the Legion of Honor could prove to be a good distraction therapy for all of us.

See the meticulous craftsmanship in a number of luxury items made exclusively for the rich and famous and previously on display at the 1900 World's Fair in Paris.
author: Justin C.

description:
I love going to museums and going to this one was no exception. We decided to go since I had the day off on a Tuesday. While I was skeptical since I hadn't heard of it, I was up for the activity. They have a exhibit occurring of Faberge, Tiffany, and Lalique. 

We spent the first hour and a half wandering the top floor of paintings and sculptures from various artists. It was interesting though there was a large emphasis in a few halls of religious artifacts. Thought I don't mind, I have a few friends who find these pieces a bit much. Loved the French pieces of the 14th and 15th century. The exhibit was awesome! If you have the chance to go, I suggest it. All the beautiful intricate pieces really lets you appreciate the artwork. 

ONE SIDE NOTE: It's $10 extra for the exhibit (student price =$16), $2 off if you use the Muni, and the 1st Tuesday of the month is free.
author: Jessica H.

description:
The architecture and the view are both breathtaking.   All the bling from the Cartier exhibition almost made my head spin.  It's available till April.  Worth every penny of admission.  

Mmmm would be nice if they plan one for Harry Winston...and Graff... and Leviev.....then I'll probably be blind from looking at all the bling-bling.

Bring your B of A Visa first weekend of the month for discounted admission to the special exhibits.  Permanent collection free with Visa.
author: Tadaa T.

description:
Nice place to go to without the major big crowds and big bucks

 I was able to look at all the art there without crowds of people in the way.. Beautiful place...

The area surrounding this place has beautiful views of this wonderful city...I went for the Impressionist exhibit here and it was great...

Highly recommended...
author: Summer M.

description:
"Someone out to tell them [Americans] how to behave in a museum.  They talk as if they were at home..."

Charles Dantzig quoted in "Objectif Lune," in Harper's magazine, May 2009.
from Encyclopédie capricieuse du tout et du rien.

Just a suggestion.

* * * * *

Perhaps because of its astonishing location, its large collection of French painting, and its association with France (the museum is dedicated to those Californians who lost their lives on the battlefields of France during the first world war), a visit to the Legion of Honor actually is rather subdued in terms of  the visitor behavior (The French, understandably, make this a point of pilgrimage).
