Among the well-known French painters represented in the Legion's collections are La Tour, Watteau, Monet, Manet, and David; other European masters include Fra Angelico, Rembrandt, Tiepolo, Rubens, and El Greco.

The hues of the Monet waterlilies--rosy pink, sapphire blue, dark green--are like a mirror reflection of the environs of the Legion d'Honneur.

No need to go to Stanford (or the Musee Rodin in Paris, for that matter)--with a larger, more importance collection--to experience Rodin. 

http://paris-ile-de-france-centre.france3.fr/emissions/le-plus-grand-musee-du-monde/index.php?page=article&numsite=1508&id_rubrique=1655&id_article=13694

Not only is there a postcard-worthy Rodin (a bronze cast of "The Thinker" at the peristyle that leads to the entrance, there is one whole room devoted to Rodin sculpture, with models of figures from "The Burghers of Calais," and other busts or figures, many of them barely emerged from the marble.

* * * * *

The Legion of Honor is located in the most breathtaking setting for an American museum, possibly excepting the Getty Museum in Los Angeles.
The view of the Golden Gate Bridge, the cypresses, the almost sapphire blue of the Pacific Ocean practically at one's feet, and the walk down towards Land's End are astonishing.

The building itself in its monumental pristine white Beaux Arts classicism is is imposing as its location.

The pricey but spacious cafe in the basement has an outdoors terrace from which one can relax in, contemplate, and admire the beautiful environs high above San Francisco Bay.
author: Lily H.

description: I am a museum nerd. The Legion of Honor is one my favorites. If you are from out of town and trying to decide where to go, I would highly recommend coming here. Not only are the pieces some of the best in the world, but the location displays one of the best views of the Golden Gate Bridge. Almost every time I have gone for a visit, there is a wedding party having their photo taken right in front of the museum. Try to take advantage of the Bank of America card holders free admission days.
author: Jenny M.

description:
I have to say that having just seen "Vertigo" (the Hitchcock film that features several scenes shot in the museum) not too long before coming here for the first time made being in the Legion of Honor feel the slightest bit creepy... but aside from that, I really had a good time here. 

I would highly recommend coming as early as possible for special exhibits - we were able to walk right in when we got there around 10:30am, but the line was already INCREDIBLY long by the time we left the exhibit around 12pm.

Be sure to keep your ears open - listening to people try to impress their dates by spouting out douchey-sounding art history facts is in itself nearly worth the price of admission!
author: Elizabeth B.

description: I've never actually been INSIDE the museum, except to use the bathroom. I'm reviewing this basically as a setting for photography - I work part-time as a model and I've done several shoots here. The grounds are beautiful - despite the amount of tourist traffic running through this place, it's kept very clean. The lawn is well-manicured and the fountain out front is clear of trash. The entryway of the museum is framed on both sides by huge concrete pillars; the minimalist atmosphere with its neutral colors make for a great backdrop in photos. From the front steps, there is an amazing view of the city; if you go down the hill a little bit toward the golf course, the entire length of the GG Bridge and part of the Marin Headlands are also visible. I also want to give a quick bit of praise to the guy at the door - even though I didn't pay, he let me run in real quick to use the bathroom in the middle of a shoot one day. A model who has to pee does not photograph very well!!!
author: Heather K.

description:
Between the two Fine Arts Museums in the City, the Legion of Honor is my preferred one. Favorites here include the collection of Rodin sculptures and several Monets.  The building's setting could not be more dramatic, perched on the cliff on the north-western corner of the City. While it is the less accessible from a transit perspective compared to the De Young, the 18 bus terminates in front. Get here when the museum opens at 9:30am for one of the coveted parking spots.

The current special exhibit is Artistic Luxury: Faberge, Tiffany, and Lalique. The exhibit is laid out very well. The works of the three are first presented in the context of the 1900 World's Fair in Paris, and you get a little taste of each at the start. It then moves on in the order of the name of the show. My favorites are definitely the Tiffany stained glass pieces and the Faberge egg that was a clock.

I highly recommend a weekend trip to the museum to see Artistic Luxury.
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description:
These are the times I've visited the Legion of Honor.

1. I took my students to see Cinderella in their beautiful theater.
2. I got a free pass to see the Egyptian exhibit last year.
3. I got married there.  

Now, about number 3...this place is the most beautiful site for a wedding.  We had ours outdoor (it was freezing in July) and the reception was held in their cafe, which we didn't recognize after they decorated it.  If you get married at the Legion, you have to hire their personal catering company, which was fine with us because the food was AMAZING.  It's a great place to get wedding pictures taken, as we found out when several other brides came to get their photos done while we were trying to set up.  Aside from the hideous events organizer they forced upon us, it was a perfect experience.  The art 'aint half bad, either.
author: Kristina R.

description:
The Legion of Honor is an ideal place to spend any weekend day. With rotating temporary exhibits, the museum is ever changing. The museum itself sits on a golf course and all around it are views of both the city and the golden gate. The "Thinker" welcomes you to the front of the museum and it is a site to see. When we were there tons of people were out and taking pictures, even a wedding was being held. Inside the museum my favorite room held Picasso and Dali, but they have art from many different time periods. You can take photos (without the flash), and they have tours almost every hour, ending around 2pm. 

The temporary exhibit when we went was "Leonardo da Vinci: Drawings from the Biblioteca Reale in Turin". It was amazing. Only downside was the extra $10 we had to pay and the 45 minute line. But, in the end it was worth it. Also, check out the café and the museum gift shop downstairs.
author: Natalie N.

description:
Diamonds are apparently a girls best friend.  I think that is why my mom dragged us to the new Faberge, Tiffany and Lalique exhibit.  Truly all of the things in the collection were beautiful and completely unrealistic for anyone to own. I was shocked the how many jeweled dog collars there were.  Rich people are so nutty!
I was surprised by how small the Legion of Honor was.  But the two wings on the main floor can be done in about an hour.  The Rodin collection is very comprehensive.  But there is not really much in the collection that is impressive.  They have pieces by major artists, but nothing of much substance.  The Spanish ceiling is probably the most impressive thing they have, so don't forget to look up!
author: Caroline B.

description:
At the Leibowitz exhibit, there's a picture of Cindy Crawford, naked from the waist up, with a snake provocatively draped around her. My date asked me if I would pose like that for $1 million. Of course, I replied, but I'd probably need to pay the $1 million, not the other way around. To be photographed by the genius that Leibowitz is an honor that few ever can claim. 

The exhibit itself was amazing and intense, but also intensely crowded and suffocating. You were basically given a few seconds for each picture before being pushed along, as if you were on an airport people mover. The crowd only slightly marred my experience however. Leibowitz has perfected the technique of capturing the human essence, both celebrity and "real people." The photos capturing the death of her father and long-time lover are poignant, and you feel almost voyeuristic observing such a personal moment, but you can't take your eyes away. 

The Legion and its permanent exhibit are an amazing testament to the curator. We only had a few minutes to investigate before closing, but from what we viewed, it seemed to have a well-chose European collection of paintings and scultpture that befits its elegant architecture and picturesque setting overlooking Seacliff and the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Suzanne R.

description:
There are days when I really just need to be alone and quiet.  I'll take a morning or sometimes a whole day and just go out and do things by myself and not say a word to anyone. 

Last Sunday I came to the Legion of Honor to recenter myself.  I love art. I was an Art History major in college.  Walking through this museum is similar to going to church for me.  It's peaceful and meditative and everyone leaves me the hell alone.  

As far as their permanent collections they have a few solid exhibits and they are a little scattered in their actual floor plans. Their Impressionist and Post-Impressionist are combined into one room and is very much lacking but still the main artists are shown.  They are lucky enough, however, to be in a circulation of amazing traveling exhibits. You can see some very famous artist if you keep up with their schedule.

The Legion is known for it's architecture, cafe and special exhibits.   You really can't walk away from here without feeling lighter and filled with a sense of amazement as you walk into an amazing outdoor ambiance.  I know when I leave, I feel much better, calmer and quite frankly nothing much can bother me.
author: Jay H.

description:
We got married here on a ridiculously gorgeous Saturday this summer.  The setting could not have been more perfect for us, and we were thrilled to have blue skies in July.  We absolutely loved our wedding day.

I really, really wish I could give it 5 stars.  However...

BRIDES BEWARE: If you happen to have a wedding dress that will wrinkle if you sit too long and are thinking that you'll be able to slip into your dress once you get to the Legion, think again.  I got ready with my bridesmaids off site but needed to put my gown on after the car ride up to the Legion.  

I was prohibited from using any bathroom or room inside the museum, even though I was willing to pay admission to be allowed into the museum for 5 minutes with my maid of honor.  I was told that I had to use the free-standing public restrooms outside the museum, which I did.  

My maid of honor laid sheets down on the gooey floor of the men's restroom and I put my wedding gown on as bridesmaids stood guard outside.  Thank goodness the scent of urine and feces didn't cling to me.  Needless to say, those sheets will never be used again.

We also had an issue with the fee for using the Court of Honor, but that got resolved with the facilities manager.  Our rental contract addendum contained a fee for having the ceremony in the Court of Honor, and the Court was not listed as one of the areas subject to an additional hourly fee.  When our final payment came due, the Legion read a 30 minute time limit into the contract and tried to charge us extra for having the Court open for an hour.  We worked it out, thankfully, and I understand that they've revised their rental materials to include a 30 minute allowance for Court of Honor ceremonies.

In spite of these things, it was a magical day!

EDIT: In response to an email I sent expressing how disappointing and gross it was to change in the men's restroom, I received a condescending, petty reply.  I'm taking away a star for an employee's immaturity and unprofessionalism.  Watch out, ladies - if you cross the facilities manager, you'll pay for it.
author: katie m.

description:
It's embarrassing to admit, but all these years being a local and I had no idea (NO IDEA) how incredible this museum is.  Coming here is like a European vacation for a few hours (spending US Dollars instead of Euros, thank Allah).

I've seen this place as I've made my way around the Lincoln Park golf course, but was completely ignorant until recently about the gems inside.  Particularly impressive to me is the Rodin collection.  I'm no art expert, but I do love his work, and this is the next best thing to being in Paris for seeing his work.  Literally.  It says so.

If you're lucky, and the weather is nice (try October or April), you can even comfortably sit outside in the front with the glass pyramid and pretend you're at the Louvre (although you might have to ignore the SF hippies playing hackysack).

Make a day of it, and walk around the trails nearby with scenic vistas of the Golden Gate Bridge, the Marin Headlands, and maybe even the Farallon Islands if you have bionic vision.  Listen quietly and you can hear the lighthouse sounding off all the way across the mouth of the bay.

Oh yeah, the museum's pretty darned nice too.  

Cash-saver tip: They have cheapo days once a month, so if you can put up with the crowds, you might try that.
author: Brad P.

description:
As someone who's been to some of the swankiest museums on either hemisphere of the earth, from the Getty to the Louvre, from the Accademia di Belle Arti Firenze to "El Prado" in Mardid; and as someone who managed to somehow get an A in a fairly comprehensive Art History Class, I really don't know jack shit about art.  

By looking at a painting I really couldn't tell you what time period its from or how it was made, much less who created it.  I'd probably even struggle telling a painting made from color pencils from one made with chalk, and a statue made from marble versus one made of play-doh--but that certainly is the beauty of art, it's all in the eye of the beholder.

Having recently gone here with a few true art buffs though, who offered more insightful comments than my usual "Oh that's pretty" or "That's hot" really added to the experience, as one would expect.  

That's the beauty of this place, its got enough history within it all to captivate the most educated of scholars to the biggest ignoramus of them all (e.g. yours truly) and all in between.  

Five full stars for making an elitist out of this Elite Yelper for a day.
author: Tien N.

description:
A replica of the Palace of Legion of Honor in France, this French inspired museum is great and well kept.  This museum was given to honor the Californians who died during WWI. Great place for wedding fotos as well.

Walking in, you will be standing in the Court of Honor, "The Thinker."

Tons of rooms, I believe there were 19 rooms w/diff exhibitions. From Medieval, Renaissance, French & Italian Baroque, 17-19th c Decorative Arts & Scuplture (2 of my fave!) British art, and Neoclassical to Post impressionist art. 

On the lower level, you can check out this porcelain collection, it was beautiful.

My personal fave galleries: 
-Michael & Hanna Naify
-Adolph/Aima de Bretteville Sprekels
-Robert Dollar

Most of the artwork were very powerful in its own way and you totally get drawn in, Idk how to describe my passion level when it comes to art.I can't really say that I didn't like one type of art over the other, since art, is you know, art. Everyone comes with a different interpretation and a different view of life.

There's a cafe that offers pasteries, sandwiches, soups and salads w/ an organic touch.

I can't wait to come back around 11/17 when they have the Antoinette exhibit. At this current time, they have Rembrandt to Thiebaud. Oh, there's also this Holocaust Memorial, as soon as you walk out of the Legion, left of the Fountain. If you creep up close you will see a replica of the Holocaust victims. And, if you keep walking to your left, you will see this Japanese tombstone looking thing overlooking the bay. (peek fotos) This thing was erected to commemorate the Japanese naval ship in SF in March 1960.

audio tour : $5 members, $6 nonmembers. 

Parking: free

Hours: tuesday-Sunday 9:30-5pm.

Admission: $10 adults, $7 seniors,  $6 youths/students

(TIP! Admission includes same day admission to the de Young museum as well)

Don't ferget to check out the de Young Museum, also located in the Richmond district. 

Coming from the Legion of Honor, make a left on Fulton, park around 8-10th street, 10th street is closer. They should seriously think about having a shuttle bus that leaves every so often for tourists or what not, it's a hassle that it's not even 3-5 blocks, its roughly 2 miles.  10 minutes or so in driving.

Check out my de Young review, the one after this.
author: Jennifer S.

description: Great collection. $10 general admission and $20 for special exhibits.
author: Lidia Z.

description:
The Legion of Honor.. Lush grounds, amazing collections, and the best museum cafe, ever. The menu is constantly changing, and the quality of the food is jawdropping. 

In times of high stress, The Legion was a chosen refuge. Everything I need to be perfectly content is contained within those lovely walls. Beauty, light and tasty food! Lose yourself in the galleries, wander the grounds, make it a point to visit. 
They also have live music on some weekends, so check the website!
author: Elise M.

description:
3 stars... I know, I know... it's hard to throw out such a mediocre rating on a museum.  I mean, I liked it, and I'm cognizant of the fact that it's not the Met or some other wonderfully endowed (*snicker*) museum.

But...I felt like there wasn't much variety in the art -- how many paintings of bloated Victorian children placed next to foxes eating pheasants staring at preternaturally pale sad baby Jesuses ringed by equally ethereally translucent disciples can you see in a fixed number of rooms?  Many.  Many, many, my friends.

The Annie Leibovitz special exhibit was nothing titillating either -- just a bunch of pictures of carefully posed celebrities occasionally showing off their junk.  Demi Moore's and Cindy Crawford's nipples may beat the baby Jesuses.  I guess it depends on what you're in the mood for, blown up U.S. Weekly photographs or the impending symbolic doom connoted by the artists of Victorian England.

Well, sarcasm aside (phew, this is so difficult for me), the museum was actually pretty cool.  I really enjoyed the Dead Sea Scrolls exhibit, and I very much liked the space.  Weirdly enough, this place reminded me of how much the Toledo Museum of Art rocked.
author: Alissa K.

description:
I love Rodin.  And I am so proud to live in the city with the largest Rodin collection outside of the Rodin Museum in Paris!  I could look at these beautiful sculptures for hours - it is enough to simply focus on one thing, like a foot or the face.  There is emotion in every muscle and movement in every detail.  It blows me away, every time.

The Legion of Honor is like the deYoung's grandmother - elegant, with a long string of pearls.  She will bring you back to the classics and show you what can be new in the familiar.

I took my mother to this museum for the first time yesterday, and she was delighted with the presentation.  We had just finished seeing the Vivienne Westwood exhibit at the deYoung, and the French Jewelry exhibit was the perfect compliment.  Completely different, but no less compelling.  Plus, some of the pieces were donated by Elizabeth Taylor - the original queen of bling.  Gotta love that!

The building and the site are so striking - the view of the headlands with the Golden Gate Bridge in the background is stunning.

The Legion of Honor is a treasure - remember to visit often, and be reminded of the artists who were ground-breaking for their time, and showed us a new way to look at the world.

A $70 Participating Membership buys you unlimited visits for 2 adults to the deYoung and the Legion of Honor, for one year - money well spent!
author: Liz S.

description:
My favorite museum in this city. It's right near the water, in a gorgeous location in the outer Richmond. A beautiful building with wonderful collections and exhibits, especially of European art. 

*This place is more for the history  buffs and lovers of the OG's of the art world than for those wanting to get your modern art kicks. SF Moma, Yerba Buena, and the De Young are good for that.

*There's a deal where you can get in for free if you've visited the De Young that same day.
author: Kimi W.

description:
I went to the Annie Leibovitz exhibition this weekend and found it to be one of the most complete and interesting special exhibits the museum has had in the past two years. While I am not a member of the museum, I make a point to visit the museum twice a year because the place has such an amazing collection of Monet, Rodin and other classic artists in the Bay Area. While I can definitely look at pictures of Brad Pitt and famous images of Demi Moore striking for the camera, the collections most riveting subjects were the photos that Annie displayed of her family. In each family photo it revealed who she is as a person and what emotions have driven her to capture moments of bliss, despair and love. It was truly inspirational.

For about five years (from being a freshman in high school to a freshman in college) I thought I wanted to become an art history teacher, so I visited the museum often. On my first visit I was just learning about Rodin and when I saw the museum's bronze cast of the Thinker in their grand agora I got so excited that I not only thought it was the real thing, but I told my history teacher the next day about it. He then laughed at me and told me it was obviously a cast....hey, well - obviously!

Still, the museum has an amazing collection of Rembrandt, Monet, Picasso, Dali, Dega, Jean-Jacquez Louis David, Reubens and of course Rodin among other amazing collections of sculpture, photography and paintings.

It costs $15 for a special exhibit and on the first Tuesday of every month it is FREE to attend.

It's really a gorgeous place to picnic near the fountain in front, but I don't recommend eating at the cafe since it's very over-priced.
author: Laura G.

description:
The Legion of Honor is one of my most favorite places in San Francisco, from the serene setting, the great views, the beautiful architecture, all without having yet stepped in the doors. Once inside you can "almost" imagine yourself to be in a small, Parisian museum. I say "small" because it's not one of those huge, rambling museums that take forever to go through. It's just the right size. The permanent collection is vast enough and diversified enough without feeling superfluous and inundating. 

Every time I go I have to check to see if my favorite painting is up (they rotate the art in the galleries). Next time you're in the Renaissance galleries check to see if you can find the painting I call "Jesus With Six Toes". It's not always up. Jesus is depicted very clearly as having six toes, and there's no mention of it in the text accompanying it. I guess that's why I like this painting....it's kind of freaky.  

Although the special exhibitions are hit or miss, there is always something there to appreciate.
author: gary c.

description:
I'm a very big fan of art galleries and museums, and this one is one of my favorite spots. There's something profound about being surrounded by some of the world's greatest work of arts, you know? 

Outside of the museum, you'll find a Holocaust memorial site. To me, it was a bit creepy with all the white painted statues piled on top of each other.. and I've heard some people take their friends there during April Fools, blindfolded and have them standing in the middle. When they take off the blindfold... oh man it's so bad. 

Anyway, Before entering the museum, you'll see Rodin's Thinker outside (it's not the real one), and a mini version of the Louvre's famous glass pyramid. You'll probably notice tons of photographers and brides posing next to the Corinthian columns, it's apparently a hotspot for wedding pictures.

I think I paid $10 to enter, but that's not too bad.I don't remember if they asked for no flash photography or not if you're going to take pictures of the painting. The guards get pissy about people who are chatting it up on their cell phones inside and they'll ask you to step out of the museum and make your noise there. You'll also see some people who bring their own easel and try to paint an exact replica of whatever art piece they are sitting in front of.

It's gorgeous here, and is a definite stop. I just hate how i waited too long to come here. My last visit was in 2006 and I need to pay this place another visit before the year ends.
author: Jaye C.

description:
Probably the best & most beautiful museum in the city.
I love the location and the look of the entrance. The artwork presented is usually worldwide class level including the permanent collection. 
During the year they have different expo and it's always a pleasure to spend an afternoon at the Legion Of Honor.
author: S D.

description:
Housed in a beautiful neoclassical building perched on a cliff with a gorgeous view of the Golden Gate, the works at the Legion of Honor are a lovely mix of everything from 13th century - early 20th century works. I especially love to go on the days where the newly married happy couples are being photographed in front, the art students are sketching the Rodins, or the classical organ concertos are being held. It's worth it to go and take in the museum, and then go for a hike down the cliff as it's so beautiful. Parking can be a bit tight on crowded days, but off days are great. 
Plus, membership (and student membership is uber cheap) gets you into the fabulous De Young as well. It's one of the better museums I've been to, not necessarily for the famous works they have, but just for the beauty and presence of the place.

Made the 2007 Top 25 Best SF Architecture List of the American Institute of Architects.
Palace of the Legion of Honor, Lincoln Park, 1916, George Applegarth
author: Kat C.

description:
Does anyone remember that episode of the original 90210 (not that crazy new shit masquerading as 90210) when Brenda and Dylan were trying not to have sex so they were picking date activities that were supposed to NOT turn them on?  Do you remember the concert?  And they totally started making out hardcore?
Yeah. I've been to an awesome violin concert here that initiated that same response from me and the ex I was with (who wasn't my ex at the time).  It didn't help (or hinder) that we were in a classy and elegant area.  The Legion is gorgeous and sexy.
Like Brenda and Dylan, we had to leave. To have steamy, passionate, naughty sex.  In the middle of Golden Gate Park in his car.
author: Jill D.

description:
Driving into Lincoln Park amidst all the golfers and museum goers is peaceful and beautiful - the green grass, sea breeze and ocean view are gorgeous. 

But then ... there's the parking situation. Sigh. On Saturday, we drove around for 20 minutes trying to find parking and finally followed some kind folks to their car where they willingly gave up their space to us. But then entered Mr.-I-Am-Entitled-To-This-Space-Museum-Guy, who argues with me that he has the right of way to the space because it is on his side of the street. Instead of arguing about it, I let him have it ... and moved on. Aren't I gracious? Turn the other cheek, right?

So we circled a few more times, and finally decided to go up the hill behind the museum. 

**Secret parking tip for all you afternoon museum goers --- there are several cars that park on the grass directly behind the museum and this looks to be fair game! Luckily for us, one of these cars was leaving, so we took their spot. Take that Mr.-I-Am-Entitled-To-This-Space-Museum-Guy!

Finally when we got to the museum we were excited to see the Annie Leibovitz exhibit, but found it to be crowded with people. The exhibit was wonderful, with many intimate family portraits amidst the great photographs of celebrities and politians. My favorites were of author Eudora Welty and Petra (Jordan). It was a bit annoying to have so many people crowding around paintings or bumping you while you were trying to observe the light and shadows in a portrait.

**Tip: if you want to see this exhibit without anyone stepping in front of you or compromising your personal space, be sure to go early in the morning.

The regular museum exhibits haven't changed much - Renaissance paintings and antique furniture are shown in the rest of the galleries. And the Dead Sea Scroll gallery is a must-see if you're interested in ancient artifacts.

All in all, the Legion of Honor has some great exhibits -- if you're willing to wait for parking and fight the masses, then you'll have a great time. If not, go early and take it all in!
author: Alison T.

description:
At the suggestion of my coworker, I went to the Legion of Honor recently to see the Faberge Egg Exhibit. I really liked it, but went during a very busy time (last day of the exhibit) and felt it was too crowded to get a really good look at each exhibit. I would recommend not going to a popular exhibit on the last day!

The rest of the museum was very interesting if you like to look at paintings, sculptures and fine furniture craftmanship. The ceilings are beautiful in a lot of these rooms.

It was also neat to see the replica of Rodan's Thinking Man and the glass pyramid skylights in the front of the museum. It made me think about the Da Vinci Code book and movie. It made me wonder if there was a crypt below. :)

My two children were probably not as interested in this museum as I was. I was so glad I brought a stroller, it was a lot of walking, way too much for my 3 year old, and we would have been miserable if we had to take turns carrying her.
author: Francine S.

description:
I really love this little museum.... it's beautiful from the outside, to begin with, perched as it is above the northern part of SF and the bay. I love being up there when the sky is clear and blue and you can see for miles out over the water.... it's really lovely.

I've seen a few exhibits here, the most memorable being the Picasso exhibit. I bet a lot of other people who read this were there, too, so "Hi! Nice to see you again!" EVERYONE turned out for that show. It was crazy. I was stepped on quite a few times, bumped around, knocked sideways.... but it's okay. No worries. I actually just stepped up onto the curb that lines the walls inside, and was fine. Just fine. (After my claustrophobia panic died down, that is...)

When it's NOT crowded, this is a wonderful place to contemplate master works of art. I mean, they have a little bit of everything here! I've seen works by Monet, Lautrec, Picasso, Cezanne, Renoir, Cassatt, Seurat, as well as artists I'm not as familiar with. If I didn't have to do a high school report on them, I won't be easily remembering if I saw them. Sorry.

I love the antiquities they have in the glassed in cases, too.... examples of Roman glass making, jewelry, coins... very cool. 

The little cafe is good for a snack and something to drink. It's not too expensive, either, if you're just looking for a sandwich or cup of soup or a little salad. If you get all of that, though, you're looking at about $20.

It's a full day for me whenever I come out here. I prefer this little museum to a lot of others... the scale is nice. The parking isn't maddening, though you might have to park down on the street and walk up. I think it's Clement? Not sure. Plus the feeling of solitude up there is wonderful. I always keep my eyes peeled for possible stray golf balls, though.... you just never know when a wild card golfer is going to poink you in the head with a golf ball. It can happen!!

Regardless of that possible danger, it's very much worth the trip. The last time I went it was about $14 to get in. For me it was entirely worth it. I hope it will be for you, too.
author: Shari D.

description:
This is a great museum that has a great view from the outside and free parking. The courtyard itself is pretty amazing as you step in from the parking lot.

Once inside, this place is a little smaller than I expected. The experience you'll have here will greatly be weighted by the special exhibit(s) at that time, so check ahead as it may/may not be worth it to you to make it all the way out here.

I had the opportunity to check out the Masterpieces of French Jewelry and I must say some of the pieces were so extravagant, exquisite and beautiful it was memorizing. I mean the detail and fine intricacies of some of these pieces were so beyond anything I've ever seen. Take for example the Zipper Necklace. As a necklace, this piece was gorgeous, but the inside teeth and tassel at the base transforms this piece into a bracelet. 

Another favorite piece of mine were these platinum diamond earrings - this piece of jewelry was my favorite. They were complimented in the same case as these other pieces such as the corn on the cob piece which was amazing.

The rest of the museum was ok. I did like the Italian Renaissance art they had on display, but like I said before, the feature exhibits are what you should pay attention to when deciding if/when to visit the Legion of Honor.

This place has free admission on the 1st Tuesday of the month as others have mentioned. Once you purchase your ticket here, you can keep the stub and get free admission (same day) to the de Young Museum.
author: E E.

description:
In a nutshell, the Legion of Honor contains the overflow from the DeYoung museum.  In fact, admission at one gives you admission to both (but only for the same day), so for people with extreme stamina, you can get 2 museums for the price of one.

While De Young contains the contemporary and indigenous art, Legion of Honor has the classic Medieval, Renaissance, and Baroque stuff (including a tantalizingly few Medieval tapestries, one of my favorite genres), as well as the largest Rodin collection outside the Musee Rodin in Paris.  The distribution of the art is very appropriate considering the differing architectures of the two museums.

The current special exhibition is of French jewelry, which is far more interesting than it sounds, especially the Art Nouveau and Art Deco collections.  Also, it's free with admission.

If your feet aren't tired after the museum, and the weather is playing along, a walk around Lands End Park is highly, highly recommended.
author: Wes M.

description:
I love the view and nature scene that surrounds this Romanesque mimicking museum. It's delightful to see the Golden Gate Bridge, the ocean, and the city skyscrapers.  

I especially made a visit here to explore the exhibition of Annie Lebovitz's wonderful photographs. Many of them are renowned celebrity photos that you might have seen in Vogue magazine or Vanity Fair.

Then  wander downstairs and upstairs to explore the rooms that display items from ancient pottery to paintings from the baroque period.

I found the museum to be pleasant and peaceful.
author: Oanh N.

description: Best $100 I have ever spent was on my FAMSF membership.  It's a great place to walk around, kill time and enjoy a quiet afternoon.
author: Lisa R.

description:
So yes, Rodin is amazing and there's a whole lotta Rodin here.

But did you know that there's a really cool space behind The Three Shades where no one can see you and you can totally make out heavy with your date provided you're both pretty sly? And you're only like four feet away from The Kiss.

It's true. And highly recommended.
author: jason l.

description:
A beautiful museum (I like the building too) in a very scenic location.  

The last time I was there was for the Monet in Normandy exhibit.  
Good:  I ended up parking down the hill, & there's fantastic views of the Pacific Ocean and Golden Gate Bridge as you walk up the hill towards the museum.  I had my camera, so that was great!

Not so good:  This is why I didn't give it 5 stars, but it's my own fault.  Well, I ended up going on the first Tuesday of the month, which is free admission day.  OK, free is good, BUT apparently the word is out that it's free that day because there was a long line to get in.  I think I ended up waiting almost an hour.  Damn, why did I leave my book in the car?  I could've been reading it while I was standing in line (I had gone by myself).  I actually considered leaving & coming back on another day where I would pay admission just to avoid the masses of people.  So, of course there were large crowds for the exhibit too, which makes it less enjoyable.  Reminds me of my Picasso Museum experience in Barcelona...it was free that day & Festes de la Merce was going on in town while I was there (OK, that wasn't planned too well), so there were hordes & hordes of people there. What can I say, I'm not a fan of really crowded museums? 

Back to the good:  If you pay for admission at Legion of Honor, it's also good for the DeYoung Museum that day, & vice-versa.  I believe you can take a shuttle between the two.   On the free admission days, the special exhibit entrance fees are also discounted.
author: Linda T.

description:
I love the location of this museum- and it seems like everytime I go here- there's a wedding photo shoot going on...and its not any wonder to me- cuz I'd probably be doing the same thing :-)
My friends and I would do our own photo op hiding behind the pillars or running across the lawn so free and unbridled by the tourists and museum goers...Once inside- We are overwhelmed by  the Rodin sculptures- undeniable serene, fleshlike- living.  I like walking through the hallways- and downstairs - how elegant this house must have been...Oh my favorite is looking at the Guanerius del Gesu donated by Yehudi Menuhin...I wonder if it misses its master or longing for a new one...
author: Arissa C.

description: I like the setting and tempo of this museum. It's warm and cozy. Can't wait to come back here.
author: Karen S.

description:
We took advantage of the Bank of America promotions this month and visited the museum! I can't believe we had not been inside. What idiots! Yes, we've taken out of towners here for the picture perfect shots, frolicking and posing with those huge pillars n the courtyard and surrounding areas but we've not been inside until this weekend. 

Love everything they had to offer and esp the Rodin sculptures and the current Master of French Jewelery exhibit featuring pieces from private collections, including those of Dame Elizabeth Taylor and Iris Cantor! Totally worth it!! Pieces by Neil Lane, Tiffany and Co, Boucheron, etc etc. 
The pieces must be beyond pricele$$! All patrons both men and women were oooo'ing and ahhh'ing over each and every pieces! It's unimaginable, how intricate each pieces are designed and filled with diamonds and collection of precious stones! Some necklaces can also convert into two separate bracelets! The exhibition also includes stunning and fanciful personal effects such as evening bags, fans, opera glasses, vanity cases, perfume bottles, ink wells and animal, bird, insect, and flower motifs appear throughout the exhibition. Amazingly creative! 

Overall a great visit and warrants a return visit any time! There were only a limited collection of impressionist art by Monet and Renoir and a few other Post-Modern pieces by Picasso and Joan Miro.
author: Yan M.

description:
Caught the Annie Leibovitz show a couple of Sundays ago, along with part of an organ concert that sounded pretty jammin'.  Interesting juxtapo between celebrity pictures & family shots-- of course much better than flipping thru her book.  It was free day (not sure if it's a monthly thing for first Sundays) but the museum is also included in my DeYoung membership.

I'm usually not too interested in what is showin' here (eg. Monet, yawn--I did the Paris thing in college many lilies ago).  But Hitchcock (and Maupin) fans will enjoy revisiting Vertigo settings, including the nearby cliffs. Just don't wear a clip-on tie...

The museum-hike combo makes a trip worth it. The Coastal Trail meanders along the rocky coast with great views.
author: Miz J.

description:
Went up here for my "once every 5 year" trip.. this time for pictures for my brother's wedding...  we only were outside.. it was a bit overcast... but fine for taking pictures.  I felt bad that while we were there, there were 3 other wedding parties that cycled through there... and none of the brides held a candle to my soon-to-be sister-in-law.

Oh well...     Go pose with the thinker!!!!
author: Eric K.

description:
Yes, Rodin's statue "The Thinker" already deserves 5 STARS RIGHT OFF THE BAT as serious as Cade said!

THEY ALSO HAVE AN EXHIBITION WITH ACTUAL PIECES OF "THE DEAD SEA SCROLLS" ON DISPLAY. 

I really like this museum and I've been going from time to time over the span of many years even as a kid on school field-trips back then. This place is still beautiful in the peaceful scenery it is hidden in in the RIchmond/SeaCliff area. You won't be disappointed making a trip here. There's at least 3 stories of extensive art/history with many extravagant and open high ceiling rooms. This is the ideal museum you would think of when going on a museum visit. 

Don't forget as some have mentioned that tickets here are also associated with the De Young in Golden Gate Park. You can easily spend a whole day for this 2 for 1 value.

Be inspire and moved, make a trip once in a while for the different exhibitions that are hosted throughout the year.
author: Brandon H.

description:
The Legion of Honor is an awesome museum for of art and history from France, England, Norhern Europe, Italy, the United States, some from Egypt, some from Greece, and some from China and Japan. Most of the employees there are friendly, and the security is strict but great there. I have learned a lot about different art and cultures from the different groups represented there. Some artwork might be disturbing to some, but overall, the place is great for all ages. 

The outside view is also artwork, and you see some of the beautiful scenes of San Francisco. It can be cold outside, but once in the museum, it can be warm, so bringing a light jacket might be a good idea. Like other museums, they are ok with photography, but not flash photography, for flash photography can damage what is on display. They have a couple of book stores and a mini cafe/restaurant. The glass pyramid that is outside brings light into the museum

The first floor has dishwear from Japan, China, and Europe. Original children storybooks from Europe, some Egyptian and Greek artifacts, and the stores and restaurants are on the floor below the entrance of the museum. The museum is two stories. The floor in which you enter the museum has many rooms that house artwork on the United States, France, Northern Europe, and Italy.
author: DJ Guan Yu M.

description: First time coming here; the paintings, antique furnitures and their designs are pretty amazing.
author: Jackie A.

description: This place is a photographers heaven.  There are many beautiful sculptures to view, in addition the backdrop of the Golden Gate Bridge and gorgeous sunsets its easily the most photographed place in the Outer Richmond.   Inside the museum holds an abundant amount of artwork from vases, porcelains, to furniture.  The size of the museum is not that big so one can enjoy what it has to offer in a full day.
author: S F.

description:
A great place to spend half a day. We recently saw the Annie Lebovitz exhibition which was fantastic. All of the collection is impressive and the exhibition that they are currently installing looks insanely brilliant too- lots of glass, I don't even know how to describe it. Picture Medusa's hair made out of glass...
We ate at the museum restaurant- don't be put off by the long line. it moves very quickly and the food was very good and had lots of healthy options. I had a quinoa and beet salad which was very good. after you are done take a walk down the hill for some stunning scenery. BTW once you have your ticket it is also good at the Deyoung the same day, so is worth driving over if you are having a full on culture vulture day, which we were.
author: Carrie A.

description:
Years ago, my grandmother always kept a post card of a painting on her dresser - a young woman sitting by a rock with a broken water vase at her feet.  What a shock when I visited this museum for the first time and there was the actual painting right in front of me!  WOW!  I go there just to look at that painting sometimes and relive my childhood.

I deducted one star only because I feel that I totally was misled when I excitedly purchased tickets to see a special Leonardo Da Vinci exhibit.  Well, turns out there was only ONE painting by Da Vinci there, and the other pieces were of his era.  WHAT?!  Totally felt ripped off.
author: Denise M.

description:
The best museum in San Francisco. 
Gorgeous museum located in the outer-edges of the city, with a spectacular view of the ocean.The views from the property are some of the best in the bay area. Beautiful inside and out and all of the ccollection is impressive.
author: christy l.

description:
Museum:

The Legion of Honor is amazing in so many ways - the views, the architecture, the art and the organ music. I can't believe I have lived in San Francisco for 6 months and only just visited. It is like an older, more refined sister of the De Young museum. 

Cafe:

My friend put it best: 'museum cafes can rip you off or serve poor quality and most often manage to do both.' Somehow, the cafe at the Legion of Honor does neither. They could easily function as a cafe on their own. The catering appears to be contracted out to Bon Appetiet. 

Come on a sunny Saturday or Sunday morning and plan to stay in the cafe for lunch (open until 4).
author: matt m.

description:
Came here for the first time ever.  Very good.

We came near to closing so they didn't make us pay for tickets.  We saw the Anne Leibovitz exhibit...spectacular.  Though I did not have time to see the other normal stuff this museum has to offer, however I shall go back soon.
 
I love the location and the views.

The one thing that made me mad was that when they were officially closed the guards turned into dicks and were kicking people out giving us all a hard time.  Our friends were in the bathroom so we were waiting in the court yard and the guard out there started yelling at us like we didn't just get yelled at by his co-worker...really annoying.  Lost one star.
author: desiree n.

description:
Undervisited no more since the advent of the Monet exhibit, it's time to get over to the Legion before the exhibit closes.  The museum has a gorgeous outdoor setting, with well kept gardens and the fountain as you approach the courtyard.

I don't know much about art-all knowledge gleaned from the requirements at my liberal arts college-but the Legion has all of the usual stuff-docent led tours, audio tours for an additional fee (always worth the investment, as far as I am concerned)  but a very enjoyable place for a wander.  Before Monet, they had a really interesting exhibit featuring artifacts (probably not the right word) from the 1906 earthquake.  Based on these last two exhibits, I plan to join because I'm probably missing lots of cool stuff.  GO!  Take tourists.  They don't have this in Boise.
author: Beth V.

description: I've never been here before and was so excited when my friend suggested we go check it out. We went on the free day which is always awesome.. Who doesn't love going to a museum and not have to pay anything for it?.. Even before I stepped into the building I was just staring in awe at how beautiful the building is as we were looking for parking. I was so giddy as soon as I stepped into the museum..I couldn't decide which room to start in.. I have to say that all the art and sculptures were amazing! I could definitely spend my whole day there.
author: Raquel T.

description: Love the sculptures and architecture. You are on top of a hill in the middle Lincoln park/golf course, so you are overlooking a lot of beautiful green land and into the pacific. Awesome view.
author: Lk W.

description:
A gorgeous museum located on top of San Francisco! Seriously, amazing view of the entire city and the bridge itself. 

Legion of Honor has been my personal favorite art museum of all of the art museums that I have been to. 

A good collection of Rodin sculptures, Impressionism, Baroque, I can go on and on!
author: Stacey T.

description:
OMGoodnesss. 
Arriving at the Legion of Honor, I was stunned by my surroundings. 
Had I been transported to La Mer Mediterranee? 
Why had it taken me so long to come back here? 
It was one of those perfect november days; cloudless sky, mild, sunny 
(the opposite of our current cold, soggy, state).
I had convinced two buddies to join me for the hedonistic Marie-Antoinette exhibit and was so thrilled to be here! 

I have to say that joining the legion/de young was one of the smartest moves I've made. My membership has paid me back in spades and I get this wonderful sense of peace and well-being when I come here.
+I can always bring a friend with me for free and we can pretend to be on an exotic vacation. 

Props to the cafe and gift shop too! They had some irresistible girly stuff to go with the M-A exhibit and the food was mmmagnifique!
author: Sandrita R.

description:
What an amazing reminder of why it's good to be alive in San Francisco!

I attended a wedding here last night and it was the perfect location for such an important life event.
The space is wonderfully filled with works of art (most of which were closed off and hidden from us drunken wedding guests...as would be expected).  The cocktails were outside on the patio.  Chilly yes, but cozy and intimate.  The dinner and dancing was indoors and housed about 175 crazy wedding guests until we were kindly ushered out at 11:30pm.  

I will definitely be going back here to check out the gallery in more detail, so I can't rate that just yet.  But 4+ stars for their hospitality and event-friendly space.
And of course I can't wait to scope out those amazing SF views that I've heard so much about.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
A place that was built dedicated to troops in the second world war...

If you've never been here, you must go.  The view, architecture, and Rodin sculpture are enough to visit.  Plus they have an actual antique art ceiling in one of the rooms.

But if you a constant art viewer, it can be a bit of a bore.  Their exhibitions often reflect their permanent collection.  It's great art for those with more classical and historical tastes.  Design and modern art enthusiasts will enjoy it, but you're better off at MOMA.

Legion of Honor is located pretty far from downtown, bart, and muni.  But if you drive here, you're not too far from Golden Gate Park, De Young Museum, and Fort Mason.

Also be sure to check out the genocide inspired sculpture outdoors near the free parking.
author: Michael H.

description:
You don't have to be Alfred Hitchcock to enjoy what the Legion of Honor has to offer (I'm referring to Vertigo, if I wasn't good about saying that.).

It's in a seemingly desolate area with views of the bay.
Parking can sometimes be annoying if you're there on a weekend or holiday.

There are Rodin sculpure castings that are permanently there as well as other mediums hanging on the walls.  
Down the stone stairs there are the temporary exhibits usually and those should be seen by visitors who may not come back soon (the others will be there longer, obviously).

It's not one of the best museums that San Francisco has to offer (in my opinion clearly), but it's a nice museum stop to make and the perks of it being in a brilliant film are kind of cool.
author: Chantal P.

description:
The Legion of Honor is a truly beautiful building that occupies one of the most picturesque pieces of property in the United States.  It possesses sweeping views of downtown San Francisco, the Bay, the Golden Gate, the Golden Gate Bridge, the Marin Headlands and the Pacific.  

The museum itself houses art from a great span of eras without delving too deeply into any of them.  It is a gorgeous museum but one without focus.
author: Jeff P.

description:
I am appalled I haven't written a review about the Legion of Honor. 

This place is absolutely gorgeous, both architecturally and scenic-wise. It's nestled in the Seacliff district of San Francisco. It's a visit MUST for tourists and SF residents. Obviously, for people that know me, I'm an absolute lover of the Arts and this institution has shown some stunning exhibitions. From Art Deco to Picasso to Thiebaud, it's a museum that showcases a wide array of classical art and art movements that should be studied by everyone and anyone. 

With the Thinker outside wondering, pondering, if you are up for an intellectual and artistic endeavor, you may be wondering what to see and where to go first? That's the beauty of this museum. Upon walking in, the docents are extremely knowledgeable and passionate about Art and it shows. Believe me, the docents are some of the best and most dedicated individuals you will meet. If I had the time, I, sincerely, would become a docent with the Legion of Honor. 

To top it off, you can have your dream wedding or birthday or milestone event at the Legion of Honor. Although pricey, it would be a dream come true to have that perfect occasion celebrated in this historic San Francisco location.
author: Dorothy S.

description:
I like many other yelpers came here specifically to view the Annie Liebovitz Photo Exhibit.  It was fabulous in spite of the $15 entry fee.  

For the most part, I didn't enjoy the permanent exhibits.  Then again, I'm just not a museum person in that way 'cause I was a bit tired of all of those museums in Madrid and Paris too.  I know I should be ashamed, but it's the truth.  I'm more of a photography/modern art kind of gal.

But I'll keep looking on their website for other special exhibits.

The surrounding grounds were beautiful and provided great fodder for the budding photographer in me.  :)
author: Tamiko J.

description:
Monet exhibition was crowded. My bf who comes often sorta guided me and my friend there. He pointed out how Monet's work got more 'abstract' regarding his age. Otherwise the exhibition was good and just crowded. 
I prefer to look at Rodin's sculpture in the main floor... much less crowded...
author: dannydan d.

description:
love the building, love the art. I like buildings to have an old feel (and be old) when looking at art, it just adds to the experience, yadda dda mean-- adding a gangsta twist 

This museum is the best in the bay area--NO DOUBT.  It even has a great view, what else can you ask for? (i'm compelled to add yaddaddamean, but i'll resist) Besides I think this is the only museum in the bay area with a Cezanne
author: Lorena R.

description:
The Legion of Honor has a great collection inside with beautiful architecture surrounding it and gorgeous views looking out.  Does it get any better than this?

In comparison to the other SF museums, I prefer the LOH.  For me, the collection of Rodin sculpture is unlike anything else you'll find.  It made the entire trip worth it.  That's not to say that the rest of the nineteen rooms don't have great art.  I also felt they housed the best Monets in the city (four total).

Sure, it may be a bit out of the way and smaller than the other museums, but you'll see some one-of-a-kind pieces.

* Specific to this visit, I was kind of disappointed by the Marie-Antoinette exhibit.  There are some absolutely massive paintings, and the royal bed is a sight to see, but other than that, it didn't do it for me.


another great review from Jacey S. [http://www.yelp.com/biz/legion-of-honor-san-francisco#hrid:Uq4Vrt1tWy5yf9q5oXQV4A]
SFMOMA [http://www.yelp.com/biz_link?biz_id=bbYCQmXbMCRZcxNI8XWAEg]
de Young [http://www.yelp.com/biz_link?biz_id=RJ3NiTTSl00iT-Hu0-2ktQ]
author: M C.

description:
Deb S. really hit the nail on the head with her review: first-rate painters, second-rate paintings. There are, to be sure, some great things here: the Watteaus are wonderful (and there are several of them! yay!) and the museum owns a dramatic Rubens. But, for the most part, the paintings and sculptures here underwhelm. 

On the other hand, the tapstries at this museum are great, but you won't see many of them on public view; the walls are mostly reserved for the bad paintings. California has many great collections of Rodin sculpture (4, I think, Stanford, the Norton Simon and LACMA also have world-class collections), and this one is as good as any.

The view from the museum is really what caused me to give this museum as many stars as I did (because, to be frank, a city as old and wealthy as San Francisco should have a MUCH better museum than this). On a clear day, the view of the Marin headlands and the Golden Gate Bridge as seen through the beautiful old trees in Licoln Park is lovely indeed.
author: Michael W.

description:
Ok - my review is probably tainted by the fact we waited over an hour and a half in the freezing cold to get to the ticket desk this Sunday - just for a Marie Antoinette exhibit that wasn't worth the extra $5 admission.
  
In any case, the inside of the museum is really nice, but I was not impressed with the exhibits.  I thought it was a little small, and didn't really understand much of the flow of the museum.  In one small room, they stuck picasso, renoir, dali, and others next to each other.  It was an odd mix - maybe just a famous painters room?  

The Marie Antoinette exhibit was rather small, had some nice items, but mainly a lot of explanation of her sad life.  What I did like was the organist playing near the front area - he was really amazing.  Definitely go when he is giving a concert.

The outside area is really beautiful as well, but to be honest, you'll get better views if you just play 18 holes on the Lincoln park course.

I enjoyed the SFMOMA and De Young more.  I guess an initial visit is good, and maybe if there is an exhibit.  But wouldn't really recommend it.
author: Paul H.

description:
I can't believe I haven't been here till just recently. What a beautiful place! The Annie Leibowitz show is great--very inspiring.

The building itself is such a beautiful structure--it always amazes me how we humans are so capable of creating such beauty. Make a whole day of it by parking over by Fort Miley, bring a picnic lunch, and enjoy a walk at Land's end before or after your visit.
author: N B.

description:
This is a partial review. To be completed after I visit.

I feel like my room mate brings up the Legion of Honor EVERY SUNDAY! It kinda drives me nuts. Therefore, word of mouth warrants a review.... I have, however, driven to the outside and ventured around the parking lot after hours. It is a beautiful building and I'm kinda excited to visit!
author: Andrew C.

description:
I like this place, but minus a star for the cashier lady who wouldn't give my girl the benefit of the doubt on the student id. 

Apart from that minor irritation, the space is great are there are some nice works here. I prefer the De Young, but it's a nice place to walk out to on the weekend and have a look around.
author: Sven S.

description:
Good place. I was raised in that area for about 20 years of my life. So I am pretty bored of it, BUT I must admit the Legion Of Honor is pretty cool. Did you know you can also book the place to be married at ? Which I think would make a awesome marrage.

I also really like to Mountain Bike around it. There are some great trails right directly around The Legion Of Honor.

Very nice view as well. A must for a tourist wanting some cool pictures of them and their companions on their trip to S.F.
author: Joel D.

description:
Being a San Franciscan since birth, I'm a little embarrassed to say that I went to the LOH for the very first time a couple of days ago. I was only able to stay for about an hr & a half because I had work, & w/ that little amount of time I had I was able to take a free docent tour & check out artwork on my own. I will def make time to stay a little longer & really look at all the pieces of art. 


Just make sure that if you are a student you have an updated sticker in order to get your student discount.
author: A M.

description: It's surprising that I've never been here before today. I've been to most of the other museums in the Bay Area, but for some obscure reason, have missed this one. Anyway, I LOVED it. This is what a true museum should feel like on the inside. The people working there were just fabulous. We have a membership to the Asian Art Museum and there is a reciprocal program for the Legion of Honor except when we got there, the person at the desk had no idea what the reciprocal was and our card wasn't able to swipe through the machine. The lady at the desk was just incredibly nice. She whispered "ENJOY YOURSELVES!" and let us in with a member's pass. How awesome was that? I mean, even though our card should've worked, we could've encountered a not-so-nice person who could've made us pay the admission fee.
author: Anita L.

description:
Even rain and fog didn't diminish this place's beauty - if anything, it only augmented it.  

I dug the exhibit with all the drawings - sometimes a pencil and some paper (and ok, talent up to wazoo) can express human emotion just as well if not better than a million colors of paint.  

Great Rodin sculptures, too.  Not as enthralled by the cases upon cases of things like tea cups and saucers, but they have their place in art history as well I suppose.  

A wonderful place to go to be quiet and thoughtful and observative.   I will definitely be back!
author: Kate M.

description:
I love coming here because the place is just gorgeous. When the weather is good, it is magnificent -- no wonder there are always people here in their wedding gowns getting their pictures taken. 

I like the exhibits here as well as the main collection but now they have Sunday prix fixe brunch with live jazz!
author: Irene S.

description:
Monet in Normandy is great. This is where I learned that renting the headsets really can make a museum. I learned all this history about Monet - He was married to Camille, then she died, then Elise (sp?) moved in to help take care of his sons - and she was the wife of his benefactor, and then her husband died and then Monet and Elise married. I would have completely missed out on this MTV reality show drama if I hadn't invested in the $6. 

That said, I think membership definitely makes sense. That whole joint thing w/ de Young makes it a no-brainer. 

A friend had knee surgery, so we got her a wheelchair, which made the viewing all the more interesting - protecting her from the others in the museum, but as a fyi there are several handicap parking spots right by the terrance level entrance. 

go early or on a weekday - the crowds are pretty extreme.
author: Heidi L.

description:
Location location location!
The views are amazing. The entrance is "grand" - it's clean, well maintained, but very small.

Probably houses one of the largest collections of Rodin's work outside of Paris's D'Orsay and Musee Rodin.

The skylights play off of the new glass sculpture exhibit preview nicely.

There is a guy who feeds the raccoons around 10pm at night. A furious group of hungry raccoons is nothing to sneeze at!
author: dj z.

description:
This is a very good museum, but it falls short in my opinion of 4 or 5 stars for two reasons:  Pricey for the size, and what they have chosen to exhibit.

i visited about 8 or 10 years ago, and was really impressed by some of the things they had that I had never seen in any other museum. They had an entire room from an 18th century French hotel reconstructed. They had a number of the interiors of houses from Europe, built during the dark ages, reconstructed. These were small, primitive, very basic dwellings. But it was fascinating to enter them and imagine how people lived in the 11-13th centuries. They also had sculptures, paintings, all the things you see in any museum.

I went back today expecting to see all that and perhaps more, since the Museum had done a renovation and added space in the years in between my visits. I was disappointed because the dark ages European homes were gone. It seemed as only a portion of the French hotel room was there, plus a wood paneled room from another structure. There was room after room of paintings. Blah...All of these museums have paintings. After a while they don't seem to be that much different. Removing the unique architectural pieces and replacing the space with more of the same paintings really takes this museum from great to average, in my opinion.

$10 for the basic admission, $15 to see the traveling exhibits and the museum. Not a good value imo.

I still recommend people visit the Legion of Honor, but in my opinion the managers have made  mistakes and could be doing much better.
author: Steve J.

description:
The Legion has a very special place in my heart for a number of reasons.  

1) My favorite painting is there called "The Broken Pitcher" by William Adolphe Bouguereau. (Try saying that 5 times fast!)  

2) Breath-taking architecture inspired by the Palace of Versailles in France.

3) Amazing collection of classical paintings and sculptures.  (None of that modern art "Look Ma, I drew a red circle" sh**.)
author: Keika L.

description:
Absolutely Magnificent.

One of my dearest friends got married here yesterday. The Legion of Honor is the perfect setting for a wedding. Looking at the Legion of Honor, you can't help but feel as though you are staring at a grand palace. The columns, like their love, are strong. The statues, many Rodin, decorate the open space. Looking over your shoulder, you have a beautiful view of San Francisco. 

The wedding was outside. The weather was perfect. White chairs set up in perfectly straight rows. Vases filled with white orchids lined the front. When the glowing bride walked from the entrance, slowly passing by the grand columns, you couldn't help but feel as though you were witnessing something incredibly special and joyous.

The Legion of Honor is simple and elegant.  I was crying by the time he kissed the bride. It was just such a beautifully simple and unique ceremony. The Legion of Honor provided the perfect background for this perfect wedding. 

Glorious.
author: Laura D.

description: Well I was very excited because I go a membership at De Young which also gets you into the Legion of Honor. We went a few weeks ago to see the Pulp fashion exhibit which was wonderful. It was amazing what that lady can do with paper! Parking can be kinda of difficult but I try to go to the museum during the week days so when we went on a Friday we find a spot right up front.
author: Michele H.

description: The first time I went to the Legion of Honor was magical. The fog was incredibly thick that day, much more than usual. I was with my mom, and as we drove up the road, the museum wasn't even visible. Then, all of a sudden it loomed up out of the fog, with the lions leading the way. Breathtaking. Then we went inside; I don't even remember getting past the first room. They had Rodin's "The Kiss" in bronze on display, and I had never seen it before. I was mesmerized; it was the most beautiful and moving sculpture I had ever seen. It still is my favorite sculpture. Thank you, Legion of Honor, you will always be one of my favorite memories.
author: Kari E.

description:
Love this beautiful museum! Blow your mind location, great collection of art, Cafe has nice outdoor area to sit under the trees when the weather permits. GO HERE! That's all I can say. 
The other nearest Cafe is the Garden House at the bottom of the hill on Clement across from the Albertson's.
author: Roanna Z.

description:
Everything about this place is perfect, except a) the actual collection, and b) parking.

Beautiful location with nice views of the Golden Gate Bridge and (to a lesser extent) downtown San Francisco. It's a great place, when not foggy, to walk around, the building itself is very nice as well. Entrance isn't too expensive either, my advice (if you're cash-strapped) is to go for a (cheap) concert (for instance, the Pocket Opera performs here regularly) so you get to go inside for free. The Gould theater inside is kind of old and decrepit, but it's fine for chamber music performances. The collection of the museum leaves much to be desired, though. It doesn't come close to being able to compete with Chicago's, New York's or Boston's fine art museums. Too bad, I really believe SF deserves better.

I love the organ that's played every Sunday at 4pm (if I'm not mistaking). It is quite a different experience wandering the museum with while hearing the organ resound through the entire building.
author: Alexander G.

description:
One thing I loved about this place is few of my local friends have been to it.  It's almost like San Francisco's best kept secret.

Very cool museum in the far northwestern part of San Francisco that is a bit of a hike to get to from the bus (although the hike is worth it).  The legion building is simple yet beautiful and positioned where you get several great views of the area.  After checking out the cool courtyard, you can either choose to see the main exhibit or some of the smaller rooms.  If you can, show up on Saturday or Sunday and enjoy a free concert at 4 PM in the Rodin Hall.  By the way, that hall is amazing!  i had no idea San Francisco had so many of his pieces.

Tip...buy the annual pass if you plan on going here and to the DeYoung more than twice.  After that it has paid for itself.
author: Charles B.

description:
Came here for the French Jewelry Exhibit and it was quite nice.  I think it made the exhibit better since we followed the docent around and she explained a lot of pieces and threw in some stories, background, anecdotes.  It made the exhibit less boring, but I like this place b/c it's quiet and it makes a great dating place.  

My bf and I spent an entire afternoon here and we had a blast.  the art was really inspiring in terms of topics and discussion.  Just something different to do on a weekend.
author: AhLin C.

description:
I have to agree with some of the other yelpers here that the museum's collection is mediocre to good.  However, it is the building it self and the surrounding that really makes the trip here worthwhile.  The architecture of the building with the statues and columns are stunning.  The weather happen to be perfect today so we walked past the golf course to the cliff/ beach area.  The view was awesome! 

I can't believe that after living in the bay for 10 years that I have never been to this part of S.F.  The view of the golden gate as well as the ocean was by far one of the most beautiful spots in Frisco that gives the city its renowned beauty.

I personally thought the museum was a bit small, didn't check out the impressionism exhibit but their collection was just okay.  I thought maybe Stanford museum had more interesting ones.  But a few really stuck out.  The two statues, the thinker and the El Cid in the front of the museum was really cool.  I am a history geek and I remember El Cid on history channel!  Seeing his statue was really cool.  There were few biblical paintings that were great too but dead sea scroll was the best for me.

I saw 2 scraps or pieces of paper that were probably one of the oldest written documents ever.  Genesis 1 on scrap of scroll like a jig saw puzzle.  Knowing that it was the oldest written word of God on paper that we have, it was just mind blowing looking at it.  (even though its just old piece of parchment lol)

So go to the museum but make sure you go to the mile stone beach behind it!!!
author: Seung O.

description:
This museum is one of the great things to do when you're unemployed.  LOL, no really, this is a gem of a small museum for so many reasons.  Every Tuesday is FREE!  Firstly, the exterior is beautiful.  My cousin took some wedding photos there (as do many couples) and many folks just do the entire ceremony there!  There's a haunting Holocaust piece outside the museum.  "The Thinker" just hangs outside in the front.  

The regular pieces of their collection are mostly ho-hum (I'm no great art critic) but there are some pieces that I enjoy revisiting.  I love sculpture and carvings (things I can touch and feel) and Auguste Rodin is one of my  favorite artists.  The exhibitions they've brought in are always interesting.  Right now they have the Monet in Normandy exhibit which sounds great (it's getting rave reviews from fellow Yelpers).  The Egyptian art exhibit they had a while back was very comprehensive and well worth seeing a few times.  The cafe is pricey but nice if the day is warm and you want to sit outside with your latte to contemplate the pieces that stayed with you.
author: Imelda M.

description:
Small but beautiful.
I'm just happy knowing that we have a quiet place like this in the Bay Area.

The collection isn't very big (I got to see the French Jewelry Collection Exhibit though, go see it while it's still here!).  But the statuesque pillars and the quiet view of the entire city is really worth a visit.  Plus, 1 day general admission to the Legion of Honor also gets you into the DeYoung Museum as well!
author: Angela Q.

description:
Highlights:

- The building and grounds which have spectacular views of the Pacific and GGB on a clear day
- Rodin's Thinker
- Monet's Water Lilies and The Grand Canal
- Seurat's Eiffel Tower
- Brunch at the cafe (http://www.yelp.com/biz/5SHsLbfXdSJOP93uMHhrFQ#hrid:7bZO8QVlruFCVqr5Na3jZg)
author: Pelle Y.

description: Lovely location, tucked away and nestled in an awesome spot where you can see the ocean, the Golden Gate, and downtown on a clear day. In all my years living here, I hadn't been to this museum until today. When you first walk in, it's slightly disorienting since there's so much to go see and the entrance leads you toward so many directions. My favorite was the Rodin collection. I love the architecture of the Legion, the high ceilings and natural light that comes through. So okay, most of it isn't modern art, but it's nice to take a step back in time and take a break from the world as we know it. It's like a breath of fresh air.
author: Monica N.

description:
Atmosphere (outside esp): 5

Permanent Collection: 2

Visiting exhibition: Variable - This is what you should pay for!

The location could only be better if you were the deYoung, and really, with the ocean view, the golf course in the city, and the getting lost in the Presidio, this place is well matched for the deYoung... On the outside.

The permanent collection is B-O-R-I-N-G.  Really, nothing you haven't seen at any art museum.  Though I am partial as a modern art lover.  But this museum had little variation for any art lover to be aware of.

If there is a visiting exhibition of interest, that's what you should pay for.  OR, if you are making a day of museum-going, your admission here will get you into the deYoung - 2 for 1 deal, and that's worth it!
author: Sarah X.

description: I really like this gallery. It's small, thoguhtfully lit and laid out. Their collection of Rodin is spectacular, and they have a nice spread of  European renaissance, baroque and early impressionist artwork as well as some beautifully crafted inlay furniture. I'm planning on becoming a member this year so I can take my guests here and show off this little hidden gem.
author: Stacey C.

description:
Out near Land's End is the innocent Legion of Honor Museum. It it's a lovely museum mostly because of its size: small. You don't have to spend  five hours roaming the halls of mediocrity. Instead, it's a concentrated experience that's large enough to feel like you are seeing a substantial museum but small enough to not tire you out. Great Rodin collection.

I saw the special Monet in Normandy exhibit downstairs and it was lovely with some well known Monet's: a haystack, a few waterlillies, many coastal pieces. The exhibit wasn't that big but still was suitable to the small downstairs gallery. Far too many people, though...

Parking has the possibility of being a nightmare. If there are a lot of people, you have to park down the road a bit. It's not that there isn't enough parking, it's that you don't know where you can park and can't park. Some signs say: "No Parking" when there are cars parked there and plenty of space. Go down to the left behind to the side of the museum and you'll find a dead-end road that, when filled up, means all cars that go down it must turn around and go back out. Try circling the main lot in front of the museum, people leave quite frequently.

Beautiful theater for all kinds of events...
author: R K.

description:
I love museums and the Legion of Honor is a great museum! I need to pay another visit soon.  The last time I went to the Legion; I went for the French Jewelry exhibit! One word...incredible! As soon as I entered the exhibit I saw a gorgeous ornate diamond necklace with a diamond a size of an apple in a glass case!! Don't think I can afford that...There were some ancient pieces of jewelry that were worn by French royalty being showcased in this exhibit dating back from the 16th century to the more recent such as, Tiffany's & Co., first pieces ever made! Wow! It was a truly amazing exhibit.

As I walked through the museum and admired the wonderful masterpieces of some well known artists; I felt a sense of gratitude for these artists who are creators of beauty and imagination. Definitely something to appreciate. I think everyone should pay a visit  to the Legion and witness it all for yourself!
author: Suzette R.

description: I went to the Legoin of honor murseum as part of an extra credit assignment for my Art history class in school. Little did i know that this museum would hold such a rich collection of art from the renaissance, gothic and modern era. The museum holds some works of art from famous painters and sculptors like Picasso, Renoir and Jan Van Eyck. The officials at the museum allow you take pictures without a flash througout the museum. I noticed a bunch of students, just like me, taking pictures and writing down notes. The entry to the museum is free every first tuesday of the month but you also get a great student discount if u manage to go there on any other day. the museum is as beautiful on the outside as it is on the inside. Its located by the ocean with a great view of the Golden Gate Bridge. This is a great place to go if u want a peaceful day, enjoying art through the ages.
author: Sandeep R.

description:
I like it here, they have a lot of very solid, proven older art. You can always get a good experience looking at art here. The Rodin is great. 
Edit: They lose 2 stars for having "Wearable Art" and "French Jewelry" exhibitions. The Second is for having the Jewelry show while the De Young is having the crappy fashion show.
author: Damon S.

description:
The Legion of Honor on a clear sunny day is the kind of place where I feel the stress and worries of my mundane life fall away like the burnt-out parts of a rocket as my spirit soars into the clear sweeping views of the city, the bridge and the ocean.  I can't help but to take a deep breath and feel inspired!  Snowy likes the fountain.
