The building's balance, scale, proportion and symmetry speaks to my primal appreciation of order and beauty.  Inside is one of the finest examples of European art in California.  The collection is small enough to enjoy without turning into a dazed zombie (ala large museums in London, Paris, Madrid etc).  The universality of the human experience expressed on canvas and given form in sculpture reaching out over hundreds and even thousands of years to touch you and reflect our common consciousness.

An exhilarating marriage of beauty and aesthetics both man-made and natural.  And to top it off, you get a discount if you use Muni to get there.  Show your transfer or fast pass.   A gem of sanity in a sometimes crazy world.
author: Tintin and Snowy x.

description: A small museum but a historical building and the best view for SF city and ocean.
author: Jacqueline X.

description:
I must agree with the other reviews. Very good food, service and ambiance is really nice to spend an afternoon with your girlfriend. The very best exhibits grace these doors and the food is just a dessert to all that candy.


 I visited this place about 8 visits so far this year and really never a negative experience. Highly recommended!
author: nicgadei

description:
I used to live very close to the Legion of Honor, out on Geary at 33rd. Every time I crossed the Golden Gate, which was often, I'd drive through the golf course and past the Thinker. 

What I love about it, is it's location, with the views all around, and the miniature feel it gives off from the outside, as though it's a little bit of a secret. I have no idea what the free days are anymore, but I used to take advantage of those all the time.

Fondest memory: Ryan H.  and I sitting in the parking lot, smoking, and watching a seemingly parked Muni bus roll into a group of parked cars. The driver had forgotten to put on the E brake and was napping in the back. He sprang up, turned the thing on, made eye contact with us, and drove off.
author: Jason R.

description:
How have I lived in SF for over 2 years and never been here?  It was a foggy day, so we couldn't see most of the city (I know how unusual), but still beautiful.  It's almost like you're not even in the city, it's so quiet and peaceful.
My friend and I bought a ticket to Chihuly and got into this museum with our De Young admission.  We didn't pay the extra to go to the Women Impressionist exhibit, but were still able to see a lot.  There were a couple of Chihuly exhibits here, as well as tons of Rodin (the Thinker, etc.)  Wish we could have stayed longer, but we had to rush back to De Young to make our timed entrance.
Free admission 1st Tue of the month.
author: Sarah M.

description:
I'm a sucker for arts.  Not an art connoisseur by any means, but I love the tranquility and aesthetic appeal of all of the artwork present at this place.

It's situated near Land's End and adjacent to the Cliff House and a beautiful golf course.  If you don't drive, you can definitely take the Muni.  If you do drive, there's plenty of parking near the fountain, to the side of the museum, or down the hill towards North Beach (and it's FREE!).  

They used to have Ford Tuesday's where it was free EVERY TUESDAY.  However, times have changed, the Republicans are screwing the economy even more, so now it's just the very first Tuesday of the month that's free.  

Best parts about this place:
- Rodin and The Thinker
- Some of the cleanest bathrooms around the city
- Orchestra performances (check the museum website for more details)

Not so great:
- No more Ford Tuesday's
- Security can be uptight when picture taking
author: Joe V.

description:
Gorgeous museum, one of the best things is the location, you can see the beautiful bay on a clear day.
The monet exhibit was beautifull, they have some of the best, and a bit of degas too so its no wonder I liked it so much. 
The cafe looks quite nice and are tempted to buy everything of its gift shop. 
This is a must museum while being in San francisco.
author: Samantha O.

description:
Nicely set up, very beautiful architecture, amazing collections.

Minus one star because for some reason the security guards were seriously shadowing my friend and I like we were going to steal a painting right off the wall!?! We are 2 normal looking 25 year old white girls - what the hell? Plus there were a TON of little kids *running* (literally) around the place, including by the sculptures... you'd think they'd be more worried about them. I don't get it. Weird trip to the museum for sure.
author: Sarah P.

description: Great place for photoshoots if you're looking for a backdrop of concrete columns. I haven't actually gone inside.
author: Jeff H.

description:
This is my favorite SF museum.   It stands on a hilltop overseeing the pacific, the bay and the gate.  It is a mostly traditionally designed building with a couple oddities.  The Circular parking lot and fountain are a statement that this isn't just a strip mall you pulled into.  The courtyard entrance is warm and inviting.  It gives feeling of shelter and a natural emotional break from the outside world to the wonderful next couple hours you can enjoy.  

The Palace of Honor has one of the best sculpture collections in the country. Rodin, Claudel, etc.  The cafe is nice.
author: jack w.

description:
The Legion of Honor has maybe the most dramatic siting in San Francisco, and its grounds are dotted with some curiosities too. Jutting out over the Pacific Ocean, and with views towards the Golden Gate, the museum cuts a dramatic figure.

Check out the tablet on the west slope facing the Pacific, it was brought as a gift from the first official delegation to the United States from Japan. There's also a creepy but very powerful Holocaust memorial over there. Flanking the entrance are equestrian statues of El Cid and Joan of Arc, with a cast of the very recognizable Thinker by Rodin in the courtyard. 

On a sunny day the Legion of Honor is a great place to visit, and it's also a good museum to bring visitors to SF.
author: Richard N.

description: Really great museum, we always visit the De Young on the same day so it's a better value (as when you pay). If you are an art lover and you live in the bay you must visit here at least once.
author: Anne H.

description: Beautiful place. Not too pricey. French exhibit was not as grand as I expected but the rest of the museum made up for it.
author: E. Y. G.

description: Amazing location, grounds, architecture and art display. This museum has some beautiful Monet paintings and often puts on exhibits that make any trip worthwhile. Recommend anyone to visit.
author: Sally Z.

description:
While the permanent collection isn't the absolute best, the Legion's building, surroundings, atmosphere, and magnificent visiting exhibits make this one of my favorite museums.  The view of the Golden Gate Bridge and the statue of the El Cid out front, the stately columns and courtyard with The Thinker and the inverted pyramid, the cozy intimate feel of its halls and cafe.  Great gift shop too.  

There are marvelous pipe organ concerts on the weekends and relevant activities for children of two different age groups on Saturdays.  My kids have enjoyed these.  

Great exhibits we have seen here include Georgia O'Keefe, Claude Lorrain, Gustave Courbet, Bouquets to Art (yearly), Monet in Normandy, Art Deco, DaVinci and Poland (?!), Max Ernst, and Henry Moore.  

You can take gorgeous walks around and behind the museum up to the VA hospital behind it and out along the ocean.  Parking can be very difficult on weekends or if you arrive after noon during the week.
author: Merry P.

description:
Incredible museum ! It is the only museum in the world with a pipe organ and it's quite a famous one. Look it up on-line for the free concerts on Sundays at 4PM (you do have to buy a ticket to enter the galleries but you can listen to the concert in the foyer for free and on summer days a huge tableau over the front doors is opened and you can hear it out into the courtyard.

There is a lovely cafe downstairs (with fairly gourmet food items) across from the also lovely Museum Store.
author: Lee S.

description: I've loved the Legion of Honor for many years. I'm repeatedly fascinated by the large collection of Rodins, and am also especially fond of the Impressionist and modern collection. Last week I richly enjoyed the special exhibit of *Dutch and Flemish Masterworks from the Rose-Marie and Eijk van Otterloo Collection.* It's a wonderful and beautiful place. Each time I visit I make a special point of stopping afterward at George Segal's starkly moving Holocaust Memorial on the grounds.
author: Michael E.

description: No better place in the city to go streaking. I love this beautiful tribute to the veterans of World War II that is now utilized as a museum. Some exquisite exhibits find there way to this lovely place perched atop a hill overlooking the Pacific Ocean. Cafe is not bad either.
author: Michael G.

description:
Small is beautiful.

This isn't San Francisco's largest museum or its most well-known. It's tucked away in Land's End. I'm a big fan of Beaux Arts architecture, so the building alone could get five stars.

The museum is also a movie star. Seriously. In Vertigo, Kim Novak visits the Palace of the Legion of Honor where she obsessively views a painting.

The San Francisco Jazz Festival has also booked acts in the small theatre. The Tord Gustavsen Trio played here in the spring of 2005. Much like the museum itself, the theatre is hidden away.
author: Timothy O.

description: Enjoyed the Annie Leibowitz exhibit.  Beautiful building and grounds too.
author: Bleep S.

description:
Stuck in Traffic.  This girl that I met from a little shing ding wanted to hang out and has been in the city all her life.

Girl:  I need to go pee in about a hour....just to let you know
Me:  No probs....there are plenty of stops along the way

5 mins later.....

Girl: Ummmm....I need to pee now
Me: Ok, let's go to legion of honors
Girl: Where?
Me: Never been? You are in for a treat!
Girl: WOW, this place is beautiful!

Thanks LOH for making this city girl so happy!!!

stinky tofu
author: StinkyTofu S.

description:
I really like this museum. I think it's so much better than MOMA. Lately I haven't got the time to go there. I used to like to go just to sit there and do my home work. It's a very peaceful place. 

The view outside the museum is gorgeous! Especially if you go right before it gets too dark. It's beautiful. 

Best spot to collect my thoughts. Not much to collect though. The size might be nothing compare to MOMA or Art Institute Chicago but I love their collections and the location. Puurrfect!
author: Perry S.

description: I love this place! Amazing collection of midevil art. They also have lots of artifacts and some art from the Persian, Greek and Roman empires. This place really expanded my mind. I will visit this museum many more times in the future!
author: Kevin A.

description: I've now been here four time this year, and I never tire of it. Firstly, its location is superb, with the green hills, and cliff view of the ocean. The building its self is old, replica of europe intermixing with greek columns. It is a mix of old and new basically. The exhibits are extraordinary, one can tell there is particular yet exquisite  taste in the layout of each painting, from the place on the wall to the color of the wall to enhance the painting. Do not venture to singly the feature exhibits; look at their in house exhibits. They will pleasantly surprise you.
author: Brittany B.

description:
I first stumbled across the Legion while riding to Santa Cruz.  My reaction was like most when they first discover it:

"What in the heck?  There's a world-class museum within walking distance from my house, sitting smack in the middle of a city golf course with a spectacular view overlooking both the Ocean and the city?"

Yup yup.  And this is why SF is the greatest city in the US of A.

Finally got a chance to visit today (1st Tuesday of every month is free, bitches!)  and was impressed.  It's not the Met, but certainly rivals the last museum I went to - the very pretentious Seattle art museum.  There's Monet, Dali, and even a Picasso I'd never seen before.  The current special exhibit, da Vinci's sketches, was a bit of a let down - just a small room with about 15 items.  Guess it was impressive from a historical perspective, but doesn't exactly take a genius to sketch a horse's butt nowadays, you know what I'm saying?
author: John H.

description:
The Legion of Honor has always been a gem in terms of its location and has always had some spectacular pieces, but in the past I think it suffered a little for the rather a jumbled collection.

That has definitely changed and it is well worth your time -- and multiple visits.  The collections have been 'tightened up' and they have hosted wonderful special exhibitions 

Visit the cafe (the food's quite good and not hideously expensive!) or bring a picnic lunch and enjoy the grounds.

06/15/06 - I visited the "Monet in Normandy" exhibition featuring over 60 paintings of Norman subjects spanning somewhere around 60 years beautifully illustrating the progress of his style.  Do yourself a favor.  After dutifully trooping through the exhibit, re-visit some of the rooms and instead of standing 2-5' away from the paintings, look at them from the way across the room.  In many cases your visual (and visceral) experience will be radically different from your first look.

Forget the silly Monet-a-bilia in the gift shop - pick up a soft cover copy of the official catalog for the exhibit  ($30) - it's a treasure trove of information.
author: Nancy W.

description:
I was driving through the loop in front of Legion, and the guy in front of me took a spot. I guess he didn't see the woman stopped on the side, waiting like a hawk for the same spot. She started honking, and drove up right behind his car like an idiot, blocking my path. What the hell is he going to do when he can't back up? 

Anyway, parking was tight for the Monet exhibit. We ended up parking down the path near the entrance. There is a slope, with parking, that leads to a dead end. If it's crowded, I wouldn't advise going down here, as the cars all need to make a three-point turn, one at a time, to go back up. There is a lot of parking by the golf course clubhouse.

The view of the Bay/Ocean is nice at the top of the hill.

Oh right, the exhibit was awesome. Breathtaking. Orgasmic.
author: Keane L.

description:
I'm not reviewing the Museum, which I like and visit once a week (cuz I'm a member yo).

They have the BEST cafe - We go on weekday mornings right when it opens so it's uncrowded.  Their food is locally sourced and organic.  My double mocha here is top notch and especially refreshing because when Eli wakes up and wants out of the stroller, I can let him explore the patio without fear.
author: Robyn C.

description:
We went recently with the family my 6 yr old had a major case of the hates..............................but what do you expect at six if they would have had a Darth Vader painting he would of loved it ( maybe something for the suggestion box ?).
Had not been in many years seemed larger than I remember.
 I did enjoy it, we did sneek in the Fabrege Egg display which was well worth the risk of  of getting my third strike.

It appears that we have not stolen nearly as much of the world's treasures as the British,or at least they are not all on display.

Lots of Frog art,the old frogs could clearly make a paint brush sing across the canvas.Picasso..had better dope than I ever had !

The building was great and there were the prerequisite people with sticks up their a- - es who think they are someone special because they are at a musuem.........is that not why they made France ?
author: Guiseppe B.

description: Their French Impressionism exhibit going on right now is righteous!
author: CM P.

description:
What a beautiful, beautiful place in an excellent garden-like location... this museum was better than I had expected it to be.

Both the inside and outside are amazing.  Not exactly a huge, gargantuan museum, but the collections are worth checking out for those interested in Western Art.  Here, you'll find several artworks by some famous artists like Van Gogh, Monet, Seurat, Rodin... as well as artworks by a bunch of people I didn't know, but still pretty impressive stuff!!  ;-)

The highlight of this place for me was being "greeted" at the front by the world famous statue, "Thinker" by Rodin.  Just the fact that I've seen so many references to that statue, whether it be on TV, movies, people's jokes and conversations... and to finally see THE STATUE was like... whoa, cool  :-)

Plus, if you visit here, you get a free admission to the De Young Museum (which is where they have American art I believe) on the same day... unfortunately we didn't have time to go there, our trip to SF was pretty short :-(
author: Melissa B.

description:
I've been to science museums before, and though I have always wanted to go to an art museum, I've never been. Now, I can actually say I've been to a "real" one. 

The location itself is beautiful and very relaxing, and I haven't even started on the paintings and exhibits here. I have to tell you now, I have no art background whatsoever. I have no extensive knowledge about it, but the fact is, you don't have to have those to appreciate this place. 

They have everything from religious paintings, 17-19th century, renaissance, etc, but I think their biggest collection is of European art, which I loved. I noticed they had many of Rodin's and Monet's that I remember from history classes. I was trying to look for Picasso because I've heard he has some here, but didn't find any. Too bad. I think I was just so distracted because there are so many things to see! 

I particularly loved the victorian room completed with its walls, doors, cabinets, and other furniture. Also, the crazy beautiful ceiling that I believe is Spanish. (?) It was as if I was in a whole different place and time. Another part of the museum that I enjoyed so much was their special exhibit of Faberge, Tiffany, and Lalique; Just amazing! Worthy of the extra $10. 

I would definitely come back again, especially that their next special exhibit is King Tut's. That's something I'm very much looking forward to. Apparently, if you are a History and Discovery Channel addict, you can not miss it. ;) 

BTW: If you're a student, dont forget to bring your ID. Also, if youre a B of A customer, you'll get a discount.
author: Jillian R.

description: Just another one of those breath taking spots in the city! I haven't actually gone inside the Legion of Honor, but exploring the park, statues, and looks out spots around it is enough to fill your day. This is a great spot to look out onto the Golden Gate Bridge. You can play golf, bike along the paths, and relax by the fountain or many statues within the grassy field. The actual Legion of Honor is a beautiful structure with a magnificent statue of the Thinking Man as you enter. It's the perfect spot to visit on a warm sunny afternoon.
author: Casi C.

description: This has been one of my favorite places to go since I was a baby and I have loved it my whole life it is great. They always have great exhibits, they have a nice cafe and museum store and it is a great tourist destination and I think it would be great for european tourists. All in all, it is a great museum and I am so excited for its upcoming dutch painting exhibit starting July 9,2011.
author: Sophia C.

description: Fabulous museum!  Incredible collection of Rodin's.  I've been to many exhibits here and they do a great job.  Highly recommend getting the audio tour for exhibits and then walking around the main museum with the head phones on.  It is worth the trip and the views from outside are fantastic!
author: Karen C.

description: The best (if not the only) place in Bay Area to see world class art exhibits. there are several new art shows each year. Another nice thing about this museum is organ concerts on Saturdays. Permanent collection is very limited, what is a shame for such a popular city as San Francisco.
author: E K.

description: This is a simple one. If you can appreciate art without getting bored, this is a great museum to visit. They have a solid collection of canvas work and antiques.  I always love their traveling pieces (ex: Monet's work).  Their exhibits are always worth checking out; I always leave impressed. I loved their Cartier exhibit and their Pulp Fiction exhibit. However, if you don't have a good attention span, this place probably isn't for you.
author: farzana k.

description:
This museum has a breathtaking view and it is a piece of fine art itself! The day we visited the museum there was a model photo-shoot as well as a couple taking wedding pictures! The French Jewelry exhibit is also something you shouldn't miss.

Being a big fan of Rodin this place has a good selection and has a few van Gogh, my fav. Obviously it can't be compared with the MET but it offers a min-version of everything a museum goer looks for.
author: T L.

description: Went on a free Bank of America weekend, which gets you into the museum but not entrance to the special exhibit (right now it's the Cartier exhibit). Beautfiul views from the museum lawns and it's just gorgeous when it's a clear day. There is an organist that plays on the weekends and it was really awesome, it was a 4:00 pm performance and it lasted about 30 minutes. I liked the organ playing the best, but there's also the artwork as well. Great museum and it's well-worth going, just for the view.
author: Glaciala A.

description:
The collection ranges from ancient Egypt and Greece to 20th century Europe including Rodin sculptures.  Every Saturday and Sunday at 4 PM there is an organ concert.  Just like the de Young it is worth a visit just for the special exhibitions.  The Marie-Antoinette and the Petit Trianon at Versailles special exhibition gave visitors a peek at the decor, paintings and furniture that once belonged to the ill-fated queen.  Don't forget to take a stroll around the grounds.  The view of the bay and the Golden Gate Bridge is spectacular.  Parking is free but very limited.  The audio tours can be rented for a fee (free for visually impaired visitors).  Members are also required to pay a fee for the audio tours.

TIPS:  Your admission ticket to The Legion of Honor can also be used at de Young so come early to give yourself enough time to visit both museums.
A limited number of wheelchairs are available to borrow for those visitors who might not be able to walk through the many of galleries.
Teachers can get a yearly membership for only $45.  It includes bringing one guest with each visit, 10% off at the museum store and covers both De Young and the Legion of Honor.
author: Rachel R.

description:
Faberge Eggs  !! - loved it , loved it !!!
not sure why i was waiting for so long....
couple more weeks left - do not miss it, recommend !
author: Lena M.

description:
Whenever I go here, I feel like I'm one of the few people that know this place exists. Not that many heads are here on a daily basis, so it's nice to be solo to roam around.

The view from around the area is beautiful, and you would miss one of the most wonderful things about the museum if you just hopped in your car. So lovely that I took my wedding pics here!

Tips: Great Rodin collection, starting with The Thinker. Fall in love with art again. If you have some free time take a walk along the park, pack a sammich and watch the golfers shank all over the place.
author: Charlene L.

description:
Once you get to the legion of honor, find a parking and hop out of the car, you are immediately taken by the beautiful view of the bay, the trees and surroundings.  It is a beautiful, romantic landscape perfect for a day at the gallery.

The art  is far ranging, medieval, impressionist, modern etc, a little bit of everything for everyone.  Their collection of medieval is beautiful and extensive, certiatinly worth seeing.  They have plenty of new or temporary exhibts and much to gaze at.

I didn't love the layout though, it didn't really flow together and you could certaintly miss something do to it.  But still it works and the building itself is beautiful, oh well.
author: Sabrina A.

description:
Went here on a beautiful Sunday afternoon with a few friends to catch the Annie Leibovitz exhibit. We had a picnic out on the front lawn, sat in the grass, people watched, and took in the view for 2 hours before making our way into the museum. A enjoyed the whole euro feel to the place and they had some interesting stuff. I can't stress how good the view is though. I can't believe i've lived in the Bay Area for upwards of a year and have only just discovered this place.

There were a few minor issues though:

1.) I thought $15 admission to the special exhibit was a bit steep and i wish it had been listed on their website so i would have known ahead of time. I guess $10 to get in for the rest of the museum isn't too bad, but still. 

2.) Its smaller than i expected. This isn't really a bad thing, but for the price and the number of people, i was expecting it to be bigger,

3.) I think the Holocaust should absolutely be recognized and remembered so that the world doesn't allow that to happen again. That being said, i thought the Holocaust memorial here was really poorly done. I don't like to criticize art because its so subjective, but really, i would liked to have seen more on this one.
author: Travis D.

description: A beautiful museum with lots of artwork. The museum is in the most beautiful area with awesome views! Great exhibitions come through this museum year round! I highly recommend this place if you want to view some classic art.
author: Lynn C.

description: breathtakingly beautiful. They have free admittance on the first Tuesday of the month, so take advantage of that. We only spent about an hour here since we came later in the day but I could have wandered around forever, getting lost in all the gorgeous art. Be sure to spend some time roaming around the grounds later, walking through the paved road looking over the ocean and the lovely SF fog. so romantic and spooky.
author: michella s.

description: I love this museum. It takes me make to the Louvre every time I step in. I takes me through many historical periods of France from f pre revolutionary, the age of Napoleon, and the rise of Impressionism. These are my favorite exhibits. I also love the neoclassical architecture. Also a good collection of Flemish and Dutch art. A good introduction to the art of Rubens, VanDyke, and other Flemish painters. Also a great collection of Rodin and Camille Claudel sculptures. The cafe is also pretty good.This is an art teachers treasure trove to bring students for an art tour!
author: N G.

description: Unbelievable. I came here today with my mom as we are on vacation in san Francisco. We rented a car from the airport and while we were visiting the museum our car got broken into and our camera bag was stolen from the trunk of the car. Is had 5000 dollars worth of equipment in it which is extremely disappointing to us. The security people were really unhelpful with us also. It's not a very good area apparently so if you do visit be prepared for shit customer service and getting your car broken into and your stuff stolen! Also, we ate at the cafe, which does not have good food.
author: Jami D.

description: Kind of a hike to get here, but very beautiful building and view from the top of a hill, and beautiful art of course.
author: Geena B.

description:
Normally I wouldn't consider myself much of a joiner. But I LOVE museum memberships. I'm a current member of the SFMOMA, for instance. But in terms of a museum I want to lose myself in, give me the Legion of Honor anyday. 

Unlike the SFMOMA, which is consistently stuffed to the gills with tourists and onlookers breathing over your shoulder, chewing gum while listening to audio tours and  bumping into you while not looking where they are going -- the Legion is ever so open, blissfully expansive (and free of the masses) and PEACEFUL, even on a Saturday. Such a gorgeous view of the city outside, such a beautiful building, with its stone walls and curving wood banisters... One can relax and hear oneself think.

The exhbits are always interesting, with a good number of works on paper, and always an exhibit of illustrated or artist's books. Many rare works of art you couldn't see anywhere else, both historic and contemporary. I was so happy to finally get my membership card in the mail, so I could visit the current show, "Rembrandt to Thiebaud: A Decade of Collecting Works on Paper," which is a real stunner. You'll want to take your time with this one.

I listened to the sounds of an antique violin on display, and wandered through the French period rooms to gaze at the historic decorative paneling, glass and furniture. I even spotted a man walking through the halls in full period costume of the 17th century.

At 4 pm, Keith Thompson played an amazing concert on the majestic symphonic organ, built into the walls of the museum itself. The acoustics of the rooms are so impressive, the music travels throughout the museum. Unfortunately, this also meant that you could hear every cell phone user and obnoxious incessant conversationalist in the rooms as well. (Such music is meant to transport you --- please consider not talking for a few minutes of music, ok, people? Silence isn't deadly, I promise. We'll all enjoy the experience, more, ok?. Text message if you must.)

You can also enjoy a meal in the cafe - not cheap, but tasty. Outside, you can enjoy the lawns, the nature, the sculpture,  the traditional Spanish guitar being played, and even watch new brides getting their pictures taken.

I am truly looking forward to my next visit. It will be a pleasure to savor.
author: Paula W.

description:
The Legion houses one of the finest museums and art collections SF has to offer. The collection consists of classical European art, which makes their collection so timeless. And the incredible scenic location puts it over the top. It's quite a climb to get to the museum but once you're up there, you can see the Golden Gate bridge and surrounding bay from the parking lot and thanks to a local, we discovered a sweet hiking trail that leads to the Sutro baths at the Cliff House!

The Rodin collection was really the highlight for me. Those sculptures were amazing! I also really enjoyed the various gaudily furnished rooms that were true to the time period, which made for a nice change of pace from the exhausting displays of wall paintings, not to undermine the paintings or anything. They, too, are remarkable. From the floor to the ceiling this museum is brimming with beauty, including the palatial building that contains it.

TIP: Legion of Honor admission tickets will grant you FREE admission into the De Young if you go the same day, and vice versa.
author: Cat L.

description:
Many fond memories here. NYE, Monet in Normandy, summer breeze, doing my summer project on art. Breathtaking views.

Just wonderful.
author: J T.

description:
My favorite museum in the world :) For me, the Louvre in Paris is far too overstimulating and the location of the LOH is a picture perfect place to house works of art.  So much more refreshing to be here instead of in the middle of the city where museums are traditionally situated.

SECRET:)  The coffee shop is much more than just a place to get a latte.  You can get champagne here, but it's not on the menu.  You 
need to know who to ask.

WARNING!!  The Greek columns are not stripper poles
author: Anastasia Beaver Housand J.

description: As a lifetime student of photography, I decided to visit the Annie Leibovitz exhibit.  this museum is located in a very picturesque part of the city.  In fact, I never even knew this place existed until I got there.  On one side, you have the golf course and on the other side, you have a very beautiful view of the bay and the Golden Gate Bridge.  The selection of pieces was incredible.  From the Dead Sea scrolls to the various timeless paintings and sculptures, my visit was a memorable one.  The Annie Leibovitz exhibit was also phenomenal.
author: Javier O.

description: Awesome and amazing museum with original works from great masters! I wish I hadn't paid the extra ten bucks for the Louvre exhibit because it sucked. The rest of the museum was wonderful, though!
author: Cherelyn W.

description:
This is one of the most beautifully set buildings, which itself is beautiful, with some of the most beautiful pieces of art I've ever been to.

The Legion suffers from large exhibitions laid out in really bad ways though.  This should change though with the De Young opening up.

I've seen the Picasso show, the Dada & Surrealist show, Art Deco show, and the Egyptian Show (from the British Museum) there.  The problem with the last two shows listed there is that they were multi-level, which really causes a hassle with trying to get to see all the pieces.

However, the museum does have a lot more to offer.  They have the wonderful Spanish Ceiling, and a large collection of Renaissance art work (not to be compared with the National Gallery's collection).  

If you're there late on a Sunday, stick around an watch the organ performance.  Also, check out the bookstore.  They usually have great bargain books and lots of unusual stuff, such as the "Book of Russian Prison Tattoos" (one that I recently picked up--extremely interesting).

The cafe isn't half bad either (a lot cleaner and better selection than the De Young's cafe).
author: David S.

description:
Lots to do in the area and easily accessible by the #1 bus line right across the street from the ferry building, the Legion of Honor has hosted many events. Most recently, the Monet exhibit, there are also many others.such as the Holocaust Memorial. 
Nearby is a sub-par golf course, but beautiful nonetheless.
author: Eugene G.

description:
This place has a LOT to see, plan on arriving early and taking at least two hours to see what catches your eye, more if you want to see everything they have to offer. I believe they have an exhibit section that changes but since I've only been there the one time I am not certain.

There is a great view of San Francisco that I could just sit and stare at for hours along with a Holocaust memorial. I would love to go back but I don't think my friends would be too interested.
author: Bruce C.

description:
Not my favorite museum of all time, but certainly not bad..
Although i have not attended, the film series that is offered included some spectacular works that i wish i could have seen.  Also two of the past temporary exhibits -Marie Antoinette and Annie Lebovitz have been terrific experiences. 

If anything, the exhibitions could do with more of the occasional benches. Nothing will detract from my attention in a blockbuster exhibit than my knees giving out on me from standing for an hour, and only being halfway through the pieces I am trying to appreciate.  

Other than that, they have been vastly improving their pompous image of yesteryear by including some interesting and innovative exhibitions recently, which has been a terrific addition to the museum offerings in San Francisco.
author: Monica B.

description:
My husband and I were married at the Legion of Honor and it the day was near perfect. I couldn't have asked for a lovelier location to exchange vows.


 The museum (along with most of the museums in San Francisco) uses an amazing caterer, which we were required to use for our ceremony. We couldn't have been happier with the meal and the service, and the fact that it held in the museum cafe made no difference. They transformed the space into the perfect wedding venue.


 Aside from the wedding, the museum itself is quite a hidden little gem in the city. Most attention goes to the Modern Art Museum or the DeYoung in Golden Gate Park. The Legion is often overlooked, I'm guessing because of the off-the-beaten-path location.


 However, if you can find your way to this landmark, do it. Be warned: The weekends are pretty brutal. You may have to fight your way through a gaggle of brides and their limos. Photographers LOVE the lighting in the courtyard and often bring their subjects here for a quick photo shootwhich is incredibly annoying for brides (like me) who are actually booked to be married at the museum.
author: sfKristina

description: I've been here MANY times over many decades and the general vibe of this place as reflected in the reception in the foyer is increasingly elitist, callous and generally unfriendly.  On a number of occasions I've accompanied a friend who has a hearing deficit and when informed that she cannot hear their instructions and asked them to please speak up she is met with a sideways glance and ignored. So, my recent visits have started out on a less than bright note.  And given that I'm not a huge fan of the bulk of their displayed collection I guess that leaves going there to enjoy the stunning setting and possibly buy something in the cafe.  I will say that the people in the cafe are much kinder and helpful than those up front.  I just wish management would be more aggressive in upgrading their menu.  On the visit to the cafe today around 11am we found the display cases empty.  Maybe I'm expecting too much to want something to eat with my coffee.  After a brief visit to view the handful of Matisse paintings, drawings, etc. we decided to check out their lunch menu.  Meh!  Would rather go home and make some lunch.  Finally, they really ought to dust the amazing pieces they have at least once a year.  So, in summary at least I can say the layer of dust on some pieces was world class!
author: j d.

description: This place is absolutely gorgeous! The architecture is superb while their permanent galleries are really lovely. I've been a couple times, though the most recent was to check out the "Royal Treasures from the Louvre: Louis XIV to Marie-Antoinette" exhibit. They have some very fascinating objects to look at here. I myself am not much of an art enthusiast but just walking around the building itself is great. This is a place you'd want to have your wedding at. Definitely stop by!
author: Christina L.

description: Fantastic place to wander around for hours. Stunning views of the Golden Gate Bridge and Bay. Endless rooms full of gorgeous (if somewhat repetitive) art works. Come by during the free day, first Tuesday of every month, since the actual art is not that stunning, though I guess it depends what you're into. Great building with interesting architecture, I especially enjoyed the dome that housed sculptures. Also, the ground around the museum are filled with golfers, though they seem nice enough.
author: judi p.

description:
I have to say I liked the Legion more than the De Young.  The building is awesome, and the Holocaust memorial just out front is moving (not inside the actual museum)  

Go on the first Tuesday of each month, why?  because its FREE.99!!!
author: Winter Lee S.

description:
I absolutely adore this museum!

I must admit that I tried and I tried to turn myself into one of those refined ladies who spends hours at the museum and follows her visit with a glass of Dom Perignon and a novel of classic literature. I've given up. Nevertheless, The Legion of Honor never fails to keep me engaged during my two hours at the museum. 

The Legion is one of those rare gems that has a little bit of everything - from Monet's Water Lilies to ancient Mesopotamian works, from wacky Picassos to French Baroque furniture.

The museum itself is absolutely gorgeous, both inside and out. The Neoclassic architecture and breathtaking views make it a perfect setting for pre and post-wedding photography. Rodin's The Thinker sits in front of the museum and never stops thinking about its beauty.

I am a fan, and inclined to say it's one of the few San Francisco museums worth going to for its permanent collection of works and not just for special exhibitions....great for a date too ;).
author: Juliya R.

description:
Gorgeous museum with good amount of collection from the Medieval to the 20th Century.
 i love the laid back location and the architecture. 
it's just classy and sophisticated.

the Rodin sculpture collection is wonderful.
author: Florence C.

description:
On the most perfect January day I've ever seen in SF, I came here with one of my favorite native San Franciscans. The initial draw was the Marie-Antoinette exhibit (http://www.famsf.org/legion/exhibitions/exhibition.asp?exhibitionkey=737) , which was pretty amazing in and of itself, but I love just about everything about this place. In fact, it's my favorite museum in the SF Bay Area.


 The architecture of the building reminds me of museums I've been to in Europe (for some reason, it reminds me of the Picasso Museum, which is my favorite museum in Paris). Big and cavernous and a little dark and dank, especially in some of the medieval art rooms at the very back. And you don't have to be a sculpture buff to appreciate the fact that this place has THE THINKER -- not the original, which is at the Rodin Museum, but one of the 20 casts made of it -- as well as an impressive collection of other Rodin sculptures. I love the fact that the Thinker represents Dante in front of the gates of hell, I suppose that would give anyone pause for thought.


 They also have nice, big rooms that are generally uncrowded, so you can sit and ponder the meaning of life just like Kim Novak did in Vertigo. And then there is "The Broken Pitcher" by Bouguereau, the poster I hung in my college dorm room, which is still as hauntingly beautiful to me now as it was 25 years ago. In January, I sat in that room on a fairly empty week day, pondering her sorrowful gaze (there are many interpretations, some form of lost innocence being the most predominant). This is not my favorite Bouguereau -- that one is The Birth of Venus at the Musee d'Orsay, one of the many interpretations that pays homage to Botticelli -- but it is a close second.


 There is also a small Holocaust memorial just to the left of the fountain outside if you are standing facing the city with your back to the museum. I wandered over there and sat in front of it for a few moments and found it very moving.


 Finally, there are the stunning city views from everywhere outside and the beautiful grounds of Lincoln Park, where the Legion is located. If you are lucky enough to be here on a clear day, the view is simply spectacular. I cannot think of a more lovely setting for a wedding, except maybe Laguna Beach, California.
author: bloomsday

description: Currently there is a Cartier in America exhibit going on at the Legion of Honor. Many shiny diamonds and jewels along with mystery clocks. If you're curious to know how Cartier became famous, you would need to visit the exhibit. It pretty much explains it all. While you're there, be sure to avoid the linebacker grannies and wannabe fashionistas that hog up the space in front of the LARGE gems. Don't be surprised to see 1 or 2 no-class ladies in leopard prints who front with an LV cap(real or fake?) and carry Fendi bags. These ladies are part of the OTHER exhibit.
author: Joseph N.

description:
When I need a day to meditate and relax, this is my favorite place in the city. It really makes you realize why you live in San Francisco.
Gorgeous!
author: angela n.

description:
First, the location and building are amazing. Peaceful and beatiful. The collections are all amazing. It's exciting to see such great works housed here in San Francisco. 

A walk through the museum helps me to reset my eyes after too many hours of the internet, Youtube, television, gossip magazines, billboards, and all the other pop culture I wade through, and enjoy, everyday. It's a good place to go and check out the craftsmanship and artistry that has survived over the years. Some great works, and some not so great works, but all are a peak at something different that at least seems to calm my nerves when the city wears them out.
author: Chris J.

description:
This museum is very classic, sophisticated, & timeless.  If you've been there, you already know that it occupies one of the best locations in San Francisco.  The view of the Golden Gate Bridge & SF in general is so gorgeous from up there.  Anyway...

It's very peaceful here.  I can't really describe it.  The art is gorgeous & you can't find anything this classic in any of the other museums in SF.

However, I was expecting the museum to be a lot bigger inside than it actually was.  This museum is definitely on the smaller side, but all the art in there are definitely quality pieces so I guess that's why it isn't bigger.

I ate at the restaurant there & didn't expect too much.  However, I ordered a chicken sandwich & it was SO GOOD.  I wasn't expecting it to be very good at all, but I was wrong. & I'm really picky with food so, that's a plus for them.

I would suggest going when they have a great exhibit going on so you get to see more art.  Still though, it's a must-visit in San Francisco!
author: Blushed M.

description:
One of the city's most beautiful buildings.  I went on a free first Tuesday, which also happened to be 4th of July, but it was still free (just the $5 surcharge for the special show).  That was nice.  I was definitely not the only one who had that idea, but took my time and weathered the storm of headphoned seniors and bored kids to really experience the Monet show.  Definitely see it; it's a crowd-pleaser, and sure, Monet isn't exactly considered avant-garde in this day, but by the end of the (60 painting!) show, you can definitely see how revolutionary he was.  

Back to the museum.  The permanent collections weren't outstanding, and it's actually a fairly small place, but again the experience was great, just because of the building and the quiet (aside from the Monet show the place was almost empty, even then).  Impressive rococo gallery, which seems random.  Anyway, the real highlight was the Rodin collection, which itself was worth the price of admission.  Which for me, was nothing, so...not saying too much, but whatever.
author: Alex T.

description:
it is a beautiful museum in this area, nice garden, good views around. close to many good site-seeing and restaurants.

good collections of differents items.

however, ticket is kind of high, and parking is difficult if you come on weekend
author: David L.

description: I came here for an organ concert and the experience was amazing. The grounds are beautiful, the views are spectacular, the museum structure itself is gorgeous, and the vast collection of art (both inside and out) is so incredible. I really loved the European paintings and could spend hours walking through the galleries. I'll definitely come back and will consider purchasing membership in the future when I have more free time.
author: Angie L.

description: The Legion of Honor in San Francisco is filled with gallery after gallery of seemingly the exact same painting you just saw. Ideal for art history classes studying 1800s style art, or group trips from the local senior center.
author: Devon H.

description: This is a beautiful building in a very serene setting. The last exhibit that I saw was the Annie Leibovitz show last spring. It definitely gets busy on weekends though. I would recommend going early or on a weekday afternoon.
author: Jen L.

description:
I've been a member for more than six years.
I love supporting the Arts that feeds the life blood of creativity.

When I talk about Art, I'm not talking about the sniveling naysayers who go from gallery to gallery with noses high and Gamay on their breath.
Most painters that we appreciate now, including Van Gogh, lived modest existences. 
Georgia O'Keefe who I highly respect as a painter I've known of since I was fifteen and first set eyes on her works. I was struck by her independence and her attention to detail. It wasn't for whatever reasons the 'patrons of the Arts' had to say anything about it. It was her, her colors flowing onto the page, and her attention to nature that drew me in. I get Georgia. I want so bad to go to Ghost Ranch-it's like a pilgrimage unrequited-for it has not happened yet. I like the fact Gaugin was interested in people that looked like me in fabrics uncommon to stuffy western society at the time. I loved the colors. Possibly the patrons might not agree with me, but I don't care. 
They don't paint. I do. 
I've seen the whole, entire Louvre, the Smithsonian, and the Musee Orsay. The De Young-does not cut it. The Legion of Honor does.

Why didn't I become an artist and only an artist? Because I never wanted to have to sell my soul, my passion, to the galleries, who treat art as if skinny jeans were the new fashion. Fashion is fickle and like a cruel mistress leaves next season and returns forlorn and strung out ten years later wishing she could have seen you for what you were. 
I'm not talking about what THEY say art is--like at the new DeYoung-believe me-I met one of the patrons and she was none to happy with my modest, mortal opinion. I remember the old De Young. It was so much livelier and more in harmony with the Louvre. Alas, the artsies took it over and destroyed the building I remember as a child. It was the place where my mother took me to show me the world under one roof. The place I first saw two inches away from my nose Monet's works come to visit its precious halls when I was 17. Guess how many Georgia O' Keefe's are in the De Young? One. Only one. I guess the Bubble Gum machine art is just a nice. It's sad really. 

The Legion of Honor on the other hand has preserved one of the places from my childhood that I certainly will take others to see. When you first walk in, you see the Replica of the Thinker by Rodin. The original is in the garden at the Musee Rodin in Paris. In the main hall is more of his works. My body communicates as a dancer and he understood the human body well, with all its twists, turns, and range of emotion gauged in a single piece of stone or metal. There is nothing like it. It is for the vivacity of existence, my love of exploding color on my paint brush, or sliding color with my multicolored, smudged finger that I appreciate the Legion over the De Young. 
It was here at the Legion that one of Leonardo Da Vinci's painting hung on the walls. I took my mother to see it to repay the favor of inspiration.
 I absolutely adore Rodin, and am convinced, that if I were to live during his time, I would have been his groupie or even better, I would have loved to be his apprentice. I applaud the Legion of Honor for treasuring the works of the past in order to honor the future and inspire the artists who just don't want to see what everyone else likes.

The mark of anything of anyone of good character is healthy love and respect for the past to inspire the future to create their own opinions. Like oral histories, the art should be honored and preserved. Not put in a basement or have a cave plundered without respect to those ancestors.
