author: J A.

description:
I decided to splurge on my self and got a museum membership, cost $80 for the year and it is so worth it! I feel like such a VIP when I can get into this museum and bring a guest any time I want. You can get tickets to the special exhibits any time as well. 

The Legion of Honor is beautiful, the grounds are amazing. When I need a "me" day I just go there, enjoy the art and the gorgeous scenery. Then all is well in my world.
author: Denise B.

description:
astonishingly beautiful. the building itself and the views it affords are incredible.

i have loved this place ever since a school field trip in grade school. we went on a friday, and they were setting up for a wedding that night. little 11-year old me saw the tufts of pink and white tulle and petals and silk, and i floated away in a day dream of my own wedding swathed in the same menagerie of pink.

the museum itself is fantastic.
author: Ahu S.

description: One of the city's most beautiful museums, with an impressive collection of ancient and European art, in a breathtaking Lincoln Park setting overlooking the Pacific and the Golden Gate Bridge. The stunning Beaux-Arts building ( which was constructed to honor 3,600 Californians who lost their lives on the battlefields of France during World War I) has the Thinker, one of seventy Rodin scupltures in the museum, greeting visitors as they enter the outdoor Court of Honor. The permanent collection includes European decorative arts and paintings, antiquities from throughout the ancient Mediterranean world and the Near East, 18th-Century English and French Porcelain, and, despite its small size, one of the largest collections of prints, drawings, and illustrated books in the country, more than 70,000 in all. Regularly scheduled tours are available Tuesdays (when entry is free) through Sundays, or you can browse at your own pace by renting a state-of-the-art random-access digital device for a $3.00 fee. Organ concerts, included in the price of admission, are presented every Saturday and Sunday at 4:00pm. If you manage to visit at an off-hour, the tranquil atmosphere can soothe the most jangled nerves and, if it's too crowded inside, you can revel in the views outdoors.
author: Gourmet G.

description: If you want a RUDE and harassing experience, then this is the place to go.  The ticket staff are incompetent and RUDE.  The tickets we purchased allowed admittance to both the de Young museum and the Legion of Honor.  We encountered no problems with the de Young museum however the Legion of Honor was another story.  The admission staff at the Legion of Honor like to argue and harass people. They don't know policy and are quite incompetent.  I'll never attend the Legion of Honor again.  Who needs to be harassed by  RUDE and incompetent people.
author: mary m.

description: Beautiful building. As you walk up to the entrance, you feel like royalty and the gods have opened their gates for you. The first statue that you see is a real Rodin - Le Penseur. I could spend a good hour in the Rodin lobby inside. It's breathtaking.
author: Susan D.

description: This place feels like I stepped in a fake version of our nations capitol. And I got in for free for reasons I cannot say but I walked in checked a few places out and was like WTF am I doing here? So I left and instead went to Sea Cliff to watch the waves. I know...I know seems pointless why I went but it was free and I was bored! And what I found even more weird was that an Asian family was taking wedding photos in the concourse. I was like who would even think of such a thing?? Oh well, I guess there is people who think, "Oh wouldn't be great to get married and take photos at the Legion of Honors?"
author: Michael H.

description:
Great place to spend an afternoon.

Spending only a week in SF on family vacation we had to decide on the places to see and we went to the Legion of Honor since we could get in free after seeing the King Tut exhibit at DeYoung. I was impressed with the Legion of Honor. It had a interesting mix of art from paintings, furniture to ancient artifacts. You will definitely find something to interest you. 

On the afternoon we went there was organ music playing, and the organist was introducing music pieces he found interesting.

Highly recommended.
author: Ed C.

description: The Legion of Honor will just take you to another world.  When you need to escape for a few hours, this is the place to go.  I thoroughly enjoyed the visiting exhibitions I have seen here (Da Vinci and Annie Liebowitz), but the permanent collections are a great starting point.  The other day I had a 3 hour "lunch" break from work so I joined a docent tour which they offer almost daily.  I recommend starting with one of those, since they walk you through many of the galleries.  Then when you return on your own, you'll have a good baseline set of information.  Try to learn the history of the museum at the 2:00 tour on Tuesdays -- it's fascinating (you get a little insight into "scandalous" San Francisco from the last century).
author: Max G.

description: A very beautiful museum.  The Faberge, Lalique, Tiffany exhibit was very nice.  Audio tour is worth the money.
author: Wakako U.

description: I won't go into detail, since so many other reviews do a much finer job that I could. I am not an art major, and where I live there is nothing like this. So, I felt like a country bunkin' who was seeing incredible art for my first time. I stayed for four hours, because I just sat and marveled at the incredible detail in so many of the paintings. This surprised me, because I expected to be a little ho-hum, and I'd be chomping at the bit to leave. I'm so glad that my friend recommended that we come here. I'm glad that I paid the $7 for the headphones so that I could better understand the art that I was looking at.  I left with a deeper appreciation for centuries of art, and I especially loved the Dutch painters.  The view, on a clear day, is breathtaking in itself. We enjoyed the drive back to the City, via Lincoln Blvd.  By the way, we had lunch in the cafeteria which was surprisingly good. Great selection of beer, quick and efficient service, and lots of organic and fresh ingredients.  Considering it was a FREE day of admission, I felt like we scored a special gem of a day in one of my favorite getaway cities.
author: Debby F.

description: The location is so splendid it would be worth visiting this gallery if it were empty. A majestic building set high on Land's End, with great views of the Pacific, and the rare treat of seeing GG Bridge and the city from the West. It's a replica of Palais de la Legion d'Honneur in Paris (respectfully rendered at 3/4 the size). Their collection is variable and kind of eccentric. Some bloody good Rodin though - as well as a few of the big classics it's interesting to look at his small studies and preparatory sculptures. The pillaging of many a European church over the years has facilitated the bringing together of some truly exceptional medieval art here - particularly their Saint portraits. Gee, thanks America, now we don't have to actually GO to Europe to see the best bits.
author: Bob G.

description: A quintessential example of San Francisco's great civic architecture, and set on a hill amidst the cypress trees overlooking downtown.  Awesome.  They frequently host some very unusual and entertaining art exhibits.  I caught the art deco exhibit about a year ago which was amazing.
author: Rick H.

description: this place brings out the artsy, upper crust, chin in the air side of anyone. from the entrance to the exterior art this place is filled with things to stare at. i've seen so many wedding photos done here that i made a mockery of it in my own little photo shoot with a friend. in the end those were some of the best pictures of the trip... i thank the columns they're very photogenic. aside from the grounds, what i love about this place is that it's free & you only pay for the main exhibit, talk about a deal. also, if you happen to go to the de young early you get to see their exhibit for free (& vice versa). it's definitely one of the most underrated museums in san francisco. it's a must see for anyone visiting for the first time.
author: Madhu D.

description: Beautiful museum but a segment of the population don't come here for the art, but rather using the location (and also down the hill from there) for spectacular backdrop used for wedding outdoor professional photography.
author: Ken K.

description: Good for Kids: Yes-------first of all, this should be the last place you decide to take your kids, unless you want to hear them complain the entire time. it would be just as fun for them as taking them to a senior center. yes, the art is impressive in some ways, but portraits, landscape, and religious art becomes redundant and boring. and no, i am not a fan of unintelligible music or stoner movies, but i prefer art that holds my interest and has meaning and relevance. highly recommended for anyone over the age of 55. if you are under this age and have any sense of innovation, you might enjoy SFMoMA or the de Young.
author: Kady M.

description: I bring tourists here to gawk at the Thinker in the courtyard. We never go in. We just look...and ...think.
author: Kelly S.

description: Romantic and beautiful by day or by night.  A little known fact about the Legion of Honour is that an old dude feeds the animals in the parking lot late at night.  Foxes, skunks, squirrels, and racoons eating bread and hotdogs together is a sight to see.
author: Olivia G.

description: Incredible. One of the coolest museums I've been to. Highly recommend it to everyone who lives here and to tourists alike.
author: Hanan H.

description:
i love this building. im not going to say anything about the art and/or the permanent collection inside. except, i have been here many a times (it helps to be a member) and every city resident should go inside at least once. also, one of the best views of GG from here. it is breathtaking.
I LOVE SAN FRANCISCO.
author: Sha A.

description: They always have fun little exhibits and showings and if you have a Bank of America card (debit or credit), you get in for free!
author: Lisa H.

description:
Haven't been to too many musems to know if the California Palace of the Legion of Honor is great or not, but I'm still giving it a 5.
Beautiful inside and out, took soo many pictures (:
Mom said that a lot of people take their wedding pictures there and sure enough, I saw a wedding photography thing going on that day.
You can see SF golden gate bridge from the musem, and also other great views.
I think they even have a little hiking thing if you walk down a bit.
One reason i loved it soo much was the fact that i got in for free. Apparently if you have your B of A ( bank of america card) you can get in for free.
Inside, clean & neat.
Not enough benches in my opinion.
soo many great paintings, and you can get so close and personal with them ahah.
serioiusly i literally put my face in each painting, especially the impression room, check this room out if you go!
author: Kimberly S.

description: The best museum in San Francisco! I am member and I always enjoy the ever changing art here. The views from the property are some of the best in the bay area. Be sure to check out this place if you have time to see just one museum today!
author: David P.

description: This is one of my favorite museums in SF. They also, have a free admission day once a month. It's a gorgeous drive and has a beautiful view looking out over the Pacific. It is worth checking out!
author: Rebekah R.

description: I visit this place far less than I should. It's a bitch to get over there and it's always freezing cold due to it's vicinity to the beach. The building itself is exquisite and the permanent collection is pretty impressive. It veers more towards antiquity, which for my Modern-leaning tastes gets a little old for me (no pun intended). But there's something about the gallery space that just gets me. I love the sound my shoes make when I'm wandering around. Yeah....that's the stuff.
author: Jackie I.

description: Alas, if only this museum was closer to my home. This is one of my favorite places in California. Aside from the Alfred Hitchcock connection ("Vertigo"), the museum has a high caliber collection of European and Ancient art. Their website is also quite helpful, especially their collections archive. Recent exhibits have impressed me are "The Splendors of Poland," "Michael Sweerts," and "St. Francis of Assisi." My family still raves about the Dresden exhibit.
author: Meghan B.

description: I've been here numerous times and no matter what exhibit is going on, it never gets old. One of my favorites was the Art Deco exhibit several years ago- which was amazing.  The Legion of Honor is one of many great ways to end a weekend in the city.  Stroll along the adjacent trails, gaze at the ocean and golden gate bridge, admire the architecture, soak in art and culture then relax at the cafe.
author: Andrea D.

description: Was up in SF at the De Young Museum viewing the Post Impressionist exhibit and notice the admission included entrance to the Legion of Honor that was showcasing Japanese Woodblock Art .  I had never been to this museum and wasn't sure what to expect.  When we arrived the parking was sparse but we lucked out as someone was leaving just steps from the front of the museum.  The museum is quite impressive from the exterior flanked with large columns.  There is a covered courtyard before entering that appears ideal for a swanky party or wedding.  Upon entering you are greeted by the ticket office and security.  There is a coat check room located on the first floor.  The permanent exhibits are located on than floor and featured several of Rodin's sculpture pieces, along with numerous rooms of private collections of artwork, primarily paintings, sculpture pieces and furniture.  The large rooms are filled with lots of natural light and warmed with herringbone-laced hardwood flooring.  It was quite impressive to see so many masterpieces in one location.  While the museum was bustling with spectators the proportions of the building never made you feel crowded, which was the opposite of the De Young exhibit (see my review of the De Young Museum for more details).  Downstairs featured the current exhibit of the Japanese Woodcut Art.  Having taken some art history classes in college along with printmaking classes, I was very interested in seeing the collection.  Of course there was the famous Hokusai's Wave, but also a showcase of how each step of color and image were laid to create the final work.  There were several rooms filled with works from various artists along with French artist's interpretation of Woodcut Art but using lithography.  In addition, spectators that were interested could view a video of a Woodcut Artist creating a print. Overall, I found the museum a true gem and would definitely like to go back and spend more time viewing the permanent collections along with any current exhibits.  If you enjoy architecture or art the Legion of Honor should be on your list of places to see.
author: Perry W.

description: Quality collection of European artwork housed in an extraordinary building overlooking the Golden Gate Bridge. Modeled as an adaptation of the 18th century Palais de la Légion d'Honneur in Paris, the building is majestic and romantic. Great place for a date or to take parents for an afternoon of art and good conversation. The European Painting collection is my favorite..... and I spent more time staring at Monet's "Grand Canal" than on any other piece in the museum. We were able to listen to the organ play in the afternoon and it made for a great background while viewing Picasso and Rodin. I'll have to go back next time I need a little bit of artistic inspiration!
author: Caroline J.

description:
One of my favorite places in the city. It is very cozy, nostalgic with an excellent little collection. A well-rounded and representative journey through centuries of European art, from early medieval paintings to late Impressionism. One of the best Rodin collections outside of Paris. The museum is offering free organ concerts on the weekends, occasional performances by the "Pocket Opera" and free art classes for children. On top of this, an amazing location and gourmet menu in their on-premises cafe. 
I would suggest getting their inexpensive yearly membership as you cover the cost in just a few visits. This Spring, members would get a free access to an extensive exhibition of Impressionist Art from D'Orsay museum.
author: Mary R.

description:
Every first Tuesday of the month lots of San Francisco musea can be visited for free!  The Legion of Honor is one of them, so today I ventured out to have a look at their collection.  I was here once before but then I only visited the temporary Monet in Normandy exhibition.

First of all: The views of the Golden Gate Bridge, the Pacific Ocean and the city are amazing!  Just walk up to the museum and walk around for a bit, you will not be disappointed.

The museum itself is a beautiful building, with a very nice 'courtyard' where you will find one of Rodin's "The Thinker".  The Rodin collection is impressive, one of the best in the world (except of course for the Rodin museum in Paris).  I was less impressed by their collection of European art, but of course that's because I'm European and visited the most beautiful European museums where the collections are much more impressive.  It's a nice collection though.

I do not understand why they put displays in the hallway to the restrooms, or even hide one of the collections behind the women's restrooms (the ceramics).  The shop is small (the one at the MoMA is way better), but that's not really a problem, but the volunteers were gossiping about the curators and visitors (not really nice of them).
author: Marijke D.

description: The Legion of Honor completely overwhelms me. I look at everything and sometimes I want to cry. I can sit in front of Bouguereau for hours. I'm such a snobby art baby. The Legion is probably my favorite art museum in San Francisco.
author: Kerry F.

description: A little Jewel of San Francisco. This place is amazing I come at least once a month. The surrounding grounds are beautiful with amazing views. The inside is just as spectacular. So much to see including rotating exhibits. Must see for anybody visiting the City.
author: wendy p.

description: One of my favorite destination for a rainy day in the city.  Small, but decent selection of art from every notable period.  This is not to mention one of the best view in town!  Tip: make sure to visit a cozy cafe downstairs.  Although a little pricey, it offers a welcome break for your tired feet.  I would suggest to purchase a yearly membership which would cover both Fine Arts Museums, Legion of Honor and De Young in Golden Gate park.  It is only about $80 per family per year, kids under 12 are always free and the cost of membership pays off after about 3 visits.  The membership would also get you a handy discount in both museums' gift shops which are full of current-exhibitions-themed books, jewelry and home decorations.  One of the great places to buy classy inexpensive gifts for friends.  This year alone the museums featured two world-class collections of Impressionist paintings, 200 years of Cartier jewelry, Tutankhamen and Ancient Egypt, outstanding Japanese graphic, just to name a few.
author: Lana L.

description: Can't believe it took me so long to get here. The current 1906 earthquake "rephotography" exhibit is really interesting, much better than similar shows at MOMA and the Historical Museum. One wing is full of fantastic early Renaissance paintings and Christian art (icons, sculptures, etc.) A lot of the porcelain, English paintings, silver sets, and furniture is not the type of thing I'm especially interested in, but its vastness and beautiful galleries make up for that. (I know this isn't a legitimate criticism of a museum - but - I buy lots of postcards to send to people, and was very disappointed by the meager selection here. Legion people, print more!)
author: Amy E.

description:
review as wedding site:

gorgeous, elegant. you have the reception in the café, which after they deco it up looks like the most elegant/coolest restaurant in NYC...

the ceremony is outside, slightly chilly, but incredible backdrop.

only negative is the limit in # of people it can accommodate.
author: Sophia Y.

description: This review is just of the outside of Legion of Honor, as my husband and I stopped by after one of our jogs through a nearby trail. It is so beautiful, and I hope to make it into the museum at some point. It also has a Holocaust memorial outside, which we were able to take a look at. It is striking. I highly recommend everyone go check it out.
author: Bridgette A.

description:
This is one of the most beautiful and memorable places for me in the City. The views are amazing, the architecture is incredible and of course the art is interesting and exquisite. I love just standing in the Court of Honor and looking up at the sky or out at the view.  I can't wait to get to the Monet exhibit. 
A lot of people get their wedding photos taken here, but I don't know if a lot of people know that you can actually get married at the museum. My husband and I did and it was an amazing experience.  The service and organization was top notch. Andree is a goddess! She really knows what she is doing. All our guests were happy and in awe that they got to attend a beautiful museum and a wedding at the same time. The food was magnificent - not your typical, boring, catered wedding food. The reception is in the museum cafe, but when they get done setting it up and decorating it, you would not even recognize it. And they open up the courtyard with the olive trees all lit up. I can go on and on...
author: Erika T.

description:
My husband and I just married at the Legion of Honor this past weekend, and my experiences were the polar opposite of what a previous bride describes in her review.

BRIDES, please read the following: 

I highly recommend the museum to all brides who wish to have a stress free, enjoyable wedding.  The facilities manager was at all times professional, and I must emphasize this, given the earlier review posted.  He accommodated our needs with ease.  For example, he helped me every step of the way in acquiring event insurance.  He was instrumental in the design of our ceremony decor.  We were able to get married among Rodin and Chihuly sculptures and the facilities manager made many useful suggestions as to how to save money on lighting and maximize the use of topiaries and waxleaf panel hedges.  He has an aesthetic gift, and combined with his experience in executing events, his input was invaluable.  When I had an issue with a vendor, he guided me as to how to resolve the problem in a professional and constructive manner.

Getting married at the Legion was simply a treat.  All of our friends remarked on the beauty of the setting and somehow, this grand space transformed into an intimate setting for our nuptials.  The museum is especially important to me because I have spent many weekends here, viewing the art and listening to the organ music, with my father.  

I hope that you enjoy this San Francisco treasure as much as I have.  And to all of the future Legion brides, remember to enjoy every moment of your wedding.  I did, and I have memories to last a lifetime!
author: Chris M.

description: Oh my gosh the location alone is absolutely stunning! If I lived in San Francisco, I would pick this place to get married it's so gorgeous.  (Though I wouldn't change our wedding place.)  They have wonderful exhibits and it's fun to even just go to the cafe and gift shop.
author: Whitney W.

description: I got married here in September and it was everything I hoped for and more. The museum itself is beautiful with gorgeous views of the bay and the Golden Gate bridge. I had my ceremony in the Court of Honor which was the perfect setting for the classic and elegant ceremony I wanted. Afterward, we had the reception in the cafe downstairs which accommodated our 170 guests perfectly. The legion is definitely not a cheap venue but compared to other gorgeous places in the city it was definitely cheaper than say the Asian Art Museum and you can't beat the view.
author: Cathy T.

description: The actual museaum itself is nice.  Very pretty area and it's nice to walk there on a nice day.  I really like the print collection they have.  Most people don't get to see it, but I was glad to have the oppurtunity and it was fun to go and check out the vaults there too :).
author: Robin L.

description: I wish I could give this a nudge toward five stars.  Four seems low, but I can't justify five.  The museum is a little small.  I like the $10/year pass for students option.  The pass is good for both LOH and de Young.  Good stuff.
author: Dave M.

description:
it's a nice drive to get out to the legion of honor.  cool they have a statue of the thinker by rodin...
and kids running around around the glass skylight on the ground

if you walk a little off the parking lot, there are some nice views to see.

this place was also in hitchcock's vertigo :)
author: charlotte s.

description: Legion of Honor - Simply beautiful and serene.  Great place to bring your out of town guests.  Great place to get married or have your wedding photo taken here.  If you haven't visit here yet, stop what you doing and go!
author: Chris R.

description: Came here with my better half for the "After the Ruins, 1906 and 2006: Rephotographing the San Francisco Earthquake and Fire". Wonderful pictures. It was foggy when we drove up which gave it an eerie feeling but the gallery was still very beautiful. The staff was friendly and kept smiling profusely.
author: Christina Y.

description: I went to the Legion of Honor to get some scenic wedding photos taken, but I was excited to return to visit the inside while not wearing a long white dress. The highlight for me was the French Jewelry exhibit (and judging from the large number of women around me "oohing" too,  I don't think I was alone). The view from the outside is amazing even on the chilliest of SF days and the interior is equally lovely. Another nice perk is that you get free same-day admission to both the DeYoung and the Legion of Honor with the price of one ticket, so you can easily peruse one and it's just a short bus ride (or a longer walk) to the next.
author: Megan K.

description: Want to go to France, but are a broke mofo like myself?  Well, just come here and you will think you're.  What a steal!
author: Jenny C.

description: Gorgeous! Simply beautiful both inside and out. A little piece of Europe tucked away in the western edge of the city. Makes me very nostolgic of my four months studying art history in Paris *sniff*.  The Legion of Honor has a great collection of Western Art without being too overwhelming. The art pieces are arranged by movement and medium to make viewing easy digestible. The building itself is amazing AND it boasts breathtaking views of the city--Golden Gate Bridge, downtown and all! If you live in San Francisco and haven't taken advantage of the musuems, get on it!
author: Natalie T.

description: The most beautiful museum in San Francisco, in my opinion.  I love the building, I love the location overlooking Lincoln Park and all the fog you can drink in the afternoon.  I love the breathtaking walnut-panelled music room transported from a chateau in France with its smug little Victor Hugo statue.  I love "The Thinker" in the courtyard outside.  I also love the current installation for making me rethink my snotty stance on contemporary art.  They even have lions flanking the entrance, although I don't believe they have names like the New York Library's lions.
author: Jude F.

description: Great collections and great shows. Buying a membership was one of the wiser moves I have made.
author: Robert M.

description:
Does this museum make you think it will be a military history museum?  Am I the only one?  
Yes?  
Well, whatever:  it was dedicated to the Soldiers of WWI, so I am not completely crazy.
Anyway, I was pleased to find that it is in fact a gorgeous fine art museum, not a military history museum, which would be sort of out of place in such a peaceful local, not to mention significantly more boring.  The museum is small, which I think is really nice, and has a nice collection of art from around the world and throughout history.  There is lovely organ music playing on Sundays, and a Sunday brunch, but, just a heads-up: the brunch costs about a million dollars (okay, $43, but still) and does not compare to the yummy brunch places to eat that abound throughout the city.  So here's what you do: go to a fabulous brunch place in the city, then make your way over to the area of the Museum (parking stink, so take what you can get), tour the museum and then end with a walk along lands end.  now that's how you spend a Sunday!
author: Claire R.

description: The Legion of Honor is a nice museum full of great art pieces. Though it doesn't compare to the MOMA or any other big museum, it still is good. I love the statue of 'The Thinker' in the front.
author: Trish P.

description:
Love the Legion...great small museum .. their membership is totally worth it as it includes all the special exhibits and the De Young...it's like two museums for the price of one. I prefer to the De Young as it is not so overwhelming and perfect for an afternoon....

They also have great special exhibits that come through. We went through the Monet exhibit this weekend and it was an awesome collection...however I do have to subtract a star because I felt like cattle while viewing the exhibit. I understand that we want to encourage people to get "cultured and shit" but honestly....tiny space with that many people is just no good for anyone... so if you want to see Monet....don't go on a weekend...
author: Joy Y.

description: I LOVED the Legion of Honor. I found it to be a truly world-class museum. We visiting during the Dutch Masterworks exhibit, and decided to see both the regular museum and the special exhibit. The general admission section of the museum was very impressive. They had so many beautiful painting and works of art from very renowned artists (Monet, Seurat, Picasso, etc.). There were also many historic pieces of furniture and a room complete with historic paneling and fireplace, as well as a unique porcelain collection downstairs. The general collection was a nice, manageable size. Not huge, and could be seen in a little less than two hours. The museum building itself is gorgeous, and the setting in Lincoln Park is beautiful. After our visit we walked to the Cliff House and on the way saw gorgeous views of the Golden Gate Bridge along the wooded path. The special collection was wonderful, totally worth seeing. If the special exhibit at the time interests you at all, I would recommend it. However, the general collection alone in certainly enough to merit a visit. We had a teenage boy in our group and even he was loving the experience.
author: A. N.

description: The Legion of Honor is a beautiful Beaux-Arts building set in a stunning local with the ocean and cyprus trees lining your drive up. The exhibits are the most intriguing of any in SF, in my opinion. The Art Deco exhibit was memorable, and the latest 1906 Earthquake photography feature is thought-provoking. For the setting and the exhibits, it's an ideal spot to bring out-of-towners. If you go on a Saturday, you're guaranteed to see lots of newly weds taking wedding photos.
author: sarah s.

description: Where else can you see Rodin, Monet, and Seurat without having to fly all the way to Paris?  Also, the Rodin collection rivals the actual Rodin museum in Paris (minus the beautiful garden) - great location on a sunny day to see the views of Golden Gate and San Francisco - make the trip out this way, and stop in Richmond for a good ethnic meal :)
author: Kellen H.

description:
one of the most beautiful buildings/museums i have ever seen. i visited in order to see seurat's eiffel tower and was blown away with the architecture and lay out of the place. the exterior is amazing. i'm sitting here trying to describe how gorgeous the place is, but adjectives fail. the view is fantastic, and on a clear day, you can get a great glance at the golden gate bridge + the sail boats.
the museum is much smaller than the deyoung but there was still plenty to see. when i visited, there was a pianist who put on a show right in the middle of the museum. patrons were dancing along, clapping, having a great time. not sure if that was a special event or if it's permanent. regardless, it was something i've never seen in an art museum. 
and if you hate art and you don't like gorgeous views and architecture, i guess i can suggest this place for people watching/observing. it's ridiculously amusing to watch all the wedding photography that goes on at this place. if you're lucky enough, you can see cheesy poses and grimacing bridesmaids who seem like they just want to get the hell out of there.
author: Becky K.

description: Not as large as other well known museums, but excellent selection and variety.  The building architecture is beautiful and quite impressive.  Totally resembles something you'd find in Europe.  And the location.  Definitely awe inspiring.  Parking is a bit of a bitch, so come early, or not later than midday.  Even if you come later in the day and end up parking at the bottom of the hill, its still worth it I think.  I'd hike up that hill for the view and of course the great exhibits in the museum as well.
author: Chanel F.

description: What a gorgeous museum inside and out.  LOVE the view!  I think the Legion is by far my favorite for their great exhibitions and awesome location in San Francisco.  Right now the Women Impressionists exhibit rocks.  I was particularly impressed with Berthe Morisot, loved her "Lilacs in Maurecourt" and "In the Bois de Boulogne" pieces, both were incredibly beautiful.  I also thought Eva Gonzales's "Awakening" was stunning.  The museum's cafe is fantastic and the little trail outside the museum to Clement street is an absolute joy to walk.
author: Swetha G.

description: If you want to impress a manatee and pretend you are cultured you need to bring her here.  I recommend going on a day with no fog or rain.  You may get lucky after the museum because manatees like views of the city.  I just need to bring mine to a buffet and I am guaranteed to get some and more.  Folds are nice.
author: Fatty A.

description: like an afghan hound- this museum was beautiful, but dull.  the art is great- but it isn't anything you haven't seen in a thousand other western art museums.  it is worth the trek for the grounds and the views- the outside is much more interesting than the inside (and it is free).
author: Samantha W.

description: This is such an awesome location.  I recently checked out the 'Monet in Normandy' exhibit.  You could easily kill an afternoon meandering around the grounds after viewing all the artwork. Highly recommended.
author: Kenny H.

description: Pure class! I've seen great art, great theater and a few films here. I also went to a wedding reception here that was a ton of fun and very refreshing with the scenic view and gorgeous grounds. One of San Francisco's best assets.
author: Colleen B.

description: The best time, although crowded is their fundraiser "Bouquets to Art" or whatever it is called, when they have floral arrangements to match various odes to the art pieces. It generally is around March and lasts for one week. A great fundraiser for the MUSEUM.
author: miriam b.

description:
this museum has a great location and parking is relatively easy. it has so many great works of art, including one of Rodin's bronze "the thinker" out in front.

ps: becoming a member of FAMSF is a great deal because you can visit as much as you want per year and also includes admission to the de Young as well as special museum events.
author: kristin e.

description:
The Legion of Honor is my favorite museum in SF. I have been visiting it for over 25 years. 

The Legion of Honor has a impressive  entrance with views of the Golden Gate Bridge, and nice landscaping of flowers. It is a jewel with  beautiful Corinthian Columns and Rodin's thinker, who greets you in the court yard.  

Currently they have a Tiffany & Faberge exhibit of jewelry, stain glass, and Faberge eggs previously owned by the  last Czar of Russia. 

The permanent collection is nice with many 1500 paintings. This would be a good place to eduacte yourself about  the extensive symbolism in Renaissance art. 

There have a few paintings of Salvador Dali and Picasso There is something for everyone here. The paintings are exhibited in a beautiful  well lite, and  comfortable  setting.

The only problem with this museum is that parking is limited. So leave plenty of time and plan to walk a fair distance. 

If your are a  member, you can pay tickets in  person and in advance for the King Tut exhibit, which will be at the De Young. We bought tickets for July 6th see you there!
author: Sarah G.

description: Stunning... perfect.  It isn't overdone, or overwhelming as some museums can be.  It is also a nice mix between the architecture and beauty of the structure, versus the art and what it is showcasing.  Fantastic!!!
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description: This is a great museum, but there is one painting in here that is worth 10 stars alone.  The Last Judgment Triptych by the Unknown Tyrolean Master is just fabulous, in a totally whacked out Bosch-esque kind of way.  If this is what Hell looks like, sign me up.  What a fabulous wonderland of interesting creatures I will encounter there.
author: Squirrel L.

description: What a great museum - world class art very nicely displayed, great exhibits, wonderful location with plenty of free parking. Fantastic building and grounds. And free admission to the De Young Museum in Golden Gate park! (and vice versa). Only drawback - very pedestrian cafe although the pommes frites (fries) were good.
author: Joe S.

description: The views are breathtaking outside and the art inside, if not always breathtaking, is definitely lovely.  They host some very nice opening nights, and it has a very comfortable feel for a museum.  They have some wonderful exhibits come through.  This reminds me that I haven't been in awhile and must check it out now.  Or tomorrow.  Or sometime soon at least. Or when someone comes to visit from out of town...
author: Kerry L.

description: The first time I went there I was just amazed at how breath taking it was! Walk around, explore, learn, and take in all it's beauty! Day or night--Check it out!
author: Mel P.

description:
one of my favorite museums.
beautiful views and backdrops. 
beautiful building and always interesting exhibits! 
bonus points for the rodin and the waterlilies
me likey!
author: Riff Raff V.

description: Beautiful museum reminiscent of the museums found in Europe, especially with the lovely European-like architecture. The views are gorgeous as well, you can see the North Bay as well as the cityscape of San Francisco, and the Golden Gate Bridge as well. There are Rodin sculptures as well as works from the Renaissance up to Impressionism and Surrealism. They also have interesting changing exhibits as well that are worth taking a look at. This museum was also featured in the film Vertigo.
author: Helena H.

description: This is a San Francisco treasure! A great scenic place for a museum. I always enjoy coming here especially when they have the special exhibits, like Monet. The cafe is a great place to hangout and relax. The price for refreshment is of course pricey, but on a nice day its worth it.
author: Leon C.

description:
location is beautiful, again kind of small for me (that's what she said)
despite the size they have an impressive permanent collection.
membership includes the de young.
i usually prefer museums to take up more of my day but oh well
author: kiki b.

description: The Legion of Honor is a wonderful art museum.  It's well worth the long trek to the west side of the city.  You are rewarded with a stunning view of the bay (and are so high up that battle ships look like toys floating in the water), Golden Gate Bridge, and the whole city.  If you go for no other reason, it should be to see the original "Thinker" statue sitting outside of the main doors.  They have an entire Rodin collection, in fact.  Also, I would recommend their collection of ancient art--very cool.
author: Heather T.

description: I've visited this grand museum many times and have been luckily enough to enjoy the special Claude Monet and Georgia O'Keefe exhibits as well.  Its classic columns, and attractive exterior make it a hotspot for San Francisco Brides and Grooms to have their picture taken outside before being whisked away in their limos. The inside is everything a good museum should be. Lots of cool clean stone and marble, some galleries have classic wooden floors, most have cushy benches so you can rest awhile and soak up the art. The museums own collection contains many grand Flemish pieces and portraits; there are a few Monets, Manets, and Van Goghs as well. They also have some great furniture pieces from Europe. Students of art and art history can also be found here viewing and being inspired by the paintings. They also have some lovely sculptures, some by Auguste Rodin as well. The museum is in/next to a golf course.
author: Tiffany T.

description: A decent art museum, some good stuff, but also some items that suggest that the rich in San Francisco do not always have good taste.  Does one really need 20 paintings of dour looking Calvinists or Venus and Cupid?   Perhaps if the special exhibit had been open it could have earned a 5th star.
author: Alured P.

description: Gorgeous building / museum with a great little theater inside - LOVED seeing a jazz concert there last year. Wonderful atmosphere, and loved walking through the museum afterwards. Memorable afternoon.
author: Jen D.

description: I've been going here for years and it is still one of the best museums I've been to. They consistently rotate their guest exihibits so you can make multiple trips a year without getting bored. The view from the grounds are amazing. Great place to take people visiting or even a date.
author: Heather L.

description: Update 9/7/06 Visited the Monet in Normandy exhibit. It was awesome! Amazing sculpture and Impressionist painting collection. The scenery outside the museum is breathtaking and highlighted by various asian artifacts.
author: Evelyn B.

description: Saw the Annie Liebowitz exhibition on Sat 03/08 and all I have to say is that it was AMAZING!!! If you are a fan of hers, a fan of photography, a fan of family PLEASE you MUST go see this before it goes! Annie shares a lot of her and her family and especially her partner Susan's struggle/battle with cancer as well as her mother & father. Surprisingly you learn a lot about Annie through her subjects in the photos. The depth and the richness of each photo is brilliant, even the ones that look "messed up" are not! Seriously a MUST!!!
author: Rob L.

description: Each visit to the Legion of Honor reminds me why I moved to San Francisco -- killer views (in this case, looking east at the Golden Gate), a regular reminder of things cultural and conversation-enhancing, and the slap-in-the-face concept that not everything significant can be captured on the 11 o'clock edition of Sportscenter.  The permanent collection is outstanding and the traveling exhibitions can be downright altering.   Bring a picnic and sit on the lawn in front of the entrance and be thankful you live here.
author: Ben S.

description: Finally got a chance to walk into this place after so many years. I'm not an artsie fartsie person so for me to come in here was just for the enjoyment. $6 for the general ticket w/ the student discount, could anyone actually complain about the price? Event without the discount, it is still cheap. I was a little annoyed that they allow little kids and babies into the museum. Please keep them out of there, I really dont need to see them running around or listening to their cry echoing from the other end of the building.
author: Derrick L.

description: Dali paintings, Rodin sculptures, Picasso paintings, I wish I had more time to see those art pieces. Absolutely as good as it gets.
author: Storm S.

description: This place is beautiful and when I was assigned a field trip here I had NO idea how to get there or where it was.  I got off my bus too early and had to walk up the gigantic hill, and after the work out I was breathless...no just because of the gigantic hill, but because of the view and the building!
author: Liz O.

description: Just attended the Annie Leibovitz: A Photographer's Life show here and it was wonderful.  It is such an beautiful museum inside and out.  There is a replica of Rodin's Thinker sculpture and a Louvre Museum glass pyramid top in the entry courtyard.  It reminded me of my trip to Paris last year and made me smile.
author: PictureGirl F.

description: Beautiful museum located in a beautiful part of the city. You don't even need to go in to enjoy the Legion of Honor, just go there to check out the architecture and the surrounding views of the city. Lovely.
author: Zell C.

description: I went here about three years ago, but I do remember that this was pretty cool. My friend was doing a class project where he had to study one painting per room and give his own interpretation so I was helping him. The paintings were mostly historical and portraits or landscapes. The art was cool and I enjoyed it. The outside was pretty cool bc it's right by golden gate park but up on a hill a bit so you can overlook the bay and see the bridge on a clear day.
author: Thao T.

description: Wonderful setting with wonderful Rodin pieces. The furniture art was also interesting but I can't say the same for paintings.  Overall, a very fine day in one of the best locations of SF!
author: Burcin T.

description: I've been here countless times.  It's one of my boyfriend's favorite spots in the city.  The drive up is beautiful and it never fails that someone is taking their wedding pictures out in front of the museum.  Maybe that'll be me someday! If you like A R T, this is the place for you.
author: Jessica T.

description: Wow. This place is very majestic. I like the man playing guitar outside on weekends. He's pretty stellar. Now, the museum itself is very beautiful.. very grand and vast and echoing. The art is really nice, but my favorite showcase was when they displayed the Leonardo da Vinci stuff... and they had this amazing painting by INGRES. I bought a postcard of it. Hmm hmm the Art Deco show was pretty sweet too. Nice car. The store is nice and the cafe actually serves delicious food -for a price!!!! LEGION OF HONOR !!1!
author: O K.

description: ART!  I loved that you could see everything in a day and have a break for champagne in the cafe in the middle of it.  I prefer the paintings to the sculptures, furniture, and glassware and I lost track of time looking at such a great collection.
author: Cory G.

description: Boring inside cuz its more of a tourist attraction but slick scenery on the outside! Many memories of me and my hunny going into a photo frenzy here.
author: Jason C. J.

description: Breathtaking!  I love art, so my friend who now works here, gave me the buzz inside and tour.  I saw the most beautiful paintings in the world!  I highly recommend this place.  When I arrived I saw a couple who just got married taking photos of their memorable day.  It is worth spending a couple of hours admiring the paintings.
author: Victoria S.

description:
This is sadly the most undervisited beautiful place in San Francisco. Half the people I talk to don't even know it's there.  Every first Tuesday is free too, so there isn't an excuse not to visit the most beautiful art museum in the world.  Really. No Joke.  First of all, it's set overlooking the Pacific ocean, the Golden Gate Bridge, Marin Headlands and back at the 7 Hills of San Francisco. 
Secondly it has the largest collection of Rodins outside of the Musee Rodin in Paris (Philadelphia argues they have a larger collection...and indeed the have the Burghers of Calais life size, but most of the pieces there are done posthumusly...not that that's a problem, but Dorothy Spreckels, of the Spreckels sugar fortune collected many pieces during Rodin's last few years alive from the artist himself and donated her collection almost in entirety to the Legion of Honor) Also there is one of 5 or 6 castings of The Thinker there.
Legion of Honor also hosts many visiting paintings from time to time. When the British museum was renovating, the Egyptian collection came, but also a very famous (and my favorite) Thomas Gainesborough made it out here of a beautiful newly wedded couple.  The collection is all in all- stunning, but strained until now because the de Young collection and Legion collection were housed in the Legion during the de Young construction.  
I love this place. Also Sherwin and I have a tree there.  Some tree was planted on our anniversary 65 or something years ago.
author: Yvonne Y.

description: Definitely worth a visit to see the Masterpieces of French Jewelry. Enough diamonds and platinum to make any jewelry-lovers eyes bobble. Make sure you check out the vintage Cartier pieces...they're worth it.
author: Jennifer M.

description: My most favorite place in The City not only for the museum but the sights along with the Lincoln Park golf course.  Great photo opportunities.
author: W L.

description: Nice art museum in a nice location for a good price. Don't miss the organ performances, which are on weekends at 4pm. They are a great way to end your day at the art museum.
author: Josh T.

description: This is the museum to go to to learn about European art history.  It spans a wide range of time from approximately the late middle ages to the 20th century and includes works from the Italian renaissance, Dutch masters and French impressionists.  It's presented in a logical manner and in small enough chunks so you can easily take it all in, and reflect on the progression of style over time.  The collection is not as huge as the most world-reknowned art museums, but this is clearly an example of doing more with less.
author: David O.

description: I never knew there is such a beautiful place in San Francisco. The view is amazing!
author: Angela L.

description:
I'm not much of a museum connoisseur.  The size of this collection is limited compared to bigger museums but is well stocked with numerous of masterpieces by Monet and other European artists, not to mention a huge collection of Rodin sculptures.

The outstanding feature of this museum is its location - it is perched on a hill overlooking the Pacific and the Golden Gate.  The lawn in front of the museum affords stunning vistas of the ocean and the Marin headlands beyond. 

On a related note: if you're really into Rodin and don't want to pay the entrance for this museum, Stanford University has a pretty good collection too and you can view these in their garden.
author: Adrian K.

description: Beautiful museum, beautiful location, neat art, a great Sunday afternoon.
author: 'toph G.

description: This was by far my favorite museum in SF. Beautiful building in excellent location overlooking golf course, bay and Golden Gate Bridge. Filled with classic European and some ancient Art. Excellent array of pottery downstairs. Beautiful rooms filled with natural light. Loved the Cartier exhibit and left with my eyes bulging from BLING overload. Loved the mystery watches. Definitely worth the additional $12, but don't pay another $7 for the audio unless you are too lazy to read-  the display cards were just as informative.
author: airess p.

description:
I just love this museum so much.  Not too overpowering for one day's perusing.  You get a taste of many different periods without spending too much time on any one.  The collection of Rodin is wonderful.  I spend a lot of time just staring at the figures, moving around them in circles..........
When I was there last, there was one of the dead sea scrolls along with some other pieces on loan from the Israel Antiquities Authority.  It was kind of surreal seeing a piece of one of the scrolls in person.  Unfortunately some guy started taking flash photography of the scroll while I was in the exhibit!!!  Can you believe it?  Another guy was knocking on the Rodins!  The only thing that is at all negative about this beautiful place is that there doesn't seem to be any security anywhere!  The view from Land's End is amazing and the exterior of the museum is nearly as breathtaking as the interior.  But Alas, my favorite thing about the museum is that there is a painting I came across which has my sister in it!  It is called Love and the Maiden and the Maiden is my sister!  I mean an exact rendition!  I sent her a picture and she couldn't believe it either.  They also have a Chihuly in the court of honor now which I haven't seen.  If you haven't been you must go at least once.  I can't speak for the cafe though because I always pack a lunch.=-)
author: Joseph S.

description: This museum is gorgeous.  The grounds are amazing you could just spend hours looking over everything and the outdoor side exhibits (holocaust).  We were lucky and found a parking spot no problem at the circular parking lot... I don't know if there was more parking elsewhere, except that there were a lot of cars circling around the place while we were walking around and after we got out of the museum.
author: Mary c.

description:
I rediscovered this museum one rainy afternoon while me and my boyfriend were exploring the city.  We drove through the presidio, though Lincoln park and along the coast.  There it was; this gorgeous building, an example of French architecture, balanced and breathtaking. It stood out in the midst of this stormy San Francisco weather with wind, rain and the turbulent waves of the pacific ocean.  This set the mood for our visit to the museum.
The Marie Antoinette exhibit was featured that day,  it was the  one before the Leiboivitz exhibit.  It was awesome;  she is one of my favorite historical figures.  The paintings were grand and there were actual pieces of her furniture displayed, remarkably well preserved.   I can't even describe in words how beautiful some of the pieces were.  It really takes your breaths away.
The rest of the museum displays some of my favorite European styles of art history.  Everything from baroque and rococo and some impressionism.  It begins in about the middle ages through the renaissance and into the classical period finishing with a few examples of modern art.  It also has some rooms of original fireplaces, chandeliers, and silver.  I can't imagine living in house so beautifully ornamented but its fun to try.
This museum is perfect for those that appreciate beauty. Some of the greatest artists are featured here. It really brings you somewhere else, takes you away from the day to day life.
author: Kristine B.

description:
Museum is beautiful. I was surprised to see The Thinker and the water lilies by Monet there. Those are like...famous...you know? I like that it's smaller because you can see the whole museum w/out having to spend days there. 

I have to mention one thing, though, their gift shop prices are higher. I bought this flower pen at deYoung for $3.50 and the exact same pen at the Legion was $5. Also, I bought these bracelets at deYoung for $10 and at the Legion, they were $12. 

Parking is a little weird. No structure, just circling around and around to park against some patches of dirt. Oh, and there's a golf park, literal a hop, skip and away. Thought that was sort of weird, too. The view of Golden Gate bridge is beautiful, though.
author: G Y.

description: Love, love, love this museum. The best in San Francisco.  It's architecture and location are magical.
author: Camille W.

description: My absolute favorite museum in San Francisco.  You can't beat its great location atop a hill in an area little known to and traversed by tourists.  If you love art from the Baroque era and can appreciate works from the likes of Rodin, then this is the place for you.  I have been drawn back to this beautiful museum time and time again for exhibits on O'Keefe and Monet.
author: John c.

description: This is probably one of my favorite museums in San Francisco. It's perfect for a quiet AND calm day looking at art (mostly paintings).And they have a large selection so its pretty big if you decide to go into all the galleries to see everything. (I think that this is also another wedding photography hot-spot too. Beware of the bridezillas.)
author: Retired B.

description: This is the only museum I feel that is worth visiting in SF. There's a statue of Rodin's thinker, as soon as you enter. We went on a Sunday, when there was a person playing beautiful music in one of the halls and it filled the entire museum. The museum is beautifully organized inside. Make sure you see the one Rembrandt painting that's there. Lots of Monet paintings, one Van Gogh, and several works by Rodin, make this place worth visiting.
author: Rasta K.

description: I came here yesterday because it was a beautiful day and we wanted to check out the Monet in Normandy special exhibit.  It is the most crowded I have ever seen it on a not free day.  I used to only come to the museum on the free day, but we have membership to the de Young museum (and Legion of Honor) so we could go any day we want now.  I love the LoH.  The view is beautiful.  And since it was so clear yesterday there were tourists galore milling about taking pictures with the beautiful backdrop.  Oh, and the usual wedding party taking their wedding pictures outside the museum.  The architecture of the building is fabulous and the artwork is great.  The museum itself is pretty small.  I used to come when they had the Bouquets to Art show, but now it's back at the de Young.  I loved the Monet exhibit.  It was way too crowded though.  I think I would've enjoyed it more if I had more time and space to look around.
author: Kris L.

description: Really this is one of the most beautiful buildings in San Francisco in one of its most picturesque settings.  They have really excellent rotating exhibits, everything from the photography of Annie Lebovitz to artifacts from Marie Antoinette's life to Chihuly glass.  The permanent collection is not huge, by most museum standards, but it is still definitely enough to fill up a few hours.  Actually, it's petite size makes it less overwhelming than say, the Louvre, so it's a great museum for the uninitiated museum-goer or out-of-town guests that don't have a lot of time to spend in one place.  The museum cafe has excellent food, though pricey as most museum cafes are, and the giftshop is modest, but equally on the expensive side.  They also have a fabulous 1924 Skinner organ in the main foyer, on which every month or so, a concert is played, as well as other various concerts throughout the year.
author: Marissa C.

description: exquisite museum. plan you day so that you can see both the LoH and the de young on the same day since you'll only pay one admission and get to take a free shuttle bus between the museums.
author: lisa w.

description: all i have to say about the legion of honor has probably already been said.
author: Jamie C.

description: recently went to a wedding there and was reminded what a gem this place is. with views overlooking Lands End, the GG Bridge and the mer de pacific, its hard to beat this place for a backdrop.  modeled on the legion of honor from paris, the local version does a great job guiding you through their exhibits and showing off a wide variety of classic art from rodin to matisse to rembrandt. not to mention a GREAT place to have a wedding.  we sipped cocktails checking out the eclectic collection of art, ate great food and shimmy'd and shaked til late in the evening.  and how often do you see newlyweds making out next to the Thinker?
author: Kevin J.

description: I give the LoH five stars in general -- it's a jewel of a museum -- but this is specifically a review of the current Fabergé/Lalique/Tiffany exhibition. In a word: exquisite. Yes, these were luxury items made for the top layer of the upper crust. Yes, the items made for the Romanovs probably could have kept a few thousand peasants from starving. Stipulated. Nonetheless, this exhibition includes some of the finest and most innovative fine craftsmanship of the late 19th and early 20th century. A dozen Fabergé imperial eggs with delicate details and cunning surprises inside! A vivid blue cigarette case with a diamond snake on it, given to King Edward VII by his mistress! A dog collar necklace (which is not actually for dogs, people -- it's the name of a style, a wide band worn high and tight around the neck) of filigree in a peacock feather pattern, with a peacock feather eye in blue and green enamels at the center! A visual feast from the first item to the last. The only thing that would have made it better would have been having lots of handy magnifying glasses lying around so we could get a better look at the fine details.
author: Fawn F.

description: Although the collection is not as impressive as the Lourve, the collection still boast great works by artists such as Rembrandt, Vigee-Lebrun and Hals...to name a few.  As another yelp memeber pointed out the collection is a bit ecenntic.  After enjoying the works of art you can grab a bite in thier cafe and walk around the garden and enjoy the fabulous views.  The legion is a bit out of the way but this place is worth checking out even if you are not that into art.
author: Elisa W.

description: This is a wonderful museum and the cafe is excellent. However, the jazz brunch (reservations required) falls way short. It's expensive ($53), the food is only OK, the service is amateurish and the music is too loud for easy conversation. A much better idea idea for brunch is simply to arrive before the noon rush and eat in the portion of the cafe nearer the door, using the cafeteria line. It's the same room with the same music (only quieter) and can be much less expensive.
author: Steve M.

description: This week,I spent a day and a half studying and enjoying its works of art at a leisurely pace.It has a fine,but not a comprehensive collection of European paintings.I appreciated the environment  of this charming art museum located in verdant Lincoln Park.Personal favorites included;Lorenzo di Bicci's"Madonna and Child Enthroned with Angels",Master of Coburg Roundels"Last Communion of Mary Magdelene",El Greco's"Saint Francis",J.M. Nattier's"Thalia,Muse of Comedy",Panini's"Ruins with Sybil"Rembrandt's"Portrait of Captain",Dandre-Bardon's"Diana and Endymion",Thomas Seddon's"Pyramids of Gizeh"Gustave Caillebotte's"Sunflowers on the Seine"Claude Monet's"Gorge at Varengeville",and William Etty's"Reclining Female Nude".This art museum has a comprehensive collection of great sculpture by Rodin.Their Late Gothic and very early Italian paintings were not display when I visited it(Ugolino da Nerio,Daddi,Fra Angelico).I also liked their temporary exhibit of Roman Mosaics from Lod,Israel.So enjoy this San Francisco treat which is a bit off the tourist trail.
author: Barry I.

description: Oh YES - Great museum, every time, without fail. Great view. How lucky we are to have this wonderful museum in our area.
author: Nicoletta K.

description: the museum is beautiful!  i came here for the monet in normandy exhibit this past weekend.  my only complaint is that it was PACKED.  if there is a special exhibit, i would highly suggest getting your tickets online in advance...otherwise, you are likely to wait outside in line for an hour.  if you don't get tix in advance, be sure to dress warmly, b/c it is FREEZING out there!!  the museum itself doesn't have a huge collection, but i do like the rodin sculptures and the french furniture.
author: Helen T.

description: I make it a point to go to the Legion of Honor once or twice a year to enjoy great art and take in the views of the Bay. It's truly in a beautiful place. The facilities are well maintained and clean. I have to say that their permanent collection never appears to change significantly. I tend to hope that they would rearrange some stuff or add more variety. In that sense it seems to always be the same. Aren't museums supposed to do that every once in a while even for their permanent collections? The museum cafe is very good but a little fancy (organic such and such/$$). I guess a museum cafe should be fancy, especially in a prestigious place like this. I would suggest checking their website in advance for information about their current exhibitions. There is a membership you can buy with which you can also visit the De Young Museum in Golden Gate Park. Parking can be a hassle. The last couple of times we had to park at the bottom of the hill in the residential area because the lots were full. No biggie really, I guess we needed the exercise : P but just keep that in mind in case you have trouble walking long distances or uphill.
author: Al B.

description: a goregous and peaceful walk that can last for hours. extremely great for budding photographers looking to capture spectacular views and surprising wildlife.
author: Aly L.

description: the beaux art architecture is absolutely stunning.  there is nothing else like it in the city.  the legion of honor is right by the ocean too, so you get a scenic view when it's sunny.  though the interior is on the smaller side, the legion of honor has a good selection of art work.  the monet exhibit is happening-be sure to check out the masterpieces!
author: Amy Z.
